The three GOP groups spent $99.6 million in the 15 months, compared with $24.2 million in spending by the three Democratic groups. Much of the spending was for 10 special congressional elections held in the past year. Contests this November involve 34 Senate seats and all 435 House seats. Democrats are incumbents in most of this fall's races. The Republicans' fund-raising advantages is offset in many cases by the incumbents' individual fund-raising powers. Of the $112.6 million raised in 15 months, the GOP groups gave a combined $1.17 million to House and Senate candidates, while the Democrats donated $940,103 to congressional candidates, much of it for special elections. The Republican groups gave $1.1 million to other party organizations, primarily to state parties for special elections, compared with slightly more than $500,000 in Democratic donations to state party organizations in the same period. The GOP groups reported combined debts of $1 million, virtually all of it owed by the House campaign group. The Democratic groups owed $1.7 million, of which $1.3 million was reported by the party's cash-strapped House campaign body.

DOC.HEAD: Roh Urges Japan to Own Up to Dark Side of Its History
DOC.TEXT: South Korean President Roh Tae-woo told lawmakers today that Japan must openly deal with the dark side of its history if it wants to present a new image to Asians. ``There must be true understanding between our two peoples on the basis of truth so that a bright future can be ensured for our bilateral relationship,'' Roh said in the first speech by a South Korean president to a joint session of Japan's Diet, or parliament. Roh also urged the Japanese to improve the status of roughly 680,000 Koreans living in Japan, most of whom are the descendants of people brought from Korea as forced laborers before and during World War II. ``Only when they become able to live in this land as good neighbors of the Japanese and without artificial inconvenience, will both our peoples feel genuine friendship to each other,'' Roh said. Although many of the Koreans living here were born and raised in Japan, few have taken the trouble to be naturalized as Japanese citizens. As aliens, they must be fingerprinted and are not eligible for many jobs, such as teaching in schools or the civil service. Roh was on the second day of a state visit to Japan that is aimed at healing the still-festering wounds from Japan's 1910-45 colonization of the Korean Peninsula. On Thursday, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and Emperor Akihito offered the most explicit apologies ever for Japan's harsh colonial rule. Akihito expressed ``deepest regret'' for Japanese actions, and Kaifu acknowledged that Japan had ``inflicted unbearable suffering and sorrow'' on the Korean people. Although Japan and South Korea normalized their diplomatic ties 25 years ago, relations between the two countries are still cool. Roh is only the second Korean head of government to visit Japan since 1965. Roh contrasted Japanese-Korean relations with the close ties developing among European countries that were bitter enemies in World War II. Roh said a ``psychological barrier'' prevents the development of friendship and bilateral ties. He poignantly recalled how Japanese colonialists refused to allow Korean schoolchildren to use their Korean names and native language. The South Korean president praised Japan's stunning economic recovery after the war and development of parliamentary democracy. ``Japan has now become a new country, much different from what it used to be,'' Roh said. But he added, ``When Japan fully opens up to history and the world, it will be able to present a new image, especially to Asians.'' Roh held forth a vision of a future with a tunnel under the 125-mile Korea Strait that would link Japan and Korea and permit people from both countries to journey together ``on a tour of friendship to link continents and make all humanity one family.'' In South Korea, many Koreans were not willing to accept the words of regret expressed by the emperor and other Japanese leaders. Thousands of radical students staged violent anti-Japanese protests Thursday, burning Japanese flags and demanding that Roh cancel his ``humiliating'' visit to Tokyo. Elderly citizens have staged noisy protests for 10 days in front of the Japanese embassy. ``It's not enough to satisfy the people's sentiments toward Japan. We can hardly accept Akihito's remarks as an apology,'' said Park Yung-nok, a vice president of the opposition Party for Peace and Democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Relatives of Dead Iowa Sailors Hail Reopened Navy Investigation
With PM-Navy-Iowa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of a gunner's mate blamed by Navy investigators for an explosion that killed him and 46 other sailors aboard the USS Iowa hailed the decision to reopen the probe. ``My son is not guilty. The Navy was barking up the wrong tree,'' Earl Hartwig said of the announcement Thursday. The Navy concluded last September that the April 19, 1989, blast probably was sabotage by Hartwig's son, Clayton Hartwig, who Navy investigators claimed was disgruntled over his treatment. The Pentagon said it was reopening the investigation and ordering an end to the firing of 16-inch guns aboard all battleships after the ``unexplained ignition'' of bags of gunpowder during testing at Sandia National Laboratory in New Mexico. ``I consider this a total victory,'' said Hartwig's sister, Kathy Kubicina. The Navy's announcement came the day before the General Accounting Office, Congress' watchdog agency, was to release a report on the investigation and conclusions. The GAO report, based on testing at Sandia, was expected to show there was no conclusive evidence that a detonator device was placed between gunpowder bags, igniting gunpowder and creating a huge fireball at one of the ship's gun turrets. Hartwig's father said the GAO report forced the Navy to reassess its earlier conclusion. ``It seems awful strange that the Navy pulled this now that the lab findings are coming out,'' said Hartwig, who was a Navy gunner's mate in World War II. Families of other Iowa victims also were overjoyed with the Navy's decision to reopen the probe, but said there is much work to be done to determine what happened aboard the Iowa. ``I hope they go back to square one on the investigation,'' said Darleen Schelin, whose son, Geoffrey, was killed. ``I hope the investigation will be unbiased.'' The Navy report drew protests from some of the families of the dead sailors. The relatives demanded that the investigation be reopened. Nancy Lewis, whose son, Richard, died in the blast, kept the families in touch about the investigation through a newsletter. She said many families had doubts about the stability of the powder used to fire the Iowa's massive guns. ``This is a tremendous sense of relief that we may finally get to the bottom of this,'' Ms. Lewis said. ``I have always felt that there was something unsafe.'' Ms. Kubicina has said green fragments found in some of the Iowa corpses would prove the gunpowder was old and more likely to explode. The gunpowder on the battleship had been stored on barges in extreme heat and had started to turn green, a sign of deterioration, she said. Critics of the Navy investigation have contended the Navy ignored numerous possible causes of the explosion in order to find a scapegoat. Sharon Ziegler, whose husband, Reginald, died in the explosion, said he had complained several times about conditions in the turret where the blast occurred. ``I think it was an accident waiting to happen,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Food Subsidies To Be Removed, Prices To Go Up in July
DOC.TEXT: The government says that as part of its market-oriented reform it will cut all food subsidies and raise the prices of about 30,000 items in July by an average of nearly 25 percent. Annual food subsidies totaling $1.68 billion in a yearly budget of $26.3 billion will be diverted to other sectors of the economy, Price Office chairman Vladimir Dvorak told reporters Thursday. Communist authorities kept food prices steady and relatively low during their 41-year rule that ended last year after massive pro-democracy demonstrations. Dvorak described the removal of food subsidies as ``a preparatory step to the rectification of price relations in our economy ... another step in gradual transition to market economy, convertible currencies and world prices.'' The measure will increase the prices of about 30,000 items by an average of 24.6 percent, effective July 9. Dvorak said the increase will hit milk and dairy products by as much as 51 percent, while prices of meat will go up only moderately. The official said meat prices will remain partially subsidized. Labor Minister Petr Miller said the country intends to fully decontrol its prices by the first of next year. Miller also confirmed energy costs and other consumer goods prices will rise as much as 30 percent in autumn. A 25 percent rise in the price of cigarettes and a doubling of bus and rail fares were announced Wednesday. Asked about inflation in Czechoslovakia, which is currently estimated at 7 percent to 8 percent annually, Dvorak said the price increases this year are likely to take that figure above 10 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Group Advocates Open Adoption Records, Open Adoption
DOC.TEXT: A push to open adoption records is ill-advised and may violate the privacy rights of people trying to put a painful past behind them, according to a group representing more than 100 adoption agencies. ``We believe in protecting the privacy of those that want to maintain their privacy, while allowing those that want to have contact to have it,'' said Mary Beth Seader of the National Committee For Adoption. ``Women who made adoption plans 20 years ago may not want to see that child,'' Seader said Thursday. ``Some adopted people also do not want to have that contact.'' Seader was reacting to a renewed effort by another group involved in the adoption issue, the American Adoption Congress, to change laws to allow adoptees, birth parents and adoptive parents access to adoption records. Historically, adoption records have been sealed. But Alabama, Alaska and Kansas have enacted laws opening them. Several other states, including California and Pennsylvania, are considering such measures, said Kate Burke, president of the Washington, D.C.-based adoption congress. It represents some 50,000 people who have been personally involved in adoption. Adoption groups estimate that about 5 million people in the United States are adopted. Burke said open records make sense from a medical standpoint, enabling adoptees to be aware, for example, of illnesses they may have inherited. Perhaps more importantly, she said, is the ``gut-level need'' to know. ``What most adoptees feel is that gnawing need to know where they came from,'' Burke said. ``Adoptees grow up ... frequently with a lack of self-esteem and other problems. The reunion is a very healing process for adoptees, as well as birth parents.'' The National Committee For Adoption, also based in Washington and representing 146 non-profit adoption agencies, favors a mutual consent registry, like those currently in place in 22 states, Seader said. Seader's group favors an exchange of medical information between adoptees and their birth parents. That exchange is possible ``without sharing identifying information,'' she said. The American Adoption Congress said a registry doesn't go far enough. ``The bond to that birth mother is always there,'' said Ken Watson, chairman of the Child Welfare League of America's national adoption task force. ``We can separate the child legally, but we cannot cut that psychological bond.'' ``The best we can do when we put a child in an adoption is to allow the child and the adoptive parents to respect that bond and to support that child in re-exploring it,'' he said. Some group members believe the adoption process itself should be changed, and relations among birth parents, adoptive parents and the adoptee should be encouraged. Seader disagrees. ``That kind of relation denies what adoption is all about,'' she said. ``Adoption is creating a family for a child. We need to protect the integrity of that family.'' The conference, which opened Thursday, was being attended by about 500 people.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Isolate Immune Cells Involved In MS
DOC.TEXT: Scientists are looking at a type of immune cell that attacks nerve tissue in the brain and may be a cause of multiple sclerosis. Separate research in Boston and Stanford University isolated two types of immune cells found in the brain tissue of MS victims. Understanding the role these cells play in the crippling disease could help in developing a way to control it. In a study published today in the journal Science, Dr. David A. Hafler of Harvard and the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston said his team isolated from the blood samples of multiple sclerosis patients a unique immune cell that attacks myelin, the nerve tissue that is destroyed in the MS disease process. Hafler, in a telephone interview, said the specific immune cell was isolated in high numbers from the blood of five multiple sclerosis patients, but was found in only very small numbers in the blood of five people who do not have MS. The researcher said it is very likely that other types of immune cells also are involved in the MS disease process, but that the cell found by his team may have a major role. Another research group, led by Dr. Lawrence Steinman of Stanford University, reported on Thursday in the journal Nature that they had isolated another type of immune cell from the brain tissue of patients with MS. The cells found in the brain studies by Steinman's group are different from the cells isolated by the Hafler group from the blood of MS patients. But both of the cells found by the two groups are parts of the immune system called T-cells. Normally, T-cells are a vital to the body's defense against infection. The body makes them by the millions and each type is equipped with a type of receptor, a protein that is attracted to specific viruses or bacteria. In MS, it is believed that for some reason not now understood, the receptors on some T-cells are attracted to myelin. This causes the T-cells to attack the nerve tissue as if it were an enemy of the body. Such an action, called an autoimmune response, leads to the crippling of MS. Hafler said that by identifying the specific T-cells that play a role in MS, researchers could design drugs that would cause these enemy T-cells to be killed or inactivated. Eventually, said Hafler, his group will propose tests in MS patients of a medication that would specifically attack the V-beta-17 T-cells found by his group. ``Whether or not this will cure the disease will have to await the clinical trials,'' he said. Most likely, said Hafler, ``We would have to identify all T-cells involved in MS and learn how to turn all of them off or eliminate them before the disease could be absolutely controlled.'' Such clinical trials are still years away, said Hafler. Dr. Stephen Reingold, the vice president for research at the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, said studies by the Hafler and Steinman groups are ``complementary'' and are important advances in the battle against MS. ``The impact of these studies is that as we get closer to an understanding of this disease, there is a possibility of developing a specific immunotherapy'' that would block the nerve tissue damage caused by the enemy T-cells, said Reingold. Hafler said the Brigham and Women's Hospital research team took blood samples from MS patients and isolated T-cells that react to the protein that is in myelin. The group then tested this group of T-cells to identify the specific amino acid chains in each cell. The researchers found that in 36 of 64 T-cell samples from MS patients there was a T-cell type called V-beta-17. A similar study on blood from people without MS found that only 9 percent of the T-cell samples contained the V-beta-17 amino acid chain. Hafler said that the finding suggests that many people may have the V-beta-17 cells in their bodies, but that something causes the immune cells ``to turn on'' and start attacking brain or nerve cells. ``If you don't have any T-cells in you that recognize (react to the) brain, then you will never get MS,'' he said. ``If you do have T-cells that can recognize brain, then something else has to happen for the disease to develop. We haven't identified yet what that is.'' Coauthors of the Science paper with Hafler were Howard L. Weiner, K.W. Wucherpfennig, Kohei Ota, Noriaki Endo, J.G. Seidman and Anthony Rosenzweig of the Harvard Medical School. Science is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: NSC Estimates 380 to 480 Deaths This Holiday Weekend
DOC.TEXT: National Safety Council officials are preparing for their grim duty this weekend _ counting the number of motorists who are killed on the highways. Last year, 441 died and 20,000 were injured over the three-day Memorial Day weekend. This year, at least 380 people will die on the nation's roads between 6 p.m. Friday and 11:50 p.m. Monday, the council estimated Thursday. ``Additionally, 18,000 to 23,000 people may suffer disabling injuries,'' said Lisa Grady, spokeswoman for the Chicago-based council. ``The National Safety Council also would like people to follow our safety rules: Don't drink and drive, and if you do drink, use the designated driver program. ``Plan plenty of travel time. It's better being late than not arriving at all. Remember to use safety belts and put small children in approved child car-seats,'' said Ms. Grady. The council estimates that more than 12,000 lives could be save each year if everyone used safety belts, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Party Wins Parliamentary Special Election, Unveils New Platform
DOC.TEXT: Britain's opposition Labor Party, riding high in the polls against Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, easily retained its seat in this Labor stronghold in a parliamentary special election, results showed today. The vote Thursday came as the party unveiled a moderate platform that marked the climax of a major policy shift. In the balloting Labor's Mike Carr polled 75 percent of the vote in Bootle, a town 155 miles northwest of London that encompasses Liverpool's docks. James Clappison, the candidate for the governing Conservative Party, polled 9 percent, or 3,220 votes, compared to Carr's 26,737. The Liberal Democrats took third place with 3,179 votes going to their candidate John Cunningham. The special election was held to fill the seat held by Allan Roberts, who died in March. The Labor Party, led by Neil Kinnock, has led opinion polls for more than a year, sometimes by as much as 20 points, and the party hammered the Conservatives at local government elections earlier this month achieving a huge 11 percent swing against the government. The popularity of Mrs. Thatcher and her Conservative Party has been weakened by high interest rates, rising inflation, which hit an eight-year high of 9.4 percent in April, and an unpopular new local government tax paid by all adults, which replaces property taxes paid only by homeowners. The next election does not have to be held until mid-1992. There is speculation, however, Mrs. Thatcher may call one in March 1991 if her policy of using high interest rates to squeeze inflation is working by then. Labor's new 20,000-word platform unveiled Thursday incorporated most of Mrs. Thatcher's stringent curbs on labor unions, envisaged private investment in state enterprises, and imposed an income tax ceiling of 50 percent. Under the last Labor Party government in 1979, the top income tax was 83 percent. On defense, the socialist party promised large, but unspecified, cuts in spending, and said money saved would be diverted to social programs. The party had already ditched its vote-losing policy of unilateral nuclear disarmament. Among other issues, the new document dropped Labor pledges to reverse with minimum compensation Mrs. Thatcher's sales of state enterprises, ranging from British Airways to the national telephone network. The policy document pledged only to return to state ownership the latest sold utility, the water supply network.

DOC.HEAD: Rural Radio Broadcast Disturbed by Deer's Visit
DOC.TEXT: Deer have become such frequent visitors to this city that they inspire jokes. A broadcaster was making fun of the creatures on a morning talk show when one came crashing through the studio window. The bleeding doe thrashed around the office and destroyed some computer equipment at station WXLP before collapsing Thursday. It was carried out on a stretcher for veterinary care. News Director Katy Cole said announcers Ian Case and Jeff Roberts were discussing the antics of deer on their daily humor program, ``Bulletins from the Boondocks,'' when the deer made its unfortunate entry. ``When the announcer mentioned the word deer, I heard a big crash,'' Ms. Cole said. ``The deer just came from nowhere. I thought someone was breaking into the station.'' Police and animal control officials heard the broadcast and rushed to the studio. ``It saw its reflection in the window and jumped through the window.'' said Phil Vroman of the Scott County Humane Society. ``Once it got in, it couldn't find its way out.'' The deer should recover from its wounds, Vroman said. Deer have been venturing into the city of about 100,000 people recently and some have been hit by cars. The radio's studios are on one of the city's busiest downtown streets.

DOC.HEAD: Audit Accuses Catholics Of Misusing Food For Poor In India
DOC.TEXT: Auditors say Roman Catholic Relief Services in India misused food for underfed women and children, but church officials say they are guilty of weak management but not theft, The Washington Post reported today. The audit accused Indian Catholic Church officials of using short-weighing measuring devices for distributing food, creating false lists of food recipients, improperly using donations to support commercial businesses and deliberately concocting inaccurate records to hide abuses. India's Catholics receive about $25 million in food from the United States each year. The U.S. Agency for International Development asked the auditing firm of Price Waterhouse to investigate the program. The audit report concludes that the food program was ``operated in an atmosphere whereby the commodities could be misused with little risk of detection,'' the newspaper said in a dispatch from New Delhi. The audit report did not, however, charge the bishops, priests and nuns involved with outright theft, and no individuals were identified. Unidentified sources were quoted as saying the audit was not broad enough to determine whether the church officials had deliberately stolen large amounts of food. However, Catholic Relief Services, based in Baltimore, was criticized for not closely monitoring the distribution of U.S. government food and inadequately overseeing the activities of the Indian church officials. The newspaper said U.S. officials were reviewing whether the church group should be allowed to continue as a subcontractor in the U.S. AID food program in India, the largest effort of its kind in the world. Catholic Relief Services sharply disputed the audit findings, claiming in a letter to AID that the conclusions were based on ``factual errors, speculation and, at times, misrepresentation,'' and that the auditors had unfairly extrapolated the violations of a few churches and convents. ``We admit the management is weak, but I don't think there is widespread abuse in the program,'' James deHarpporte, chairman of the Catholic Relief Services program in India, was quoted as saying. ``Do you think Mother Theresa is corrupt?'' Unidentified U.S. officials were quoted as saying they believed problems uncovered by Price Waterhouse were serious and widespread.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Confirms Ambassador to Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: The Senate early today confirmed President Bush's nomination of Harry W. Shlaudeman to be the U.S. ambassador to Nicaragua. Shlaudeman, 64, will be the first ambassador to represent the United States in that Central American country since the leftist Nicaraguan government expelled Ambassador Richard Melton and seven other diplomats in 1988. The ouster stemmed from a dispute over whether the U.S. officials were encouraging anti-government activists. The new ambassador was confirmed on a voice vote moments after the Senate gave final approval to a supplemental money bill that includes $300 million as the first installment in a new U.S. aid program for Nicaragua. Shlaudeman, a career diplomat, is the State Department's top expert on Latin America. He was called out of retirement last year to act as the department's liaison to the anti-Sandinista Contra rebels. In his new role, he will represent the United States before the newly elected government of President Violeta Chamorro, who led an opposition coalition that defeated Sandinista President Daniel Ortega in elections in February. Previously, Shlaudeman has been an ambassador to Argentina, Peru, Brazil and Venezuela. The Bush administration has been eager to establish closer ties with Nicaragua since the change in governments. The country's new leaders face serious problems, including a ruined economy, an entrenched Sandinista bureaucracy and reticence on the part of the Contras to lay down their arms and demobilize.

DOC.HEAD: Fans Line Up Early for `Back to Future' Trilogy Screening
DOC.TEXT: ``Back to the Future'' fans lined up early for a back-to-back-to-back film trilogy as the latest time-travel adventure officially opened the summer film sweepstakes. To promote ``Back to the Future Part III,'' opening nationwide in about 2,000 theaters today, Universal Pictures organized special marathons in 19 cities Thursday night. Patrons could watch all three ``Back to the Future'' films for a single admission. At the Pacific Cinerama Dome in Los Angeles, fans started lining up at 2 a.m. Wednesday, and more than 100 devotees, wearing all sorts of ``Back to the Future'' paraphernalia, were in place six hours before the trilogy was set to begin. At the sold-out showing at the Cineplex Odeon National in New York City, some customers bought 10 to 20 tickets at a time. The line of customers, stretching along Broadway and down 43rd Street, was entertained by a group of stilt-walkers outfitted like cowboys. ``Back to the Future Part III,'' starring Michael J. Fox as time traveler Marty McFly, is set in the Old West. Universal reported early queues at theaters showing the trilogy in Orange County, Santa Barbara, Sacramento, San Francisco, as well as Portland, Ore., Denver, Chicago, Dallas, St. Louis and Toronto. ``I was first in line to see `Back to the Future' and I was second in line to see `Back to the Future Part II,''' said Adam Mast, 21, who was first in line at the Cinerama Dome. ``There are more inside jokes in the `Back to the Future' films than most people realize,'' he said. ``I've seen the first two dozens of times and I always find something new to laugh at.'' Last year's ``Back to the Future Part II'' opened last November and generated domestic box-office revenues of $110 million. ``Back to the Future Part III'' finds McFly and Doc Brown (Christopher Lloyd) arriving in 1885 to stop Doc's murder. Early reviews of the film have been mixed. In last summer's film season, which spans from Memorial Day weekend to Labor Day, a record $2.04 billion worth of tickets were sold. ``Back to the Future Part III'' is not considered to be this season's most anticipated title. Hollywood odds makers say Arnold Schwarzenegger's ``Total Recall,'' Eddie Murphy's ``Another 48 HRS.'' and Tom Cruise's ``Days of Thunder'' should lead the box-office charts at summer's end.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Sharply Lower; Tokyo Stocks Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined sharply against the yen Friday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange continued to rise. The dollar closed at 150.05 yen, down 1.38 yen from Thursday's close of 151.43 yen. After opening at 150.45 yen, the currency ranged between 149.90 yen and 150.85 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 482.13 points, or 1.49 percent, closing the week at 32,793.88. The Nikkei index gained 135.24 points on Thursday. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds edged higher to 88.30 points as of 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT), up from Thursday's close of 87.76. The yield fell to 6.890 percent, down from the previous day's 7.010 percent. Currency dealers said the dollar's retreat followed its overnight decline in New York, where it finished at 151.15 yen, down from 151.45 yen on Wednesday. Masaki Shikada, a dealer with Fuji Bank, said the dollar moved upward slightly during early trading on buying by institutional investors, including life insurance firms. ``But the dollar then stayed at a 150.70-.80 yen range'' in the absence of fresh news, Shikada said. Stocks moved up gradually in a favorable reaction to the yen's appreciation against the dollar, traders said. ``Issues centering on large-capital stocks attracted buyers' attention, encouraged by the high yen,'' a Nomura Securities analyst said on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Extension of China's Favored Trade Status a Relief for Hong Kong
With PM-US-China, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Government and business leaders said today President Bush's decision to continue favorable trade status for Beijing is welcome news for this British colony that relies heavily on commerce with China. Trade and Industry Secretary John Chan called Bush's move Thursday ``very good news from Hong Kong's point of view.'' In a statement, he noted that the business community and government had engaged in intensive lobbying during the past few weeks to explain how termination of special trade status would harm Hong Kong, which will return to Chinese sovereignty in 1997. Seto Fai, honorary president of the Chinese Manufacturers' Association, said the U.S. decision will help prevent Hong Kong from sliding into economic recession. ``Hong Kong is already experiencing a slowing of economic growth and could not afford to stand a blow from the United States,'' he said. ``Now, we have at least another year to breathe.'' The news drew little response from the stock market, which had rallied sharply earlier in the week on expectation that Bush would renew China's most-favored-nation trade status. The blue-chip Hang Seng Index today rose 20 points in early trading before finishing the morning session virtually unchanged at 3,049. The market had gained 130 points in the preceding five sessions, largely on anticipation of the U.S. decision. Most-favored-nation status gives Chinese exports to the United States the lowest possible tariffs. Denial would send tariffs rising sharply on about $12 billion in annual imports from China of textiles, toys and other products. Much of the Chinese exports to the United States are produced in joint-venture factories set up by Hong Kong investors in southern China. About 70 percent of Chinese products sent to the U.S. market are shipped through Hong Kong, Seto said. ``Hong Kong nowadays shares an inseparable economic link with China. Any threat to sanction China economically would inevitably drag us into it,'' said Carson Chan, assistant director for the Federation of Hong Kong Industries. He said termination of the special trade status for China would have resulted in at least 20,000 Hong Kong people losing their jobs in industries such as trade, transportation and banking. Hong Kong's economy already is experiencing high inflation and sluggish growth, with the gross domestic product forecast to rise only 3 percent this year. Industrialists expressed confidence that the U.S. Congress will not reject Bush's decision, despite opposition by some lawmakers.

DOC.HEAD: Feet Found in Shark Caught by Fishing Boat
DOC.TEXT: A pair of sneakers covering the feet found in a shark's belly helped the family of a police officer tentatively identify him as the victim. Relatives of officer Thomas Caron, shown a picture of the sneakers, said he was wearing similiar shoes when he and two companions left April 27 to fish in the Atlantic, said Dr. Margarita Arruza of the county Medical Examiner's office. The office is working on a positive identification, she said. The crew of the Patricia Anne, a fishing boat out of Daytona Beach, reported Wednesday that while gutting a 8- to 10-foot-long tiger shark they found the shoes containing the feet, Coast Guard radioman Jon Morris said Thursday. Caron and a companion, Robert Duncan, have been missing since their boat capsized April 27 about 12 miles southeast of Mayport, on the coast off Jacksonville. The body of a third man, police officer Robert Jones, was recovered off the Georgia coast. An autopsy showed he had drowned.

DOC.HEAD: Will to Live Helps Hit-And-Run Victim Survive
DOC.TEXT: A hit-and-run victim who crawled into the brushy median of a freeway and spent four days and nights lying there is making a remarkable recovery, doctors said. Juan Francisco Camacho, 20, was returning home to a northern San Diego County migrant camp May 5 after looking for work when he was hit while walking along the inside shoulder of Interstate 5. It was shortly after dark. Camacho, an undocumented worker who has lived in the United States since 1986, said he never heard the car coming. ``The only thing I heard was music _ American music,'' Camacho said from his bed at Scripps Memorial Hospital, where he was in fair condition Thursday. As the driver sped away, Camacho crawled into the median, shrouded by thick oleander bushes, to avoid being hit again. ``I crawled so I could get beneath a tree,'' he said. ``I was rolling and dragging myself.'' Doctors said the car apparently hit Camacho from behind, shattering his midsection. ``When we got him, he was in shock from loss of blood and his blood pressure was down to about 60, which is about half the normal pressure,'' said Dr. Edgar Gamboa, a trauma surgeon at Scripps. ``He was dehydrated, he had a dislocated knee and his pelvis was cracked open like a book. There was bacteria and infection from all the dirt in his wounds.'' As cars whizzed past Camacho the first night and day, he shouted for help in Spanish and rattled a small tree branch overhead to try to attract attention. He had nothing to eat, but soon noticed a water sprinkler nearby, and crawled to it so he could sip water to stay alive. As the days passed, Camacho said, he entered a daydream state. He recalled talking to himself and imagining that the telephone wires overhead were answering back. Eventually he lost the feeling in his legs, and on the fourth day, decided to crawl back out by the road to become more visible. A northbound motorist spotted him during rush hour that afternoon and called 911 from Camp Pendleton. ``I was shocked,'' Gamboa said. ``It's really incredible that he's still here. Even if (trauma victims) get treatment within the first hour, many people still die from these types of injuries.'' ``Even after we got him in the hospital, we half expected him to die for the first two days.'' Doctors say Camacho survived probably because he was in good physical condition and none of his vital organs were crushed _ that and his determination to live. ``How long could he have survived? There's no way of telling,'' Gamboa said. ``I guess it was up to him.'' Camacho's recovery is expected to take several months. He wonders who hit him and why they didn't stop, but says he's not angry about it. ``For me, it's not a problem. I just thank God I'm better,'' Camacho said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Proposes Center Lights for Trucks, Vans
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of accidents and injuries could be prevented by a proposed federal rule that would require new light trucks and vans to be equipped with center high-mounted rear brake lamps, says the government's top highway safety official. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration proposed the regulation Thursday, four years after requiring the rear lamps on new cars. ``The extra light is effective because it signals just one thing: braking action,'' said Jerry R. Curry, administrator of the agency. ``It can't be confused with rear lights or turn signals. It is in the direct line of sight of the following driver, forming a triangle with the other two brake lamps.'' The regulation would require the lamps on all light trucks and vans by the 1993 model year, giving manufacturers time for design changes, Curry said. A similar requirement imposed on cars in 1986 has been successful, he said, pointing out that cars with the center brake lights experience 17 percent fewer rear-end collisions than those without. The proposed regulation will be printed in the Federal Register, opening a 60-day public comment period after which the agency will decide what action to take. The law would apply to multipurpose passenger vehicles, including mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles, pickups and other trucks under 10,000 pounds, and small buses.
DOC.HEAD: Congress May Soon Tell DC How to Spend its Federal Payment
DOC.TEXT: If Sen. Phil Gramm has his way, Congress will soon take the unprecedented step of dictating how the District of Columbia spends part of its annual payment from the federal government. Gramm told Mayor Marion Barry during a hearing on the city's budget Thursday that he wants to earmark part of the annual payment for the police department. City police overtime patrols, particularly in the city's upscale Georgetown section, were recently threatened by funding shortages. ``I'm not into trying to play mayor ... but something is wrong when people are being notified to stay out of Georgetown at night because we don't have police officers,'' the Texas Republican said. Congress, which has review power over all city law, has never told the city how to spend any of the annual payment it receives from the federal government. Under Gramm's plan, an unspecified portion of the proposed $430.5 million payment would be spent on the police department. Sen. Brock Adams, who chairs the Senate Appropriations Committee that oversees the district, also told Barry he was concerned about the city's spending priorities. Congress has been increasingly critical of the city's crime situation over the past two years, during which the district has set two annual murder records and witnessed dramatic increases in drug-related crime. Congress last year gave the city $31.7 million extra to help fight the drug war. Barry assured the panel the district will use money from the special payment to cover the unexpectedly high overtime costs. ``No one in this city is more concerned about public safety than I am,'' said Barry, who is awaiting trial on drug possession and perjury charges.
DOC.HEAD: Marine Group Says Trash Still Major Problem on U.S. Beaches
DOC.TEXT: Plastic trash is still littering beaches and choking wildlife because boaters ignore laws that forbid dumping garbage overboard, says the Center for Marine Conservation. ``Some people are annoyed by the trash, some are surprised, and most don't seem to care,'' spokeswoman Kathy O'Hara said at a news conference Thursday, where the floor was littered with plastic bottles, cups and bags similar to trash collected during the group's second annual national beach cleanup. The center said the Gulf of Mexico, the Pacific Northwest and the Chesapeake Bay suffered most from offshore-generated waste because of the large volume of commercial and recreational boating in those waters. Two-thirds of the trash picked up by the center's 65,000 volunteers was plastic _ eating utensils, lids, cups and tampon applicators. ``Plastic trash not only lasts longer, it kills wildlife,'' O'Hara said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Granted Embryo Custody Now Wants to Donate Them
DOC.TEXT: A woman who won a bitter custody battle for seven frozen embryos says she no longer wants them and will donate them to her fertility clinic, with hopes someone else can use them. Mary Sue Stowe described her decision in papers filed with the Tennessee Court of Appeals. Her ex-husband, Junior Lewis Davis, has appealed a ruling in the couple's divorce case last September that granted her temporary custody over the embryos. Blount County Circuit Judge Dale Young had ruled that ``life begins at conception'' and the embryos deserved the same legal status as children would have in custody disputes between their parents. Young's ruling prevented Mrs. Stowe from using the embryos until the appeals were settled. ``She does not wish us to discuss her decision,'' Mrs. Stowe's lawyer, Kurt Erlenbach, said Thursday. ``It's a very private matter and a very hard decision. She made it within the last few weeks.'' Mrs. Stowe, who remarried in December, had testified that the embryos represented her best chance to have a child. Davis said he did not want the embryos used without his consent. Mrs. Stowe, who moved from Maryville to Titusville, Fla., after the ruling, needs the court's consent and the consent of her ex-husband to donate the embryos, Erlenbach said, adding he believed Davis opposed donation. Oral arguments on Davis' appeal were scheduled for June 6. Telephone calls to the home of Janet Mayfield, one of Davis' attorneys, went unanswered late Thursday and his other lawyer, Charles Clifford, has an unpublished home telephone number. The embryos were produced through in vitro fertilization in December 1988 after the couple's continued efforts to have children resulted in Mrs. Stowe having five tubal pregnancies. After two of nine fertilized eggs were unsuccessfully implanted, the others were frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at the Knoxville clinic. They will have been frozen two years in December, Erlenbach said. Doctors have told Mrs. Stowe she has a 52 percent of giving birth from one of the seven embryos, Erlenbach said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Drops, Stocks Advance Fourth Straight Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Wraps up with details, comments
DOC.TEXT: The dollar dropped sharply against the yen today, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange advanced for the fourth consecutive day. The dollar closed at 150.05 yen, down 1.38 yen from Thursday's finish of 151.43 yen. After opening at 150.45 yen, the currency ranged between 149.90 yen and 150.85 yen. ``The dollar still remains under selling pressure from overseas,'' said Tsuyoshi Yamamoto, a dealer with the Industrial Bank of Japan. Yamamoto said the day's trading was focused rather on West German mark cross trading with the yen, in which market players bought the yen and sold the mark. But he said that affected yen-dollar trading. Yamamoto and other dealers said the dollar's retreat followed Thursday's remark by Sidney Jones, U.S. assistant treasury secretary, that the dollar was undervalued against all currencies but the yen. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 482.13 points, or 1.49 percent, closing the week at 32,793.88. A total of 1 billion shares changed hands in the market's first section, up from Thursday's 600 million shares. The index's advance followed an 855.58-point gain from Tuesday through Thursday. Declining long-term interest rates, rising bond prices and the high yen all combined to contribute to pushing up the Nikkei index, said a dealer with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities who spoke anonymously. ``A low rate of return in bonds would bring funds into the stock market,'' the dealer said. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds moved higher to 88.46 points as of 4 p.m. (3 a.m. EDT), up from Thursday's close of 87.76. The yield fell to 6.875 percent, down from the previous day's 7.010 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Families of 16 Dead Settle for $4.5 Million Per Death
DOC.TEXT: A company whose truck plowed into a school bus in an accident that killed 21 students has agreed to pay $72 million to 16 of the victims' families. Settlements completed Thursday call for Valley Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Inc. to pay $4.5 million per death, lawyers for the families and the company said. Parents will receive the bulk of the money, but some of it will go to trust funds valued from $50,000 to $250,000 established for 30 surviving brothers and sisters, lawyers said. Some of the siblings won't receive trust money until they reach the age of 25. In February, a family that lost a child in the wreck settled its wrongful death lawsuit with the company for $1.5 million. That leaves four wrongful death cases unresolved. Mike Mills, an attorney for Valley Coca-Cola, said two of them ``will be closed out shortly.'' Attorneys packed the small courtroom where District Court Judge Juan Partida approved the settlements Thursday. The settlements were taken before the judge because siblings receiving trust funds are minors. ``They (the families) are not going to want for many things,'' said attorney Abel Orendain, who was appointed to represent 8-year-old Omar Garcia, brother of deceased Abdon Garcia Jr., 14. ``At least all of these kids will get educated.'' Mills declined to say how many of the soft drink concern's insurance companies would share in paying the damages. A truck owned by Valley Coca-Cola ran through a stop sign and knocked the school bus into a water-filled pit in the Hidalgo County city of Alton on Sept. 21, 1989. Twenty-one students drowned; 60 escaped the submerged bus and survived. Also pending are injury cases filed against Valley Coca-Cola by some of the survivors, rescue workers and other bystanders.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Files New Claim in Thrift Takeover
DOC.TEXT: Charles Keating Jr. has filed a new $300 million lawsuit claiming that federal banking regulators waged a vendetta against him, destroying American Continental Corp. and his personal fortunes. In the claim filed Thursday in U.S. Claims Court in Washington, Keating blamed his financial collapse on Resolution Trust Corp.'s takeover of his troubled Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. It is the second suit Keating has filed in the claims court. ``They have caused my family and I to lose everything we own,'' Keating said. ``I think we're entitled to get it back.'' The claim also names as plaintiffs Keating's wife, Mary Elaine, their children and grandchildren, and two top American Continental executives. The Phoenix financier and lawyer plans to handle the case himself, keeping the cost of the lawsuit down. Keating said he had not argued a case since the early 1960s. The corporation also has a $575 million action against the government in the claims court. A hearing on that lawsuit is set for June 5. Keating said the $300 million action represents 50 percent of the plaintiffs' stock in American Continental, which he contends was ruined by the government's April 14, 1989, takeover of Lincoln. The day before federal regulators seized the Irvine, Calif.-based thrift, Keating and his management team at American Continental filed a petition in U.S. Bankruptcy Court for Chapter 11 protection from the company's creditors. Keating maintains the government violated a constitutional protection against taking private property without due process. David Barr, a spokesman for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said the agency had not seen the claim and could not comment. Keating also has filed a third civil lawsuit, asking U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin of Washington to return Lincoln to his management. Final arguments in that case have been set for June 19. He said his new lawsuit likely could not be resolved until Sporkin rules in the civil action against the government to reclaim Lincoln. A Senate Ethics Committee is investigating five senators who met with savings and loan regulators on Keating's behalf in March 1987, two years before regulators seized Lincoln. The five _ Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio and John McCain, R-Ariz. _ all had received political contributions from Keating.

DOC.HEAD: Massive Survey Reveals Sex Life Changing in China
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note content
DOC.TEXT: A new sex survey conducted in China says attitudes have liberalized in the past decade of openness to the outside world, but that there is a great need for sex education. ``I believe that Chinese concepts of sex are in a process of change,'' said Liu Daling, whose Shanghai Sex Sociological Research Center conducted the survey. ``We've broken through some of the old concepts, but not completely.'' The June 4 military crackdown on dissent last year almost killed the survey before it got under way, as foreign investors withdrew funding and some leaders said the project's timing was inappropriate. But Liu solved the funding crisis by dipping into his own savings. By August, hundreds of volunteers were interviewing married couples, students and sex criminals in 15 provinces of the world's most populous nation of 1.2 billion. Interviewers often faced resistance from a population not used to discussing details of their private lives. ``They didn't understand why someone would want to ask that kind of question: How many times do you have sex with your husband each month,'' Liu explained. ``They'd say, 'Why do you want to ask this? Are you kidding?``' While most of the respondents were given a written form to fill out and deposit in a sealed box to maintain secrecy, illiterate peasants were questioned verbally. By October, about 23,000 usable questionnaires were completed, and what the respondents had to say indicated a change of attitudes for what long has been a prudish society. As an example, more than half of the married respondents said they do not limit sexual intercourse to only the missionary position, which Liu described as a departure from past practice. The survey also found 54 percent of city dwellers and 44 percent of peasants do not object to extramarital affairs, attitudes that Liu said would have been espoused by only a small minority just 10 years ago. Nearly 15 percent of married city women who were questioned acknowledged having one or more affair. Liu, who was in Hong Kong this week to attend a seminar on sexology, said in an interview that 90 percent of the married respondents expressed some degree of satisfaction with their sex lives. About one-fourth of village women and one-third of city women said they often experienced ``pleasant feelings' during intercourse, and many others said they had such feelings occassionally. Up to one-third of the surveyed women said they did not miss their spouses when they left home for an extended period of time. About one-third of respondents also said they thought their lives would be better had they married someone else. The survey also found that while Chinese couples typically have sex four to seven times a month, it can be a painful and perfunctory experience. About 45 percent of city women and 37 percent of peasant women said they experienced pain during intercourse often or sometimes, says Liu. One-third of respondents in villages and 17 percent in cities said they usually spend less than one minute on foreplay. ``It's a little like animals,'' said Liu. ``They start as soon as they hit the bed.'' Communist China's state-controlled media has yet to report details of the survey, although a brief Xinhua News Agency report noted that the findings show sex education should be strengthened and the spread of pornography has ``seriously affected the healthy growth of young people.'' Among the many campaigns launched in the past year by China's conservative leadership has been a crackdown on pornography and prostitution, which have become particularly widespread in the country's relatively open coastal regions. Liu applauds the anti-pornography sweep but says sex education is even more important for society to develop properly. Besides learning the basics such as contraception, he believes Chinese should be exposed to a ``moral education'' on how to maintain healthy and fulfilling relations between the sexes. ``I think we should adopt a normal and natural attitude to a normal and natural thing,'' he said. Precisely how much support government authorities are willing to provide sex education and sexology is not clear, particularly in the current conservative climate.

DOC.HEAD: Government Claims It Recaptured Strategic City
DOC.TEXT: Liberia claims its forces have recaptured a strategic port seized by rebels earlier in the week, a Liberian radio station said. Rebels fighting since December to topple President Samuel Doe had taken Buchanan, the country's main port for iron ore exports, after attacking it Sunday. ELWA radio, a missionary station monitored in Abidjan, said the government on Thursday announced it drove the rebels from the city. `When contacted, President Doe ... confirmed reports of the successes made by the government troops in Grand Bassa county,'' the radio said. It added, ``The president said that the victory of the Liberian soldiers is a clear indication that the armed forces are on their way to wiping out the remaining rebels in Liberia.'' No independent confirmation of the government claim was immediately available. The government said nothing about casualties in the latest fighting. Rebels of the National Patriotic Front, led by former Doe aide Charles Taylor, invaded Liberia from its northeastern border with Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. Taylor's National Patriotic Front forces has vowed to take Monrovia, the capital and largest city, and topple Doe's government. Government troops had been unable to halt the advance of the rebels, who attacked the southern Atlantic Ocean port of Buchanan, its third-largest city with about 30,000 residents, on Sunday. The capture of Buchanan, 88 miles from Monrovia, was a major victory for the rebels. It is the country's main exit point for iron ore, which earns more than 70 percent of the country's foreign currency. The mine itself, in northern Nimba County, was captured by rebels last week. The government only confirmed Buchanan had been captured Wednesday, saying it would retake the town but wanted to minimize casualities. In another development, some wives of 10 men in Monrovia who were beheaded by unidentified attackers were quoted Thursday as linking the killings to the guerrilla war. The Daily Observer newspaper quoted the wives as saying their husbands, many of them soldiers, were all Gio and Mano, the two dominant tribes in Nimba County. Many rebels are also Gio and Mano. International human rights groups and survivors have accused government troops of massacring hundreds of Gio and Mano civilians in the battle against the rebels. The insurgents are accused of slaying Mandingos and Krahns, the tribe of Doe and most of his officers. The United States, Liberia's main foreign aid donor, condemned the violence Thursday. ``We call on officials entrusted with the law to vigorously pursue the perpetrators of these heinous crimes and to bring them to justice under the rule of law,'' said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler in Washington. U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they were especially disturbed of reports that some rebels had been executed. The fighting has prompted an estimated 250,000 Liberians to flee their homes. Many have taken refuge in neighboring Guinea and the Ivory Coast. Many Americans have left the country, though there has been no official evacuation. The U.S. Embassy presence has been reduced by 80 percent, the U.S. officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Twisters Derail Train, Damage Homes, Injure at Least Four People
LaserPhoto HUT4
DOC.TEXT: Nine tornadoes hurtled across central Kansas, derailing a freight train, destroying homes and injuring at least four people, authorities said. The National Weather Service also reported six tornadoes in Wyoming, two in Montana and one in South Dakota on Thursday.No deaths were reported in any of the twisters. Four oil field workers spotted a tornado near Bushton from atop an oil rig and tried to outrun it in a car, but the twister won, throwing them into a farm field and rolling their automobile several times, Barton County Sheriff Jim Daily said. ``As the tornado was coming it just about beat us to death with dirt,'' said one of the injured workers, Leland Hamby. He said he shut the rig down and got in the car ``and the next thing I know I was in the field.'' Rescue workers cut the four men out of the car. They were taken to the Central Kansas Medical Center in Great Bend where they were listed in good condition early today with cuts and bruises, said Teddy Williamson, nursing supervisor. A tornado derailed 88 of 107 cars on a Missouri Pacific Railroad freight train just west of Bushton, which is about 160 miles west of Topeka. None of the train crew members were injured. ``I was doing 45 when I started putting on the brakes. We never did see a tornado,'' said the train's engineer, C.H. Copke. ``It hit us out of the blue.'' Ida Gassoway said she was working in her yard near Bushton when she heard a twister coming, ran into her wood-frame house and laid down in a closet, covering herself with some blankets. ``And then the first thing I knew I was moving,'' said Mrs. Gassoway, who suffered a broken foot and scratches. ``When I finally realized where I was at, I was out of the house and out past the porch.'' The tornado ripped her garage off its foundation and leveled her small house. Downed power lines closed an eight-mile section of Kansas 4 between Claflin and Bushton for three hours. Great Bend resident Nolan Howell said he counted at least a dozen heavily damaged or demolished farms between those two towns. ``We've got a very large amount of damage,'' said Travis Kershner, a dispatcher for the Barton County Sheriff's Department. Tornadoes also destroyed a farm near Lorraine, about eight miles northeast of Bushton, and a mobile home near Lindsborg, about 30 miles east of Bushton, authorities said. No injuries were reported in either incident. Harold Winnie, district manager for KPL Gas Service in Hutchinson, said at least 900 customers were temporarily without electrical and gas service in the area.

DOC.HEAD: Gallery Asks For Dismissal in Mapplethorpe Case
DOC.TEXT: Defense lawyers asked a judge to dismiss an indictment against an art gallery showing photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe, saying the gallery is immune from Ohio obscenity laws. The lawyers on Thursday also asked Hamilton County Judge David J. Albanese to dismiss the charges on grounds that prosecutors unfairly singled out the Contemporary Arts Center gallery and its director, Dennis Barrie. Marc Mezibov, who represents Barrie, said that even if seven photographs cited in the indictment are found obscene, Ohio law exempts material exhibited for a ``proper purpose'' by artistic and educational institutions. ``Do you think the U.S. Supreme Court would buy that?'' Albanese asked during a three-hour hearing. ``Oh, absolutely,'' Mezibov said. ``What these laws are all about is an attempt to eliminate commercial, hard-core pornography. The CAC is not in the profit-making business. They are an educational institution.'' Senior assistant city Prosecutor Frank Prouty disagreed. ``The issue here is not their status. The issue is whether what they displayed is obscene,'' he said. Albanese did not say when he would rule on the defense request or the contention that prosecutors singled out the gallery. At least some of the pictures in the indictment are available in books at the University of Cincinnati and on display at the Cincinnati Art Museum, said H. Louis Sirkin, who represents the Arts Center. ``I'm not here to get these institutions in trouble. I'm here to point out that law enforcement officers were well aware that the material was available,'' he said. The arguments by Mezibov and Sirkin came after Albanese let the city amend the indictment to add references to U.S. Supreme Court obscenity and child pornography standards. The judge granted Prouty's request that the indictment allege that the two pictures featuring children in the 175-photograph exhibit include a ``lewd exhibition or graphic focus on genitals.'' Albanese also agreed to have the indictment allege that five other pictures depicting sex acts meet Supreme Court requirements that obscene material violate community standards, depict clearly offensive sexual conduct and lack artistic value. ``It's clear that the state can amend that charge so long as ... the defendants have a chance to prepare for a trial,'' the judge said. Barrie and the gallery are charged with pandering obscenity and using children in material involving nudity. If convicted, they face $6,000 in fines and Barrie faces six months in jail. Their lawyers had argued that the indictment accused them of no crime, referring only to depictions of sex acts and nude children, which are not automatically obscene. Albanese also rejected a defense request to see a transcript from the county grand jury that returned the charges April 7. Defense lawyers said the indictment doesn't indicate whether grand jurors were told of Supreme Court standards that pictures found to have artistic value can't be ruled obscene. Albanese refused to violate the traditional confidentiality of the grand jury, noting that a county Common Pleas Court judge had reviewed the transcript before refusing a similar request last month.

DOC.HEAD: Goetz Claims Youth He Shot Is Not as Brain Damaged as He Pretends
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Court hearing set for 9:30 a.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Subway gunman Bernhard Goetz says one of the men he shot more than five years ago is faking the extent of his brain damage. Goetz, who is being sued by the injured man, Darrell Cabey, for $50 million, held a news conference Thursday on the steps of City Hall and passed out videotapes that he said prove Cabey can function normally. He said he would provide evidence today at a hearing in state Supreme Court, New York's trial-level court, that Cabey, though paralyzed from the waist down by a bullet that shattered his spine, is fully aware of the world around him. ``He is not a mental vegetable,'' Goetz said. One of Cabey's lawyers, Ronald Kuby, said he had seen Goetz' videotape. ``The tape proves nothing but that Darrell knew what he had for lunch and knew who the mayor of New York was on Dec. 27,'' Kuby said. ``The tape also shows that there is no depth too low for Bernhard Goetz to sink,'' he continued. ``He harbors a murderous and sadistic hatred for Darrell Cabey. He shot him at point-blank range _ in the back _ after saying, `You don't look so bad; here's another one.' He's crippled the young man for life, caused him permanent brain damage.'' Harry Katz, Goetz' paralegal, said he shot the eight-minute videotape at the United Cerebral Palsy building, on East 23rd Street and Lexington Avenue, by ``subterfuge, trickery or whatever you want to call it.'' Goetz, 42, shot Cabey, now 22, and three other youths with an unlicensed gun on Dec. 22, 1984. Goetz said the teens surrounded him on a subway train and were trying to rob him. The youths claimed they were panhandling money for video games. Goetz was acquitted of attempted murder and assault charges but was convicted of illegal possession of a gun and served 8{ months of a one-year sentence. He is acting as his own lawyer in Cabey's civil lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Government Bans Three Neo-Nazi Publications
DOC.TEXT: France says it is banning three neo-Nazi magazines from West Germany that it says are racist and could cause violence following two weeks of anti-Semitic incidents. In Thursday's order, Interior Secretary Pierre Joxe prohibited distribution and sale of the small-circulation magazines, which are translated into French for distribution to extreme-right groups. However, Joxe said the works ``threaten the public order because of their apologies for Nazism, racism and anti-Semitism.'' His authority to ban them comes under a 1939 law controlling foreign publications. France has been ungoing a wave of protests and recriminations since a Jewish cemetery in Carpentras was desecrated two weeks ago. A corpse was mutilated and 34 tombs desecrated, and the case remains unsolved. Since then, similar incidents have been carried out in France, Israel, Canada and elsewhere. In the latest French legal action, a court in Poissy, west of Paris, charged a 26-year-old man with painting anti-Semitic graffiti on the doors of a vocational school. The messages, discovered Tuesday, were aimed at the school's Jewish director. On Wednesday, a judge in Saint Herblain freed under court supervision three skinheads charged with profaning 90 graves at a Catholic cemetery in the eastern French village. Mayor Charles Gautier denounced the decision by Judge Gilles Dubigeon. In a letter Thursday to Prime Minister Michel Rocard, the mayor said the three suspects should have been held in jail while awaiting trial. In another development, extreme-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen on Thursday criticized a court decision to fine him for referring to the Nazi gas chambers as ``a detail of World War II history.'' In a statement by his National Front party, Le Pen criticized Wednesday's ruling as political persecution and an infringement on his free speech rights. The court in Nanterre, outside Paris, ordered Le Pen to pay 18 cents to each of 11 organizations that filed suit against him after the remark in 1987. Judge Lefoyer de Costil said ``freedom of expression ... has a limit.'' He also ordered Le Pen to pay $720 to each of the groups to cover legal fees. ``This decision only takes into account the interpretations of my political enemies and not at all the explanations I provided,'' Le Pen said. ``This irreversible judgment is proof of political persecution against me.'' The 61-year-old politician has been increasingly ostracized since the desecration of the cemetery at Carpentras. Le Pen, a deputy in the European Parliament, wants to expel immigrants from France and enact laws to keep them out. He denies repeated accusations of being racist or anti-Semitic.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down Against Yen, Gold Steady
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued to fall against the Japanese yen in European trading this morning but held steady against the West German mark. Gold was little changed. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 150.05 yen, down 1.38 yen from Thursday's finish. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 149.60 yen. ``The dollar still remains under selling pressure from overseas,'' said Tsuyoshi Yamamoto, a dealer in Tokyo with the Industrial Bank of Japan. Yamamoto said the day's trading was focused on sales of West German marks to buy yen, and the dollar was caught in the cross fire. Yamamoto and other dealers said the dollar's retreat followed Thursday's remark by Sidney Jones, U.S. assistant treasury secretary, that the dollar was undervalued against all currencies but the yen. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday: _ 1.6781 West German marks, up from 1.6780 _ 1.4190 Swiss francs, unchanged _ 5.6460 French francs, up from 5.6445 _ 1,231.00 Italian lire, up from 1,230.75 _ 1.1835 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1853. The dollar was quoted today at 1.8872 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8740 guilders late Wednesday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6920 from $1.6890 late Thursday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $366.35 per ounce this morning, up from $366.25 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, where the market was closed Thursday, gold opened this morning at $366.25 per ounce. Gold in Hong Kong dropped 51 cents an ounce to close at $367.83 an ounce. Silver bullion opened in London at a bid price of $5.21 an ounce, down from $5.26 bid late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Communist Protesters Demand Iliescu's Resignation
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of demonstrators chanting ``Down with Communism'' demanded the ouster of President-elect Ion Iliescu in the largest anti-government protest since the first free election in 53 years. The demonstration Thursday came four days after the election in which Iliescu scored a landslide victory despite opposition claims that he and other members of the National Salvation Front are neo-Communist. The estimated 8,000 protesters demonstrated peacefully for about seven hours in University Square in downtown Bucharest. About 600 people led by three black-robed Orthodox priests staged a candlelight march to the television station late in the evening. The marchers were demanding that the government-run television show a tape, which they claimed showed members of the National Salvation Front dividing up top posts on Dec. 22, the same day Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu fell from power. The Front, dominated by former Communists, has insisted it did not form until after the revolution began. The demonstrators said the tape showed that the Front actually existed some time before Ceausescu's ouster and that its members took advantage of the revolutionary chaos to grab power. The demonstrators said they planned to march to the television again this evening because they arrived too late Thursday to present their demands. Two dozen soldiers, supported by half a dozen armored personnel carriers, were deployed around the TV Center in northern Bucharest, the scene of some of the heaviest fighting in December's revolution. About 200 soldiers in riot gear replaced the usual police guard around the government's headquarters. With almost all the ballots counted from Sunday's election, Iliescu had 85.2 percent of the vote in the three-way presidential race. Radu Campeanu of the National Liberal Party received 10.6 percent, while Ion Ratiu of the National Peasant Party trailed with 4.2 percent. In another development, the General Prosecutor's office announced Thursday that the final death toll among civilians and soldiers in December's revolution was 1,038. It added that 2,000 people were injured in the clashes between revolutionaries and Ceausescu loyalists. It was not clear whether the casualty figures included the Securitate secret police and pro-Ceausescu loyalists. The death toll is way below estimates in the tens of thousands offered by Romanian and foreign observers during the revolt. Opposition activists suggest the Front deliberately exaggerated the death toll at first in order to strengthen its position in the revolution's early days.

DOC.HEAD: Malik Sentenced to 24 Years on Drug Charges
DOC.TEXT: A man prosecutors describe as a major international heroin trafficker has been sentenced to more than 24 years in prison on federal drug charges. Mushtaq Malik, 41, whose defense included a claim that he was double-crossed in a plot to kill Pakistan's former leader, told a judge at his sentencing Thursday that he did not believe justice had been done. ``It seems to me that being a poor man from a Third World nation nobody's looking at my side,'' Malik told U.S. District Judge Frank H. Freedman. Malik was convicted by a jury last November on charges of importing heroin and conspiracy to import. Prosecutors alleged that Malik arranged for a Jordanian man to bring $10 million worth of heroin to the United States. An appeal was expected on Malik's behalf. At his trial, Malik testified that his involvement with an accused drug dealer was merely an effort to track down a man he said had double-crossed him in a plot to kill former Pakistani President Gen. Mohammed Zia ul-Haq. A Pakistani official denied the assassination plot at the time of the testimony. Malik did not say he was involved in a mysterious plane crash that killed Zia on Aug. 17, 1988, several months after Malik had been arrested. The judge sentenced Malik to two concurrent prison terms of 24 years and five months, with five years supervised release. At the sentencing, Assistant U.S. Attorney Kevin O'Regan asked that Malik be sentenced to 30 years. ``Mr. Malik is an international narcotics trafficker of the highest level. Only the most serious punishment is appropriate in this case,'' O'Regan said. But Malik's attorney, Michael O. Jennings, asked the judge to consider a lower sentence, saying that people who commit more serious crimes do not get as long as 20 years to serve.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Midwest; Thunderstorms in Plains
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in the Midwest early today and tornado watches were sprinkled with thunderstorms in parts of the Great Plains. Rain also fell in southern Florida and high winds buffeted the northern Rockies again today. The first tropical depression of the year formed in the northwest Caribbean and was expected to spread heavy rain across parts of Cuba today. There was fair but cooler-than-normal weather again in the Northeast. The Pacific Northwest also had fair weather early today, but evening showers were forecast along the coast. Clear skies were over the Southwest and southern Rockies. A tornado watch was posted for early today in parts of Kansas, Montana, Wyoming, South Dakota and Nebraska. A hot and humid Gulf current was to push northward into Missouri. Thunderstorms were ahead of a cold front across the central Plains. Rain was likely in a wide swath from the Rockies in Montana to the northern Plains and into the Midwest. Thunderstorms were likely in the mid-Mississippi Valley. Temperatures along the Sun Belt were to reach well into the 80s. Temperatures in the desert Southwest were to be in the 90s. Severe thunderstorms over the Great Plains on Thursday unleashed at least 18 tornadoes. The nation's high on Thursday was 105 degrees at Lajitas, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Five More Boeing 737s Missing Pins on Steering Wheels
DOC.TEXT: Emergency inspections have turned up five more Boeing 737 jets missing pins that help keep steering wheels in place, a Boeing Co. spokesman says. That brings to seven the number of missing cotter pins spotted on Boeing-made 737s within the last two weeks, said the spokesman, Jack Gamble. The five jets reported Tuesday belonged to foreign carriers that neither Boeing nor the Federal Aviation Administration would name. The FAA last week ordered U.S.-owned airlines to inspect steering assemblies on 737 models 300, 400 and 500 that were built over the past two years. The order came after a steering wheel came off in a co-pilot's hands during a test flight of a 737-400 delivered to a West German air carrier. The pilot immediately took control. The plane landed safely, Boeing said. The plane's steering mechanism was later found to be missing cotter pins. The second missing cotter pin involved a 737 parked on Boeing's flight test line at Boeing Field in Seattle. The FAA said last week it has launched an investigation to determine whether the problem is due to a breakdown in Boeing's quality control. The cotter pin is fastened behind the nut in the nut-and-bolt assembly that holds the steering wheel to the steering assembly in the airplane cockpit. It is designed to prevent the bolt from working loose, which could allow the bolt to drop out and the wheel to come free. The nuts and bolts were tight on six of the seven planes found to have missing cotter pins, Gamble said. A total of 378 airplanes qualified for inspection under the FAA order. While the order applied only to U.S.-based airlines, Gamble said foreign-owned airlines routinely act on such orders. The U.S. airlines were required to report by last Monday any problems with steering assemblies and there were no reports, Gamble said. Airlines were trying to determine why cotter pins were missing, the Boeing spokesman said. It was possible that maintenance work had been done and the pins had not been replaced, Gamble said. The 737 is the smallest jetliner made by Boeing, a twin-engine, short-to-medium range plane produced at its plant in the Seattle suburb of Renton. The model 300 can carry as many as 141 passengers, the 400 as many as 159 passengers and the 500, the newest model, up to 122 passengers.

DOC.HEAD: Ragtag Flotilla Commemorates 50th Anniversary of Allied Evacuation
DOC.TEXT: Vessels large and small, many of them the same ones that rescued hundreds of thousands of Allied troops from the Nazi onslaught, made their way across the English Channel to mark the 50th anniversary of the evacuation. Thursday's 10-hour crossing by the so-called ``Little Ships'' began a weekend of celebrations reuniting about 5,000 French and British veterans _ some in their 90s _ who fled to England just ahead of the advancing German army in 1940. The dozens of vessels in the flotilla hoisted the British naval ensign and entered Dunkirk waters in formation Thursday afternoon behind the frigate HMS Alacrity to be greeted by a throng of local officials and well-wishers. ``It's a once-in-a-lifetime thing, I suppose,'' Hon. British Consul to Dunkirk Sandy Baker said. ``They won't be able to do this again 50 years from now.'' Britain's Prince Philip, husband of Queen Elizabeth II, stood on the Dover docks to give a royal send-off to 76 vessels reenacting the World War II mission that rescued 338,000 troops off beaches in northern France and Belgium before onrushing German troops. At the end of May 1940, tank-led German forces drove Allied troops onto the beaches of Dunkirk and De Panne, Belgium, 20 miles away, where they were trapped with their backs to the channel. On May 29 of that year, the British government appealed to owners of all types of vessels to volunteer to help make up for the shortage of troop transports, and amateur and professional sailors raced across the channel in their boats to aid the Allies. Over the next seven days an armada of about 860 naval ships, fishing boats and pleasure craft rescued almost 400,000 British, French and Belgian troops under enemy fire. British coast guard boats on Thursday stood by to shepherd the elderly fleet, which could only travel as fast as the slowest boat, about 7 mph. In addition to winds and high seas, the boats had to sail through the wakes of the ferries that frequently crisscross the channel. About eight miles out, a boat that once carried Katharine Hepburn and Humphrey Bogart in the Hollywood film ``The African Queen'' began taking on water off Ramsgate. A rescue helicopter from a neary Royal Air Force base and a lifeboat were sent to escort and tow the 30-foot steam-driven vessel back to harbor. A Dover coastguard spokesman said four people were on board, including the American owner of the boat, Jim Hendricks. Hendricks, 55, a hotel owner from Key Largo, Fla., said the system that pumps water into the boiler quit working. ``It was much rougher than I expected, the waves were getting pretty high,'' Hendricks said, adding, ``It was just too much for her.'' The three-man crew of the boat, which Hendricks purchased in 1982, said they were afraid the boat was going to overturn in the rough channel. The flotilla, which will spend three days in the marine basin at Dunkirk, included motor launches, cabin cruisers, Thames barges, yachts, old lifeboats and a former torpedo boat. Many are the original preserved craft that returned from the beaches in 1940 with thousands of expeditionary forces aboard. Events commemorating the rescue will include a parade, wreath layings, lunches, parties and a prayer service in Dunkirk and in nearby De Pannes.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Denied for Parolee Charged in Racial Slaying
DOC.TEXT: Catherine McCants believed her son was gunned down in a grocery store parking lot because he was black and dating a white woman. She was half right, investigators say. On Thursday, they charged a prison parolee who ``just hated blacks'' with fatally shooting 21-year-old Darren Jessie on March 31.
