Mobile County Sheriff Tom Purvis said the man arrested, Daniel Amos Pilot, did not know Jessie, Jessie's injured 17-year-old friend, Joseph O'Cain, or Jessie's white girlfriend, Amanda Hicks. Pilot, 34, was charged with murder and attempted murder and ordered held without bond. O'Cain was shot in the back and is partially paralyzed. Pilot was paroled March 12 from a state prison after serving four years of a 12-year sentence for receiving stolen property, said prison spokeswoman Debbie Herbert. ``In my opinion, it was a spontaneous, unprovoked, senseless act of violence,'' Purvis said. ``If there was any provocation it was merely the hatred in Pilot toward blacks.'' It wasn't the interracial dating, the sheriff said, because Pilot didn't know the victims or anyone in the store. ``They were customers in the store,'' he said. Purvis said investigators determined that Pilot and a friend had gone into a Winn Dixie grocery store in the mostly white surburb of Theodore to buy beer. Pilot passed a car where Jessie and O'Cain were waiting to pick up Ms. Hicks from work. They were listening to the radio when the shots were fired. ``When they said he was killed in Theodore by a white man, I knew it was race,'' Mrs. McCants said. ``He should get the chair. They don't need to send him back to prison to live.''

DOC.HEAD: Factory Explosion Forces Hundreds from Homes
DOC.TEXT: An explosion at a plastics factory forced hundreds of people to evacuate their homes temporarily and sent up to 14 people to the hospital with eye and skin irritation, authorities said. Between 500 and 1,000 people were routed for several hours Thursday by the accident at Sil-Tech Corp., which makes silicone-based fluids, said police Sgt. James Knierm. Among those evacuated were people gathered for a golf tournament near the plant, which employs about 10 people in this southeastern Michigan town. Between 10 and 14 people were treated and released from Herrick Memorial Health Care Center for eye and skin irritation, firefighter David Ousterhout said. The fire was extinguished in about two hours, Ousterhout said. The cause of the explosion was under investigation. Bruce Van Wieren, a conservation officer for the Michigan Department of Natural Resources, said no hazardous substances leaked and smoke quickly dissipated.

DOC.HEAD: Witness Tells of Meetings To Plan Drug Agent's Kidnapping
DOC.TEXT: All four men on trial in the 1985 kidnapping and torture-murder of a U.S. drug agent in Mexico attended one or more meetings where the crime was planned, a witness testified. Hector Cervantes Santos, former security chief for a Guadalajara drug cartel, testified that at one meeting, Mexican drug lord Rafael Caro Quintero also suggested kidnapping John Gavin, then the U.S. ambassador to Mexico. Cervantes, testifying Thursday through an interpreter, said that at the time he was a bodyguard for Javier Barba Hernandez, a Guadalajara lawyer and confidante of numerous drug traffickers. Ruben Zuno Arce, the brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria, attended the meetings and supported the idea of kidnapping Gavin, Cervantes said. Gavin was not kidnapped, but U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique ``Kiki'' Camarena was abducted on Feb. 7, 1985, along with his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. Their bodies were discovered about a month later at a ranch 65 miles outside Guadalajara, Mexico's second-largest city. On trial in U.S. District Court for alleged involvement in the slayings are Zuno; convicted Honduran drug kingpin Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros; Javier Vasquez Velasco, a Mexican citizen who also has lived in the United States; and Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez, a former Mexican police officer. Cervantes testified that at the last of the four meetings, held just days before Camarena's abduction, ``Don Ruben said he agreed that the person should be picked up and (it should be) found out how much he knew and who he was cooperating with.'' The drug lords reportedly were incensed because Camarena's undercover work had led U.S. and Mexican authorities to a desert marijuana plantation, where they seized 10,000 tons of the drug worth billions of dollars. In his testimony, Cervantes also implicated several former Mexican police officials and Mexico City's current police chief, Javier Garcia Paniagua. Matta's lawyer, Martin Stolar, challenged Cervantes' testimony. ``He's basically the butler who wandered in and out of meetings and claimed to hear what was going on,'' Stolar said. Zuno's lawyer, Edward Medvene, has said Cervantes' testimony should be viewed with skepticism because he didn't come forward when the slayings occurred. He did not comment on Thursday's testimony. DEA records show Cervantes has been a U.S. government-paid informant since Nov. 24, 1989. He and his family were relocated to the United States and have received more than $36,000 in DEA payments since November, the records show.

DOC.HEAD: Wildcat Rail Strike Widens; Cuts Off Baltic Coast
DOC.TEXT: A wildcat rail strike spread today to Gdansk and cut off all train traffic to the country's Baltic ports, posing the most serious challenge yet to the Solidarity-led government and its economic reform program. The Ministry of Transport said talks to resolve the walkout are at a ``total impasse.'' The strike began Sunday as a wildcat protest by workers demanding higher pay. It has now received the support of the one-time Communist-backed labor federation, which is challenging Solidarity for support among workers. Solidarity chairman Lech Walesa canceled a trip to Scandinavia today due to the labor crisis. In a reference to the rival federation, Walesa said in a nationwide radio broadcast that ``demagogical forces'' were trying to exploit workers' legitimate grievances in a game that could lead to ``civil war.'' ``I hope that reason will win,'' he said in a midday radio interview. ``The strikers should be given a way out of it with honor because they are right.'' But he said the route of strikes ``leads nowhere,'' even though ``I am unhappy and almost the entire society is unhappy.'' Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a former Solidarity adviser who became head of the East bloc's first non-Communist government last summer, has said the strike could seriously damage Poland's reform program. Railway workers at stations in the port city of Gdansk joined the strike today, crippling the harbor where the Solidarity labor movement was born during a 1980 shipyard strike. ``There is no access to the entire coast by train now,'' said Transport Ministry spokesman Stefan Pozniak. ``So it's getting really serious.'' The ports handle most of Poland's coal exports, the country's leading hard currency earner. In addition to Gdansk, the labor dispute has paralyzed Szczecin, the country's busiest port, where 12 ships awaited unloading. A rail route linking Berlin with Gdansk through Szczecin was blocked, as was freight from Czechoslovakia and Hungary en route to the Polish ports, Pozniak said. Officials say ``thousands'' of the 400,000 workers employed by the state-run railway are on strike, but have not given any specific numbers for the strikers. About 50 railway workers are on a hunger strike. Rail traffic to two dozen key junctions across northwest Poland has been cut off, and the army was called in to move perishable and essential goods. Mazowiecki appealed for an end to the strike at a local election rally Thursday, warning it could ``destabilize'' the government and discourage Western investors. The prime minister said there are ``other means of claiming one's rights in a state that is democratic and no longer totalitarian.'' Negotiations broke off Thursday when three of the four unions which represent the railway workers demanded that the talks be moved to Slupsk, the northwest city were the wildcat strike committee is based. The government had refused to negotiate with the strikers directly because they were not protesting within legal union structures. But two branches of the OPZZ labor federation, the union created by the Communists after they banned Solidarity in 1982, and a small independent union stepped in to represent the strikers. The Solidarity union was the only one to agree to remain in Warsaw for the talks. It has called the strike a ``strong warning'' for the government it helped create, but is urging the workers to end the protest. In his radio interview, Walesa accused the OPZZ of manipulating the strikers in a ``game that will solve nothing but may lead even to a civil war.'' The government has made no announcement about whether it would send its negotiators to Slupsk. However, the government has firmly resisted granting the railway workers the pay raise they are requesting, saying that making an exception for one group of workers would unleash a torrent of similar demands. The government says this could scuttle the ``shock therapy'' economic reform program it instituted on Jan. 1. The drive to create a market economy from the shattered socialist system is built on cutting government subsidies to ailing state-run enterprises, including the railroad. Pay raises have to come from an industry's own resources. The strict wage controls, coupled with the raising of prices to market levels, have reduced Poles' real incomes by an estimated 40 percent. The railway workers are demanding that their basic monthly salary be raised to $8 above the average monthly salary of $79. The strikers are also seeking the dismissal of railroad directors installed by the former Communist regime who they say are incompetent and hampering reforms. The government fired the Communist-appointed director of the strike-bound Pomerania rail district in northwest Poland on Thursday. Officials say interviews are under way for a new general railway director and a restructuring plan for the railroad is being drafted, including a new pay scale.

DOC.HEAD: Serbian Authorities Order Expulsion of 17 Albanian Refugees
DOC.TEXT: Serbian authorities have ordered the expulsion of 17 Albanian refugees accused of provoking ethnic unrest in the troubled province of Kosovo, official news reports said. The Albanians, mostly the offspring of defectors who escaped Albania's harsh Stalinist regime after 1945, were given 30 days to leave Yugoslavia and find a new country in which to resettle, the official reports said Thursday. The U.N. High Commission for Refugees in Belgrade, meanwhile, denied reports that it had been formally notified of the expulsion orders and would help the refugees find a country willing to take them. ``The crux of the matter is whether these people formally have the right to refugee status,'' Judith Kumin, an official of the U.N. commission, said. She said that according to the 1951 U.N. Convention on Refugee Status, which Yugoslavia has ratified, children of refugees are automatically granted the same rights and cannot be expelled ``unless convicted of serious crimes.'' ``There are many more safeguards involved in expelling a refugee than (expelling) an ordinary alien. We don't know whether these people have been afforded the same level of (legal) protection,'' Kumin said in an interview. Serbia's Communist-controlled newspapers reported that the 17 Albanians, who live in Kosovo, ``were denied hospitality because they broke Yugoslav laws.'' The reports did not specify what laws the Albanians had violated. Serbia, the largest Yugoslav republic, has launched a campaign to expel some 730 Albanian refugees in Kosovo who allegedly do not possess valid residence permits. Serbia's Communist authorities claim the Albanians worked for their native country's Sigurimi secret police and were instructed to provoke tensions between the ethnic Albanian majority and Serbian minority in Kosovo, an autonomous province in Serbia which borders Albania. Several of the refugees, interviewed by the liberal press in the republics of Slovenia and Croatia, denied they were Sigurimi agents. They said their families escaped from Albania because of political or religious persecution. In another development, Kosovo's Premier Jusuf Zeinulahu and three other ethnic Albanian ministers withdrew the resignations they had submitted during a two-day session of the province's legislature. The four wanted to resign to protest moves by Serbian authorities to tighten their police and administrative control over Kosovo, where 60 ethnic Albanians have died since February 1989 in anti-Serbian riots. They withdrew their resignations at the request of ethnic Albanian lawmakers. Ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.6 million population and are fighting for more autonomy from Serbia, which says it must control the province to protect the Serbian minority from alleged Albanian harassment.

DOC.HEAD: Rabbi Says Political Leaders Eat Non-Kosher Foods
DOC.TEXT: The diet of Israeli leaders became a political issue today after a powerful rabbi privately accused several politicians of eating non-kosher foods such as pork and shellfish. The accusations against Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and others were secretly recorded as Rabbi Ovadia Yosef spoke to other religious leaders at a Jewish seminary on Thursday night. Yosef's comments were the lead item on both Israel and armed forces radio stations this morning and were quoted on the front page of the daily Yediot Ahronot newspaper. Israel radio said it obtained the tape recording from an unidentified person who made the recording without the rabbi's knowledge. Yosef, the spiritual mentor of the ultra-Orthodox Shas party, said of Shamir: ``He eats only impure fish. That's what he likes, he's dying for it.'' He also said of Ariel Sharon, a leading right-wing figure: ``He doesn't eat shellfish, but he really loves pork.'' Israel radio reported that Shamir refused to comment when asked in an interview about Yosef's charges. Neither Sharon nor his spokesman could be reached for comment. Yossef Azran, head of the Shas faction in parliament, told army radio that Yosef's remarks on the politicians' dining habits were taken out of context. Many religious Jews adhere to strict dietary laws that prohibit them from eating foods they consider unclean, such as pork and shellfish. Shamir and other top politicians lead a secular lifestyle, but publicly they observe Jewish holidays and some of the customs. The accusations were broadcast as Shamir, the interim prime minister, tries to persuade ultra-Orthodox religious parties to join a coalition Cabinet that would be led by his right-wing Likud bloc. Yosef played a key role two months ago in toppling Shamir's coalition government with the left-leaning Labor Party. The coalition lost a vote of confidence in Parliament after Yosef ordered the six Shas lawmakers to abstain. Shas traditionally has supported Likud.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquakes Cause Damage in Southern Sudan
DOC.TEXT: Strong earthquakes shook southern Sudan for the second time in a week, causing damage in the town of Juba, a relief official said today. ``It went on and off all night. A building at the airport collapsed and there appears to be damage in the town,'' said Bob Koepp of the Lutheran World Federation. Koepp runs a relief air shuttle from Nairobi. He was relaying a report from one of his pilots, who made a round trip to Juba this morning. The pilot did not go into the town and had no information about possible casualties, Koepp said. He said the airport runway sustained no damage. Koepp reported the pilot said the quake began Thursday morning and that tremors continuing throughout the day. The U.S. Geological Survey in Boulder, Colo., reported a quake measuring 7.1 on the Richter scale about 50 miles east of Juba shortly after a 6.8 tremor rocked the same area. The Hong Kong Observatory also reported a 6.8 tremor in the same region but made no mention of the 7.1 quake. The quakes were strong enough to be felt in neighboring Uganda and western Kenya and shook buildings near Lake Victoria, 375 miles south of the epicenter, the Daily Nation newspaper of Nairobi reported today. They were in the same area where an earthquake measuring 7.4 struck Saturday. The area is sparsely populated, with the few residences consisting of grass-thatched mud huts. In Cairo, Egypt, Rashad Kebeasy, a geologist, said the latest quakes were aftershocks of last weekend's earthquake. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. A quake of magnitude 6 can cause severe damage on land while a tremor of magnitude 7 is capable of causing heavy and widespread damage.

DOC.HEAD: India Replaces Hardline Governor in Kashmir
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jagmohan, one name, cq.
DOC.TEXT: The governor of Jammu-Kashmir state, whose harsh tactics fanned the flames of a Moslem separatist revolt, resigned today, a senior official and news reports said. The resignation, reportedly at the request of the New Delhi government, came four days after paramilitary police in Srinagar opened fire on a procession bearing the body of a slain Moslem religious leader. At least 58 people were killed and 300 wounded in what survivors claimed was an unprovoked attack. The government said the troops fired after they were shot at by militants in the procession. A senior government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, reported the resignation of the governor, Jagmohan, who uses only one name. ``Perhaps he now feels that he has become an object of oontroversy and his presence is not likely to help the people of Kashmir to join the mainstream,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. In mostly Hindu Jammu, the winter capital of predominantly Moslem Jammu-Kashmir state, shops closed in protest as word of Jagmohan's resignation spread. Jagmohan, 61, was appointed governor of Jammu-Kashmir on Jan. 19 to try to halt the increasingly violent Moslem campaign for independence from predominantly Hindu India. The next day his government launched the harshest crackdown ever against the four-decade-old secessionist movement. At least 460 people, mostly Moslem militants and supporters shot by security troops, have been killed in Kashmir since then, according to daily tallies verified by reporters and sources. The government said the toll was less than 300, while some sources claimed it was as high as 1,200. In Srinagar, Jammu-Kashmir's summer capital, Moslem demonstrators used Jagmohan's name as a synonym for repression. He said he used ``fairness and firmness,'' but Kashmiris claimed he allowed troops to rob and torture them. Srinagar, a once-thriving tourist town of 1 million people, has been under curfew every night for the past four months and often during the daytime. Jagmohan, a career civil servant, will be succeeded by Girish Saxena, security adviser to Prime Minister V.P. Singh, Press Trust of India said. Like Jagmohan, the new governor is a Hindu. United News of India quoted L.K. Advani, head of a conservative Hindu party, as saying Jagmohan submitted his resignation at the request of Singh's government. Advani, whose party supports but does not formally participate in Singh's minority coalition, criticized the dismissal but said it would not cause his party to withdraw its support of Singh. Such a move could have brought down the government. Calls for Jagmohan's dismissal had been raised in Parliament this week by Moslem and leftist legislators and ex-Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, leader of the opposition Congress Party. The demands followed Monday's killings of mourners carrying the body of the assassinated Islamic clergyman, Maulvi Mohammad Farooq, whose killers have not been caught. The clergyman had long advocated political discussions to resolve Kashmir's future, but recently he started calling for independence. Kashmir, a former princely state, was divided along a still-disputed frontier between India and Pakistan after the two nations became independent from Britain in 1947 and were partitioned along religious lines. About 64 percent of the 6 million people in Indian-governed Jammu-Kashmir state are Moslems, making it the only state in India with a Moslem majority. Nationwide, Moslems account for 12 percent of India's 880 million people while Hindus comprise 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Beijing Linked Entire Range Of Ties With Bush Decision On Trade Status
With PM-US-China, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Chinese comment. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `Their arguments...'
DOC.HEAD: AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: China has made clear that President Bush's decision on trade relations would have bearing on political and cultural ties. China today welcomed Bush's announcement on Thursday that he favored extending China's most-favored-nation trade status for one year, allowing Beijing to continue enjoying low tariffs. ``This is not only in the interests of China but in the interests of the United States, too,'' the official Xinhua News Agency today quoted Premier Li Peng as telling visiting Japanese businessmen. Xinhua had said earlier that only a ``small number of Americans, under the pretext of so-called human rights, opposed the renewal of China's MFN status. ``Their arguments have been strongly rejected by the majority of American people, who cherish the long-term interests of relations between the two countries,'' the news agency wrote. Some U.S. congressmen say they will fight Bush's decision, citing China's brutal crushing of a pro-democracy movement a year ago. Trade between China and the United States has flourished since 1979, when diplomatic ties were renewed. In recent days, China indicated that raising tariffs on its goods would lead not just to higher duties on U.S. products and a sharp drop in trade, but diminished political and cultural contacts as well. China fought hard on the issue, mixing veiled warnings with calls for Washington to be sensible and ``consider the matter from a long-term perspective,'' as Communist Party General Secretary Jiang Zemin said recently. China also made concessions to critics of its human rights record by lifting martial law in the Tibetan capital and releasing 211 people jailed for taking part in last year's democracy movement in Beijing. Bush's decision can thus be seen as a Chinese diplomatic victory, but a limited one. China's leaders still have failed to convince the White House or the U.S. Congress that how they treat political dissidents is an internal matter on which the United States has no right to comment. In making his announcement, Bush said he was not condoning China's suppression of dissent and urged Chinese leaders to improve their human rights record. Many Americans still believe China's leaders should be punished in some way for having ordered the army to fire on unarmed pro-democracy protesters last June, when hundreds and perhaps thousands were killed. Given such deep differences in outlook, continued friction between Beijing and Washington is inevitable. There will be no lack of new occasion for conflict. For example, the World Bank is scheduled to consider several new loans to China next week. Although China insists such loans should not be linked to politics, the United States has blocked past loans, making exceptions only for those considered for humanitarian purposes. Fang Lizhi, China's most famous dissident, and his wife, Li Shuxian, remain in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, a constant irritant in relations. There appears no progress toward winning them safe passage from China. Jiang reiterated recently the couple must admit their guilt and promise not to fight the government again. The more than 30,000 Chinese students in the United States will become a growing point of friction if, as their studies finish, significant numbers fail to return home. Bush has said those who were in the United States last June can stay at least until Jan. 1, 1994, if they fear persecution at home.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Kathy Wilhelm has reported for The Associated Press from Beijing since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush's Talks With Gorbachev Mark a Historic Turning Point
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs graf 8, And Gorbachev, with new grafs 8-11, further background.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's summit next week with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev may mark the end of one era in U.S.-Soviet relations and the beginning of another. The main business the two will conduct symbolizes the old era. They will sign a declaration to reduce U.S. and Soviet strategic nuclear weapons _ by much less than the 50 percent initially advertised _ and probably commit themselves to pursue further cutbacks. The declaration will make the May 31-June 3 summit, like the majority of its predecessors, an arms control summit. At the same time, Bush and Gorbachev will begin the transition to a new superpower relationship forced on them by a rapidly changing world. The Germans, taking charge of their future, are moving speedily toward unification. This is creating a new Europe, and Bush and Gorbachev will have to put their heads together and decide how to adjust. Michael Mandelbaum, director of the East-West project of the private Council on Foreign Relations, has suggested the two leaders use the summit to begin plotting ``a new European security order.'' He calls the task far more important than arms control. Bush is not about to jettison the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But he has to look into a future Europe anchored by an immensely powerful Germany and lacking the stabilizing standoff of two military alliances. What is going on in Germany is upsetting the old balance of power between NATO and the Warsaw Pact. It is forcing Bush and Gorbachev to come up with a new formula. NATO's days may be numbered, the Warsaw Pact's surely are. Officials of the two superpowers have had some preliminary discussions about fitting Germany into a new structure. The talks were held ithout the fireworks that marked deliberations in the fast-fading Cold War era. Gorbachev is not trying to hold on to East Germany, once the Soviets' most reliable ally. The future of the 360,000 Soviet troops there is uncertain, while the Soviet leader is likely to comply with requests by Hungary and Czechoslovakia to remove all traces of the Red Army by next year. Poland is making noises along the same line. So there is no reason for Bush to play the heavy, to poke a finger in Gorbachev's eye. The president insists that the new Germany be in NATO. And yet, he also is aware of the anxieties that causes the Soviets, who are losing their East European buffer and have stark memories of World War II, to oppose such an affiliation. Within the Soviet Union, meanwhile, the diverse nationalities are threatening to go their separate ways. That weakens Moscow but also raises a danger of ethnic strife and instability. Like German unification, these events are outpacing the ability of the two superpowers to take charge of history. Bush and Gorbachev, working together, would have a better chance of keeping up. The pressure on Gorbachev, of course, is far more severe than the strains on Bush, although the president must keep a wary eye on the drive toward unification in Western Europe and the economic colossus challenging the United States that could result. The West Germans, seeking Soviet blessing for unification, may be ready to buy that approval with economic assistance. Bush so far has promised Moscow almost nothing. Feeling the heat of congressional conservatives, who are worked up over Gorbachev's treatment of the Baltics, Bush is reluctant to assist perestroika. He has ruled out lowering tariff barriers until final passage of a new Soviet law establishing the right to emigrate. The Soviet parliament was supposed to finish work on the law next Thursday, as the summit opened. Now the calendar is slipping, and Bush will not recommend lower tariffs to Congress unless the law is on the books. Bush also may delay signing a new trade deal with the Soviets even though negotiators reached broad agreement late last month in Paris. Again, conservatives are pressuring the White House to retaliate against Gorbachev's moves to blunt independence drives in Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. Hard-liners like former Pentagon official Richard Perle are urging Bush to take advantage of Gorbachev's troubles to force completion of a treaty to withdraw tens of thousands of Soviet troops and tanks from Eastern and Central Europe. Bush apparently will not heed the advice. The president and Secretary of State James A. Baker III want to improve the U.S.-Soviet relationship even with the slowdown in the arms talks and the squeeze on Lithuania. Bush will observe the tradition of past arms control summits by joining Gorbachev in the declaration to cut U.S. and Soviet nuclear bombers, missiles and submarines. But the president also will take a look down the uncertain road of Europe with the Soviet leader and may begin the transition to a new and more peaceful relationship.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid will be covering his 10th summit for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Visiting Malta for First Time
By VICTOR L. SIMPSON
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II left today for a three-day visit to Malta, the first papal visit to the Mediterranean island. Although Malta has a long Christian tradition, a papal visit would have been unthinkable under the previous socialist government. John Paul's 48th foreign tour as pope takes him to a republic of 350,000 people, nearly 99 percent Catholic, where abortion is banned and divorce is not allowed. Malta, the site of the U.S.-Soviet summit in December, planned joyous celebrations. Hundreds of Maltese working outside the country have returned this week to join the festivities. John Paul will tour both Malta and Gozo, the second largest island in the archipelago and deliver about a dozen speeches. The first Christian community on Malta is said to date to the year 60, when St. Paul was shipwrecked on the island. The island was home to the Knights of Malta, mobilized in the 16th century to defend Christian Europe from the Ottoman Turks. Church-state relations soured during the long period of socialist rule from 1971 to 1987. Some of the bitterness stemmed from the church's treatment of socialist officials and supporters in the 1960s. The church-state crisis reached a head in 1984 when then-Prime Minister Dom Mintoff's government decreed private schools, including Catholic ones, could no longer charge tuition. But relations between the Nationalist government of Prime Minster Eddie Fenech Adami, a regular churchgoer, and the Cathoic hierarchy, are described as excellent. Maltese President Vincent Tabone paid a state visit to the Vatican in December. John Paul's visit will be a fitting start to the annual series of village parties in honor of patron saints. Malta boasts 313 churches, and its main monument, the 16th century St. John's Cathedral, was restored for the occasion.

DOC.HEAD: Audit Says American Food Aid May Have Been Misused In India
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD more background and comment from charity official.
DOC.TEXT: An audit of U.S. aid to Roman Catholic charities in India says bishops, priests and nuns misused millions of dollars, and the U.S. Embassy said today that an investigation is under way. The audit by the U.S. accounting firm Price Waterhouse said officials in India's Roman Catholic Church, which receives $25 million in U.S. food annually, drew up bogus lists of food recipients and used donations to run businesses. Clergy also purposely exaggerated the amount of aid they distributed and filed false reports to hide the abuses, the audit said. The audit was ordered by the Inspector General's office of the U.S. Agency for International Development and focused on Catholic Relief Services, a Baltimore-based charity, which gives food to 4,600 groups that distribute the food to the needy, mostly children and pregnant women. Most of the organizations are Roman Catholic, although Hindu, Moslem and non-religious groups participate. They include the Missionaries of Charity run by Nobel Peace Prize winner Mother Teresa. James DeHarpporte, head of Catholic Relief Services' operations in India, said the audit was ``unfair and highly exaggerated the extent of our problems.'' But he acknowledged the organization was undergoing a management shake-up. The U.S. Embassy said today that the Central Bureau of Investigation, India's version of the FBI, and the investigative wing of the U.S. Agency for International Development are looking into the reported abuses. News of the audit came first in today's Washington Post. Details subsequently were provided by auditors and a U.S. official in New Delhi. Tridibes Basu, a partner at Price Waterhouse in the Indian capital, said the audit does not accuse Roman Catholic clergy with theft but the report says the relief program ``was operated in an atmosphere whereby the commodities could be misused with little risk of detection.'' But some officials said they believed the report showed substantial evidence of widespread corruption and theft of the free American food. ``Quantities of food stored in warehouses did not tally with written records of food delivered to and distributed from these warehouses,'' a U.S. official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Proper quantities of food were not distributed to beneficiaries and distribution of food was done irregularly or not at all at some sites.'' The audit estimated that records for food distribution and actual food distribution differed by about $4 million. The U.S. official said record-keeping was shoddy, food storage was poor and Catholic Relief Services' role in monitoring the aid had generally been ``deficient.'' He said that due to the audit, Catholic Relief Services had cut its operations in India, and that the U.S. Agency for International Development was reconsidering its aid to the organization. ``Future operations will depend on improvements in Catholic Relief Services management ability,'' the official said. DeHarpporte said his organization had slowed operations but he denied there were widespread abuses. He acknowledged that the charity had terminated its relationship with some organizations and was seeking repayment for lost or stolen food. In one case, 2,000 bags of food worth $20,000 disappeared from one warehouse. ``Not everybody's an angel, not everybody's a saint, but when we do find abuses we terminate our agreement,'' he said. The United States gives India about $100 million worth of food annually. Wheat, corn, soy beans, vegetable oil and milk comprise the bulk of the aid. The CARE charity gets most of the aid. The audit was completed in December 1989 and filed with the Inspector General's Office of the U.S. Agency for International Development in March, said Vali Nijhawan, senior manager of Price Waterhouse in New Delhi.

DOC.HEAD: Trinity Floodwaters Crest, Killer Gnats on the Rise
DOC.TEXT: An end to the worst flooding in decades was in sight today after the Trinity River crested at a record mark, but gnats spawned in floodwaters gathered in swarms lethal to animals, and some Arkansas farmers blamed water managers for crippling crop damage. The Trinity River reached 29.98 feet Thursday at Liberty, up slightly from 29.96 feet the day before. Flood stage on the river is 24 feet and the old record high-water mark was 29 feet in 1942. ``The water will be with us for a while, but we hope we've turned the tide,'' said Jim Mitchum, Liberty County emergency management coordinator. Barring another onslaught of heavy rains, officials said the river was unlikely to rise further. Upstream waters were receding and were expected to begin dropping at Liberty as early as today. About 100 miles to the north, clouds of blood-sucking turkey gnats rose from floodwaters to menace people, poultry and other animals. ``This is probably the worst infestation of the turkey gnat in East Texas since the 1930s or 1940s,'' said Dr. James Robinson, an entomologist for the Texas Agricultural Extension Service at Overton. ``We have confirmed reports of infestations in at least 14 counties, all joining or near major rivers or streams.'' Turkey gnats are members of the black fly family and are slightly larger than fruit flies. Robinson said the infestations could persist for six weeks. ``We have reports of more than 1,000 head of fowl dying as a result of turkey gnat infestations,'' said Gayle Finch, extension agent in Henderson County. ``Numerous people have called within the past two weeks reporting losses of chickens, ducks, geese, guineas and birds.'' The gnats also can inflict painful bites that raise itchy red welts on humans. ``Some people have gone to the doctor for treatment of bites. We are finding the bites to be worse than mosquito bites,'' said Denise Easterling, a veterinarian in Leon County. Flooding, an early killing freeze and high winds caused an estimated $235.67 million in losses to the state's farmers and ranchers, the Arkansas Farm Bureau said Thursday. The losses amount to 28 percent of their usual net income. Flood damage far outweighed other weather-caused problems, officials said. ``We had one farmer with about 2,000 acres, and he hadn't seen it since the first of May,'' said Frank Plafcan, staff director for the Jefferson County Extension Service. Farmers from Oklahoma and Arkansas who gathered for a meeting in Fort Smith, Ark., on Thursday with Army Corps of Engineers officials complained about perceived flood control shortcomings. The hearing was the third of five the Army engineers are holding to explain how they operate reservoirs. Some farmers said they received too little warning about impending floods and accused Army engineers of failing to lower reservoir levels in anticipation of possible floods. ``We're getting floods from controlled waters,'' Hartman farmer Richard Plugge said. Applause erupted when he said Army engineers focused on maintaining recreation water levels rather than flood control. James Proctor, Little Rock district reservoir control chief, said flooding would have occurred regardless of any action taken by water managers. ``We don't have infinite wisdom,'' said Col. Lee Smith of the corps' Tulsa District. Train service across the Trinity River and a nearly 100-year-old bridge was remained detoured as crews worked to stabilize a 300-foot trestle knocked askew by floodwaters. The bridge was built in 1904, with later construction in 1919. The river has come within 7 inches of railroad ties. Texas officials estimate that about 10,000 people statewide have been forced from their homes by storms and flooding that began late last month in northern Texas. Nearly $1 million for temporary housing has been given to families forced from their homes by the high water. Federal agencies have received requests for help from some 4,123 Texas families. No deaths or injuries have been blamed on the floods along the lower Trinity River. Thirteen deaths were blamed on storms and flooding in northern Texas. Elsewhere, Louisiana and Oklahoma officials said flooding there caused more than $20 million damage to farms. Parts of Indiana also suffered severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Precede UNDATED
Chinese Premier Welcomes Renewal of Favored Trade Status
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with Chinese reaction. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng today welcomed President Bush's decision to renew China's most-favored-nation trade status, saying it would help U.S-Chinese ties. At least two other Asian governments _ Hong Kong and Japan _ also praised the move, saying friendly ties were important despite Beijing's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators a year ago. Bush announced Thursday that he favors renewing the trade status for one year, entitling China to the lowest available tariffs on its exports. ``This is not only in the interests of China but in the interests of the United States, too,'' the official Xinhua News Agency quoted Li as telling visiting Japanese businessmen. Xinhua said Li ``noted that his government will, as always, make due efforts to restore and promote Sino-U.S. relations.'' U.S. congressional critics said they would try to overturn the decision in order to protest China's killing of pro-democracy demonstrators last year. China maintains that its treatment of dissidents is an internal matter. China had made it clear that downgrading its trade status would have hurt political and cultural ties with the United States as well as cause a sharp drop in trade. U.S.-Chinese relations were already badly strained by conflict over last year's killings. Xinhua, in its report on Bush's decision, claimed that only a small number of Americans supported ending the favored trade status ``under the pretext of so-called human rights.'' Other official Chinese media argued before Bush's announcement that American consumers, rather than Chinese manufacturers, would be hurt most by canceling the favored status. China Daily said without cheap Chinese canvas shoes, ``some Americans would be unable to afford similar shoes manufactured in the United States.'' Last year, China exported about $12 billion worth of goods to the United States, mostly garments and toys. The United States sold China about $5.7 billion worth of goods, led by wheat, fertilizer and aviation equipment. Hong Kong's trade and industry secretary, John Chan, today said Bush's move was ``very good news from Hong Kong's point of view.'' In a statement, Chan noted the British colony's business community and government had engaged in intensive lobbying during the past few weeks to explain how termination of special trade status would harm Hong Kong, which will return to Chinese sovereignty in 1997. Much of the Chinese exports to the United States are produced in joint-venture factories set up by Hong Kong investors in southern China. The Japanese government today welcomed the Bush decision and said stable ties between Washington and Beijing are ``an indispensable factor for maintaining the peace and stability of Asia and the Pacific.'' Japan had urged Bush to resist pressure to punish China for last year's crackdown in which hundreds and perhaps thousands of students were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Madonna Cancels Concert Because of Throat Problem
DOC.TEXT: Madonna's Blond Ambition concert at Rosemont tonight has been canceled because the singer has a throat infection, the promoter said. Refunds will be offered for the concert, which was sold out, Jam Productions announced. Doctors who examined Madonna on Thursday had advised her to cancel her concerts both Thursday night and tonight. But she decided to perform Thursday night anyway.

DOC.HEAD: 91-Year-Old Woman Hurt in Scuffle over Met Game
DOC.TEXT: An 91-year-old nursing home resident balked when she was told she could not stay up to watch the end of a baseball game on TV that went into extra innings. As a result, she was injured and a nurse's aide who wanted her to turn off the Mets game was fired and charged with assault. The alleged assault took place April 17 when Elizabeth Gusette was watching a Mets-Cubs game on television at the A. Holly Peterson Geriatric Center in Uniondale on New York's Long Island, according to today's New York Post and New York Daily News. The 13-inning game started at 7:30 p.m. and lasted more than 4{ hours before Chicago downed New York, 8-6. Gusette claims that aide Jacqueline St. Jean, 46, told her it was time to go to sleep. But Gusette cried foul. She wanted to continue watching the Mets _ ``I just love the game,'' she said _ and the two got into a scuffle. St. Jean allegedly grabbed the elderly woman by the hands and arms. When the fight was over, the TV was off and Gusette's wrist was bloodied. St. Jean was fired because of the incident, and Thursday she was charged with assault. As for the Mets, one game under .500 and in fourth place in the National League East, all Gusette would say is she's ``not impressed.''

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Gets Boost in Campaign for Russian President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to ADD background on Russian republic; clarify reference to Soviet government. Moves up graf on Gorbachev's recent attack on Yeltsin's platform. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `Gorbachev holds...'
DOC.TEXT: The candidate backed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev for president of the Russian republic withdrew from the race today, strengthening the campaign of Boris N. Yeltsin, the populist who has repeatedly clashed with Gorbachev. The state news agency Tass reported the withrawal of Russian Premier Aleksandr V. Vlasov but did not give a reason. It said Vlasov's pullout had been announced at the Congress of the Russian Federation, which will elect the president, a newly created post in the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. On Wednesday, Gorbachev attacked Yeltsin's platform, accusing him of calling for the ``breakup of the Soviet Union.'' The Russian republic contains Moscow and encompasses 11 time zones, from the Baltic to the Pacific. The Russian language predominates in the Soviet Union, and much of the nation's wealth, including vast natural resources, is concentrated in the republic. In addition to Yeltsin, two other men remained in the race _ Ivan Polozkov and Vladimir Morokin _ but from the start the campaign had appeared to be a contest between Yeltsin and Vlasov. A vote was possible later in the day. Prior to Vlasov's announcement, Yeltsin delivered a well-received speech pledging that if elected, he would defend the republic from meddling by the national Soviet government, but refrain from clashing with Gorbachev. Gorbachev holds the posts of president of the Soviet Union and general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, the two most powerful jobs in the Soviet Union. ``I am for businesslike relations, dialogue and negotiations with the president and the government, but on the principle that Russia's sovereignty is not damaged,'' Yeltsin told the Russian Congress. His bass voice booming through the hall of the Great Kremlin Palace, Yeltsin pressed a radical platform for bringing the Russian republic ``out of crisis.'' He presented a point-by-point program on how he would fight for Russian's sovereignty, unleash market forces, increase housing and flood stores with consumer goods. He blasted the government program for a transition to a market economy presented by Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov on Thursday, saying it had ``already created panic in the stores today.'' Instead, he backed an alternative program involving sale of government property, more liberal laws on ownership and foreign loans to make the transition without ``everything falling on the shoulders of the people.'' Yeltsin already is a member of the Congress of People's Deputies, which is the national parliament; the Russian Congress of People's Deputies, the Russian republic's parliament; and the Communist Party Central Committee. During a question-and-answer session, he was asked several times about his relations with Gorbachev, who entered the hall halfway through the speech. Yeltsin, formerly Gorbachev's protege, has become an opponent in the last two years, blaming the Soviet president for ``halfway reforms.'' But Yeltsin said their personal relationship would not influence their interaction as presidents. ``If there was or is something personal, I'll set it aside,'' he said. Yeltsin left the podium to prolonged applause, and was followed by Ivan Polozkov, a Communist Party chief from Krasnodar who is now considered Yeltsin's main rival. Russia is the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, with just more than half the country's population and two-thirds of its territory.

DOC.HEAD: UN Scientists Warn Global Warming Has Begun
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf pvs, `A number...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with new quotes from environmentalists. Pickup 7th graf, `The United...'
DOC.TEXT: United Nations scientists today warned that global warming has begun, temperatures will rise in the next century faster than in the last 10,000 years and that urgent measures are needed to curb ``greenhouse'' gases. In addition, a separate report warns that warming poses serious threats to the planet, including rising sea levels, the spread of disease and mass starvation in poor countries. The world temperature is likely to increase about 1.8 degrees in the next 35 years and 5.4 degrees before the end of the next century, said a report released by a working group of the U.N.'s Intergovernment Panel on Climate Change. Sea levels were predicted to rise by 2.3 inches each decade, or 8 inches by 2030, and 25.5 inches by the end of the next century. These conclusions represent something of an international consensus on the scientific certainty of global warming. ``It's the biggest international research drive into global warming ever conducted. It's authoritative and objective, it was set up by the United Nations General Assembly and staffed by first-rank scientists from around the world,'' said Greenpeace spokesman Steve Elsworth. Dan Lashoff, an observer at the meeting from the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington, said the report will bring increased pressure on the United States to take action. ``The White House must take this report seriously. ... The White House will no longer be able to pick its favorite scientific skeptics as an excuse for not reducing U.S. emissions,'' Lashoff said. President Bush has called for more study on global warming. The United Nations established three working groups which together called on the expertise of about 1,000 scientists around the world. Global warming is the process by which greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide and chlorofluorocarbons, collect on the outer edges of the Earth's atmosphere and trap heat within. The release of the report by the respected U.N. panel of scientists could move the international agenda from discussions of whether global warming exists to plans for how to deal with it. Shortly after the report's release, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher urged a ``giant international effort'' to deal with the threat and committed Britain to a 30 percent reduction in carbon dioxide emissions by the year 2005. ``If the panel's predictions are broadly right then the world could become hotter than at any time in the last 100,000 years,'' she said in a speech at the opening of the Hadley Center for Climate Prediction and Research at the Meteorological Office in Bracknell. She said the problem cannot be dealt with by individual countries. ``We shall only be able to deal with the problem by a giant international effort in which we all cooperate,'' she said. In fixing the country's carbon dioxide target, the British government took a position between what environmentalists and scientists are asking and what the government feels is politically and practically possible. Many scientists want to reduce carbon dioxide emissions 20 percent worldwide by 2005, instead of simply stabilizing them. ``If the world followed the target Mrs. Thatcher has announced ... we will fail to control global warming. It is totally inadequate,'' said Andrew Dilworth, spokesman for Friends of the Earth. A preliminary report by a Soviet-led panel on the impact of climate change warned that global warming poses a serious threat to the planet. Parts of the report were published in Britain this week. Melting at the poles will cause seas to rise, coastlines to flood and vast migrations from coastal and drought-hit agricultural regions, the report predicted. Tropical diseases, such as malaria, would spread to higher latitudes, the report said. Agricultural regions, such as the corn belt in North America, could shift toward the poles by 125 to 185 miles for every degree of warming. Forests might move hundreds of miles toward the poles. Food production overall could be sustained, but agricultural costs worldwide would increase by 10 percent and poor countries with burgeoning populations would face mass starvation, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Fell to $26.4 Billion During First Quarter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES extraneous material after 5th graf, bgng, The disparity...; picks up 6th graf pvs, Analysts were ...
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit fell to $26.4 billion from January through March, the lowest quarterly imbalance in more than six years, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said the 8.2 percent improvement from a $28.7 billion fourth-quarter deficit resulted from a record level of U.S. sales abroad offsetting the highest volume of oil imports in more than 12 years. For the first quarter, U.S. exports rose 4.7 percent to an all-time high of $96.04 billion. Imports were also at a record level, based on a surge in oil demand, climbing 1.6 percent to $122.4 billion. The trade deficit is the difference between imports and exports. Today's report on merchandise trade as calculated on a balance-of-payments basis confirmed trends already noted in the department's monthly merchandise trade reports. They showed a first quarter deficit of $23.9 billion. The disparity in the two figures comes from the fact that today's report excludes military sales by the U.S. government and makes other minor adjustments to the monthly figures. Analysts were generally heartened by the new figures despite the surge in oil imports. They noted that U.S. export sales remain at strong levels. Since growth in exports has fueled a large portion of U.S. economic growth over the past three years, the continuation of this trend is seen as a promising sign for the future. The first-quarter deficit was the smallest since a $21.7 billion shortfall in the fourth quarter of 1983. Exports of machine tools, industrial supplies and consumer goods climbed 4 percent to a record $85.1 billion in the first quarter. More than one-half of this increase came from a boom in exports of civilian aircraft following the end of the Boeing strike. Farm exports were up 7 percent to $11 billion with increases recorded in overseas sales of wheat, vegetables, fruits and nuts. Corn exports were down, reflecting sharply lower shipments to the Soviet Union. Average prices of corn and cotton increased 2 percent while prices of other commodities changed little, the government said. Imports of petroleum were up 17 percent in the first quarter to $15.6 billion, with the average number of barrels imported daily climbing to 8.9 million, the highest level since the third quarter of 1977. The average price per barrel increased to $19.47, the highest since the first quarter of 1986, when the price per barrel was $17.65. America's deficits declined with several countries, including Japan, down $1.9 billion to $10.4 billion for the first quarter. The United States even posted a $400 million trading surplus with the countries of Western Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Unrest Prompts Evacuation of Foreign Women, Children from Oil Center
DOC.TEXT: A military plane began evacuating foreign women and children from the oil-production center of Port Gentil today after two days of riots and hostage-taking over the death of an opposition leader. The government created a panel to investigate the death of the opposition leader, Joseph Rendjambe, secretary-general of the Gabon Progress Party. Opponents accuse President Omar Bongo's government of being behind the killing. A government newspaper, L'Union, reported two deaths in the rioting, and hospital sources said 17 people were hurt. French troops today patrolled the streets of Port Gentil, which appeared calm this morning as soldiers escorted women and children, mostly French, to the airport to be flown to Libreville, the capital. Libreville also was quiet today. People returned to work, and there was no extraordinary police or military presence. Sources said two large aircraft were on the way to this West African nation from France to fly the evacuees on to Paris. The evacuation was voluntary. There are several thousand French citizens in Port Gentil, as well as a smaller number of Americans, Britons and others who work for oil companies based in the city, 100 miles south of Libreville. Port Gentil is ringed by a lagoon and is only accessible by air and boat. French diplomats in Libreville said up to 700 people were to be brought out today by air, women and children going first. Rioting in the port city last month led to a similar evacuation of foreign staff and dependents of the French Elf oil company, Royal Dutch Shell and British Gas. The French government sent reinforcements to its garrison in its former colony in central Africa after opposition supporters took a French diplomat hostage for several hours. Opposition party members then took 10 oil executives hostage in Port Gentil. They were released after French troops were sent to the scene and held talks with the dissidents. The government said in a statement it remained committed to replacing Bongo's one-party rule with democracy. On Monday, the constitution was amended to allow opposition parties to contest elections in September.

DOC.HEAD: `Somebody Killed My Parents,' Accused Killer Son Sobbed in Emergency Call
With PM-Mansion-Transcript
DOC.TEXT: Two brothers charged with the shotgun slayings of their affluent parents wailed hysterically in an emergency telephone call reporting the murders. The recording was made after the Aug. 20 slayings of multimillionaire entertainment executive Jose Menendez and wife, Kitty. It was released Thursday after news media attorneys obtained a court order requiring that it be made public. The emotional two-minute call appears to have been made by the slain couple's elder son, Lyle, 22, who has been charged with his brother, Erik, 19, in the murders. Prosecutors say greed was the motive. Superior Court Judge James Albracht ordered the audio tape release, along with a videotape documenting a police search of the home of the Menendez brothers' psychologist. But psychologist Jerome Oziel on Thursday won an emergency appellate court stay blocking release of the videotape. ``I believe that release of the search warrant videotape ... would be a complete violation of my family's constitutional right to privacy,'' Oziel said. ``It would serve no purpose whatsoever in clarifying any relevant issues in this case.'' The Court of Appeal asked for written argument on the matter by May 29. The brothers' defense counsel opposed the release of the audio tape but did not appeal it. It recorded dispatchers trying to calm down a sobbing, screaming man and determine what happened: ``Somebody killed my parents,'' were the first words choked out by the caller after a dispatcher asked repeatedly, ``What's the problem?'' When asked to repeat who the victims were, the caller said, ``My mom and dad.'' At least twice the caller yelled to Erik by name and a dispatcher, hearing the name, asked to speak with Erik. The second brother never took the phone but his cries could be heard in the background throughout the tape. At one point the caller sobbed, ``I came home and found them.'' The first call ended with a dispatcher saying that an ambulance was on the way. The tape also contained a brief call from the 911 dispatchers back to the house. A man answered ``Hello'' quickly, and then began sobbing. ``OK, I want you to come outside,'' the male dispatcher said. ``I've got to get my brother,'' came the reply. ``You tell your brother come out the front door. Everybody come outside,'' the dispatcher said. The brothers claim they discovered their parents' bodies when they returned home after a night out at a restaurant and the movies. Prosecutors contend the boys committed the murders to collect a $14 million inheritance. Jose Menendez was an executive with Live Entertainment Inc., a video distribution company. An autopsy report said the couple was killed in an upstairs den of their mansion by shotgun blasts at close range. Both large pellet and birdshot ammunition were used. Menendez was hit by five blasts. His wife was hit 10 times.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Faces Hearing on Motion to Dismiss Drug Charges
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 6 grafs new with poll results. Picks up 5th graf pvs, The government.
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors say Mayor Marion Barry is making unfounded claims of government misconduct and is not entitled to have the 14-count drug case against him dismissed. Barry was indicted on eight drug-related charges on Feb. 15. Six new charges, including one count of conspiracy and five counts of cocaine possession, were brought May 10. He is scheduled to go to trial June 4, and his lawyers have moved to dismiss the indictment on grounds the prosecution retaliated against him by bringing six new drug charges against him less than a month before his trial. A hearing on the dismissal motion and other requests by Barry was scheduled today before U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. Meanwhile, the Washington Post said today today a poll showed Barry has suffered no significant erosion in his political base since his arrest. He and Councilman John Ray were tied with 23 percent each of the 760 self-described Democrats polled by the newspaper about their preference for the Democratic mayoral nomination. The rest were split among four additional challengers. Barry has not officially announced whether he will seek a fourth term. The government is making a ``diligent effort'' to investigate criminal wrongdoing and is not retaliating against Barry's refusal to plead guilty to the original indictment, prosecutors said in court papers filed Thursday. No plea offers were extended by the government, they added. ``The charges set out in the original indictment did not reflect the full extent of the defendant's criminal conduct,'' said U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens. ``Nothing that has happened in this case even remotely supports the defendant's suggestion that the government acted with a retaliatory motive in seeking additional charges,'' Stephens added. Barry lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy said the government has refused to provide the names of the alleged co-conspirators in the new indictment. Mundy said there is a ``presumption of vindictiveness'' and that the government should be required to justify charging a conspiracy spanning five years less than a month before trial. Stephens said the timing of the new indictment was ``not unreasonable'' and that the government is not required to disclose the identity of unindicted co-conspirators or its witnesses. The U.S. attorney said he has filed the co-conspirators' names with the court, requesting that they be turned over to Barry without being publicly disclosed. The original indictment accuses Barry of three felony counts of lying to a federal grand jury about his alleged involvement with drugs and five counts of cocaine possession. One possession count stems from his Jan. 18 arrest in an FBI sting operation at the Vista Hotel, where officials said he was videotaped smoking crack cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: Summer Fun Can Be Dangerous, CDC Says
DOC.TEXT: Horseback riding, swimming and sunbathing add up to summer fun for millions, but government health researchers are warning that it's also the season for broken necks, drownings and skin cancer. The national Centers for Disease Control, in three reports Thursday, urged caution for people participating in those popular, but hazardous, outdoor activities. The CDC said horseback riders should wear helmets, sunbathers should protect their skin and swimmers should limit their alcohol intake, though researchers said they still are not certain about the relationship between drinking and drowning. ``The main issue here is people can be seriously injured riding a horse, and there is a safety mechanism and it is a helmet,'' said Dr. David Nelson, the CDC epidemiologist who wrote the report on horseback riding. About 30 million Americans ride horses each year, and the rate of serious injury per riding hours is higher than that for motorcyclists and car racers, the CDC report said. In 1987 and 1988, according to the CDC, horseback riding accounted for 92,763 injuries, of which 9.9 percent required hospitalization. Of those hospitalized, 42.2 percent had head or neck injuries. One study quoted by the CDC said fewer than 20 percent of those falling off a horse were wearing a helmet. ``Even when riders wear headgear, the headgear may be decorative or improperly secured, thereby providing limited or no protection,'' the CDC said. Nelson said several medical and trade organizations have endorsed the use of helmets by horseback riders, though it has not been as well publicized as efforts to get motorcyclists to wear headgear. A separate report released Thursday by the CDC was based on a study in Massachusetts that showed almost one-quarter of 221 people responding to a survey drank alcohol while participating in aquatic activities, including swimming and boating. Among the alcohol users, 29 percent reported having more than four drinks from two hours before the activity until the end of the outing, the CDC said. Though 25 percent to 50 percent of the annual 8,000 adolescent and adult drownings in the United States involve alcohol consumption, a researcher said the link between drinking and drowning is unclear. ``The prevalence of drinking when you're out in the water is really quite high. It's much higher than drinking and driving,'' said Dr. Jonathan Howland of Boston University's School of Public Health. ``We can determine with some accuracy how many people who drown are drinking. But we need to know more about the behavior of people who drink and didn't drown,'' said Howland, who helped compile the report. With current information, however, Howland said there is no doubt that drinking contributes in general to injuries. Another CDC report said the New Jersey State Department of Health, in response to a study showing a high death rate for a type of skin cancer, is preparing a publicity campaign emphasizing the danger of excessive exposure to the sun. The CDC suggested that people avoid heavy exposure to the sun from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., wear hats and use a waterproof sunscreen. According to the New Jersey study, from 1979 to 1985 an average of 381 males and 324 females were diagnosed annually in the state with malignant melanoma. An average of 111 males and 79 females died each year from the cancer.

DOC.HEAD: Noted Sculptor Nina Winkel Dead at 85
DOC.TEXT: Noted sculptor Nina Winkel, who was in a coma for more than three months following a car accident, has died from her injuries. She was 85. Winkel lapsed into a coma on Jan 22, after the car her husband was driving skidded off a snow-covered highway near Plattsburgh in northern New York state and struck a guardrail. She died Thursday at Elizabethtown Community Hospital. Born in 1905 in Germany, she studied art there, but fled the Nazi regime in 1942 and settled in New York City. She received many accolades for her sculptures in the United States, including the National Sculpture Society's Medal of Honor and the Samuel F.B. Morse Medal. She moved to the Essex County town of Keene Valley about 30 years ago. Winkel held an honorary degree from the State University of New York. She is survived by her husband, George, a retired importer.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Military Jet Crashes into Homes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details, conflicting reports on casualties.
DOC.TEXT: A military jet crashed into a residential area in southern Georgia today, setting fire to at least two homes, authorities said. There were conflicting reports on casualties. Kathleen Guthrie, executive secretary at the Atkinson County Sheriff's Department, reported at least three deaths, but she later said she could not confirm any deaths. ``We heard the explosion; it was a helluva explosion. It knocked our power off,'' said Martha White, owner of the Country Kitchen Restaurant about 1{ miles from the crash site. ``It was very loud _ almost like a sonic boom,'' said David McDonald, assistant principal at Atkinson County High School, about half a mile from the site. ``It shook real hard.'' The plane from Moody Air Force Base near Valdosta crashed about 9:38 a.m. off U.S. 441, about two miles outside Pearson, said Angel Riggins, a dispatcher at the Atkinson County Sheriff's Department. ``There were about six houses involved. We know one completely burned, and a mobile home,'' but it was unknown whether anyone was inside the homes, she said. Authorities said four other houses were damaged. She added that she had no word on the fate of the pilot, the type of plane or whether other crew members were aboard. Moody officials declined to confirm that a plane from the base had crashed but said they were preparing an announcement. The Pearson Volunteer Fire Department sent both of its units to fight the fires, and departments from neighboring towns also were called in, said a Pearson police spokeswoman who asked not to be identified. Pearson, a town of about 2,000, is the county seat of rural Atkinson County. Moody Air Force Base is located about 40 miles away.

DOC.HEAD: Remains of U.S. Soldiers to be Released on Memorial Day
DOC.TEXT: North Korea said today that the remains of five U.S. servicemen killed in the Korean War will be released on Memorial Day. It will mark the first time remains have been handed over since 1954. Jong Ho, North Korea's deputy permanant representative at its U.N. mission, said, ``We are happy to settle this issue in a humanitarian way.'' ``We are sensitive to the feelings of the families concerned and to the appeals of veterans groups,'' he said. The remains were to be handed over to a U.S. congressional delegation in the truce village of Panmnujon. Ho said North Korea was prepared to follow up with discussions ``in the same spirit'' to return other remains. The North Korean envoy said one of the men whose remains were being handed over was believed to have been a pilot, but he said the U.S. side had asked that there be no public identification made for the time being. The move is an ``eloquent illustration'' of North Korea's willingness to ``settle pending issues with the U.S. government in a good way,'' Ho said. He said efforts to turn over the remains began in 1986, but were sidelined by the 1988 U.S. characterization of the North Korean government as a state sponsor of terrorism. North Korea denied the accusation. The agreement on the return of the remains was worked out late last year and this year by U.S.-North Korean contacts in New York and Washington.

DOC.HEAD: First Transplant Using Umbilical Cord Blood in U.S. Called Success
DOC.TEXT: The nation's first bone marrow transplant using umbilical cord blood from one sibling to start blood production in another was a success, hospital officials said. Officials at Children's Hospital Medical Center said Thursday that 6-year-old Eric Miller of McFarland, Wis., is making good progress since the April 17 transplant. In that operation, similar to an ordinary blood transfusion, Eric was given umbilical cord blood that had been frozen since the birth of his 6-month-old brother, Ethan. Doctors had waited until Ethan was 6 months old in case more blood was needed. If another transfusion had been necessary, they did not want to subject a newborn to the procedure. Matching blood characteristics is vital to a bone marrow transplant's success. Not all family members have compatible bone marrow, but siblings often are a good source, and umbilical cord blood is particularly rich in stem cells, from which the body forms marrow. Eric suffers from Fanconi's anemia, a rare inherited disorder that causes severe bone marrow failure. Hospital officials said Eric's operation was the first of its kind in North America, although two other operations of this type have been performed in France. At the time of the transplant, doctors said it would take several weeks to determine its success. Hospital spokeswoman Margaret Devereux said Thursday that the bone marrow has grown and reproduced in Eric. He was listed in good condition and was expected to be released from the hospital within two weeks, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Transport Chief Orders Philippines Boeing 737 Planes Grounded
DOC.TEXT: The air transport chief ordered Philippine Airlines on Friday to ground all its Boeing 737-300 jetliners, two weeks after an explosion and fire on a Boeing jet killed eight people. Oscar Alejandro, director of the Air Transport Office, said the seven 737-300 jets were being grounded so they can be inspected. On May 11, a Boeing 737 was preparing for takeoff from Manila when an explosion and fire ripped through the passenger section. Eight of the 119 people on board were killed, and 30 were injured. The cause of the blast has not been determined. Alejandro said U.S. experts will ship 26 electrical components of the damaged aircraft's fuel system to the United States to see whether a fault in the system could have caused the explosion.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Jolts Indonesia
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake jolted the eastern part of Indonesia on Friday, but there were no reports of casualties or damage, the meteorology office said. Siswoyo, a meteorology official, said the quake measured 6.3 on the Richter scale and was centered in the sea about 1,060 miles east of Jakarta. About the same time that earthquake hit, another was recorded in the western part of the country. The second quake measured 2.5 on the Richter scale and occurred in West Sumatra, Siswoyo said. He said the quake was centered in the Indian Ocean, about 625 miles northwest of Jakarta. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Kerosene Reported Missing From U.S. Embassy
DOC.TEXT: More than 65,529 gallons of kerosene have disappeared from a storage tank in the U.S. Embassy in Tokyo since January, police reported Friday. The Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department is investigating the missing kerosene, which it estimated to be worth $36,000. A spokesman at the embassy said the U.S. government was cooperating with police, but he would not offer further comment. Newspapers said police suspect embassy-related personnel might be involved in the theft because the kerosene likely would have been transported in large trucks.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Priest Sentenced to Prison on Molestation Charges
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic priest has been sentenced to six years in prison after pleading guilty to charges of molesting four altar boys. The Rev. Anton Mowat, who fled Georgia for his native Great Britain, eluded authorities there for 21 months until his arrest in January. He made no statement Thursday during a brief hearing before DeKalb County Superior Court Judge Curtis V. Tillman. Mowat, who was a visiting priest at Corpus Christi Catholic Church in Stone Mountain, will be deported when he is released from prison, one of several conditions included in his sentence. He also was sentenced to nine years on probation. Mowat, 47, is prohibited from entering the United States during his probation, cannot be alone with or reside with children, must enter a treatment program within 30 days of his release from prison and must report his progress to DeKalb probation officials within 90 days after entering a program. His status as a priest is up to the Roman Catholic bishop in Great Britain, a spokesman for the Atlanta Archdiocese said.

DOC.HEAD: Kurdish Guerrillas Claim Killing 15 Iranian Troops
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian Kurdish group said Friday its guerrillas killed 15 Iranian Revolutionary Guards in an ambush and attacked a university campus in northern Iran. Ghafour Hamzai, a spokesman for the Iraqi-backed Kurdish Democratic Party in Iran, said the guerrillas ambushed the guards May 16 in the village of Geli Douland in northern Iran, near the Iraqi border. He said two of the revolutionary guards killed were identified as commanders of the guards in the area. One Kurdish guerrilla was also killed in the attack, Hamzai said. He said the guerrillas attacked the College of Agriculture building at the University of Oroumieh on May 17 and set fire to its stores, destroying equipment. There was no Iranian comment on the guerrillas' claim. Kurdish guerrillas resumed fighting last month after the snows melted in the mainly mountainous area bordering Iraq, where they are taking refuge.

DOC.HEAD: Election Advice: Vote Early, Get Off The Streets
DOC.TEXT: Gonzalo Pereira plans to get to his polling station early for Sunday's presidential election _ the less time spent standing in line, the less chance of being killed by a bomb, he says. A lot of Colombians are saying the same thing as car bombs explode in major cities. Most are believed set by drug lords trying to sabotage the vote. At least eight bombs have exploded across the country in the past two weeks alone, killing 34 people. More than 200 people have died in attacks since the government declared war on drug traffickers in August. The latest fatal bombing was Thursday in Medellin, where five people died when a car bomb exploded. Another blast in the city Friday injured three people. ``I get nervous every time I walk by a parked car, thinking this could be the next one to blow up,'' said Pereira, an oil industry executive. Pereira said he figures that by showing up when polls open at 8 a.m., the line will be short and he can vote in perhaps 15 minutes. Most voting will take place at wooden sheds placed side by side along sidewalks and streets. It is difficult to have a conversation with a Colombian these days without the subject getting around to bombs and other terrorist acts. ``The violence is keeping people away from public areas and overwhelmingly reducing their activities. It might also keep people at home for the elections,'' Camilo Castellanos, a social scientist, told The Associated Press. A low voter turnout could wrest legitimacy from the winner. That may be exactly what the perpetrators of the violence are seeking in their campaigns to destabilize politics, officials say. The terrorism is overshadowing major election issues such as constitutional reform and negotiations with leftist rebels. Instead, staying clear of an indiscriminate terrorist attack is on the minds of most people. Restaurant business at night is off sharply, said an American who owns one of Bogota's biggest restaurants. People are scared of bombs, he said, refusing to be identified. Soldiers forced their way into dozens of houses a week ago in search of bombs. The army says it had learned of a drug traffickers' plan to pack a house with tons of dynamite and set it off. Cars entering parking lots at shopping centers and supermarkets are inspected for bombs. Schoolchildren are being taught to take cover under desks in case of a bomb. Army officers are giving speeches to neighborhood housing organizations on evacuation and disaster control. The army and police said they were mobilizing about 230,000 troops to ensure peaceful elections. Bogota is an armed camp. Military checkpoints line major streets and highways, and armored personnel carriers mounted with machine guns patrol the cities. Soldiers are everywhere. Security concerns have prevented many candidates from appearing in public, forcing them to conduct their campaigns through television and radio. Three of the main presidential candidates have been murdered during the campaign. ``These are the most tense and difficult elections in Colombian history,'' Antonio Navarro, the presidential candidate for the left-wing M-19 party, told reporters Wednesday.
