Navarro took over as M-19 candidate after his predecessor, Carlos Pizarro, was murdered in April by an assailant who shot him to death on a commercial jetliner over Bogota. The candidate who is expected to win the race, Cesar Gaviria, has sunk into a bunker mentality in the campaign. Gaviria, candidate for the ruling Liberal Party, has a security force of about 200 men. The current president, Virgilio Barco, is barred by the constitution from seeking a second consecutive term. According to the Bogota daily newspaper El Tiempo, Gaviria's office is a ``super-protected bunker'' with steel enforced doors and iron-clad windows designed to absorb dynamite blasts. He leaves the room only when absolutely necessary, the paper said. ``Being a presidential candidate is obviously a very risky business in Colombia,'' said Castellanos. The life-and-death issue dominates much of the campaigning. Alvaro Gomez, center-right candidate for the National Salvation Movement, woos voters with the slogan, ``To Live Again.''

DOC.HEAD: Train Jumps Tracks, Tanker Explodes; 750 Evacuated
DOC.TEXT: A freight train jumped the tracks and a tanker car carrying grain alcohol exploded, sending a fireball skyward and prompting the evacuation of 750 people because of fears toxic cargo might ignite. Fifteen of the train's 90 cars derailed late Thursday. Eight of those contained flammable ethyl alcohol, authorities said. Hazardous chemicals were being shipped in cars that did not derail, and fears they might catch fire forced the evacuation of all those living within three miles of the crash, said Cecil Whaley, of the state Emergency Management Agency in Nashville. ``We were very fortunate there were no injuries,'' Whaley said. ``We had good luck.'' Evacuees who spent the night at Red Cross shelters established at nearby schools began returning home by mid-morning. Train crew members were tested for drug or alcohol use, but results were not immediately available, said Illinois Central spokesman Tom Utroska. There were no reports from the scene that the crew was impaired, he said. Such freighters normally carry a crew of three, an engineer, brakeman and conductor. ``The cars that piled up were almost on top of each other,'' Whaley said. ``There was tremendous damage to the train bed itself.'' The Memphis-bound train originated in Fulton, Ky., Illinois Central officials said. It crashed south of Covington, about 40 miles northeast of Memphis. ``The sky was lit up with fire. It was awesome,'' said resident Denise Edmundson. State and federal railway authorities were examining the wreckage, seeking clues about what triggered the crash. The National Transportation Safety Board in Washington said an investigator was traveling from Chicago to join the investigation. Among those evacuated were 80 residents of a nearby nursing home. They were returned there this morning. Three train cars caught fire and were allowed to burn through the night. Beside its medical uses, ethyl alcohol can be used as a fuel and a chemical solvent. Whaley said there were 17 other cars carrying hazardous materials. The fire did not reach them, he said. ``It was touch and go at first because we were afraid vinyl chloride or the poisons could have been part of the fire,'' he said, referring to the other cars. ``It had us worried. It was scary.''

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Calls for U.N. Intervention in Occupied Lands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Israeli reaction, more Arafat quotes, details. Pickup 11th graf pvs, `The PLO chief...'
DOC.TEXT: PLO leader Yasser Arafat today accused Israel of waging a ``war of extermination'' and called on the United Nations to set up an international force to protect the Arab population in Israeli-occupied lands. In a 50-minute speech that opened the special session of the 15-member U.N. Security Council, the Palestine Liberation Organization chief also urged the creation of a separate United Nations observer team charged with helping end the 23-year-old Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israel, which has rejected the presence of United Nations observers in the territories, accused Arafat of using ``lies and distortions'' in his speech. Arafat, addressing the council for the first time, also urged a ban on all Israeli settlements in the occupied territories and the appointment of a permanent U.N. representative to deal with the Arab-Israeli strife. Clad in his customary uniform and headscarf and speaking in Arabic, Arafat did not give any details about either of the two U.N. teams he was requesting for deployment in the occupied territories. It was the first time the Security Council had met in Geneva. The gathering was moved from New York to avoid a showdown with the United States, which in the past has refused to give Arafat an entry visa. The PLO demand for safeguards for the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied territories followed a renewed outbreak of violence triggered by the slaying on Sunday of seven Palestinian laborers by an apparently deranged former Israeli soldier. Subsequent rioting left at least 15 Arabs dead, most by gunfire from Israeli troops, and more than 800 injured or wounded. Arafat denied that the killing of the Palestinian laborers was an isolated attack by a disturbed man. He said it was instead an outgrowth of Israel's ``illusions of defunct racial superiority'' and the ``stupid arrogance of military superiority.'' He demanded sanctions against Israel for refusing to comply with U.N. resolutions and what he said was a violation of the Geneva convention protecting civilians in time of war. ``The situation now requires urgent action in order to enforce reverence for international legitimacy, '' he said. During the Palestinian uprising, he said, ``the Israeli occupation forces have been waging a war of extermination on all fronts.'' He denounced ``terrorist and barbaric'' treatment of Palestinians and vowed the uprising would continue until the occupation ended. The PLO chief also urged immediate moves by the United Nations toward an international Middle East peace conference and said the PLO was prepared to deal ``flexibly'' with all international peace initiatives. Arafat's comments drew 45 seconds of applause from the Security Council members and 20 observers present. Before the session began, Israel's Deputy Foreign Minister Benyamin Netanyahu told reporters that Israel regards the gathering as ``an attempt to cynically exploit the solitary act of a crazed madman.'' A U.S. official, also speaking before the opening of today's session, said the American delegation would not speak at the meeting. ``There seems to be a consensus here that the recent outbreak of violence in the occupied territories in particular should cease as rapidly as one could bring it about,'' said the U.S. official, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Wednesday the United States was ready to discuss the idea of setting up a U.N. force in the occupied lands. But on Thursday, the State Department softened that somewhat. It said in a statement that Baker had in mind temporary visits by U.N. observers to ``check out'' the situation in the occupied territories, rather than a permanant force. No decision was likely to be made in Geneva, according to the chief U.N. spokesman, Francois Giuliani. He told reporters the Security Council would vote on the issue when delegates reconvene in New York, probably on Tuesday. Giuliani said the United Nations sent the United States a request on Arafat's behalf to allow him entry, but did not make a formal application. The Geneva session is open to all U.N. members who wish to speak on the issue. Giuliani said the session could continue until late tonight and possibly reconvene on Saturday. Arafat, who was also to meet with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, planned to leave Geneva on Friday afternoon. In December 1988, at a special U.N. General Assembly session in Geneva, Arafat renounced terrorism and recognized Israel's right to exist. That paved the way for a dialogue with the United States after a 13-year American refusal to deal with his Palestine Liberation Organization. To date, 720 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians since the Arab uprising began in December 1987 in the occupied territories. An additional 216 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have died.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed, Five Wounded in Rocket Attack
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of rockets bombarded residential areas of the Afghan capital Friday, killing three people and wounding five others, state-run radio reported. Kabul Radio, monitored in Islamabad, said ``Pakistan-based extremists'' fired 26 surface-to-surface missiles into the shell-shocked capital of Kabul, causing extensive damage. The radio uses the term ``extremists'' when referring to the Moslem guerrillas who have been trying for 12 years to overthrow the Soviet-backed government of Afghanistan. Hundreds of people have been killed in rocket attacks on the capital in recent years. The guerrillas, bankrolled by the United States, Saudi Arabia and other sympathetic Arab states, insist they target only military installations but admit they sometimes misfire and hit residential areas. Western diplomats in Pakistan said the guerrillas apparently stepped up their attacks on the capital to coincide with preparations for a Loya Jirga, or traditional grand council, which is expected to approve major changes in the constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Customs Men Block Main Road, Shots Fired in Air
DOC.TEXT: Customs agents went on strike Friday and blocked one of the city's main roads to demand better pay, and witnesses said some police fired into the air in apparent support of the strikers. This West African nation, once considered the economic miracle of black Africa, has been jolted by a wave of strikes and protests for more than two months. Soldiers, police, bus drivers, shipyard workers and others have struck. Each time, President Felix Houphouet-Boigny has met a delegation of the strikers and promised to improve their salaries and working conditions. The government has been unable to pay its foreign debt for two years and has had difficulty meeting government payrolls. It attributes the problem to sharply reduced earnings for exports, particularly cocoa. But critics say Houphouet-Boigny has wasted hundreds of millions of dollars on personal projects and indulged his top advisers with fancy homes and cars. The protests were triggered by an attempt to impose pay cuts and other austerity measures in March. The measures were withdrawn, but government employees, whose salaries have been frozen eight years, have kept up their pressure on the government. The protests forced the closure of the country's schools for the rest of this school year. Houphouet-Boigny also gave into demands to permit opposition parties. His Ivory Coast Democratic Party has ruled the nation as a de facto one-party state since independence from France in 1960.

DOC.HEAD: Winnie Mandela's Former Bodyguard Convicted of Murder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to CORRECT spelling of Stompie's name, CLARIFY judge said Mrs. Mandela home the day the beatings occurred, not necessarily when they occurred, ADDS more on conviction charges. Pickup 4th, `Mrs. Mandela....'
DOC.TEXT: A judge today convicted Winnie Mandela's former bodyguard of killing a black teen-age activist and said Mrs. Mandela was at home the day the kidnapped boy was brought there and beaten. Supreme Court Justice Brian O'Donovan convicted Jerry Richardson of murdering 14-year-old James Stompie Seipei Moeketsi on Jan. 1, 1989. He also was convicted of kidnapping and assault in cases involving Stompie and three other men who were abducted and beaten at Mrs. Mandela's home in Soweto township, according to testimony. In addition, Richardson was convicted of attempted murder in a case unrelated to the abductions. Mrs. Mandela, the wife of black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela and a prominent anti-apartheid activist herself, was not charged in the case, even though witnesses testified that she participated in the beatings. Mrs. Mandela has said she was not at her house when any assaults took place. Richardson once was Mrs. Mandela's chief bodyguard and the coach of the Mandela United soccer team, whose members also served as guards. His sentencing was postponed until Aug. 6 while he undergoes psychiatric examinations. If no extenuating circumstances are found, the death penalty is mandatory. However, President F.W. de Klerk suspended executions in February as part of his efforts to encourage negotiations between the white minority government and black organizations such as the African National Congress. Nelson Mandela is deputy president of the ANC. Three men testified during the 23-day trial that Richardson and other bodyguards kidnapped them and Stompie from a Methodist Church house in Soweto on Dec. 29, 1988. They said they were taken to Mrs. Mandela's home, and that she beat them and Stompie with her fists and a whip, then allowed her bodyguards to continue assaulting them. Eight other former bodyguards face trial on lesser charges. Mrs. Mandela did not testify at Richardson's trial, although his attorney asked her to do so. Mandela said Wednesday that the government was trying to ruin his wife's reputation by deliberately not charging her in a ``case which centers on her.'' However, he said he was not calling on the government to prosecute his wife. Mrs. Mandela has made no public statement on the case since last year, when leaders of major anti-apartheid organizations accused her of complicity in the abductions and assaults and called on the Soweto community to ostracize her. A few months later she reappeared on the stage at anti-apartheid rallies, however, and she has accompanied her husband at most public engagements since he was freed Feb. 11 after serving 27 years in prison. Mrs. Mandela has denied committing any crime but said the abductions were justified. She claimed that a Methodist priest was engaging in homosexual activity with men at the church house. The church investigated and cleared the priest of the allegations. Justice O' Donovan ruled that most of the assaults occurred on Dec. 29, 1989. ``I find that Mrs. Mandela was present on the 29th ... for at least part of the time,'' he said. He made no further comment on Mrs. Mandela's involvement.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Spending Continues Rise, Dampening Recession Fears
DOC.TEXT: Consumer spending posted a moderate 0.6 percent gain in April, the government said Friday in a report that analysts said was another sign the sluggish economy will avoid a recession. The Commerce Department said consumer spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.68 trillion. That followed 0.5 percent increases in both February and March and was the largest gain since it jumped 1.2 percent in January. ``Consumers are willing to spend on goods and services if given a bargain,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a New York government securities dealer. ``Even though spending is selective and moderate, it is holding up well and is likely to keep the economy out of a recession this year,'' Jones said. Consumer spending is considered a barometer of economic health since it accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. But the department said personal income increased only half as fast as spending, for a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.69 trillion. That was the lowest increase since last September's 0.2 percent and it followed 8 percent annual rate gains during each of the three previous months. As a result, Americans' savings rate _ savings as a percent of disposable income _ slipped from 5.8 percent in March to 5.5 percent in April. The rate had been 5.5 percent in February, up from 5.3 percent in January. Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI@McGraw-Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting organization, said recent spending levels are not sustainable without matching levels of income growth. ``I don't think consumers on their own will push the economy into a recession,'' she said. ``So while spending will slow, it is not likely to turn negative.'' Personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, rose $21.9 billion, up from March's $19.4 billion increase. Purchases of durable goods _ products expected to last at least three years _ rebounded $3.8 billion from a $3.2 billion drop in March. Ms. Latta said much of the gain was in automobile sales. Purchases of non-durable goods also bounced back, gaining $1.3 billion after falling $400 million the previous month. Services gained $16.8 billion on top of a $23 billion rise in March. The department said both the April and March increases in personal income were affected by farm subsidy payments. Excluding subsidies, personal incomes rose 0.5 percent in both months. The report said Americans' income after taxes slowed to a 0.2 percent increase from a 0.8 percent gain in March and a 0.7 percent jump in February. It had risen 0.9 percent in both December and January. The key component of the income category _ wages and salaries _ rose $19.1 billion at an annual rate after a $15.4 billion gain in March.

DOC.HEAD: Countdown Preparations Proceeding Normally For Shuttle Columbia
DOC.TEXT: Countdown preparations continued without incident Friday for space shuttle Columbia, which is scheduled to lift off next week on an astronomy mission with seven astronauts. Launch is scheduled for 12:38 a.m. EDT Wednesday. The countdown begins early Sunday morning. ``Everything's moving right along, no problems,'' said Lisa Malone, spokeswoman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Technicians on Friday were making the final connections to explosive devices on the shuttle's external tank, solid rocket boosters and ground support equipment. Columbia's payload is a $150 million observatory called Astro, which is composed of four telescopes that will probe ultraviolet light and X-rays during the nine- to 10-day mission. Film was loaded into Astro's Ultraviolet Imaging Telescope on Thursday, said NASA program scientist Ed Weiler. The film will be developed after the mission and provide wide-angle views of the sky. Columbia's payload bay doors will be closed after Astro's Broad Band X-Ray Telescope is restocked with argon, a coolant, late Saturday. Columbia's crew is scheduled to arrive at Kennedy Space Center on Sunday. Four are astronomers who will operate the observatory.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Leader Says He Would Resign, Hold Elections to End Unrest
DOC.TEXT: President Samuel Doe said Friday he is ready to step down or hold early elections under international supervision to help end a northern-based rebellion in which hundreds of Liberians have been killed. Doe made the offer at a pro-government rally the day after his forces announced their first victory against rebels: the recapture of the strategic Atlantic port of Buchanan in southeastern Liberia. The rebel National Patriotic Front of Charles Taylor did not respond immediately to Doe's offer. The two men have refused to hold direct negotiations, as the United States has suggested. It was not possible to confirm the government's claim its forces had recaptured Buchanan. Diplomats said they were receiving conflicting reports on who held Buchanan, Liberia's main port, which rebels took Sunday. Telephone lines to the city were down. Doe told the rally he did not want to remain president if it meant Liberians had to suffer and die. ``I can go into private life while continuing my education at the university here,'' he said. ``No! No! We want Doe!'' supporters shouted in response. The rally began with a march through the streets of Monrovia. Demonstrators carried placards denouncing Burkina Faso, Ivory Coast and Libya for allegedly supporting the rebels. ``Gadhafi Kills Peace,'' said one of the banners. ``Ivory Coast, unfriendly neighbor. Burkina Faso, unfriendly country.'' Doe also said that, if Liberians wished it, he would invite international observers and an independent electoral commission to supervise early elections. But the rallying group shouted that it would be interference in the West African nation's internal affairs. Internal and exiled opposition parties have said their experience at previous polls _ which observers said were rigged _ left them with no confidence in elections due to be held next year. Doe did not say when he might hold earlier elections. At a news conference Friday, Deputy Information Minister Moses Washington said 350 rebels were killed in a government ambush as they tried to infiltrate past Gbarnga, a garrisoned town 107 miles northeast of Monrovia. Washington said government forces retook Buchanan after moving in slowly to minimize civilian casualities. He gave no figures on deaths in the Buchanan fighting, saying only that troops were pursuing rebel commander Moses Duopu, a former Liberian Cabinet minister, who led forces in the port. This appeared to contradict reports that Duopu had broken with Taylor, another former Doe aide, and was commanding a separate rebel force in northern Liberia. Forces loyal to Doe had mostly avoided contact with the rebels who invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. Many soldiers fled to neighboring Guinea when the insurgents attacked. The rebels controlled Nimba County, where the invasion began, and most of two other counties. Doe took power in a bloody 1980 coup that ended domination by freed American slaves who founded Liberia in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: You've heard of Air Jordan? What about Air Abdul? Paula Abdul, following in the footsteps of Michael Jordan, Michael Jackson and others, will have her own line of athletic shoes. L.A. Gear, which also has Jackson and Joe Montana under contract, announced Thursday the signing of its latest celebrity shoe salesman. Miss Abdul, a Laker cheerleader-turned-video choreographer-turned pop star, used to pitch Reeboks, which is now negotiating with Madonna. The endorsement continues a trend by manufacturers who are increasingly betting on star power to sell athletic shoes. Nike started the shoe wars with Michael Jordan and Air Jordan. Like Jackson and Montana, Miss Abdul, 27, will get a whole line of shoes bearing her name. A line of sportswear under her name also is planned, with shoes and garments to appear in stores next spring. She'll get a commission based on sales as well as cash, a person familiar with the deal said. The deal will yield less than $10 million, in the second tier as such fees go, the source said on condition of anonymity.

Oops! Dan did it again. Vice President Dan Quayle told 3,000 high school students Thursday that he was proud to be the first vice president to visit Wausau since Vice President Calvin Coolidge did so in 1928. Wrong, Dan. Coolidge was president in 1928. Tom Fischer, principal at Wausau West High School, where Quayle spoke, said he expected few students even noticed the mistake. ``What the teachers and kids realize is here is a guy who is on the road constantly, giving speech after speech and under public scrutiny, so those things happen,'' Fischer said. ``He probably misread a card.'' Mostlhy, Fischer said, the visit went well. ``He was very personable to everybody,'' he said. ``He went out of his way to shake hands and talk to the kids and he was just very warm to everyone.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Surprise: Sportscaster Brent Musburger agrees with the critics who wish he'd shut up once in a while. ``When I'm watching tapes of a game I did, there are many times when I get tired of the sound of my own voice,'' Musburger says in an interview in the June 1 issue of Entertainment Weekly. ``I turn the sound off or just shut the damn thing off and walk away.'' Musburger, for years the sports anchor at CBS, was fired by the network the day before he announced the NCAA college basketball final, his final event at CBS. He signed a month later with ABC, for whom his first assignment will be the Little League World Series. ``I don't care what you put me on,'' he says in the interview. ``I've done more schlock sports than anybody. I've done the Human Fly, a guy walking on airplanes.'' Musburger also acknowledges that he may over-hype events that he covers. ``If I'm not going to be enthusiastic about it, who's going to be?'' he asks. ``It would be virtually impossible for someone who shares the responsibility for making an event a success to be a pure journalist.''

Gloria Estefan of Miami Sound Machine received the crossover artist of the year award in the second annual Latin music awards. The male artists of the year were Luis Enrique, tropical-salsa; Chayanne, pop-ballad; and Vicente Fernandez, Mexican regional. Ana Gabriel won the female artist of the year award, only presented in the pop-ballad category. Her ``Tierra de Nadie'' was the pop-ballad album of the year. In a new category, singer Celia Cruz was given a lifetime achievement award Thursday night. The award program was created last year by the Spanish-language television network Univision and Billboard magazine to recognize excellence in the Latin music industry. Awards were given in special categories, plus pop-ballad, tropical-salsa and Mexican regional. Record retailers and radio program directors from Spanish-language radio stations throughout the U.S. and in Puerto Rico voted on the awards.

Madonna has a throat infection and had to cancel her sold-out Friday night concert at Rosement, the promoter said. The singer, who currently has the No. 1 single with ``Vogue,'' had performed Thursday night against the advice of doctors. Refunds will be offered for the concert, part of Madonna's ``Blond Ambition'' tour, Jam Productions announced.

Reba McEntire says sixth-graders should choose their heroes carefully _ and set an example for their younger peers. ``Be careful who your role models are. Pick the good ones,'' the county singer told the 1990 graduting class of Eakin Elementary School on Wednesday. ``It doesn't hurt to start thinking or dreaming now. Not only will you learn things in the classroom, but you learn things from people from other states and other countries,'' she told the 72-member class. McEntire said that when she was a youngster her idols were just a few years older. ``Kids in the first grade will be looking up to you, so watch what you say or do,'' said McEntire, who had her first child in February. McEntire is best known for her hits ``Whoever's in New England'' and ``Cathy's Clown.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Calls Lithuanian Leaders `Adventurists'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs with Gorbachev comments from news conference, EDITS thereafter to CONFORM, tighten; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today branded the leaders of secessionist Lithuania ``adventurists'' and called on them to rescind their March 11 declaration of independence. ``We have great reserves of willpower, but we are looking for ways'' to end the impasse, Gorbachev said at a news conference with visiting French President Francois Mitterrand. He repeated an earlier appeal to the Lithuanians to back away from their independence declaration and follow a new Soviet law that requires a referendum for any of the 15 republics to secede. ``Let's return to March 10 and start the constitutional process,'' he said at the news conference, which was broadcast live on Soviet television. Gorbachev, half-joking, said the Lithuanians had decided ``not to make a gift to President Gorbachev on the eve of his visit to the United States,'' where he is to meet with President Bush next week. He also justified the use of army troops to occupy Communist Party buildings in Lithuania in March and economic sanctions that included cutting off oil and natural gas shipments. ``What happened in Lithuania was that a group of adventurists is speculating on such issues as independence,'' he said. ``I can say that in a similar situation, the American president would put the situation under control in 24 hours.'' Gorbachev also has decreed that the other two Baltic states, Latvia and Estonia, violated Soviet law by taking more moderate steps toward independence. Leaders of the three republics, all forcibly annexed in 1940, say they are willing to compromise but will not surrender their goal of seceding from the Soviet Union. Gorbachev has refused to negotiate with Lithuania unless it suspends the independence declaration. He told four Lithuanian legislators on Thursday that if they agreed to suspend the declaration and follow Moscow's procedures for secession, Lithuania could gain independence in as little as two years, said one of the legislators, Vaidotas Antanaitis. As a result of Kremlin sanctions against Lithuania, numerous factories across the republic have been forced to shut down, throwing an estimated 19,000 people out of work. Lithuanian officials said that central hot water supplies were shut off throughout the republic today because regional distribution stations had run out of oil. In the Latvian capital of Riga, legislative today leaders rejected Gorbachev's May 14 order voiding their declaration of independence, a spokesman said. Ivars Embrekts, a spokeseman for the presidium _ or executive council _ of Latvia's Supreme Council, said the body sent Gorbachev a telegram that said: ``The constitution of the U.S.S.R. does not give the president of the U.S.S.R. the right to repeal laws or decisions which have been taken by the Supreme Council of the Republic of Latvia.'' It said the dispute should be resolved in negotiations. In Tallinn, centrist and radical deputies clashed today over what role the new Estonian Congress, elected by ethnic Estonians, should have in relation to the republic's traditional Supreme Soviet. In Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, a spokesman for Lithuania's Supreme Council said that legislature's executive council met behind closed doors to hear a report on Thursday's talks in Moscow between Gorbachev and the four Lithuanian lawmakers. But another spokesman, Aidas Palubinskas, said later the issue did not come up today. Antanaitis, speaking in a telephone interview, said that at Thursday's meeting Gorbachev also threatened to impose presidential rule on Lithuania unless it suspends its declaration of independence. ``On the one hand, there were concessions, but also threats that if you continue taking action on your own, we'll take such measures,'' Antanaitis said of Gorbachev's statements. The New York Times today quoted other participants in the meeting as saying that Gorbachev acknowledged there was pressure on him to impose presidential rule, but he said he did not see that as a reasonable act in this case. Presidential rule would be a major escalation in the test of wills between the Kremlin and the republic of 3.8 million people. Under such rule, Lithuania's parliament and government could be replaced with officials appointed by Moscow. Ethnic Russian residents of Lithuania who oppose independence, as well as some Soviet politicians, have pressed Gorbachev for weeks to impose presidential rule. But he said on April 10 that such a step would be extreme and used only in a civil conflict.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Presidents of Nicaragua, Panama
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush called the presidents of Nicaragua and Panama today to tell them $720 million in U.S. help will soon be on its way after Congress finally approved his emergency aid package for the hemisphere's two newest democracies. Bush ``will sign the aid bill as soon as he receives it,'' deputy White House press secretary Stephen Hart said. That could come later today or Saturday, he added. The White House announced as Bush arrived here for a Memorial Day weekend vacation that he had telephoned both Nicaraguan President Violeta Chamorro and Panamanian President Guillermo Endara to inform them that Congress had finally passed the emergency aid early today. The two Latin leaders ``expressed their gratitude for the congressional action and thanked (Bush) for his efforts on behalf of their countries,'' Hart said in a statement. ``They stated that this is a major step forward in solidifying and supporting the growth of democracy in Panama and Nicaragua,'' said Hart. Congress gave final approval to the $420 million for Panama and $300 million for Nicaragua as the lawmakers rushed to adjourn for their own holiday weekend recess. Bush had asked for $800 million in early March. The lawmakers whittled that down, and padded the bill with $4 in hometown spending for every dollar of Latin aid. When finally sent to Bush on a 308-108 House vote, the measure had swelled to more than $4 billion. It included programs that ranged from filling in a collapsed utility tunnel on a street in Salisbury, N.C., to giving the Samoan islands a $750,000 ferry boat. Chamorro is seeking to revive Nicaragua's government after 11 years of Sandinista rule, while Panama is still recovering from U.S. trade sanctions and last December's invasion. It also included other foreign assistance: $75 million to meet refugee needs around the world, $45 million in anti-narcotics aid to Bolivia and Peru, $30 million for aid to Caribbean countries and $30 million for Africa. But overshadowing those amounts was several billion dollars in domestic programs, such as the $1.2 billion needed to make up a shortfall in food stamp funds for the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30; $545 million for veterans benefits; $166 million for Head Start; and $432 million for fighting forest fires. In what amounts to the first application of a ``peace dividend'' from reduced East-West tensions, roughly half of the new spending is being financed by cuts in this year's proposed Pentagon budget _ cuts agreed to by the administration. The measure includes $110 million to help the Census Bureau finish its lagging 1990 head count and $216 million for disaster aid, primarily for southern states affected by flooding and hurricanes. Most of that was wanted both by lawmakers and by the White House. But there were many other items that could make Bush hold his nose when he signs the measure, most pet projects of individual members of Congress. Among the items approved were nearly 40 individual grants through the Department of Housing and Urban Development totaling $28 million, most of them for communities whose members of Congress are on the House and Senate Appropriations committees. On the list was $400,000 to fill in a collapsed utility tunnel in Salisbury, N.C., sought by Rep. Bill Hefner, D-N.C., and $990,000 to fix up a waterfront park in Bay City, Mich., in the district of Democratic Rep. Bob Traxler. Rep. Robert Walker, R-Pa., complained that the pork-barrel allocation process was no different than the political favoritism that led to the HUD scandal Congress is now investigating. ``If it's corrupt at HUD, it's corrupt here,'' Walker said. A $6 million provision sought by Rep. Neal Smith, D-Iowa, would buy land near Des Moines, Iowa, from a power company and turn it into a wildlife refuge. Smith argued on the House floor that the purchase was ``an unusual and unexpected opportunity.'' Republicans complained the provision was a special-interest item and noted that it was opposed by the Fish and Wildlife Service. But the Democratic-controlled House voted 246-160 to leave the provision in. Among other additions were: _Transfer of a $750,000 ship from the Defense Department to American Samoa to provide transportation among the islands. The provision was written into the bill by Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, a senior member of the Senate Appropriations panel, who found it difficult to get around during visits to the islands. _An order for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to build an experimental fish farming laboratory at Stuttgart, Ark., the state of Democratic Appropriations Committee member Sen. Dale Bumpers, a Democrat. _$12 million to modify the Mormon Island auxiliary dam in California, added by House Appropriations Committee member Vic Fazio, D-Calif. _A discount of more than 80 percent for Israel on the fees that normally would be paid for U.S. guarantees for $400 million in housing loans, along with a waiver of many of the usual requirements of the housing program. The provision was added by Sens. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., and Robert Kasten, R-Wis. _A reminder to the Postal Service not to move the post office out of Holly Springs, Miss., in the district of Democratic Rep. Jamie Whitten, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee. _A $185 million FBI automated fingerprint lab planned for Clarksburg, W.Va., attached by Senate Appropriations Committee Chairman Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va.

DOC.HEAD: Spooked Horse Drags, Fatally Injures Armless Woman
DOC.TEXT: A woman who could swim, play the drums and even change a baby's diaper despite being born without arms died after she was dragged by a horse that spooked while tied to her waist. Stacey McInroe Conner of Stephenville suffered severe head injuries and died Wednesday at Harris Methodist Fort Worth Hospital, family members said. The 22-year-old college student, who learned to ride at an early age, was feeding her 2-year-old filly, with the horse's lead rope tied around her waist, before the accident. ``Something spooked the little horse and she just took off, dragging Stacey,'' said Ms. Conner's mother, Lometa Reed. ``She was out there by herself and a neighbor saw her, cut the lead rope and called the ambulance.'' Friends and family said Ms. Conner never let her disability prevent her from pursuing a variety of interests. She parachuted from 13,000 feet in November, strapped to a friend, and skiied for the first time in December. She could swim, ride horses, fish, play drums, and used her feet to change the diapers of a friend's squirming baby. ``Even though she was handicapped by having no arms, she just couldn't accept that she couldn't do anything like anybody else,'' said Leon Manley, principal of Stephenville High School. ``She actually wrote with her feet,'' Manley said. Ms. Conner's disability was blamed on a virus her mother contracted while pregnant. The child learned to swim while still a toddler and later excelled at soccer. She played the drums with her feet in the high school band and learned to ride on a Shetland pony. ``About the gutsiest lady I ever saw,'' said Darrell Allison of Fort Worth, a family friend who knew Ms. Conner since she was a child. He arranged the skydiving venture in November. Ms. Conner, would have graduated next year from Tarleton State University, where she was majoring in accounting. Stephenville is about 50 miles southwest of Fort Worth.

DOC.HEAD: Dealocked School Races Decided By Drawing Cards, Picking Name From Hat
DOC.TEXT: One deadlocked school board race was broken when candidates played a winner-take-all game of high card draw. A second tie in the same county was decided by picking a name from a hat. Bloomfield School Board contender Milton Johnson moved into the November general election on Thursday after he drew an ace and opponent Richard Ketelson drew a jack, Knox County Clerk Virginia Buerman said. Both men had 105 votes after a recount of the May 15 primary vote. In another tie-breaker, Jerry Kitto's name was drawn out of a hat to give him a four-year term on the Santee School Board. Kitto had tied with his brother, Richard. A recount showed each had 30 votes. Richard didn't appear at the county courthouse for a high card showdown, so after waiting an hour both names were thrown into a hat and Jerry's name was drawn, Ms. Buerman said. The Nebraska secretary of state's office was consulted to be sure the drawings were the correct way to break the ties, she said. The ties were broken in Center because that's the Knox County seat. And despite it's name, Center is in extreme northeastern Nebraska.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Faults Navy Iowa Investigation
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS Moosally's rank to captain in 8th graf, subs 9th graf with new grafs 9-11 to incorporate Navy statement
DOC.TEXT: Congressional investigators said today their tests did not support the Navy's finding that sabotage caused the explosion that killed 47 sailors aboard the USS Iowa. The congressional report, which came a day after the Navy reopened its investigation into the disaster, said the explosion could have resulted from gunpowder bags in the ship's guns being rammed at ``higher than normal speeds.'' The report was presented to the Senate Armed Services Committee by the General Accounting Office, which investigated the Navy's controversial finding that gunner's mate Clayton Hartwig probably sabotaged the battleship in the April 19, 1989, explosion. Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., said today's testimony by the GAO report ``cast grave doubts on the Navy's findings'' that foreign material had been found in the gun barrel. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, responding to the GAO report, said he would ``reserve judgement'' until further investigation. ``They did the best job they could. Now there's new evidence, new information that warrants reopening the investigation,'' Cheney said. ``But I think at this point I'd want to keep my powder dry, so to speak, until we have a better sense of exactly what this new information may contribute.'' Hartwig's sister, Kathy Kubicina, who attended the hearing, told reporters, ``My brother was only a victim. ... I hope after today this will get rid of any doubt in anyone's mind.'' Retired Capt. Fred Moosally, the USS Iowa's skipper at the time of the explosion and an outspoken critic of the investigation, sat in the front row during the hearing. But he declined to comment, saying, ``I'm only here to listen.'' The Navy issued a statement saying it ``will continue to test additional theories dealing with the possible causes of the explosion.'' ``Technical tests continue and results of that testing will be made public as soon as the analysis and report is completed and reviewed by the secretary of the Navy,'' the statement said. ``Any further discussion on aspects of the additional testing would be premature at this present time.'' On Thursday, the Navy ordered a halt to any firing of 16-inch guns aboard the service's four battleships after an ``unexplained'' ignition of some gunpowder bags during testing. Nunn said the GAO finding ``will essentially eviscerate the Navy's conclusion'' that the explosion aboard the USS Iowa was the result of a wrongful, intentional act. The GAO said tests at the Sandia National Laboratories ``could not corroborate the Navy's technical finding that an improvised chemical device initiated the explosion.'' Last fall, the Navy said Hartwig, who was killed in the explosion, ``most probably'' had placed ``some type of detonation device'' between gunpowder bags when he supervised the loading of the warship's guns. The GAO analysis made no mention specifically of Hartwig in its report. The report said the Sandia Laboratory was ``confident in its findings, which conclude that the foreign materials that the Navy found were not inconsistent with the nominal levels found throughout gun turrets and were consistent with the maritime environment.'' Elements of calcium and chlorine, which the Navy contended came from a detonator placed between the gunpowder bags, were readily found in turret No.1 aboard the Iowa and in turrets on the battleships New Jersey and Wisconsin, the report said. ``Therefore, Sandia could not corroborate the Navy's finding that such foreign material was evidence of a detonator,'' the report said. The Sandia Laboratory testing also questioned the Navy's finding that impact and compression of the gunpowder bags did not contribute to the Iowa explosion. ``Sandia believes that a possible alternate scenario to the Navy's finding of a deliberate act is that an unintentional high-speed over-ram of the powder bags combined with the impact sensitivity of the powder led to the explosion,'' the report said. ``Sandia does not consider its study complete, in the sense that a clear and definite cause of the explosion has been identified, and it recommends areas of further investigation by the Navy.'' The GAO also recommended in its report that because of problems with manning and training for the World War II-era battleships and their complex gun systems, the battleships that remain in the Navy's fleet ``seem to be top candidates for decommissioning as we look for ways to scale back U.S. forces.'' All four of the Navy's battleships are now in port _ the USS Iowa and the USS Wisconsin at Norfolk, Va., and the USS New Jersey and the USS Missouri at Long Beach, Calif. The Iowa and New Jersey are slated for retirement this year to save money and the investigators' suggestion that the Missouri and Wisconsin be mothballed would remove all battleships from the nation's arsenal. Sen. John Warner, R-Va., the committee's ranking Republican, disagreed with statements asserting that the Navy had been involved in a coverup and should apologize. ``It's far too early ... to make such conclusions,'' Warner said. Earlier in the day, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said ``I think some of those who headed up the investigation ought to be called on the carpet. ... I think it is posible some heads will roll.'' The Navy's report last fall said the fireball aboard the Iowa ``most probably'' was an intentional act by Hartwig, who it said was upset about the breakup of his friendship with another crew member, Kendall Truitt. ``It's long overdue,'' Truitt said today of the Navy's decision to reopen the investigation. Hartwig's father, Earl Hartwig, himself a Navy gunner's mate in World War II, said in Cleveland: ``This is what we've been saying all along. My son is not guilty. The Navy was barking up the wrong tree.'' The ignition of several gunpowder bags came Thursday during ``follow-up testing which the Navy has been doing periodically as new theories were brought forward'' since the Iowa blast and the Navy's review of it, the service said. After conducting a four-month examination of the Iowa explosion _ and about 20,000 technical tests of gunpowder blasts _ the Navy contended in September that it had found no technical reason for the explosion. The service admitted it only had circumstantial evidence for its finding because all witnesses died in the fire. Members of Congress and others attacked that conclusion as unsupported by evidence and faulted the investigation as inadequate. Ten days ago Nunn wrote Adm. Carlisle A.H. Trost, the chief of naval operations, to complain the service was not moving fast enough to act on evidence that the Iowa blast might have been caused by a friction problem, Pentagon sources said. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Navy was informed several weeks ago about the results of tests conducted by the Sandia Laboratory in Albuquerque, N.M. In the new experiment, five 96-pound bags filled with gunpowder pellets were dropped in a vertical column with weights on top of them, in an attempt to recreate the force that rams the bags through a 16-inch gun barrel on a warship. ``On the 18th try they got a detonation,'' said the source, who asked not to be quoted by name.

DOC.HEAD: Vote Should Oust Former Communists from Last Power Bastion
DOC.TEXT: The revolution that toppled one-party rule in Poland last year remains a work-in-progress, and the next stage of demolition occurs Sunday in democratic elections for 52,000 local council members nationwide. They are the first fully free elections since World War II and are expected to root out thousands of Communist holdovers _ many of whom ran their towns and villages as virtual dictators _ from their last bastion of authority. The aim is to restore, after a four-decade absence, the concept of freely chosen local governments empowered to raise and spend local revenues and free from direct control of the central government. ``Regardless who wins the elections ... it will be the end of totalitarian authority in Poland,'' Election Commissioner Jerzy Stepien said at a news conference. ``This is the most important event in Poland in the last 40 years,'' said 23-year-old medical student Jerzy Kryszton, studying a list of Solidarity Civic Committee candidates posted at a Warsaw campaign office. ``First of all, these are the first really democratic and free elections in Poland. Secondly, this will be the only chance and the only way to get rid of the local mafias, to get rid of the local Communist activist who still controls everything in the countryside.'' Although the electoral battles are being fought locally, the results are being watched nationally in the country of 38 million as an important test for the Solidarity movement, whose unity is strained between its trade union and political wings. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki took to the hustings in the campaign's closing days to build support for the ballot and for the candidates being put forth by the Solidarity-linked Citizens Committees, still Poland's most potent political force. Scores of new independent political parties have arisen since last year's parliamentary elections. The voting will show if any of them is developed enough to grab a significant chunk of Solidarity's following. Among those vying are the Confederation for an Independent Poland and the Christian National Union on the right wing; the environmentally minded Green Party; the libertarian Union of Real Politics; the center-right Christian Democratic Party of Labor; several similarly named Peasant parties and at least four Socialist parties. The main successor to the now-dissolved Communist Party, the Social Democracy of the Polish Republic, is struggling to remain on the political stage. In addition to those endorsed by political groups, about 40 percent of the approximately 146,000 people seeking seats are independents or are backed only by local resident or neighborhood associations. Government officials hope for a high turnout but fear many Poles alienated by the painful economic policies will stay away in a passive protest. Polls so far indicate a 60 percent turnout, slightly lower than the 62 percent that took part in the partially free parliamentary voting last June that gave Solidarity a landslide and paved the way to the East bloc's first non-Communist-led government in September. ``I'm not going to vote,'' said Stalislawa Czajkowska, a 40-year-old secretary. ``I have lost all hope that things might change for the better here. Solidarity has achieved nothing but an even bigger mess,'' she said, citing rising crime and higher prices. ``I doubt it is possible to achieve anything in this country with this society,'' said photographer Antoni Gontarki, 42, who said he probably would stay home election day. If he did vote, it would be for one of the extreme anti-Communist parties like the Confederation for an Independent Poland. Poland had independent local councils and mayors during its 21 years of independence between World War I and World War II. But by 1950, the Communists who seized control had done away with the local governments that reappeared after the war. After the adoption of a Soviet-modeled constitution in 1952, local People's Councils were established. But candidates could only run with Communist Party approval and the councils were essentially local agents of the central government in Warsaw _ which provided all their operating money and could dismiss council members and reverse decisions. A large part of the government's role in the elections has been simply to explain to people what local governments are and how they function in the West. The elections will also mark a huge divestiture of wealth from the central government, which owns more than 90 percent of Polish property. About one-fifth of these assets _ including land, buildings and factories _ will be turned over to the newly established local governments overnight.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Says Germany's Decision on NATO Could Affect Arms Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 7 grafs with more Gorbachev comment. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that the Soviet Union would review its policies on European arms control and security negotiations if a reunited Germany joined NATO. The Soviet leader told a news conference that Western leaders seem to be assuming a unified Germany would join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and said Moscow was very wary of that prospect. ``What should we do then about all the negotiating processes, including the European process, the CSCE process, the Vienna disarmament processs? Then we must take a fresh look at whether we should pursue the same policy, whether we should base it on the same approaches,'' Gorbachev told reporters in the Soviet Foreign Ministry press center. The superpowers are involved in negotiations on reducing their nuclear and conventional forces and hope to reach some agreements during the summit between President Bush and Gorbachev in Washington from May 31 to June 3. CSCE refers to the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which deals with military security, economic cooperation and human rights. Gorbachev's remarks contained the Kremlin's most dire warning yet about what steps it would take if a reunited Germany joins the Western military alliance. The Soviet preference, repeated by Gorbachev today, was that a reunited Germany belong to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Gorbachev said discussion of German reunification took up 70 percent of his talks earlier in the day with French President Francois Mitterrand, who also appeared at the news conference. The Bush administration favors NATO membership for a reunited Germany. The Soviet leader did not say his country would withdraw from the European negotiating processes, which cover reductions of troops and tanks on the continent and other security issues, and did not specify how the Kremlin's positions in those talks might change. He justified the policy review by saying NATO would take similar action if the shoe were on the other foot. ``If a unified Germany should find itself part of the Warsaw Treaty, then I'm sure the Western countries would immediately get together to discuss how they should proceed further,'' Gorbachev said. Skewing a reunited Germany in either direction, he said, would upset the strategic balance in European negotiations. ``There is a question whether these processes would not become hostages to that kind of imbalance,'' he said. The Kremlin chief told reporters he issued the warning ``not to try to scare any of you so that you would begin to reflect right away what kind of trump card is being prepared by the Soviet Union,'' but to appeal for a joint search for ``the right solutions, (so) that we not weaken the positive processes in international relations.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Earth First! Activists Arrested After Explosion Injures Them
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with comments from police news conference on evidence. Picks up 7th graf, ``For them...'. Earth First! is cq
DOC.TEXT: Two members of a radical environmentalist group have been arrested in connection with a pipe bomb that blew their car apart and injured both of them, police said today. Judi Bari, 40, and Darryl Cherney, 33, were booked for investigation of possession and transportation of explosives, said Oakland Police Lt. Mike Sims. Bari was in serious but stable condition today under police guard at a hospital after undergoing surgery for a fractured pelvis. Cherney was treated for a minor injury above his eye and jailed, Sims said. Members of Earth First! said Bari and Cherney were targets of the bomb after receiving several death threats in recent weeks. But Sims said there was strong evidence from searches of various locations that the two were knowingly transporting the bomb. ``Based on our determination of the placement of the device in the car, we believe they should have known it was there. We believe it went off accidently,'' Sims said. He said officers found no more explosives in their searches, but turned up other evidence he would not discuss. ``I don't believe it,'' said Mark Huntington, a friend of the pair and an Earth First! supporter. ``If the police produced evidence and put it on TV, I still wouldn't believe it. I think they planted it ... The FBI has a lot of reasons to get rid of Darryl and Judi and shut down Redwood Summer.'' ``For them to say they could possibly be involved in what was obviously a threat on their lives is really outrageous,'' said Mike Roselle, an Earth First! founder. ``They would never have anything to do with bombs or guns. They are completely non-violent. ... No way,'' said Earth First! spokeswoman Kelpie Wilson. As many as 50 members of Earth First! and their supporters crowded the Police Department lobby in what they called a vigil, vowing not to leave until Cherney was released. The crowd sang, played guitars and made signs reading ``Free Cherney,'' ``Trees Not Bombs'' and ``Smash FBI Frame-Ups.'' Police also refused to say why officers, on Thursday night, blocked the headquarters of the group Seeds of Peace, which has worked with Earth First!. Officers searched a van parked near the peace group's headquarters on the Oakland-Berkeley border and removed several items from the van. Cherney, of Piercy, and Bari, of Ukiah, in Northern California, were in the San Francisco Bay area to drum up support for a summer campaign to slow timber cutting in the old-growth forests of Northern California. Cherney was driving Bari's station wagon near Oakland High School when the bomb went off inside the car shortly before noon. The car continued on about a block before hitting two parked cars. Both injured activists were organizing the ``Redwood Summer'' campaign of continual demonstrations to block what some environmentalists call excessive logging, Earth First! spokeswoman Wilson said. Pacific Lumber Co., which has been a target of Earth First! protests, issued a statement late Thursday saying the company does not condone or promote violence _ ``be it spiking trees, blowing up power lines or bombing cars'' _ and hopes Bari and Cherney fully recover from ``this appalling incident.'' Wilson said Bari is a well-known ``eco warrior'' who advocated ``tree spiking,'' the driving of long metal spikes into trees to damage lumbering equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Shrinks
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit shrank to $26.4 billion from January through March, the smallest quarterly imbalance in more than six years, the government reported Friday. The Commerce Department said the 8.2 percent improvement in the trade balance was a result of record-high export sales that offset the highest volume of foreign oil shipments in more than 12 years. The improving trade performance, if it continues, would be good news for the U.S. economy. Over the past three years, rising exports have accounted for more than one-third of total domestic growth as American manufacturers enjoyed a boom in foreign sales. In other economic news Friday, the Commerce Department reported that consumer spending shot up by 0.6 percent in April. However, the National Association of Realtors reported that sales of existing homes fell 2.1 percent in April. The better-than-expected performance sent many economists scurrying to revise their trade forecasts for the year. Many had been expecting that weaker foreign demand and a rising oil bill would translate into a worsening trade deficit. ``We have continued strong export growth and that is leading to better trade numbers than a lot of people were predicting, including us,'' said Howard Lewis, vice president for international economic affairs at the National Association of Manufacturers. David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., said export growth should continue to be an important source of strength for the U.S. economy for some time to come. ``Europe and Germany in particular and to a lesser degree Asia will be the locomotive for U.S. growth,'' he said. However, some analysts cautioned that it was too soon to tell whether the first quarter performance would continue for the rest of the year. They noted that oil imports are surging because U.S. production has dropped to 25-year lows and that the strength of the U.S. dollar in comparison to the Japanese yen could start showing up in rising imports of Japanese products. Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI-McGraw Hill, said her forecasting company was still expecting only a small improvement in the overall trade deficit when compared with 1989. For the first quarter, U.S. exports rose 4.7 percent, to an all-time high of $96.04 billion. Imports were also at a record level, reflecting the surge in oil demand. They climbed 1.6 percent, to $122.4 billion. The report Friday on merchandise trade as calculated on a balance-of-payments basis confirmed trends already noted in the department's monthly merchandise trade reports. They showed a first quarter deficit of $23.9 billion. The disparity in the two figures comes from the fact that Friday's report excludes military sales by the U.S. government and makes other minor adjustments to the monthly figures. The increase in consumer spending was the biggest gain since January and was double the 0.3 percent rise in personal incomes last month. Analysts said the strength in consumer spending coupled with the strong gains in export sales were good indications for future economic growth. The decrease in sales of existing home was the third decline in the past four months, with high mortgage rates blamed for the weakness. The first-quarter trade performance marked the second consecutive quarterly improvement in the deficit. In the fourth quarter, the gap between exports and imports had fallen 3.5 percent, to $28.7 billion. Exports of machine tools, industrial supplies and consumer goods climbed 4 percent to a record $85.1 billion in the first quarter. More than one-half of this increase was attributed to a rise in civilian aircraft shipments after the end of the Boeing strike. Exports of farm products were up 7 percent to $11 billion with increases recorded in overseas sales of wheat, vegetables, fruits and nuts. Corn exports were down, reflecting sharply lower shipments to the Soviet Union. Average prices of corn and cotton increased 2 percent while prices of other commodities changed little, the government said. Imports of petroleum surged 17 percent in the first quarter to $15.6 billion, with the average number of barrels imported daily climbing to 8.9 million, the highest level since the third quarter of 1977. The average price per barrel increased to $19.47, the highest since the first quarter of 1986, when the price per barrel was $17.65. America's deficits declined with several countries, including Japan, down $1.9 billion to $10.4 billion for the first quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Lawyer Testifies Regarding Marcos Swiss Bank Accounts
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos reportedly met recently with a lawyer hired to fight the Philippine government's effort to seize billions of dollars she and her late husband allegedly stashed in Swiss banks, a witness testified today. Sergio Salvioni, an attorney representing the government in Manila, told a U.S. District Court jury he was told of the New York meeting by Bruno DePreux, who he said had identified himself as representing Mrs. Marcos, the former Philippine first lady. ``He said he met Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos in Honolulu two times and he met Imelda Marcos one time here in the continental United States,'' Salvioni said. ``The last time was more or less two to three weeks ago, here in New York.'' Under questioning by Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella, Salvioni quoted DePreux as saying he originally was hired to represent both Mrs. Marcos and her husband after Marcos' ouster as president of the Philippines in early 1986. Marcos died last year in Hawaiian exile. ``And now he represents Mrs. Marcos and her heirs,'' Salvioni said. Mrs. Marcos is accused of having helped her husband steal more than $220 million from their country's treasury, using the money to support a luxury lifestyle and investments including four secretly purchased New York office buildings. Salvioni, a member of the Swiss parliament, flew to New York from Geneva to testify. Prosecutors hoped he would help prove the Marcoses used secret accounts in at least eight Swiss banks to hold some of the embezzled funds during Marcos' 20-year reign. Judge John F. Keenan allowed Salvioni to testify before jurors on certain details after rejecting defense protests that his information would be ``explosive and prejudicial'' to Mrs. Marcos. Keenan turned aside defense arguments that Salvioni's remarks quoting DePreux were ``hearsay'' and therefore inadmissible, but barred any references to actual details of the bank accounts. Mrs. Marcos, wearing her customary black, showed no visible emotion as the Swiss lawyer explained the efforts by President Corazon Aquino's government to gain access to the Swiss accounts.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Israel-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat's 50-minute speech Friday to the United Nations Security Council. He spoke in Arabic. An English translation was provided by the PLO.

``When the Palestine Liberation Organization supported by the Arab Group requested the convening of this urgent sesion of your august council, its request stemmed from the realization that the situation has reached an extremely dangerous and explosive point ... The situation now requires urgent action in order to enforce reverence for international legitimacy...

``It was not the insanity of an individual or his derangement, as the Israeli officials have claimed, that was responsible for the massacre of Black Sunday (in which seven Arab workers were killed by an Israeli gunman on May 20). The primary responsibility falls on the insanity and derangement of the whole system, a system which is haunted by mythical ghosts, by illusions of defunct racial superiority, and by the obsession with expansion and invasion which stems from the stupid arrogance of military superiority in order to create `Greater Israel' ...

``Over the last 30 months, 1,200 Palestinian martyrs have fallen by the bullets of the occupiers. More than 80,000 citizens have been injured as a result of variuous kinds of repression ranging from severe beatings, breaking bones, the use of rubber bullets, live ammunition, to the use of internationally prohibited poison gases which have caused more than 6,000 miscarriages and permanent handicaps to thousands of children, women and men, in addition to other kinds of terrorism and repression. Over 30 months the Israeli occupation forces have been waging a war of extermination on all fronts ...

``I see it as my duty to point out, most regrettably, the unlimited support on all levels given by the U.S.A. to Israel, which has encouraged it to continue the occupation and to escalate the terrorist and barbaric practice against the Palestinian people, challenging the decisions of the international community and impeding all peace initiatives in the Middle East region, including the U.S. proposals themselves...

``The Palestine Liberation Organization, which affirms its strategic commitment to peace, submits to your august body the following practical steps ... First, the designation by the U.N. secretary-general of a special and permanent envoy to work full time on the peace process and to conduct the necessary contacts to secure a peaceful, just and durable solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict or that the secretary-general undertake the duties of this mission on his own. ``Second, the adoption by your august body of a resolution to provide international protection to the Palestinian people, to safeguard their lives, properties and holy places in the occupied territories under the flag of the United Nations and by means of international emergency forces in addition to the deployment along with it of the U.N. observer force now stationed in Jerusalem, with the purpose of ending completely the Israeli occupation of our Palestinian land. ``Third, the adoption by your august council of a clear resolution and ensuring its supervision and implementation in order to stop settler immigration to the occupied Palestinian territories, a decision that will prevent completely the construction and expansion of Israeli settlements, military or civilian in the occupied Palestinian lands, particularly in Arab Jerusalem, in implementation of the relevant international resolutions. ``Fourth, that your august body call the representatives of the permanent members of the Security Council (United States, Britain, the Soviet Union, China, and France) to an immediate meeting to discuss the peace settlement, the peace process, and to prepare for the convening of the International Conference for Peace in the Middle East, in implementation of international resolutions. ``Fifth, to start adopting the necessary arrangements preparing for the imposition of sanctions on Israel in accordance with Chapter Seven of the U.N. Charter, as a response to the crimes committed by Israel against the Palestinian people in the occupied territories and as a consequence of its breach of the Fourth Geneva Convention relative to the treatment of civilians in time of war and also for its refusal to implement the relevant international international resolutions, and for its deliberate defiance and for impeding the peace process in the Middle East... ``Obligations and commitment to the human heritage and to the concepts of justice and righteousness to which that heritage have been dedicated, require that your esteemed council decides upon the formation of an international investigation committee from members of the council to investigate all the crimes against humanity which have been perpetrated by the Israeli government against the Palestinian people... ``In reaffirming that our choice of the path of peace is a genuine strategic alternative we also affirm our right to continue our resistance and our self-defense until an end is put to the Israeli occupation. That is a sacred right guaranteed to us by the law of human rights, the United Nations Charter, international decisions, and by the will of the Palestinian people. The heroic peoples' intefadeh will continue against the Israeli occupation until we wrest our right to freedom and national independence on our national soil.''

DOC.HEAD: Energy Official Leads Team to Collider Talks in Japan, Korea
DOC.TEXT: The United States will make the first invitation for foreign participation in the superconducting super collider to Japan and South Korea, Deputy Secretary of Energy Henson Moore said Friday. Moore and a team of administration officials are scheduled to visit Japan and South Korea next week to discuss the project with government officials. ``The point is to begin the process, to officially ask them to join us, to answer their questions and to discuss with them what we think is appropriate participation ... and get their feedback,'' Moore said. Moore said foreign participation was typical in all large science labs and Congress has insisted on it for the collider, to be built south of Dallas. The collider will be a 54-mile tunnel, where protons will crash into each other at high speeds at the direction of superconducting magnets. Scientists hope the particles will break apart, yielding clues to the fundamental nature of matter. A similar trip to Europe is likely in October, Moore said, although India is the only country that has formally expressed interest in the collider. It sent a letter of intent to pledge $50 million. Japan and South Korea have been waiting ``for this visit to officially begin their considerations within their governments,'' Moore said. But Moore said both countries had indicated interest in the giant atom smasher. He refused to elaborate. ``It may well be a year before we have any kind of solid feeling from the Japanese government and Korean government,'' Moore said. ``We hope to have some indication of interest on this trip.'' The House earlier this month authorized spending $5 billion on the approximately $8 billion project. The rest is to be made up from outside sources, such as foreign investors. Texas has pledged $1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Beleaguered Soviet Premier Tries to Calm Panicked Consumers
DOC.TEXT: A beleaguered Soviet premier appealed to consumers Friday to stop their panic buying of food, triggered by his announcement of plans for sharp price increases, and urged lawmakers to quickly approve economic reforms. Opposition deputies in parliament demanded a no-confidence vote aimed at bringing down Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov's government, but he got one important voice of support for his program: from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``I'm hoping in the end, after all the debates _ and they won't be simple _ we'll agree that we have to move toward a market. I'm sure of this,'' Gorbachev said at a news conference. Ryzhkov's plan, broadcast on national television Thursday, proposes tripling the price of bread and other flour-based products on July 1 and increasing the prices of most other consumer goods in January. It envisions a five-year gradual shift to a government-regulated market economy by freeing most prices, raising taxes, selling off state property, and reducing central control of industry. Announcement of the plan triggered immediate rushes to stores for macaroni and bread, Ryzhkov told reporters at the Kremlin. ``Now this wave for bread and bread products has already rolled through half the country, and it's gotten to Moscow,'' he said. ``I am appealing for restraint and calm,'' said Ryzhkov, looking haggard and with his voice ragged from fatigue. ``Tension is growing. We're getting a lot of telegrams expressing concern: `How are we going to live?''' Ryzhkov told the Supreme Soviet parliament that must approve his economic plan. The premier, who bears responsibility for the economic program, indicated that if it led to a vote of no-confidence against his government, he would abide by the outcome. ``If there is no confidence in the government, then what?'' he asked. ``A new government will work.'' Opposition deputies in the Supreme Soviet have already demanded a no-confidence vote after the legislature votes on the economic plan. They have said they expect it to fail, but believe they have to make the political gesture. Deputy after deputy, both conservatives and radicals, took the podium Friday to attack the government plan. Ryzhkov said the criticism had helped the government see ``the weak sides'' of the program and should continue into next week, but urged a quick decision on whether bread prices should rise as planned. ``You have to decide, because this question is so difficult for us and for the people,'' he said. Bread is the staple of the Soviet diet, virtually the only product that's always readily available and remains cheap at about 32 cents a loaf. In the Ukraine, long known as the Soviet Union's breadbasket, the republic's prime minister said his government would fight Ryzhkov's plan, Ukrainian activists reported. Miners in the Ukraine's Donetsk coal region will consider calling for a countrywide coal strike to protest the plan when they meet June 11, according to the Rukh Press, an arm of the Ukrainian popular front. Supreme Soviet deputy Mikhail Bronstein warned that the entire country would need a ration card system to make it through the transition period. Ryzhkov indicated after his report Thursday that increased rationing might be needed. Most regions of the country already have some form of rationing. Radical economist Pavel Bunich told the Supreme Soviet the government had rejected more severe ``shock therapy'' reforms only to offer ``shock therapy without the therapy'' _ reforms that will hurt without leading to a real market system. Bunich proposed putting the whole plan back on the government drawing board. Ryzhkov acknowledged that the country will ``have to live through a pretty hard period,'' as the market reforms take effect. But he pledged government support for low-income families and other measures to cushion the bumpy economic ride ahead, in which economists have predicted millions of unemployed. Announcement of the economic program has already prompted Muscovites to stock up. At Food Shop Number One on Gorky Street, a shop assistant, who asked not to be identified, said panic-stricken buyers ``are literally clearing full shelves for hoarding.'' At another food shop near the center, an unusually long line of 25 to 30 people were packed into the grocery department. ``This is the first time I saw people lining up like this for some cheap cereals,'' a regular customer said. At the Novoarbatsky supermarket, however, manager Valentina Aramasova said the situation was normal, the same as the days before the economic program was announced.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Says He'll Consider Lifting State of Emergency
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa said Friday his government will consider lifting the nationwide state of emergency that has been in force for four years. Winding up his nine-nation European tour, de Klerk also said he senses that there is an emerging consensus that economic sanctions imposed on South Africa because of its apartheid policy should be lifted. ``My impression is that it is becoming more and more clear to everybody concerned that sanctions are becoming irrelevant,'' he told reporters after meetings with Italian government and business leaders. De Klerk left for South Africa on Friday evening. The state of emergency in South Africa was imposed June 12, 1986, by de Klerk's predecessor, P.W. Botha, to quell political and racial violence. The decree gives police wide powers to detain people without charge, ban political rallies, restrict the movement of journalists and prohibit ``any act'' deemed a threat to public order. The proclamation comes up for reconsideration in June, as it does each year. ``We will consider all alternatives'' at that time, de Klerk said. ``We sincerely believe that the state of emergency must go as soon as possible. ... There are various alternatives at which we will look. I don't want to raise any expectations apart from saying we will be looking at this fundamentally.'' ``We can only afford to lift it should the level of violence go down,'' de Klerk said. ``In some areas it is extremely high.'' Fighting between rival black factions has wracked many urban areas in recent months. De Klerk said his European tour had confirmed international support for his reform policies. He visited France, Greece, Portugal, Belgium, Britain, West Germany, Switzerland, Spain and Italy. Since assuming power in August, he has released black leader Nelson Mandela after 27 years in prison, legalized black opposition groups and pledged to share power with the black majority. South Africa's white minority now controls the government, and de Klerk has stopped short of supporting black majority rule. De Klerk visited European nations last year as leader of the National Party, and he said Friday that there was much less skepticism now over whether South Africa was committed to change. ``They wanted to believe us but they wanted to see,'' he said. ``Now I found credibility.
