South Africa is being believed.'' He described the international sanctions imposed on South Africa as ``a dismal failure'' that contributed to unemployment and the volatile atmosphere. In 1986, the European Community banned imports of South African iron, steel and gold coins, and prohibited new investments in the country. Italian Premier Giulio Andreotti and President Francesco Cossiga expressed support for de Klerk's policies. ``The road taken is the right one,'' Andreotti said. ``Continuing on this path, de Klerk can count on the help of Italy and Europe.'' Giovanni Agnelli, chairman of Fiat, said Italian industrialists will be interested in doing business in South Africa.

DOC.BYLINE: Mired In Impasse, Rail Strike Widens, Cuts Off Baltic Coast ^By DRUSILLA MENAKER
DOC.TEXT: A wildcat rail strike spread to the port city of Gdansk on Friday and cut off all rail traffic to Poland's Baltic coast, and a government spokesman said workers and officials were at an impasse. The strikes for higher pay and railroad reforms began Sunday and represented a growing challenge to Poland's first post-Communist government and its program to establish a market economy. The government ``cannot meet the pay proposals being put forward and will not agree to discuss them in the conditions of a strike paralyzing everything,'' Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki told a crowd at a local election rally Friday in the southwestern city of Wroclaw. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa said on nationwide radio that ``demagogical forces'' were trying to exploit workers' legitimate grievances. The government has refused to negotiate with workers because the strike was not organized through legal unions. The OPZZ union, the onetime Communist-backed labor federation, endorsed the strike Thursday. The union is challenging Solidarity for the support of workers, and Walesa accused its leadership of manipulating the strikers in a ``game that will solve nothing but may lead even to a civil war.'' There were some signs of easing tensions late Friday. A hunger strike by 42 rail workers, six of them hospitalized, was suspended. Three rail stations in northern Poland reopened, officials said. But Transport Ministry spokesman Stefan Pozniak said the labor dispute remained at ``a total impasse.'' ``The entire coast is affected by the strike now, and there is not a single port working normally. ... It's getting really serious,'' Pozniak said. Freight stations in Gdansk joined the strike Friday. At the nation's busiest port, in Szczecin, 12 ships awaited unloading. Pozniak said freight headed to those ports from southern Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary was blocked. Two dozen rail junctions in northwestern Poland were idled, and the army was moving perishable and essential goods. Officials said thousands of the 400,000 railroad workers nationwide were on strike but could give no specific number. ``It takes only a few people to block traffic,'' Pozniak said. Walesa canceled a trip to Scandinavia and presided over a meeting of Solidarity's National Commission on the dispute. ``I hope that reason will win,'' he said in an afternoon radio interview. ``The strikers should be given a way of out it with honor because they are right.'' He also said the route of strikes ``leads nowhere,'' even though ``I am unhappy and almost the entire society is unhappy.'' The railway workers are demanding that their basic monthly salary be raised to $8 above the average monthly salary of $79. The government says granting the pay increases would unleash a torrent of demands from other sectors of society and ruin its economic reform program, begun Jan. 1. Mazowiecki, a top adviser to the Solidarity union before taking charge of the East bloc's first non-Communist government, said the strikes show ``society's fatigue and impatience.'' They also are ``evidence a lack of understanding of the essence of our economic changes,'' he said. In addition to strictly controlling wages, the government has raised prices to market levels and ended government subsidies to industry. As a result, Pole's real incomes have been reduced by an estimated 40 percent. There have been signs of slackening public support for the economic reforms, but a poll by the pro-Solidarity Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper Friday showed overwhelming opposition to the rail strike. The survey found 61.9 percent opposed it, 16.6 percent supported it and 21.5 percent had no opinion. No details on the poll methods were given.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet President Warms Up With Canada Before Hitting Washington
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will travel to Canada Tuesday for talks with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, giving both men a brief respite from domestic troubles stirred up in restive provinces. Gorbachev's 36-hour visit also will allow him to recover from jet lag before heading to Washington for his summit with President Bush. Officials here bristle at suggestions the short stopover is just an afterthought to the U.S.-Soviet summit. But they acknowledge it is unlikely Gorbachev would have come to Ottawa at this time otherwise. That is particularly so because Mulroney was just in Moscow in November, the first official visit by a Canadian prime minister since Pierre Trudeau went in 1971. Mulroney and Gorbachev discussed a wide range of issues and signed 14 agreements on issues ranging from the environment to Arctic cooperation. ``We're pleased with the visit and don't like to think of it as a mere rest stop en route to Washington,'' said a Canadian official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We realize it is a difficult time for him, especially with the trouble in the Baltic countries.'' Emerging nationalism in the Soviet Union is one of the biggest headaches facing Gorbachev, who has been locked in a war of nerves with Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia over their moves toward independence. In Canada, the desire of French-speaking Quebec for recognition as a ``distinct society'' has led to the biggest political crisis of Mulroney's career. The subject of Quebec independence once again is the topic of the day. Quebec did not sign Canada's 1982 constitution. A proposed amendment containing five major points sought by the Quebecois was agreed to and signed by Mulroney and all 10 provincial premiers in 1987. But governments changed in three provinces and the new premiers balked, creating the present crisis. Because they covered most of the bilateral issues in November, Mulroney and Gorbachev are expected to focus on more global matters. The Canadians pride themselves on being the only country that participates in NATO summits, G-7 economic summits, Commonwealth summits and francophone summits, giving them a special role in East-West matters. Gorbachev is concerned about German reunification. The question of NATO membership for the new Germany certainly will be a point of Soviet-Canadian divergence, the official said, adding that the emergence of a new, stronger Germany ``raises concerns everywhere.'' ``Both sides are also concerned about the new architecture of Europe,'' he said. ``Everybody would like to see a stronger Eastern Europe, economically and culturally.'' Ottawa wants to learn Gorbachev's vision of a new Soviet Union and a new Europe. ``Our view is that Mr. Gorbachev is the best man to have around at this time,'' the official said. Canada is most eager to talk about the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, the mechanism created by the 35-nation conference at Helsinki, Finland, in 1975. The Canadians believe the CSCE is the best framework for Soviet participation in the new Europe. ``We want to reaffirm in Soviet eyes that we are North American, but still an important part of the European process,'' the official said, stressing that ``Canada is not a superpower and doesn't threaten anybody.'' In Moscow on Friday, Gorbachev said the Soviet Union would review its policies on European arms control and security negotiations _ including CSCE _ if a reunited Germany joined NATO. Gorbachev arrives in Ottawa at midday Tuesday and goes for a private lunch with Mulroney at his official residence. Later in the afternoon he plans to meet Governor General Ray Hnatyshn. On Wednesday, there is a wreath-laying ceremony at the national War Memorial followed by another meeting with Mulroney. A late afternoon luncheon at the National Gallery of art will precede Gorbachev's departure for Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Poet Mark Strand Gets Laureate's Post at Library of Congress
DOC.TEXT: Poet Mark Strand, an English professor at the University of Utah, was named Friday as the new poet laureate consultant in poetry at the Library of Congress. Strand, who also is a short-story writer, editor, translator and author of children's books, will start his one-year assignment in September. He will receive $35,000 to give a poetry reading and a lecture during the year, to work with students and to advise Librarian of Congress James H. Billington on new library acquisitions. He will succeed poet Howard Nemerov, who served for two years. The position of consultant in poetry was created 54 years ago, but Congress voted in 1985 to expand the title to designate its holder as the equivalent of poet laureate of the United States. Since then, four poets have been named as poet laureate consultant in poetry at the libary. Besides Strand and Nemerov, they were the late Robert Penn Warren and Richard Wilbur. Strand has published seven collections of poetry. His eighth, ``The Continuous Life,'' is to be released in October. He also has translated works by other poets, written three children's books and two books on art, and has published three anthologies. A former Fulbright Scholar, Strand taught at 14 colleges and universities, including Harvard, Yale and Princeton, before he joined the University of Utah faculty in Salt Lake City in 1981. Among his awards are the Edgar Allan Poe prize in 1974 and the National Institute of Arts and Letters award in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Slick Stretches Almost 60 Miles After Collision on Mississippi River
DOC.TEXT: An oil slick stretched almost 60 miles downstream from the French Quarter on Friday after a freighter collided with some barges, dumping up to 60,000 gallons of fuel oil into the Mississippi River, officials said. ``It's diesel fuel. I'm told it's not as heavy as the motor oil you put in your car. It's somewhere between that and gasoline,'' said Senior Chief Petty Officer Joe Gibson of the U.S. Coast Guard. The spill occurred at 8:25 p.m. Thursday at Algiers Point in New Orleans when the 800-foot Stonewall Jackson ran into empty barges, the Coast Guard said. The ship and the barges belong to Waterman Industries. The accident ripped three holes in the freighter, rupturing several tanks of No. 6 fuel oil and allowing 50,000 to 60,000 gallons of the 300,000 gallons aboard the ship to spill. Workers on Friday were transferring the ship's remaining fuel to other tanks and shifting cargo and ballast to keep the damage above the water line, Gibson said. The collision was under investigation, Gibson said. The leading edge of the slick was at Port Sulfur, 58 miles downriver from New Orleans by noon Friday, Gibson said. ``It's possible it could reach the Gulf,'' Gibson said of the slick. ``As fast as the river is moving, it could get down there. It depends on a lot of conditions and how much it pools up along the banks of the river.'' A number of communities including New Orleans draw their drinking water from the Mississippi River. But the accident happened below the New Orleans intakes and only threatened one intake for the town of Pointe a La Hache, Gibson said. Rubark Co. of New Orleans was contracted by Waterman to clean up the spill and the company planned to put booms at the Pointe a La Hache water intake to prevent contamination, the Coast Guard said. Rubark also planned to place booms at two other places in the river, Gibson said. ``Our pollution response team is studying aerial video tapes of the spill to determine how to clean it up. They'll look to see where the concentration is the heaviest and clean it up there first,'' Gibson said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Navy-Iowa Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here are some comments concerning Friday's hearing involving the explosion aboard the USS Iowa: In its report to Congress, the General Accounting Office said the tests conducted from January to May 1990 at the Sandia National Laboratory ``could not corroborate the Navy's technical finding that an improvised chemical device initiated the explosion.'' ``Furthermore, Sandia has identified a potential hazard _ the impact sensitivity of the gunpowder in combination with an overram at higher than normal speeds which could have caused the explosion. Sandia believes further testing on this is needed to confirm its finding.''
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, on the Navy investigators: ``They did the best job they could. Now there's new evidence, new information that warrants reopening the investigation. ... But I think at this point I'd want to keep my powder dry, so to speak, until we have a better sense of exactly what this new information may contribute.''
The Navy issued a statement saying it ``will continue to test additional theories dealing with the possible causes of the explosion. ... Any further discussion on aspects of the additional testing would be premature at this present time.''
Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee: ``At the outset of this hearing, I stated that I anticipated that the testimony we would receive this morning would expose significant shortcomings in the Navy's investigation and would cast grave doubt on the conclusions the Navy drew as a result of their investigation. I believe that the testimony we have heard has done that and more. Moreover, this morning's testimony has identified a very plausible, if not probable, explanation for the explosion.''
Sen. John Warner, R-Va., ranking Republican on Senate Armed Services Committee: ``It's far too early to jump to any conclusion.''
Kendall Truitt, Navy friend of Clayton Hartwig: ``I think we should all be thankful that nobody else had to die before they started looking at this. I knew from the beginning my friend didn't do it.''
Hartwig's sister, Kathy Kubicina, who attended the hearing: ``My brother was only a victim. ... I hope after today this will get rid of any doubt in anyone's mind.''
Retired Capt. Fred Moosally, the USS Iowa's skipper at the time of the explosion, from his front-row seat at Friday's hearing: ``I'm only here to listen.''

DOC.HEAD: Ultra-Orthodox Rabbi Accuses Shamir of Eating Non-Kosher Food
DOC.TEXT: A powerful rabbi who two months ago helped bring down the government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is now accusing Shamir of frequently eating non-kosher food. Rabbi Ovadia Yosef made similar accusations Thursday night about former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, saying the two politicians routinely ate foods considered impure, such as pork and shellfish. The accusations came at a politically sensitive time. Shamir is having trouble persuading ultra-Orthodox religious parties to join a coalition Cabinet to be led by his right-wing Likud bloc. The allegations about Shamir and Sharon, both leading members of the right-wing Likud bloc, were secretly recorded as the rabbi addressed activists of his ultra-Orthodox Shas Party. Portions of the tape were broadcast on both Israel radio and Armed Forces radio. Israel radio said it obtained the tape from an unidentified person who made the recording without the rabbi's knowledge. Shamir refused to respond to questions about the matter during an interview with Israel radio, to be broadcast Saturday. Sharon aides could not be reached for comment. Yosef said of Shamir: ``He eats only impure fish. That's what he likes.'' About Sharon he said: ``He doesn't eat shellfish, but he really loves pork.'' Yossef Azran, head of the Shas faction in Parliament, told army radio that the remarks on the politicians' dining habits were taken out of context. The rabbi's speech was about the special budget allocations made to religious institutions. Shas rabbis and activists have threatened to split from the party because they felt their institutions weren't getting their fair share of the funds. In March, Shamir's coalition government with the left-leaning Labor Party lost a crucial vote of confidence in Parliament after Yosef ordered his six Shas lawmakers to abstain in the vote.

DOC.HEAD: Mother, Daughter Get Stiff Sentences for Fortunetelling Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A fortuneteller and her daughter preyed on troubled people's fears in a supernatural fraud scheme that bilked victims out of $275,000, a judge said before levying stiff prison terms. Gardenia Ephraim, 44, received a 20-year sentence Thursday and her daughter Mary Ann, 23, was ordered to serve a 15-year term by Judge David M. Barry. They were convicted April 17 of larceny, conspiracy and racketeering. The women, members of a Gypsy community in West Hartford, were found guilty of cheating victims who paid large sums for rituals to rid homes of evil spirits. Their lawyer had argued unsuccessfully that fortunetelling was a valid part of traditional Gypsy beliefs. ``You not only diminished these people and bankrupted some of them economically, but also bankrupted them emotionally,'' Barry said. They women used the proceeds to buy sports cars and expensive watches, prosecutors said. One victim, Harris Sanders, said the sentences ``couldn't happen to a nicer pair of ladies. Their remorse is nonexistent.'' Sanders said he paid the women $80,000 in property and cash. Defense attorney William T. Gerace called the sentences ``severe and cruel,'' and said he will appeal. He argued that the women were raised according to traditional Gypsy beliefs, including faith in fortunetelling and spiritualistic rituals. The younger Ms. Ephraim tearfully asked the judge for mercy. ``If you give me a chance, I will show you I can be an upstanding citizen,'' she said. ``I will work two jobs to do whatever needs to be done.'' The two women, imprisoned for the past 16 months, were returned to prison immediately after sentencing.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Graves and Ceausescu Burial Place Vandalized
DOC.TEXT: Vandals have desecrated about 70 graves in three cities, nearly half of them belonging to Jews, officials said Friday. They also struck the presumed graves of executed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife. The Ceausescus were secretly buried on opposite sides of a path in a public cemetery under different names, shortly after the December revolution that ended nearly half a century of communism. They were executed Dec. 25. Ceausescu's presumed grave was topped by a common oak cross with the inscription Col. Popa Dan, 1920-1989. Elena Ceausescu's assumed grave, which last week looked as freshly dug as her husband's, had an identical wooden cross carrying the name of Col. Enescu Vasile, 1921-1989. The authorities, fearing the couple's graves could be desecrated by revengeful Romanians, never disclosed the actual burial site. But after a high-ranking official last Saturday confirmed rumors the Ceausescus were buried at the Ghencea civilian cemetery in Bucharest, the crosses vanished. The chief administrator of the cemetery, Virginia Cismarescu, said at least 30 graves were desecrated in the past two days. ``It is a disaster. ... I do not know who can actually be against crosses,'' she said. ``I think it is the police who want to take away the myth of Ceausescu and leave the grave unmarked,'' said a grave digger who refused to be identified. The state-run news agency Rompres, quoting the Jewish Community office, reported that within the past two weeks, 28 Jewish graves were vandalized in the Jewish cemetery in the Transylvanian town of Tirgu Mures. Eight more were desecrated in the eastern city of Galati at ``Eternity'' cemetery. The incidents may have been inspired by the desecration of a Jewish cemetery in Carpentras, France, two weeks ago, said Bernard Zauber, president of the Jewish Community in Tirgu Mures. ``This was done on purpose, because people who survived the horrors of Auschwitz were buried there,'' Zauber told The Associated Press. The Jewish Community numbers only 300 people, aged 63 or older, in Tirgu Mures. Of the 28 graves vandalized there, five were destroyed, Zauber said. The desecrations outraged the dwindling Jewish community of Romania, where latent anti-Semitism continues. There are some 20,000 Jews left in Romania and many have applied to emigrate to Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Gorbachev to Open New Exhibit of Soviet Manuscripts
DOC.TEXT: Raisa Gorbachev will visit the Library of Congress next Thursday during the superpower summit to formally open an exhibit of historic Russian manuscripts, the library said Friday. A reception in the ornate Southwest Hall will be hosted by Armand Hammer, the Occidental Petroleum Corp. chairman and longtime Soviet business partner, who is underwriting the exhibit of 25 books and manuscripts from the Soviet Union. Some of the materials have never been exhibited in the Soviet Union and none has been seen outside that country, the library said. Among the 200 others expected to attend the reception are Vice President Dan Quayle's wife, Marilyn; Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I. First lady Barbara Bush may also attend. Mrs. Gorbachev will be shown some American artifacts, including letters written by George Washington, and will get a demonstration of the library's computer data collection system and a look at the library's main reading room. The Library of Congress was established in 1800 and is the world's largest library. It has the largest Slavic manuscript collection outside the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say Housing Shortage Blocking Troop Pullout from East Germany
With AM-Gorbachev-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union said Friday that a massive housing shortage back home has forced it to suspend indefinitely the withdrawal of nearly one-tenth of its troops from East Germany. In December 1988, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev promised the unilateral withdrawal of one-tenth of the Red Army soldiers in East Germany. Officials in Bonn say it was to include about 36,000 troops. West German authorities say the Soviets have pulled out about 12,000 military personnel. Soviet officials say the number is higher. The suspension comes as Moscow apparently is balking at signing an overall troop reduction agreement for central Europe. In recent days, the Soviets have been hesitating about signing a treaty that would reduce Soviet forces and U.S. forces to 195,000 for each side in central Europe. That area includes East Germany. Soviet diplomats, at a news conference in East Berlin on Friday, insisted that housing rather than politics was behind the suspension. Mikhail Logvinov, a counselor with the Soviet Embasssy, said ``the housing shortage is a problem that will take years to solve.'' Western experts have said that some of the troops being pulled out of Eastern Europe have been kept in tents back home while they wait for permanent homes. ``The army barracks are still filled with refugees from the earthquake area of Armenia and Azerbaijan, where there has been unrest,'' Logvinov said. ``The army has been put into action building apartments for these people,'' he said. ``Now, sufficient numbers of apartments must be built for the officers, junior officers and their families returning from abroad.'' He estimated that number at 100,000. The Soviet Union also has agreed to pull tens of thousands of troops from Hungary and Czechoslovakia. The superpowers are involved in negotiations on reducing their nuclear and conventional forces in Europe and hope to reach some agreements during the summit between President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev that begins May 31. Gorbachev said in Moscow on Friday that the Soviet Union would review its policies on European arms control and security negotiations if a united Germany joined NATO. The Soviet Union wants Germany to belong to NATO and the Warsaw Pact. The Bush administration favors NATO membership only. Gorbachev justified the policy review by saying NATO would take similar action if the Soviet Union insisted on Warsaw Pact membership for a united Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Aide Denounces Arafat Speech to Security Council
With AM-Israel-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A top aide to Prime Minster Yitzhak Shamir said Friday that PLO leader Yasser Arafat's speech to the U.N. Security Council was ``full of lies and distortions.'' In his speech, Arafat accused Israel of waging a ``war of extermination'' against Palestinians and urged the United Nations to set up an international force to protect Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories. ``Here again, Arafat has used the United Nations as a platform for a vicious attack on Israel, making accusations that are full of lies and distortion,'' Shamir aide Avi Pazner told The Associated Press. He said Arafat raised ``proposals which he knows have no chance whatsoever to be accepted by Israel.'' Danny Naveh, a top aide to Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, charged that Arafat was ``personally responsible for the murder of many innocent victims'' and that ``the PLO is still engaged in terrorism.'' Israel refuses contact with the PLO, arguing that it is a terror organization. The Jewish state also has rejected Arafat's December 1988 declaration in which he renounced terrorism. Earlier Friday, Shamir said he opposed any U.N. observer force in Israeli-controlled territory. In Arab east Jerusalem, Arafat's speech was broadcast over loudspeakers set up in a tent at the Red Cross, where dozens of Palestinian activists have been on a hunger strike since Sunday to press for a U.N. observer force. When the speech ended, applause erupted among the scores of listeners who jumped up from mattresses in the tent and began chanting ``Long live Abu Ammar!'' Abu Ammar is Arafat's nom de guerre. Faisal Husseini, the most prominent PLO supporter in the occupied lands and a potential peace negotiator with Israel, said Arafat was ``not only fighting for the liberation of his own people, but for peace in the whole area.'' Husseini also said the demands by Arafat, especially the call for an observer force, originated among activists in the occupied lands who daily confront Israeli troops. Representatives of the four main PLO factions, including those usually critical of Arafat, were also in the tent. ``We are united against our common enemy and we are united behind the demands of Arafat,'' said Riyad Malki, a West Bank university lecturer whose views have been identified with those of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. The PFLP is a radical Marxist faction backed by Syria. Israeli media played down the Arafat speech. The first item on Israel radio's hourly newscast after the speech was the drowning death of a 4-year-old girl. In its report on the speech, the radio carried a brief summary, but not Arafat's voice. Israel telvision continued with its scheduled program, a U.S.-made adventure film. The PLO demand for U.N. observers gained momentum after an outbreak of violence in the occupied lands to protest the slaying of seven Palestinian laborers by an Israeli gunman on Sunday. Israeli officials say the gunman was deranged. At least 15 Arabs were killed, most by gunfire from Israeli troops, and more than 800 hurt in subsequent clashes. Since the start of the Palestinian uprising more than 29 months ago, 710 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians and 43 Israelis have been slain by Palestinians. At least 216 other Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most as suspected collaborators with Israel. An Israeli army spokesman said four Palestinian laborers armed with knives stabbed a Jewish settler in the chest Friday while working in his orchard in the occupied West Bank. The victim was in fair condition. The army spokesman said the motive for the stabbing apparently was Palestinian nationalism. The attack came as the army continued to enforce widespread curfews in the occupied territories, confining more than a million Palestinians to their homes to prevent further violence. During this week's upsurge in violence, the army placed most of the occupied lands under curfew. Journalists were only allowed to enter with a military escort and could not roam freely.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Bodyguard Convicted of Murder
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Friday convicted Winnie Mandela's former chief bodyguard of murdering a black teen-ager after beating him at Mrs. Mandela's home while she was present. Jerry Richardson, 41, was found guilty of murdering 14-year-old black activist James Stompie Seipei Moeketsi on Jan. 1, 1989. He was also convicted of assaulting and kidnapping the teen-ager and three black men, who testified that Mrs. Mandela had beaten all of them with a whip and her fists on Dec. 29, 1988, and then allowed her bodyguards to continue the assaults. Mrs. Mandela is the wife of black leader Nelson Mandela. Richardson was also convicted of attempted murder in a case unrelated to Stompie's death. Supreme Court Justice Brian O'Donovan delayed sentencing Richardson until he receives a psychiatric report on Aug. 6. O'Donovan, commenting on the evidence, said whips with traces of human blood were found in the house, and blood matching one of the surviving victims was found on walls and curtains of a room in Mrs. Mandela's Soweto township home. Stompie's decomposed body, with three stab wounds in the neck, was found in a Soweto field on Jan. 6, 1989. It was not identified until after community leaders got the surviving victims out of the house and the case became public. O'Donovan ruled that most of the assaults occurred on Dec. 29, 1989. He added, ``I find that Mrs. Mandela was present on the 29th ... for at least part of the time.'' He said nothing else of her involvement. Mrs. Mandela has made no public statement on the case since last year, when she denied committing any crime or being home when any assaults took place. The court also heard evidence that Nelson Mandela had sent his attorney to Mrs. Mandela's home to try to get the three men released but had failed. Mandela was freed Feb. 11 after serving 27 years of a life term for sabotage and plotting the overthrow of the white minority government. He is now deputy president of the African National Congress, the leading group fighting South Africa's apartheid system of racial separation. Last year, leading black anti-apartheid activists accused Mrs. Mandela of complicity in the abductions and assaults, and they urged Soweto to shun her. A few months later, however, she reappeared on stage at anti-government rallies and has accompanied her husband in public since his release. Mandela accused the government Wednesday of deliberately defaming his wife by not charging her in a case that centers on her. However, Mandela said he was not saying the government should prosecute her. Eight former associates of Mrs. Mandela, including her driver and other bodyguards, are scheduled to face trial beginning next week on charges of abduction and assault with intent to do serious bodily harm in connection with the same case. If no extenuating circumstances are found for Richardson's actions, the death penalty is mandatory. However, President F.W. de Klerk suspended all death sentences in February as part of his program to encourage negotiations between the government and black groups. He is trying to bring blacks into the nation's political system. Though denying involvement, Mrs. Mandela has said the abductions were justified, claiming Stompie was staying at a church-run house where a Methodist priest was engaging in homosexual activity. However, O'Donovan said there was no evidence of homosexuality at the church-run house. He said Richardson had given no explanation for the assaults on Stompie. The witnesses testified Mrs. Mandela had accused the teen-ager of having been a police spy when he led an organization of youth activists in the Orange Free State.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Lashes Out at Lithuanian Leaders
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday branded the leaders of secessionist Lithuania ``adventurists'' and repeated his demand that they back down from their March 11 declaration of independence. ``We have great reserves of will power, but we are looking for ways'' to end the impasse, Gorbachev said at a news conference after meeting with visiting French President Francois Mitterrand. As a result of an economic embargo by the Kremlin, Lithuanian factories have been forced to close, throwing an estimated 19,000 people out of work. Lithuanian officials said hot water supplies throughout the Baltic republic were shut off Friday because regional distribution stations had run out of oil. Gorbachev repeated an appeal for the Lithuanians to follow a new Soviet law that requires a referendum for any of the 15 republics to secede. Lithuanian leaders say the law does not apply to them, as it was passed after they declared the republic independent. ``Let's return to March 10 and start the constitutional process,'' Gorbachev said at the news conference, broadcast live on Soviet television. Half-joking, the Soviet leader said the Lithuanians had decided ``not to make a gift to President Gorbachev on the eve of his visit to the United States.'' Gorbachev meets with President Bush next week in Washington. Gorbachev defended the use of army troops to occupy Communist Party buildings in Lithuania in March. He also defended the economic sanctions he has brought against the republic, which include shutting off oil and natural gas shipments. ``What happened in Lithuania was that a group of adventurists is speculating on such issues as independence,'' he said. ``I can say that in a similar situation, the American president would put the situation under control in 24 hours,'' he added. Gorbachev also has decreed that the other two Baltic states, Latvia and Estonia, violated Soviet law by making gradual moves toward independence without Moscow's approval. But Gorbachev has imposed economic sanctions only against Lithuania. He told Lithuanian legislators on Thursday that if the republic agreed to suspend its declaration of independence and follow Moscow's procedures for secession, Lithuania could gain independence in as little as two years, said one of the legislators, Vaidotas Antanaitis. Meanwhile, in the Latvian capital of Riga, legislative leaders rejected Gorbachev's recent order voiding their declaration of independence, a spokesman said. The presidium, or executive council, of Latvia's Supreme Council sent a telegram to Gorbachev saying he exceeded his authority May 14, when he issued a decree that Latvia's declaration was illegal, said legislative spokesman Ivars Embrekts. ``The constitution of the U.S.S.R. does not give the president of the U.S.S.R. the right to repeal laws or decisions which have been taken by the Supreme Council of the Republic of Latvia,'' the telegram said. ``The decree does not have the force of law in the republic.'' The three Baltic republics, forcibly annexed in 1940, are taking varied approaches toward secession. While Lithuania has proclaimed immediate independence, Estonia and Latvia are following a more cautious path by declaring a transition period. In the Estonian capital of Tallinn, centrist and radical deputies clashed Friday over what role the new Estonian Congress, elected by ethnic Estonians, should have in relation to the republic's traditional Supreme Soviet. The chairman of the new congress, Tunne Kelam, opened its session with a complaint that it was being ignored by the republic's Supreme Soviet legislature and given only an observer's role during the transition to independence, the Estonian news agency ETA reported. The Congress, with 499 representatives, has no formal political power, but considers itself the highest representative of ethnic Estonians living in the republic and abroad. ``We are not being allowed into the family room, where everyone else is,'' Kelam was quoted as saying. ``We are not an illegitimate son. We have the right to join our half-sister.'' Prime Minister Edgar Savisaar responded that giving the Congress the right to legislative power alongside the elected Supreme Soviet would result in a dual power structure. ``This can only work against us,'' Savisaar said. He also said Estonia should learn from Lithuania's experience. ``The events in Lithuania have sobered us up to the fact that the West is not about to help us to any great degree,'' the Estonian leader told the Congress. Despite a recent tour of Western capitals by Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, Lithuania has not been granted diplomatic recognition by the United States or European powers.

DOC.HEAD: Art Leaders Back NEA Grants
DOC.TEXT: A group of art supporters urged Congress on Friday to reauthorize the embattled National Endowment for the Arts without any provisions restricting federal support for works some may consider obscene. The panel, representing major organizations supporting the arts, issued a statement that also recommended no change in the method of distributing money to state arts councils for use in subsidizing artists. The panel was gathered by a key congressional supporter of the NEA, Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., in an effort to head off increasing criticism of the endowment in light of controversial grants for art many considered to be offensive. The arts groups said the NEA would not support obscene art. But at the same time it said the NEA should consider only artistic merit, and that obscenity was a matter to be left to the courts. ``The endowment can and should only determine artistic excellence. In our system of government only the courts can and should determine constitutional issues of obscenity,'' the art leaders said in their statement. ``Obscenity is without artistic merit, is unprotected by the First Amendment of the Constitution, and we do not support it.'' Williams, chairman of a House subcommittee considering legislation to continue the endowment, said he would support the proposals in hearings early next month. Williams invited the arts leaders to come up with suggestions, and the group met privately for four days. Williams told the group he believed it would be difficult to win congressional approval of a reauthorization that had no limits on the NEA's ability to fund obscene works. The Bush administration has backed legislation to renew the NEA in its present form for five years. An alternative proposal offered by Reps. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo., and Steve Gunderson, R-Wis., would distribute a majority of federal arts money directly to state arts agencies. The group's statement called for other changes in the NEA that include creating a new program of arts education and accessibility, to be paid for with a new appropriation of up to $40 million, and require policy meetings of the NEA's council on the arts be open to the public. Joining in the statement were 16 arts groups, including the American Council for the Arts, the National Assembly of State Arts Agencies and four independent citizens and artists. Recent debate over the NEA was triggered by several controversial artistic exhibits, including photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe of homosexual acts and nude children. The NEA had given $30,000 to a Philadelphia museum to show Mapplethorpe's work. Since then, an exhibit of his work by the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington was canceled, and a Cincinnati museum and its director were indicted on obscenity charges for displaying Mapplethorpe's pictures. A group of 61 House members wrote Bush urging him to support restrictions against federal funding of obscene, indecent or sacrilegious works.

DOC.HEAD: Violence in Nagorno-Karabakh Leaves 1 Soldier Dead, Four Injured
DOC.TEXT: Militants fired on soldiers in the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, killing one and injuring four others, Tass said Friday. The attackers first fired at a checkpoint in the Nagorno-Karabakh center of Stepanakert, gravely wounding private A. Gataulin, the official news agency said. An hour later that same day, Thursday, another checkpoint was attacked, but there were no casualties, Tass said. In a third incident, gunmen shot at a military patrol near a bus terminal, killing private V. Kirrilov and seriously injuring two other soldiers and a lieutenant, the report said. In an ensuing shootout, one of the gunmen, G. Khachaturyan, was killed and six others wounded. The report did not specify whether the attackers were Armenians or Azerbaijani but the name of the fatality was Armenian. It also did not say whether the same gunmen were involved in all the incidents. The predominantly Armenian enclave of Nagorno-Kharabakh has been at the center of a territorial dispute between Armenia and Azerbaijan for 2{ years. Four civilians were reported killed earlier this month in armed clashes in the border regions between Azerbaijan and Armenia. Among the victims were a 9-year-old boy and an elderly woman.

DOC.HEAD: Leader of West German Ultrarightist Party Quits
DOC.TEXT: Franz Schoenhuber, the ex-Nazi Waffen SS soldier whose ultrarightist Republicans became the shooting star of West German politics, quit as party leader Friday, complaining extremists had taken over. Mainstream politicians in Bonn said his decision marks the near-certain demise of one of Europe's most controversial political parties, which went from a mushrooming political force to a fringe group in disarray. Otto Lambsdorff, head of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's junior coalition partners, the Free Democrats, said Friday, ``The remains ... of this party will soon scatter themselves into the wind.'' The Republicans' main office in Munich said Schoenhuber's former deputy, Johanna Grund, 56, would replace him until a new chairperson is elected. Schoenhuber, 66, said ``small clique of extremist functionaries'' existed at top party levels and he was quitting because he felt unable to oppose them. His resignation further splintered a party already reeling from ideological bickering and from major election setbacks that reversed the party's meteroic rise. Schoenhuber led the Republicans to head-spinning fame last year, championing xenophobic and right-wing platforms to appeal to West Germans tired of competing with foreigners for scarce jobs and housing. Beginning with West Berlin in January 1989, the Republicans scored large gains in state and local elections and also won 7.2 percent in last June's elections for the European Parliament, landing Schoenhuber a seat there. But the wind went out of Schoenhuber's sails after the East German revolution last fall and the sudden realization that German reunification was no longer just a dream. With every mainstream party embracing unification, the Republicans lost much of their nationalist appeal. The party says its membership climbed from 18,000 to 26,000 the past year. Whatever their actual membership, it's clear their voter support has taken a beating. In recent state elections, the Republicans mustered less than 2 percent of the vote. They slipped badly in national polls _ far below the 5 percent needed to gain seats in the federal parliament in scheduled Dec. 2 elections. Schoenhuber told reporters in Munich he would try to create a new leadership to challenge his successor, but Republican officials said efforts were already under way among the leadership to oust Schoenhuber from the party. In recent days, Schoenhuber repeatedly cautioned that the party was heading too far right and was becoming an extremist right-wing group. His charges drew fire from other party leaders. Schoenhuber said Friday he could not take further responsibility for the party following clashes between police and party members during recent rallies for Oct. 14 Bavarian state parliamentary elections. He said he himself was withdrawing as a candidate for parliament in those elections. One Republican candidate, Franz Glasauer, was recently fined 5,000 marks ($2,975) for telling a rally a ``work camp'' should be created for ``riffraff and scum.'' He was charged under a law banning ``incitement of the public.'' Far-right political parties in West Germany have a history of fizzling out, unable to sustain strong membership in a nation where the Nazi past makes the electorate especially sensitive.

DOC.HEAD: Old Photo Helps Man Clear Record
LaserPhoto BX9
DOC.TEXT: A man who lost his college scholarship and his job when he was convicted of assaulting a police officer during an anti-war demonstration has cleared his name with a 20-year-old photograph. The photo, taken by a newspaper photographer but not published until this week, shows Malcolm Emory with an armload of books at about the time police said that he had thrown a rock. He had said he had just left the library. Emory, now 39, maintained he was wrongly convicted of the assault, which allegedly occurred during a protest at Northeastern University in 1970. He never served time for the offense, but the conviction cost him his college scholarship, his job doing research for the Navy and a promising future as a physicist. But this year, using a newspaper photograph taken at the protest, Emory got his conviction set aside and won a new trial. On Wednesday, the Suffolk County district attorney's office said it would drop the case rather than retry it. And on Thursday, Northeastern University awarded Emory, who has spent most of the last 20 years as a welder, a full scholarship to complete the physics studies he began there in 1969. ``It's a great relief. I'm very happy to have this solved,'' Emory said. A police officer, Vincent Logan, maintained that Emory threw a rock at police during the anti-war protest of Jan. 29, 1970. Emory said was attacked by the officer after he left the library and decided to take a look at the protest. Emory was arrested on a charge of assault and battery on a police officer. He was convicted on the testimony of Logan. He was given a six-month suspended sentence and put on probation for three years. He also lost his college scholarship and his Navy security clearance; he had been working his way through college as a government researcher. ``For the first few years, I was very angry about what had happened,'' Emory said. ``I really expected some sort of apology from Logan. But after four or five years and nothing was forthcoming, I realized I had to get on with my life.'' So after his probation ended, Emory became a welder and worked in machine shops and shipyards. While at the library five years ago, Emory found in the Boston Globe a front-page photograph that showed him surrounded by police in the midst of the 1970 demonstration. His books could not be seen in the photograph, but he hoped there might be others that would support his claim. He found that the Globe will release photographs only only if there is a subpoena. ``It was a legal catch-22,'' said his lawyer, John Legasey. ``You can only get a subpoena if there is a motion for a new trial. You can only move for a new trial if you have new evidence. And we only had new evidence if there was (another) photo. We needed a subpoena to find out.'' Last year, the Globe relented, and Emory found one picture of him holding his books as he was being dragged away by police. Superior Court Judge Sandra Hamlin ruled this year that the photograph provided sufficient grounds for a new trial. Logan, the arresting officer, continues to dispute Emory's story, saying he was careful to keep his eye on the person who threw the rock, which injured another officer standing near him. ``All I saw was blood splatter, and I keep my eye on the guy who throws the rock,'' he said. He said the photograph of Emory holding books was taken after his arrest, but he doesn't know where the books came from. Although he can never regain the life he lost, Emory says he hopes to finally finish his physics degree. He enrolled at Northeastern again last fall, and now with his full scholarship he hopes to complete his bachelor's degree next year. ``If this hadn't happened, I would have continued on in the same direction _ I would have been a physicist,'' Emory said. ``When I when to the library, that night, I expected to come back,'' he added. ``I'd never been involved in students protests, I wasn't politically active. I just wanted to study and come back. But I came back completely different.''

DOC.HEAD: Genscher, Baker Looking for Soviet Move on Conventional Weapons
DOC.TEXT: West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and Secretary of State James Baker said Friday they had signs Soviet leaders were willing to make progress in talks to cut conventional forces in Europe. Genscher said Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze told him earlier this week the Soviets are ``keen on concluding these negotiations soon.'' Baker called the meeting between Genscher and Shevardnadze significant. ``Now, time will tell,'' said Baker, who met last week with Shevardnadze and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. However, Gorbachev warned Friday that the Soviet Union would review its policies on European arms control and security negotiations if a reunited Germany joined NATO. Gorbachev's remarks contained the Kremlin's most dire warning about what steps it would take if a reunited Germany joins the Western military alliance. Baker, who made his comments before Gorbachev spoke in Moscow, said he didn't want to predict that U.S. and Soviet negotiators would make progress toward an arms cut as early as next week, when Gorbachev meets with President Bush in Washington. ``We have not seen a lot of progress over the course of the past few weeks, as you know. And we took note of that fact when I was in Moscow last week,'' Baker said. ``We need to see some concrete action, but I'm hopeful that we will begin to see that.'' Baker and Genscher said their discussions, coming barely eight days after the foreign minister was last in Washington with Chancellor Helmut Kohl for talks with Bush, also included plans for German unification and a summit conference of NATO leaders. ``We find ourselves in practically total agreement on all of these issues,'' Baker said. ``It's a rather amazing of degree of convergence of views, and represents the fact that we have spent quite a bit of time in very close consultation and cooperation in this period of rapid change in Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: Russian Lawmakers Vote for Yeltsin, Opponents for President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead prospects uncertain. Voting results may be available late Friday
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: Russian lawmakers cast ballots Friday night in a vote to determine whether populist Boris N. Yeltsin would become president of the Soviet Union's largest republic. Yeltsin, a onetime Gorbachev ally ousted two years ago as Moscow Communist Party chief after calling for faster reform, gained a double boost Friday. Russian deputies and Soviet media praised a key campaign speech he made, and the candidate backed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev withdrew. But Yeltsin, 59, needs backing from 531 of the 1,059 members of the Russian Congress, more than he himself has estimated he could count on. Official results from voting late Friday are expected by Saturday morning. The candidate backed by Gorbachev, Russian premier Alexander Vlasov, withdrew from the race after it became clear he lacked Yeltsin's popularity. Vlasov's departure left Ivan Polozkov, a Communist Party chief from the southern Russia city of Krasnodar, as Yeltsin's main rival. The third remaining candidate, aviation instructor Vladimir Morokin, did not appear to have any chance of winning. Russia, by far the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, comprises more than two-thirds of the country's territory. It is home to half the Soviet populace. A Yeltsin victory would mean an important setback for Gorbachev, who has clashed repeatedly with his former protege. Gorbachev spoke out Wednesday against Yeltsin's plan for increased Russian autonomy, claiming it would mean ``the breakup of the Soviet Union.'' Yeltsin, however, pledged Friday that if elected, he would defend the republic from Moscow interference while not letting personal conflicts interfere with his Kremlin dealings. ``I am for business-like relations, dialogue and negotiations with the president and the government, but on the principle that Russia's sovereignty is not damaged,'' Yeltsin told the Russian Congress. The Russians use the term ``sovereignty'' to mean increased autonomy _ not secession. With his bass voice booming through the hall of the Great Kremlin Palace, Yeltsin pressed a point-by-point program on promoting for Russian sovereignty, unleashing market forces, increasing housing and flooding stores with consumer goods. ``Vremya,'' the nightly news program on state-run Soviet television, gave Yeltsin high marks for his platform. ``Having heard all the contenders, I can say his program for the rebirth of Russia came off the best-argued and thought-through,'' the Vremya report said. ``The people believe in Boris Nikolayevich Yeltsin,'' deputy Nina Sivova told the Congress. ``His great force of will is needed today.'' In an early indication of Yeltsin's plans if he wins, his speech blasted the government program announced Thursday for a transition to a free market economy. He said it had ``already created panic in the stores today.'' Instead, he backed an alternative program involving sale of government property, full independence for enterprises, more liberal laws on ownership and foreign loans. Yeltsin is already a member of the national Congress of People's Deputies and a member of the Communist Party Central Committee. He has made a remarkable political comeback from disgrace two years ago, when he was ousted from his post as Moscow party chief and ostracized by the Kremlin elite, including Gorbachev. Yeltsin has continued to level public blasts of criticism at Gorbachev for his ``halfway reforms.'' If no one wins more than 50 percent of the vote in the first round, the election goes into a runoff between the top two vote-getters.

DOC.HEAD: Doonesbury Comic Strip Character Dies of AIDS
DOC.TEXT: The death of a ``Doonesbury'' character who suffered from AIDS didn't prompt any angry phone calls, the strip's syndicator said Friday. Universal Press Syndicate has received complaints about ``Doonesbury'' in the past and once did not distribute strips that dealt with abortion. The strip was created by Garry Trudeau. ``It wasn't a big shock at all,'' said Lee Salem, editorial director for Universal Press. ``I think Garry is always known for dealing with major issues of social concern, and I think the way our society copes with AIDS is certainly within that.'' The character Andy Lippincott, who has appeared in the strip since 1976, died in the panels that appeared in Thursday's newspapers. The character, who was gay, began as a law school student and evolved into an attorney and a political aide to another character. ``It's not the first time in Doonesbury that a character died,'' Salem said. ``Dick Davenport, another character, died a few years ago of a heart attack.'' But Andy's death was apparently the first time AIDS killed a comic strip figure. Andy was diagnosed with AIDS in the strip in early 1989.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Leader Urges U.N. to Send Emergency Force Into Occupied Lands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6 grafs for 15-18 bgng `The council's' to UPDATE with Israeli comment at U.N. session, meeting ending; pickup graf 19 `The session...' Minor editing thereafter to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos GEV6,7
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat urged the U.N. Security Council on Friday to send an emergency force to protect Arabs in the Israeli-occupied territories from a ``war of extermination.'' Opening an emergency council session, Arafat called for an end to Israel's 23-year-old occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, a ban on Jewish settlements in the territories, and international sanctions against Israel. The violence ``has reached an extremely dangerous and explosive point,'' the Palestine Liberation Organization chief said. ``The situation now requires urgent action in order to enforce reverence for international legitimacy,'' he said. ``Over 30 months, the Israeli occupation forces have been waging a war of extermination on all fronts.'' Arafat said the Palestinian uprising, which began in December 1987, would continue until Israel is ousted from the occupied areas _ home to 1.7 million Palestinians. He urged appointment of a permanent U.N. envoy to monitor the situation, a Security Council investigation into ``all crimes'' allegedly committed by Israel against Palestinians, and immediate preparations for an international Middle East peace conference. Initial responses from other delegates were largely non-committal. France and the Soviet Union said the council should consider a U.N. observer force. In Israel, a top aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Arafat's speech was ``full of lies and distortions.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III reiterated in Washington the United States' opposition tostationing a U.N. observer force in the territories but said the ``idea of the secretary-general sending one of his top aides to take a look at the situation and return is something quite different.'' Baker also said he believed some people misinterpreted a statement he made Wednesday, when he said the Bush administration was willing to discuss sending observers into the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The comment had touched off speculation the United States would support permanent observers. Asked to appraise Arafat's speech, Baker said he had not read it. Arab delegations called the emergency meeting of the 15-nation Security Council to consider ways to quell a surge of Arab-Israeli clashes in the territories and Israel. The violence followed the killing of seven unarmed Arab workers by an Israeli on Sunday. Arafat challenged Israel's claim that Sunday's killings were the act of an isolated madman, saying ``the primary responsibility falls on the insanity and derangement of the whole system.'' Israeli Deputy Foreign Minister Benyamin Netanyahu rejected sending observers, which he called a bid to end Israel's role ``as the responsible governing power in the territories.'' ``What we are now facing is a further attempt to delegitimize Israel and Jewish immigration to it,'' he told the council. The council's session was shifted from New York to Geneva to allow Arafat to speak. Arab delegations wanted to avoid a showdown with the United States, which has barred the PLO chief from entry in the past. It was the second time in 18 months a U.N. session was moved to Geneva from the world body's New York headquarters so Arafat could address it. In December 1988, Arafat addressed the U.N. General Assembly to renounce terrorism and acknowledge Israel's right to exist _ meeting two U.S. demands that led to the opening of a dialogue between the PLO and the United States. After a six-hour debate, the council session was adjourned until Saturday with no decisions made. The session is likely to resume Tuesday in New York, U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliani said. For his first speech to the Security Council, Arafat wore his traditional kaffiyeh Arab headdress and military uniform. French ambassador Pierre-Louis Blanc said the council should consider sending a U.N. fact-finding mission to the occupied territories. He urged Israel to accept such a mission, which could come up with concrete proposals on the ``establishment of U.N. observers'' in the area. Soviet Ambassador Yuli Vorontsov also backed sending international observers, who would later become a permanent body in the occupied territories. Britain said it was ready ``to look at proposals for further U.N. involvement to ease the tense situation'' and appealed for restraint by both Israel and Palestinians. Clovis Maksoud, the Arab League ambassador, told a news conference he supports international monitoring ``broadly along the lines put forward'' by Arafat. In his five-point proposal, Arafat urged the Security Council to adopt a resolution ``to provide international protection to the Palestinian people, to safeguard their lives, properties and holy places in the occupied territories under the flag of the United Nations and by means of international emergency forces.'' Arafat did not elaborate on what kind of forces he meant. He also urged the deployment of a U.N. observer force ``with the purpose of ending completely the Israeli occupation.'' The permanent members of the Security Council, which have veto power, are the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, Franc and China. Current temporary members are Canada, Colombia, Ivory Coast, Yemen, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, Malaysia, Romania and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Who Ditched Plane Over Atlantic Faces FCC Disbarment
DOC.TEXT: The Washington attorney who ditched his plane in the Atlantic Ocean last summer was ordered Friday to show why he shouldn't be disbarred from practicing before the Federal Communications Commission. In the interim, Thomas L. Root has been suspended from practicing law before the commission, the FCC said. The commission said it had acted because the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia entered an order April 12 disbarring Root by consent. FCC rules require that attorneys practicing before it not be under any disbarment order. Telephone calls to Root's office Friday went unanswered. In March, Root was indicted on 33 counts of fraud and other crimes involving radio stations he was representing before the FCC. The federal indictment accused Root of defrauding the government and five clients in FCC proceedings on permits to construct FM radio stations throughout the United States. Root gained notoriety last July when his single-engine plane ran out of fuel and plunged into the Atlantic off the Bahamas following a six-hour, 800-mile flight that began near Washington. He told authorities that he had been unconscious for most of the odyssey, but Navy fighter pilots flying alongside the plane reported seeing him move in the cockpit. When he was taken to a Florida hospital, Root was found to have suffered a gunshot wound to the abdomen. Less than a week after the crash, Sonrise Management Services of Columbus, Ga., sued Root for $584,000, claiming he failed to perform work and double-billed a client. Root filed for bankruptcy court protection from creditors in October 1989, claiming he had $1.64 million in liabilities. The federal indictment charged Root with 20 counts of wire and mail fraud, seven counts of filing false legal documents with the FCC, four counts of using counterfeit and altered federal documents, and one count each of forgery and obstruction of the grand jury's investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Real Estate Man Links Imelda Marcos to New York Properties
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos was almost certainly the owner of four Manhattan commercial buildings, a real estate developer testified Friday. Victor Politis, recalling a meeting where Mrs. Marcos was briefed on the status of the buildings, said he would ``have to consider myself a fool'' not to believe she was the owner. Defense attorneys expressed private dismay, conceding the testimony may have been a sharp setback to Mrs. Marcos' claim that she was never involved in the dealings. Under an increasingly hostile cross-examination by her attorney, Gerry Spence, the prosecution witness said Mrs. Marcos never spoke to him but that her closest friend had confided that she was the ``principal,'' or owner, of the buildings. ``You don't have the slightest idea whether what Mrs. (Gliceria) Tantoco told you was true or not, do you?'' Spence demanded in the hushed courtroom. ``If I had not met Mrs. Marcos and she had not acted like the owner, you would be right,'' Politis replied. ``But I would have to consider myself a fool not to put two and two together.'' Mrs. Marcos is charged with fraud and embezzlement. She is alleged to have helped her late husband, former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos, steal more than $220 million from their country's treasury. The money was allegedly used to support a luxury lifestyle and investments, including the four secretly purchased New York properties. Earlier, a Geneva attorney testified that Mrs. Marcos reportedly met as recently as two weeks ago with a Swiss lawyer hired to fight the Philippine government's effort to seize billions of dollars allegedly stashed in Swiss banks by her and her late husband. Sergio Salvioni, a Swiss lawyer representing the Manila government, said he was told of the New York meeting by Bruno DePreux, who he said had identified himself as representing the former Philippine first lady. Under questioning by assistant U.S. attorney Charles LaBella, Salvioni quoted DePreux as saying he originally was hired to represent both Mrs. Marcos and her husband, following Marcos' ouster in early 1986. Marcos died last year in Hawaiian exile. ``And now he represents Mrs. Marcos and her heirs,'' Salvioni said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses To Dismiss Charges Against Mayor
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with rulings by judge; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Friday refused to dismiss criminal charges or suppress videotapes in the drug case against Mayor Marion Barry. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson rejected defense arguments that the government engaged in prosecutorial vindictiveness in bringing two indictments against the Washington, D.C., mayor since February. Barry is scheduled to go to trial June 4 on cocaine possession, conspiracy and perjury charges. There was no evidence of ``actual vindictiveness'' by the government, the judge said in ruling on a series of pre-trial motions. Defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy alleged the government jeopardized Barry's life by with the FBI sting operation Jan. 18 at the Vista Hotel designed to coerce him into smoking crack cocaine. But ``no violence occurred, and no coercion was employed'' in the Vista incident, the judge said in refusing to throw out the charges. The judge said the FBI videotapes from the Vista were taken with the permission of the room's occupant, ex-model Rasheeda Moore, who cooperated with the government to persuade Barry to come there. Jackson refused to bar the government from using the videotapes at the trial. Jackson's decisions came at the end of a day of courtroom arguments on aspects of the 14-count indictment. ``I feel very good about today,'' Barry said afterwards. ``We're ready to go to trial.'' A Feb. 15 indictment accused Barry of cocaine possession in the sting operation, and with four other misdemeanor counts of possessing cocaine and three felony counts of lying to a federal grand jury. A superseding indictment adding five new possession charges and a conspiracy charge was returned May 10. The government on Friday provided Barry with a list of the alleged co-conspirators and agreed to provide the times and places of the alleged cocaine possessions. Mundy will decide by Tuesday whether he wants to ask for the six new charges to be separated from the earlier counts, which would mean having a second trial at a later date. On the political front, Barry campaign officials said they intend to pick up petitions for the upcoming mayoral race. Such a move would be the first formal step Barry can take to enter the Sept. 11 Democratic primary. The Washington Post said Friday a poll showed Barry has suffered no significant erosion in his political base since his arrest. He and Councilman John Ray were tied with 23 percent each of the 760 Democrats polled by the newspaper about their preference for the Democratic mayoral nomination. The rest were split among four other challengers. Barry has not publicly disclosed his political plans but has made a series of campaign-style appearances across the District of Columbia in recent weeks. Top Barry political aides, speaking on condition of anonymity, say the mayor intends to seek a fourth, four-year term. Mundy said a cardiologist had concluded ``there was a high risk'' to the ``life of Mr. Barry when the government offered him 89 percent pure crack cocaine.'' Mundy said ``three very heavy drinks'' of cognac were poured ``just before the crack cocaine was smoked'' during Barry's videotaped hotel room visit. FBI agents who burst into the room to arrest the mayor told Barry to stay calm, that a doctor was present and that ``we are aware of your prior cardiac problems,'' said Mundy. Barry has no history of heart trouble, according to medical records the mayor released last year. Mundy wanted the cardiologist to testify, but the judge said his testimony would be ``legally irrelevant'' and denied the request.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Asks For Nuclear Update
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has asked the heads of the three national defense laboratories to explain their new concerns about the safety of a short-range nuclear missile carried aboard strategic bombers, the Pentagon said Friday. The directors, in congressional testimony Wednesday that apparently caught some administration officials by surprise, called for the withdrawal of the weapons, suggesting they could leak plutonium in an accident. The weapons are known as the Short-Range Attack Missile-A, or SRAM-A, and are carried on the B-1B, B-52 and FB-111A bombers and is armed with a warhead known as the W-79. ``I have asked the Secretary of Energy and the directors of the three national laboratories to brief me on their latest views of the safety of the weapon, which the laboratory directors apparently discussed with Congress earlier this week. If there is new information about the SRAM-A, I want to hear it,'' Cheney said in a statement released by the Pentagon. On Thursday, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said the SRAM-A meets all safety standards, but said a study was under way that included looking into whether the weapons might be removed from the bombers. The weapons will remain on the bombers pending the outcome of the study, Williams said. Cheney's statement said that the safety of the warhead had been reviewed in the summer of 1989, and that based on that review, some handling procedures were modified. ``After that review, Secretary Cheney was assured that the weapon was safe,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Leader to Receive Martin Luther King Peace Prize
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was named Friday as the 1991 recipient of the Martin Luther King Jr. Nonviolent Peace Prize. The award will be presented to Gorbachev on June 1 at the Soviet Embassy in Washington, said Coretta Scott King, chief executive officer of The King Center and widow of the slain civil rights leader for whom the prize is named. ``No world leader has done more than President Gorbachev to de-escalate the arms race and pave the way for greater democracy and economic freedom around the world,'' Mrs. King said. The annual award includes a medal bearing the likeness of King, a citation and a $1,000 stipend. The '91 award is being presented early so that it can be given to Gorbachev during his U.S. visit, said King Center spokesman Steve Klein. The 1990 recipient was the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, the civil rights group founded by King.

DOC.HEAD: Tennessee Derailment Could Have Been Worse, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: A freight train derailment and explosion that forced the evacuation of 750 people could have posed a greater danger if it had occurred just two miles farther down the line, authorities said Friday. Fifteen cars of a 90-car Illinois Central train derailed in a rural area on the southern edge of this western Tennessee city of 6,100 at 10:30 p.m. Thursday, authorities said. One tanker filled with ethyl alcohol exploded, and three other cars caught fire, but no one was hurt. ``We were lucky it occurred there and not two miles away in downtown Covington,'' said Cecil Whaley, operation officer for the Tennessee Emergency Management Agency in Nashville. Whaley said the biggest concentration of people that had to be evacuated was 193 from a nursing home on U.S. Highway 51, which runs parallel to the train tracks. ``We were very fortunate there were no injuries,'' he said. ``The cars that piled up were almost on top of each other. ... There was tremendous damage to the train bed itself.'' The cause of the accident was under investigation Friday by a field representative from the Chicago office of the National Transportation Safety Board and officers from the Tennessee Public Service Commission. The NTSB in Washington said it was unlikely the cause would be determined quickly. ``We can't say a lot until we develop information at the scene,'' said Dave Watson of the NTSB's railroad division. People within a three-mile radius of the accident site were evacuated, but were returning to their homes Friday. The exploded tanker and the two other cars that caught fire were left to burn themselves out overnight. One was still burning Friday afternoon. Of the derailed cars, eight contained denatured alcohol, and the rest contained rock, soybeans and corn, said Covington Police Chief Jerry Craig. Routine tests on the train's crew for drug or alcohol use would be sent to a laboratory chosen by the Federal Railway Administration, said Tom Utroska, transportation superintendent at Illinois Central's Chicago office. There were no reports from the scene that the crew was impaired, he said. Roy Davis, assistant superintendent of transportation for Illinois Central, said the train originated in Champaign, Ill. It was headed to Memphis, 40 miles southwest of Covington. Lt. Mike Craig of the Covington Fire Department said railroad traffic would have to be rerouted. ``There's no way they can get through here,'' he said. ``It just completely mangled the rails. They're backed up from here to I don't know where.'' Nellie Wilson, business manager of the Covington Manor Nursing Home, said local people helped evacuate the residents by school buses and ambulances. ``Local authorities and the community came together and were just wonderful,'' she said. Denise Edmundson, a floral designer, said she returned to her floral shop Thursday night to check on damage from the explosion. ``The sky was lit up with fire,'' she said. ``It was awesome.''

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Rights Groups Makes Iowa Endorsement
DOC.TEXT: An abortion rights group Friday endorsed Democrat Don Avenson for governor, saying pro-choice forces should unite behind a single candidate in the Democratic primary even though two of three candidates support abortion rights. ``The stakes are too high for pro-choice leaders to remain on the sidelines,'' said Shelley Bain, head of the Iowa affiliate of the National Abortion Rights Action League. The group picked Avenson over former banker John Chrystal, another pro- choice Democrat. Avenson, speaker of the Iowa House; Chrystal; and Attorney General Tom Miller, an opponent of abortion, are all running in the June 5 Democratic primary. After the Avenson endorsement, an angry Chrystal called NARAL ``tin-horn, would-be kingmakers from Washington.'' ``Iowa Democrats won't let these would-be kingmakers tell them how to vote,'' Chrystal said in a statement. He said NARAL ``does not in any sense represent the views of Iowa voters concerned about freedom of choice.'' Miller echoed that sentiment, labeling the group an ``outside, narrow, negative, single-interest group with their own agenda.'' Avenson called the reaction of the other Democrats ``sour grapes'' and said ``every one of them would love to have it. But once we got it, there's something wrong with it.'' The primary is the first major election in Iowa since the U.S. Supreme Court last summer handed states new freedom to restrict abortions. The exchange illustrates why many pro-choice activists worry that Avenson and Chrystal will split the pro-choice vote and give Miller the nomination. Ms. Bain said that political analysis brought the NARAL endorsement. ``We were looking for a candidate we believed could win the election on June 5 and also win against Terry Branstad in November,'' she said. Branstad, the Republican incumbent, is unopposed in the GOP primary. Like Miller, he is an opponent of abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Showers, Thunderstorms Across Much of the Nation
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms fell Friday in sections of the Midwest, the Northwest, and the Northeast, including a storm that dropped marble-size hail on a southern Illinois town. Rain fell over much of southern Indiana, and in the southwest part of the state the Wabash River was at its highest levels in 21 years. Showers and thunderstorms fell in west central New England and in parts of Kentucky, North Carolina, Ohio, Illinois, Iowa, West Virginia, New York, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Texas, Montana, Florida and Missouri. Marble-size hail fell in Chester, Ill, and rain was heavy in northwest North Dakota. Snow was mixed with rain at higher elevations in Montana. A severe thunderstorm watch was in effect in southwest Kentucky as well as western and central Tennessee. The low for the Lower 48 states was 24 degrees at Burns, Ore. Temperatures at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 35 degrees at Yellowstone National Park, Wyo., to 101 degrees at Midland, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Rejects Final Appeal of Ceausescu's Top Henchmen
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Friday rejected the final appeal by four of Nicolae Ceausescu's top henchmen against life sentences for backing the Communist dictator's order to shoot in the December revolution, the state news agency Rompres reported. The four were convicted of genocide on Feb. 2 at the first major trial of top officials of the Ceausescu regime and sentenced to life imprisonment. Emil Bobu, 62, former secretary of the Communist Party and third-ranking member of Ceausescu's leadership; former state council vice-president Manea Manescu, 74; politburo member Ion Dinca, 64; and former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu, 59, admitted they backed Ceausescu's orders to put down the uprising. The prosecution said they could have ended Ceausescu's 24-year hold on power and prevented bloodshed. Rompres said the maximum life sentences on the four defendants would remain. The military court at their trial ordered the seizure of all property including gold, jewels and large sums of money, and stripped them of their civil rights. In March, the four ex-officials won a postponement of their appeal after lawyers argued the need for international research for the first such case in Romania's history. The prosecution agreed on grounds the defense should have all necessary information. During the appeal, heard in April, Postelnicu's lawyer argued that the interior minister was guilty of a lesser charge and Manescu's lawyer asked that all charges against him be dismissed. Postelnicu burst into tears asking for a 15-20 year prison term. He told the court he did not try to absolve himself of guilt and of the responsibility his position implied. ``I am a bloody sinner and handicapped. Please do not think that I try to play the hero now but I ordered them not to shoot at workers,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Husband Rejects Suggestion To Donate Embryos
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 10th graf, `In it...', to add that Mrs. Stowe won't disclose reason for change. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `If faced...'.
