DOC.TEXT: A woman's decision to donate seven frozen embryos she won in a custody fight, rather than use them to become pregnant, does not end the battle, her ex-husband said Friday. ``I am totally against it,'' Junior Lewis Davis, who produced the sperm for the embryos, said of his ex-wife's decision to donate them to another childless couple. ``There is just no way I am going to donate them,'' Davis said. ``I feel that's my right. If there was a child from them, then I would be a parent to it. And I don't want a child out there to be mine if I can't be a parent to it.'' Davis, 31, and his ex-wife, Mary Sue Davis Stowe, 29, have been locked in a legal battle over the four-to-eight-cell embryos conceived through in vitro fertilization in 1988 while they were still married. In the only contested issue in their divorce, Blount County Circuit Judge W. Dale Young ruled in September that temporary custody of the embryos should go to Mrs. Stowe, who at the time said she wanted to try to bring a child to term. The judge, taking the unprecedented step of ruling that ``life begins at conception,'' accorded the embryos the same rights as children. He said it would be in the embryos' best interests to be with Mrs. Stowe. Davis has appealed the decision, which touched off a nationwide debate on its impact on reproductive rights. The Tennessee Court of Appeals scheduled oral arguments for June 6. Mrs. Stowe, who agreed she would not try to become pregnant with the embryos until the case is settled, filed a response Thursday to Davis' appeal. In it, her attorney, Kurt Erlenbach, wrote that if the court rules in her favor ``her intention ... is not to implant the embryos. She wants authority to donate the embryos so another childless couple may use them. Erlenbach's wife and law partner, Susan Erlenbach, said that Mrs. Stowe did not wish to disclose her reasons for deciding not to have the frozen embryos implanted. ``All I can say is it's been a long and painful process in making the decision,'' Mrs. Erlenbach said Friday from her office in Titusville, Fla., where Mrs. Stowe now lives. ``If faced with the options of implantation or destruction through non-use, (Mrs. Stowe) would strongly argue for the right to implant the embryos,'' Erlenbach's brief said. ``The former Mrs. Davis seeks in this case only to preserve what she has created while Mr. Davis seeks to destroy the potential for life he very willingly and intentionally created.'' But Davis said, ``That was very willingly and intentionally only on the grounds of marriage in trying to produce a child. ``They need to be disposed of. In my view, they are not life. I realize they are the potential for life, no matter how small the percentage (of successful pregnancy) is. But they are not life.'' Davis said his position has nothing to do with concern over any potential legal obligations to children born from the embryos. ``It's really that it is my right to decide if I want to become a parent,'' he said. Davis' appeal and a friend-of-the-court brief by the American Civil Liberties Union argues that Young overstepped the bounds of Tennessee law and the U.S. Constitution in his ruling. ``Because Judge Young's decision is inconsistent with the existing laws, if not reversed, it will give rise to future anomalous and absurd legal quagmires,'' Davis' appeal said. ``Forty-eight-hour-(old), fertilized embryos kept frozen will enjoy enhanced protection, while first trimester fetuses will continue to be aborted,'' the appeal said. Mrs. Stowe's response contends that the case has nothing to do with abortion rights or parental privacy rights, and has no impact beyond the fight between herself and her ex-husband.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Robbery And State Trooper Wounding Suspects Elude Capture
DOC.TEXT: Police on Friday called off an intense air and ground hunt for two men suspected of shooting and wounding a state trooper, briefly kidnapping a mother of three, and robbing a savings and loan in Nebraska. About 100 officers cordoned off a square mile of rural country west of here within 90 minutes of the shooting Thursday afternoon, but didn't find the suspects. ``We were about 30 minutes behind them, though,'' Sedgwick County Sheriff Mike Hill said Friday morning. ``We now believe they probably are no longer in that area.'' Highway Patrol Trooper Jeff Hersh was in good condition Friday in a Wichita hospital. He was shot at least six times, in the abdomen, arm and neck. Other bullets were stopped by his bulletproof vest. The kidnap victim escaped unharmed. Hersh was shot after stopping a speeding car at 3:45 p.m. Thursday on Interstate 135 about eight miles north of downtown Wichita _ without knowing its occupants were suspected of having robbed a savings and loan in Omaha that morning. As he approached the car to write a ticket, one of two men inside opened fire with a 9mm pistol. Hersh returned fire, apparently wounding one suspect, authorities said. The trooper was able to talk to officers who came to his aid. ``He was conscious. He was able to give us good information,'' said patrol Sgt. George Westphal. The suspects drove off and headed south for about a mile, then left the highway and pulled into the driveway of a house near the suburb of Valley Center at about 4 p.m. One man went into the house and confronted a baby sitter and three children. A few minutes later, the children's mother, Kathy George, 35, arrived home. The suspect pushed Mrs. George around and ordered her into the family van, which the two men then drove off. The suspects left their car in the George driveway, where it was later found by police. After heading southwest for about an hour, the van hit a bump on a rural road that jarred open the back door, said Mrs. George's husband, Mike. When one suspect got out to close the door, Mrs. George jumped out and ran, her husband said. She ran about a quarter-mile to a home and called for help. The van was found abandoned near where she escaped, about three miles west of Wichita. Officers swarmed the area to search wheat fields and hedgerows with two airplanes, helicopters, dogs and horses. ``We really feel like we've done the best we can at this point both on the ground and in the air, so we're going to call it off,'' Wichita Police Chief Rick Stone said Friday morning.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Indicted In Death of Child; Advocates for Battered Women Object
DOC.TEXT: In a child abuse case that has sparked an outcry from advocates for battered women, a woman and her former husband have been indicted in the beating death of the woman's 2-year-old son. A Travis County grand jury on Thursday returned indictments against Robbi Zuliani and Gerald Christopher Zuliani, both 23. Zuliani is accused of beating Christopher Wohlers, Ms. Zuliani's son from a previous marriage, and slamming him into a bathroom wall on Jan. 2. The toddler died the next day. The boy had been hospitalized Dec. 22 after apparently being abused, but was returned to the Zulianis, according to a Department of Human Services investigation and a probe by the Texas attorney general's office. Ms. Zuliani is accused of murder for failing to protect the child or remove him. She and her ex-husband both face up to 99 years in prison if convicted. It wasn't the first time criminal charges had been brought in connection with abuse of the the boy. Last summer, Ms. Zuliani's then-boyfriend, Wayne Michael Hoffman, pleaded guilty to charges that he forced the boy to sit in scalding water. He was sentenced to 10 years in prison. Ms. Zuliani married Gerald Zuliani in December and divorced him last month. She has said she was the victim of repeated abuse from Zuliani and did not intervene for her child because she was afraid for herself and her 4-year-old daughter. A psychologist has testified that Ms. Zuliani has a dependent personality disorder and suffers from post-traumatic stress syndrome. The charges against her triggered a courthouse protest by people carrying signs that said: ``Stop Blaming the Victim'' and ``Arrest Criminals, Not Battered Women.'' The fact that the child was abused by a previous mate does not make Ms. Zuliani any more to blame, said Kimberly Bryant, vice chairman of a group called the Formerly Battered Women's Task Force. ``That just indicates how serious of a cycle of victimization that any battered woman can be in,'' she said. But District Attorney Ronnie Earle said ``the law provides for the same kind of punishment whether the crime is done by act or by omission.'' He added, however, that ``it doesn't mean we will seek the same punishment'' for the two defendants. She could be placed on probation, he said. Zuliani remains in the Travis County Jail in lieu of $50,000 bond. Ms. Zuliani is free on bond.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Pushes Soviets on NATO Membership for a United Germany
With AM-Gorbachev-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl urged Moscow on Friday to stop fighting NATO membership for a united Germany, saying history shows European stability is best assured when Germany is firmly anchored to an alliance. ``There must be no second Versailles,'' said Kohl, referring to the 1919 treaty that resulted in German isolation and paved the way for the rise of Nazism. Speaking at the end of a 113-nation disarmament conference in Bonn, Kohl also said he favors reducing nuclear weapons in Europe to a minimum but not their complete removal. He was addressing the International Parliamentary Union, which is made up of federal lawmakers from around the world who meet periodically to discuss disarmament and other matters. The organization has no actual powers. The Soviet Union rejects NATO's demand that a united Germany belong to the Western alliance. But Kohl said such membership was actually in the best interests of the Soviet Union and all Europe. ``The first and most important lesson which history has taught us is that peace, stability and security were guaranteed in Europe whenever Germany ... maintained firm bonds with its neighbors .. . in a relationship marked by mutually beneficial exchanges,'' said Kohl. Alluding to two world wars waged by the Germans, Kohl added, ``Whenever Germany chose _ out of overbearing blindness or criminal hubris _ to pursue a separate path or when former enemies forced it into isolation following its defeat, the immediate consequence for Europe was conflict, instability and uncertainty. ``For this reason, there can be no thought of united Germany being neutral, demilitarized or non-aligned. ``We Germans therefore want to exercise our sovereign right: we want to belong to an alliance, namely to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.'' Kohl said only NATO ``can create true equilibrium in Europe.'' In East Berlin, East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere said he would like to see a new ``collective European security system'' with a united Germany as member. It was not clear if de Maiziere was saying he opposed at least temporary NATO membership for a united Germany until such a security system is created. De Maiziere has been vague on the issue. Kohl sought to soothe Soviet worries about a shift in the European balance of power after unification, saying NATO does not ``wish to gain any unilateral advantage.'' But he also indirectly criticized the Soviets for slower progress at conventional forces negotiations in Vienna. ``I appeal to all participants: do not squander the historic opportunity to make headway now in Europe toward a more secure and stable balance of conventional forces at lower levels,'' Kohl said. He said Germans will continue to ``renounce the possession, manufacture and control of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons.'' The chancellor said he favors not only keeping U.S. troops in Europe, but keeping nuclear weapons on the Continent. He said NATO's nuclear capability has ``guaranteed the longest period of peace in modern history in Europe.'' Kohl proposed a summit every two years of leaders of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and creation of ``pan-European institutions'' such as a ``conflict prevention center'' and one for the ``verification of arms control agreements.'' Earlier Friday, Kohl's government renewed its warning that delays in the planned July 2 economic merger with East Germany could trigger discontent among the East German populace.

DOC.HEAD: Romania's New Leader Calls for Freer Markets
DOC.TEXT: Ion Iliescu, the first ex-Communist to win a popular presidential election in Eastern Europe, pledged Friday to begin dismantling centralized planning in favor of freer markets. Also Friday, final official results from Sunday's election gave Iliescu a landslide 85 percent of the vote in Romania's first free election in 53 years. Iliescu, 60, a former Communist Party Politburo member, said Parliament's main task will be to write a new constitution the next two years. Iliescu's National Salvation Front, which won two-thirds of the seats in the two-chamber Parliament, has enough votes to draft the document singlehandedly. Now that he is president-elect, Iliescu announced he would resign as the Front's president. He said it was up to the members of the Front to choose a new president. In the final tally announced Friday, Iliescu's strongest rival, Radu Campeanu of the National Liberal Party, won only 10 percent of the vote. Ion Ratiu of the National Peasant Party came in third with 4 percent. In the Chamber of Deputies, the Front received 66 percent of the vote. The Hungarian Democratic Union, with just over 7 percent of the vote, emerged as the biggest opposition party, reflecting the unity of Romania's 2 million ethnic Hungarians. In the Senate, the Front gained 67 percent, and the Hungarian Democratic Union took 7 percent. Iliescu was vague Friday on his plans for his new government to be announced in 20 days. ``The coming period will ... be complicated for the country's economy, social life and political climate,'' he added. ``Measures should be elaborated ...to move from a rigid centralized economy to a market economy.'' Iliescu said the Front would spearhead the fight against corruption, which he said had worsened since the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. However, Iliescu's earlier call for a broad coalition government appeared to be drawing little support. ``I believe that we are going to make a constructive opposition,'' said Hungarian Democratic Union leader Geza Domokos. The Liberals said Friday they plan to take their seats in Parliament, despite charges of election fraud. They said they favor a united opposition. ``We will firmly contribute to the establishment of genuine democracy in Romania,'' their statement said. ``We will collaborate with all forces joining in the struggle against totalitarian structures. We think a realistic parliamentary opposition must be formed.'' In another development, six anti-government groups occupying University Square for more than a month said in a statement Friday they didn't want hunger strikers supporting them to die and therefore wanted to change the nature of their protest. However, one protest leader, Marian Andrusca, said, ``We will not leave the square, and we do not agree with the communique.''

DOC.HEAD: Shooting Death of Former Devotee Was Key in Indictment, U.S. Attorney Says
DOC.TEXT: The shooting death of a disillusioned devotee played a key role in the indictment of a Hare Krishna swami and two followers on murder and racketeering charges, a federal prosecutor said Friday. The indictment Thursday by a special federal grand jury in Elkins charged that Kirtanananda Swami Bhaktipada, 54, previously known as Keith Ham, was part of a conspiracy to kill Stephen Bryant of suburban Detroit. Bhaktipada was named in five racketeering counts, including conspiracy to commit murder-for-hire, and six counts of mail fraud. Bryant, who'd launched a one-man campaign against Bhaktipada's New Vrindaban community about 80 miles southwest of Pittsburgh, was gunned down on a Los Angeles street in May 1986. He had accused Bhaktipada and others at the commune of drug trafficking, prostitution, and child abuse, the indictment said. ``There was never one particular break in the case,'' U.S. Attorney William Kolibash said Friday. ``The FBI has been involved in this investigation back about five or six years ago based upon some of Bryant's allegations. ``But what really got us all involved in the case was the Bryant murder,'' Kolibash said. ``That's when it appeared there was some federal jurisdiction.'' The 46-page document alleged that Bhaktipada authorized Bryant's killing and the 1983 murder of Charles St. Denis, a fringe member of New Vrindaban. Thomas A. Drescher, who once lived at New Vrindaban, was convicted of St. Denis' murder. He also has been charged with Bryant's slaying and is awaiting trial on a murder charge in Los Angeles. In addition to the alleged murder conspiracies and racketeering operations, the indictment said Bhaktipada was involved in a child's abduction in 1979 and used the mails in a fraudulent charity scam and to defraud an insurance company. Also named in the indictment were Terry Sheldon, 31, also known as Mr. Scam and Tapahpunja; Steven Fitzpatrick, 36, also known as Sundarakara; New Vrindaban Community Inc.; Govardhan Inc.; and the Cathedral of Healing Inc. Kolibash said Bhaktipada's representatives have assured the government that the swami would appear for his arraignment, which is to be held within the next two weeks. Bhaktipada was expected to return to New Vrindaban, late Friday night or early Saturday, said Gadadhar Das, a spokesman for the community. Sheldon and Fitzpatrick are not in custody and remain fugitives, according to Bob Reutter, head agent in the FBI's Pittsburgh office. Leaders of the community on Friday called the charges ``spurious and entirely without merit.'' ``Millions of taxpayer dollars were spent on the investigation yielding those trumped-up charges against Swami Bhaktipada,'' the community said in a statement. ``But we welcome the opportunity because it will establish our innocence.'' The three racketeering counts against Bhaktipada each carry a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison and a fine of $250,000, Kolibash said. Interstate travel to commit murder for hire carries a maximum penalty of life in prison and a $250,000 fine; conspiracy to travel in interstate commerce to commit murder for hire, conspiracy to commit mail fraud and mail fraud each carry a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a fine of $250,000. The corporations named in the indictment face only fines and no corporate officers were charged, Kolibash said. Federal prosecutors are seeking the forfeiture of any holdings that Bhaktipada, Sheldon or the corporations have in New Vrindaban that were gained as a result of the alleged racketeering. The government also is seeking a temporary restraining order to prevent the destruction or alteration of buildings on the compound's 4,000 acres.

DOC.HEAD: A Look At Friday's Soviet Developments
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at some major events in the Soviet Union and Soviet-related events elsewhere on Friday:

MOSCOW _ President Mikhail S. Gorbachev made the Kremlin's most dire warning yet about what steps the Soviet Union would take if a reunited Germany joins the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, as both President Bush and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl desire. He told a news conference after meeting visiting French President Francois Mitterrand that Moscow would keep its troops in eastern Germany and would review its policies on European arms control and security negotiations if Germany joined NATO. He repeated the Soviet preference that a reunited Germany belong to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact, or _ as an alternative _ follow France's lead and take part only in NATO political activities.

EAST BERLIN _ The Soviet Union said a massive housing shortage back home has forced it to suspend indefinitely withdrawal of nearly one-tenth of its troops from East Germany, as it promised in December 1988. Officials in Bonn say the pullout was to include about 36,000 troops and that Moscow had pulled out about 12,000. Soviet officials put the number higher.

MOSCOW _ The leaders of secessionist Lithuania are ``adventurists,'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said, and he demanded again that they back down from their March 11 declaration of independence. ``We have great reserves of will power, but we are looking for ways'' to end the impasse, Gorbachev said. Lithuanian officials said hot water supplies throughout the Baltic republic were shut off because regional distribution stations ran out of oil as a result of Soviet economic sanctions.

OTTAWA _ Prime Minister Brian Mulroney will hold talks next week with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, giving both men a brief respite from domestic troubles stirred up in restive provinces. Gorbachev will arrive Tuesday for a 36-hour visit before heading to Washington for his summit with President Bush. Emerging nationalism in the Soviet Union is a major headache facing Gorbachev. In Canada, the desire of French-speaking Quebec for recognition as a ``distinct society'' has led to Mulroney's biggest political crisis.

MOSCOW _ Beleaguered Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov asked consumers to stop panic buying of food, triggered by his announcement of plans for steep price increases, and urged parliament to quickly approve economic reforms. Opposition deputies demanded a no-confidence vote to bring down Ryzhkov's government, but President Mikhail S. Gorbachev expressed support for Ryzhkov. Ryzhkov's plan proposes tripling the price of bread and other flour-based products on July 1 and increasing the prices of most other consumer goods in January. It envisions a five-year gradual shift to a government-regulated market economy by freeing most prices, raising taxes, selling off state property, and reducing central control of industry.

MOSCOW _ Russian lawmakers voted on whether populist Boris N. Yeltsin, a onetime Gorbachev ally, would become president of the Soviet Union's largest republic. Yeltsin, ousted two years ago as Moscow Communist Party chief after calling for faster reform, got a double boost when Russian deputies and Soviet news media praised a key campaign speech he made, and when Russian Premier Alexander Vlasov, the candidate backed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, withdrew. But Yeltsin needs backing from 531 of the 1,059 members of the Russian Congress, more than he himself has estimated he could count on. Official results are expected Saturday. Ivan Polozkov, a Communist Party chief from the southern Russia city of Krasnodar, is Yeltsin's main rival.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Threat Eases, More Thunderstorms Seen for Nation's Mid-Section
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Tornadoes battered central Kansas and swept through several other states in the Midwest and the Rockies before stormy weather eased Friday. In central Kansas, residents began cleaning up from nine twisters Thursday that derailed a freight train, destroyed homes and injured at least four people. Authorities estimated damage at more than $3 million. Six tornadoes were reported in Wyoming, two hit Montana and one touched down in South Dakota, the National Weather Service said. No deaths were reported in any of the twisters. Four oil workers leapt from an oil rig near Bushton, Kan., and tried to outrun an approaching tornado in a car. But the car was tossed into a field and the four men had to be cut free, said Barton County Sheriff Jim Daily. They were hospitalized in good condition Friday with cuts and buises, he said. A twister derailed 88 of 107 cars on a Missouri Pacific Railroad freight train just west of Bushton, about 160 miles west of Topeka. None of the crew members was injured. Downed power lines forced officials to close an eight-mile stretch of state Highway 4 between Claflin and Bushton for three hours. Nolan Howell of Great Bend said he counted at least a dozen demolished or seriously damaged farms between those two towns. Weekend forecasts for the tornado-stricken area called for milder weather, with thunderstorms possible, the weather service said. In Nebraska, more than an inch of rain and hail as big as golf balls fell overnight on northern and eastern sections of the state. Rain runoff washed out some county roads and caused minor flooding, said officials in Valentine. The break in the weather was welcomed in flooded areas of Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas. In Arkansas on Friday, six counties were added to the federal disaster list, increasing to 31 the number of counties in which residents are eligible for emergency assistance. Arkansas recorded its first flood-related death on Thursday. Larry Johnson, 35, of Hot Springs, who had been in a coma since Saturday night, died of injuries suffered when he was swept through a drainage ditch while trying to rescue occupants of a car trapped in high water. Flooding that began late last month has been blamed for 13 deaths in Texas and one in Oklahoma and hundreds of millions of dollars in crop and property damage. On Friday, Trinity River Authority officials slowed the release of water through the floodgates of the Lake Livingston Dam to 71,500 cubic feet per second, and expected to lower it further during the weekend. Last week, releases hit a record 100,800 cfs, causing flooding along the Trinity River downstream. One cubic foot of water equals 7.5 gallons. In Louisiana, also hard-hit by recent floods, officials said they expected rainwater flowing down the Black and Mississippi rivers to spill over during the first week of June. Farmers in the Brouillette area of Avoyelles Parish hastily brought in wheat harvests to beat the anticipated flooding. The overflow was expected to begin south of Alexandria in central Louisiana on June 4, said John Barnhart of the Army Corps of Engineers.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say Church-run Food Program Will Continue
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Roman Catholic charities officials said Friday a church-administered program to feed poor people in India will continue under tighter control because of irregularities discovered in an audit. ``The food supply may be reduced temporarily until Catholic Relief Services improves the management of the program,'' said John Metelsky, a spokesman for the U.S. Agency for International Development. ``CRS has already reduced the (number of) feeding centers in India.'' Catholic Relief Services had been receiving $25 million a year in U.S. grain for distribution by 4,600 groups in India. The organization's headquarters in Baltimore described as ``misleading and distorted'' reports from India about the audit. First word of the audit appeared in a dispatch from New Delhi in Friday editions of The Washington Post. Officials in New Delhi later provided additional information. A reorganization two years ago strengthened management and record-keeping ``and the recent audit acknowledged the improvements being undertaken,'' said Robert Chatten, the charity's director of public and governmental affairs. Chatten said the audit ``did not find, nor do we believe there exists, any pattern of widespread misuse of food in the India program. The audit did conclude that, whatever problems may exist, food is reaching the poor'' and ``that is the point of the program,'' he added. The audit by the U.S. accounting firm of Price Waterhouse was ordered by AID officials and concluded last December. It said officials of India's Roman Catholic Church drew up bogus lists of food recipients and used donations to run businesses. Clergy also purposely exaggerated the amount of aid they distributed and filed false reports to hide the abuses, the audit said. The audit estimated that records for food distribution and actual food distribution differed by about $4 million. The U.S. Embassy in New Delhi said the Central Bureau of Investigation, India's version of the FBI, and the investigative wing of the U.S. Agency for International Development are looking into the reported abuses.

DOC.HEAD: Reported Massacre Prompts France to Cancel Trip to Zaire
DOC.TEXT: The French government on Friday postponed an official's visit to Zaire because of reports that country's troops massacred university students opposed to President Mobutu Sese Seko. The Foreign Ministry statement did not say if the postponement was made to protest the reported killings. It said only that the visit of Francophone Minister Alain Decaux to the central African nation will be delayed indefinitely. Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens of Belgium confirmed Thursday that a number of Lubumbashi University students in that southeastern city had been killed by Zairean soldiers two weeks ago. Belgian press reports say 50 to 150 students opposing Mobutu's regime had been murdered by special commandos of his personal guard on the night of May 11. Amnesty International, the human rights group, said Thursday the unarmed students died in a ``premeditated and extensive'' attack. Many more students were believed to have been injured, the London-based organization said. Zaire authorities have acknowledged one dead and 13 injured. Mobutu, who has ruled for 25 years, recently announced he would allow two opposition political parties. But student opponents want quicker and broader democratic changes. Decaux was to meet with Mobutu on Tuesday to discuss an October 1991 summit in Zaire of French-speaking nations. Decaux is charged by the French government with fostering the French language.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Battles Kill Four, Wound 42, Trap Schoolchildren
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with higher tolls, new fighting. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem militias fought in west Beirut with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades on Friday, killing four people, wounding 42 and trapping scores of children in schools, police said. At sundown, the combat spread to south Beirut's shantytowns of Hajjaj and Hay Madi, where many of the 16 Western hostages in Lebanon are believed held by pro-Iranian Shiite extremists. Police said they could not tell if the hostages were in immediate danger. Radio stations interrupted programs to broadcast appeals for a cease-fire so parents could evacuate the children. ``Please, please, let them stop fighting. Let them have mercy on these innocent children,'' an unidentified woman pleaded on the Moslem Voice of the Nation radio. Fighters of pro-Iranian Hezbollah and Syrian-backed Amal battled around the city's sports stadium for three hours. The fighting stopped shortly after noon when Syrian soldiers intervened, police said _ only to re-ignite three hours later in the densely populated, mostly Shiite slums south of the capital. Both factions fought heavy street battles in the dusty alleyways of Shiyah and Ghobeiri, police said. They also reported fighting around the airport highway on the outskirts of the southern suburbs. The west Beirut contingent of an estimated 40,000 Syrian troops deployed in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate intervened again to try to end the slums' fighting and withdraw militiamen from the streets. By police count, at least 1,048 people have been killed and 3,136 wounded in a 2{-year-old power struggle between the rival militias for supremacy of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. Fighting broke out after Hezbollah accused Amal militiamen of kidnapping four of its members. It came as Christian spiritual leaders met in Bkirki, north of the capital, and called for consolidation of a cease-fire to end three months of savage fighting between rebel Gen. Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces militia under Samir Geagea. The two forces have fought for control of the Christian enclave north of the capital since Jan.30 in the fiercest fighting between rival Christians since Lebanon's civil war began in 1975. The leaders received a videotaped message from Pope John Paul II urging the Lebanese ``in the name of the love I feel for you ... to seek dialogue, overcome your fears and always love your Lebanon.'' At least 1,031 people have died in the Christian battles. Excerpts of the pope's message were broadcast in Arabic by Beirut radio stations.

DOC.HEAD: International Monetary Fund Renews Aid to Argentina
DOC.TEXT: Argentina will be allowed to draw $240 million of a $1.7 billion International Monetary Fund loan from which payments were suspended last February, a source said Friday. The disbursements were suspended after IMF said President Carlos Menem's government had failed to meet conditions. The source, speaking only on condition of anonymity, said Argentina could use part of the $240 million to buy back some of its $60 billion debt at a discount. It owes about $40 billion to banks, most of them in the United States. Last week, that part of the debt could be bought on the New York market for 14 cents on the dollar. A portion of the new disbursement also could be used to reduce the South American nation's $4 billion annual loan payments, the source said. One official said the amount available for that purpose would be more than 25 percent of the $240 million. Argentina is $6 billion behind on payments. The spokesman said future drawings also could be used for reduction of Argentine debt and payments. But whether they would be permitted depends on whether the fund decides that Menem's government is meeting new requirements. Menem's government has been following the kind of austerity program the fund usually requires as a condition for aid. Budget cuts have been made, price controls have been lifted and plans have been announced for privatization of government-owned companies. The fund's decision was made behind closed doors by the 22 members of the IMF's board of executive directors, who represent the 152 countries that own the fund. It rarely gives details of its decisions, saying it's up to the borrowers to disclose them.

DOC.HEAD: Fiery Crash Ignites Homes, Kills Two in South Georgia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-9, `At least ..,' with 13 grafs to UPDATE with nine homes damaged, details, description of crash site, plane carrying practice bullets and bombs, cost of plane, second plane participated in exercise; picks up 10th graf pvs, ``We heard ...' DELETES pvs grafs 13, `A Moody ...,' and 15, `Authorities closed ...,' to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XTIF1, WX32
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force fighter jet crashed into a residential area in rural south Georgia on Friday, killing the pilot and a housekeeper as it ignited two homes and hurled fiery debris across a highway. It was the second time since November that a military jet crashed in Georgia and killed civilians on the ground. Kathleen Guthrie, executive secretary at the Atkinson County sheriff's department, confirmed the deaths, but identities were unavailable. Ms. Guthrie said no one else was killed, although she earlier had reported three deaths. The F-16A ``Fighting Falcon'' was on a training flight from Moody Air Force Base near Valdosta _ about 40 miles away _ to Lake George Weapons Range in Florida when it crashed. The pilot was the only occupant, said base spokeswoman Dee Tait. One house and a mobile home were destroyed when the jet slammed into a row of homes on U.S. 441 north of Pearson shortly after 9:30 a.m., authorities said. At least seven other homes, including that of Mary Alice and Curtiss Corbitt across the highway, were damaged by debris that flew in all directions. ``I'm going to praise the Lord for protecting me and my wife,'' said Corbitt, 65, who suffered scrapes and bruises. ``When it happened, I said `This is the end.''' Firefighters continued spraying water Friday afternoon onto the smoldering remains of a brick house leveled by the crash, in which the housekeeper was killed. The plane apparently hit the house and the mobile home behind it, then traveled diagonally across the highway to the Corbitt house, where all the windows were blown out and large sections of the roof ripped away. Corbitt family members said flying debris touched off a fire inside the house and cut two tall pine trees in front of the house in half. Parts of pine trees and twisted metal pieces of the aircraft, the largest about the size of a briefcase, littered the highway, which was reopened to traffic late Friday afternoon. Atkinson County Sheriff Earl Haskins said the largest piece of debris he has seen from the wreckage was part of a wing, which was about the size of a car roof. A search team from the Moody base combed the woods near the Corbitt house, putting remains of the plane into black plastic bags. Air Force Col. Stu Mosbey, interim president of Moody's board of inquiry, refused to say whether the pilot's body had been recovered. The plane was carrying 20mm practice bullets, some of which apparently caught fire after the crash; six practice bombs, and a practice, unarmed, Sidewinder missile, Mosbey said. All the items were recovered, he said. The plane cost about $9 million, said manufacturer General Dynamics Corp. Another plane participating in the training flight returned to Moody after the crash, Mosbey said. Mosbey estimated it would take 30 days to determine the cause of the crash. ``We heard the explosion. ... It knocked our power off,'' said Martha White, owner of the Country Kitchen Restaurant, about 1{ miles from the crash site. ``It was very loud _ almost like a sonic boom,'' said David McDonald, assistant principal at Atkinson County High School, less than a mile from the site. ``It shook real hard.'' The crash site is about two miles north of Pearson, a town of about 2,000 and the county seat of rural Atkinson County. The Pearson Volunteer Fire Department sent both of its units to fight the fires, and departments from neighboring towns also were called in. In November, a Navy jet crashed into an apartment complex north of Atlanta and burst into flames, killing two residents of the complex and seriously wounding the pilot. The fighter was trying to land at Dobbins Air Force Base when it crashed in suburban Smyrna. A year ago, a jet from Moody accidentally dropped a live, 500-pound bomb onto a rural area of Marion County in western Georgia. Air Force officials said a worn-out, malfunctioning bomb rack caused the F-16 to drop it. The bomb exploded, but no one was injured and no major damage was reported.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Champions Maltese Church
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Friday said the Roman Catholic Church must be allowed to play its historic leading role on Malta, despite recent church-state tensions on this Mediterranean island nation. John Paul flew in from Rome for a three-day visit, the first by a pope to Malta. The Vatican says Malta, south of Italy, is 99 percent Catholic. During his visit, the pontiff stressed ``the unique and lasting contribution that the Christian faith has made to Malta.'' He also made thinly veiled references to the problems the church has faced. The Maltese say their Christian tradition dates to the year 60, when Saint Paul was shipwrecked on the island. However, a visit by the pope was considered unthinkable under the previous socialist government. Ruling from 1971 until an electoral defeat in 1987, the Labor Party carried out a campaign the church said was aimed at undermining its dominant role in Maltese life. The government barred private schools, including Catholic ones, from charging tuition. It also ordered the church to hand over property it could not prove the it owned. Some of the bitterness stemmed from the 1960s, when the church was at odds with socialist officials and supporters. John Paul praised the new climate is this country of 350,000 residents under the Nationalist administration of Eddie Fenech Adami, a regular churchgoer. In remarks to Prime Minister Adami and President Vincent Tabone, the pope sketched his vision of the role of the church in Malta. ``It is important that the church should enjoy freedom in the institutional and administrative spheres, and that she should be free from all undue pressures, obstacles and manipulation,'' John Paul said. ``In a word, it is essential that the church should be enabled to act effectively in fulfilling her mission to all people.'' Scores of Maltese in a holiday mood lined the pope's motorcade route as he drove in from the airport Friday and passed the fortresses built by the Knights of Malta, mobilized in the 16th century to defend Christian Europe against the Ottoman Turks. On Saturday, John Paul will cross in a catamaran to Gozo, the second largest island in the archipelago, and address workers in a Labor Party stronghold. The Maltese pilgrimage is John Paul's 48th foreign tour as pope. President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met at Malta for a summit in December.

DOC.BYLINE: World Bank to Consider China Loans ^By CARL HARTMAN
DOC.TEXT: The president of the World Bank will not hold back $450 million worth of proposed loans for China, despite pressure from Congress and uncertainty by the Bush administration, a spokesman said Friday. ``He has no intention of withdrawing them,'' said Peter Riddleberger, a spokesman for President Barber Conable. Of the total, $400 million would be lent at less than 1 percent annual interest. Opponents say the loans should not be granted because of China's suppression of human rights. The Bush administration has said that loans should be only granted for basic human needs. Conable has said the bank lends only on economic considerations, and the delay of $780 million worth of loans after the brutal suppression of pro-Democracy demonstrations last June was to gain time to look into the economic effects of the action. Pastor Sison, a bank Asia specialist, said a projected $300 million for planting trees in 15 Chinese provinces would be the biggest loan ever granted for forestry. That loan and another for $150 million, to improve roads and waterways in the Nanjing area, are due to be considered behind closed doors on Tuesday. The decision will be made by a 22-member board of executive directors, who represent the 152 countries that own the bank. The United States holds about 20 percent of the voting power on the board. One official, who spoke on condition he not be named, said the Bush administration was opposing the transport loan and was still considering its stand on the forestry loan Friday. Robert Levine, a spokesman for the Treasury, said he would have nothing to disclose on the U.S. position until after the vote. On Thursday the office of Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, distributed copies of a letter he sent to Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, arguing against the loans. Gonzalez said approval would make it hard to get approval of more money for the World Bank and would raise opposition to the new Bank for European Reconstruction and Development being established to help the new democracies of Eastern Europe. Last year the bank lent $1.35 billion to China, but in 11 months of the current fiscal year loans to China have totaled on $140 million.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney for One Iowa Family Ready to File Claim Against Navy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `And on ...,' to CORRECT that GAO report did not cite equipment failure, but said gunpowder bags may have been overrammed; SUBS 14th graf, `Kathy Kubicina ...,' to CORRECT that arrangement of gunpowder pellets, not gunpowder itself, may have been faulty.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Navy-Iowa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Navy should pay millions in damages after a congressional report rejected the service's finding that a sailor's sabatoge caused last year's fatal USS Iowa explosion, an attorney for the sailor's family said Friday. ``I am more convinced than ever that we have a legitimate claim for intentional and negligent infliction of emotion distress against the Navy,'' Kreig Brusnahan said from his Cleveland office. Brusnahan represents the family of Gunner's Mate Clayton Hartwig, one of 47 sailors killed when an explosion and fireball ripped through the battleship's No. 2 turret April 19, 1989. A four-month, $4 million investigation by the Navy concluded Hartwig most likely caused the explosion by inserting a detonating device between bags of powder in the 16-inch guns. But Thursday, the Navy announced it was reopening its investigation and was suspending the use of the 16-inch guns after an explosion at a test site. And on Friday, a General Accounting Office report to the Senate Armed Services committee said it could not support the Navy's original findings. The GAO report suggested that gunpowder bags may have been unintentionally rammed too hard and too far into the barrel. ``It is my belief that the Navy spent in excess of $4 million to frame Clayton Hartwig,'' Brusnahan said. ``They ought to give the family at least that much to compensate for the hell they have put them through.'' The Navy's original report triggered protests from some of the families of the 47 sailors. Other families said they were satisfied with the report. The protests prompted the Senate and House Armed Services committees to hold hearings on the Navy's investigation. Earlier this year, the House committee issued a report highly critical of the Navy's probe. With the investigation reopened, many of the families are hoping the questions they had about the explosion will be answered. The GAO report said the Navy's battleships were troubled by lack of qualified sailors in the turrets. ``That's what my husband always complained about,'' said Sharon Ziegler. Her husband, Reginald, was the senior enlisted man in the turret. ``He had to spend a lot of extra overtime in training the kids. They pushed a lot of people into the turret, but most of them didn't know what to do,'' she said from her home in Rushville, N.Y. Kathy Kubicina, Hartwig's sister, raised questions about the powder used in the 16-inch guns. The GAO report pointed to the arrangement of gunpowder pellets in the bags as a possible cause of excess friction that may have caused detonation. ``What we're driving for is for them to get rid of all that powder,'' Nancy Lewis said. The Northville, Mich., woman was in Washington with Ms. Kubicina for the Senate hearing. Mrs. Lewis' son, Richard, died in the explosion. Brusnahan expects to submit a claim to the Navy within 90 days. The Navy will have six months to respond. If the claim is rejected, Brusnahan said he will file with the federal courts. Several of the families said the best result of the reopening of the investigation was the clearing of Hartwig's name. ``I'm glad that that family has finally gotten some relief out of this,'' Mrs. Ziegler said. ``Not only have they lost their son, they have had to suffer with the accusation that their son killed 46 other people. I can't conceive the pain and heartache they must feel,'' said Darleen Schelin of El Toro, Calif. Mrs. Schelin's son, Geoffrey, was among the 47 killed. ``At a minimum, the Navy should be ashamed of itself for allowing the other families to believe that Clayton Hartwig killed their sons,'' Brusnahan said. The Navy issued a statement saying it ``will continue to test additional theories dealing with the possible causes of the explosion.''

DOC.HEAD: Vehicles Banned as Smog Emergency Declared in Chilean Capital
DOC.TEXT: The government banned 40 percent of all motor vehicles from downtown Friday in an effort to reduce a health-threatening cloud of smog covering the city and its 4.5 million residents. Declaring a state of environmental emergency in Santiago, the government also ordered 18 industries across the city to reduce production by 20 percent. In addition, it banned weekday use of fireplaces in private homes. Half the city's public buses were ordered to remain off the streets on Saturday and Sunday. Eduardo Arriagada, head of a federal anti-pollution commission for Santiago, said the measures will be examined daily to determine whether they should be lifted, maintained or intensified. For several years, authorities have kept 20 percent of the city vehicles off the streets on weekdays. The new measure, expected to continue until pollution conditions improve, doubled the restriction. The banned vehicles are determined according to the final digit in their license plates. The numbers change each day. Arriagada said the emergency was declared after the number of contaminating particles in the air surpassed 300, a level internationally considered dangerous to the human health. Santiago is considered one of the world's smoggiest cities, along with Mexico City and Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Women Who Helped Plan Ax Attack Sentenced to Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jeffery cq in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: Two of three women who tried to kill and dismember a man with an ax in an attempt to resurrect Jack the Ripper were sentenced Friday to five years each in prison. Catherine Lipsham, 23, and Ramona Barry, 27, pleaded guilty last month to attempted first-degree intentional homicide in the May 1989 attack on Jeffery Meka, 27, who suffered a severe gash above the eye. Deborah Kazuck, 27, who a jury ruled wielded the ax, was found insane by a judge in the second phase of her trial and sent to a mental hospital. Attorneys for Ms. Lipsham and Ms. Barry asked the court for leniency Friday, saying the women suffered from mental illness and past abuses and had not actually committed the assault. But Milwaukee County Circuit Judge William D. Gardner called them members of ``an immoral cult of three'' and sentenced them to prison. Although the two women cooperated with prosecutors during Ms. Kazuck's trial, the victim could have been killed if he was ``less strong or if the blow had been more appropriately placed,'' the judge noted. Meka testified he was lured to an apartment and attacked by the three women, who sprang from behind a shower curtain chanting ``redrum'' _ ``murder'' backwards _ and struck him with the ax. Ms. Lipsham and Ms. Barry could each have received a maximum prison term of 20 years. Assistant District Attorney Mark Williams, citing their cooperation, asked that they be sentenced to six to eight years. At her trial, Ms. Kazuck testified she struck Meka with an ax because he tried to sexually assault her. Ms. Lipsham and Ms. Barry said that was untrue. All three women told police they had participated in satanism. Ms. Barry admitted luring Meka to an apartment she shared with Ms. Lipsham so they could kill and dismember him and drain his blood in a ceremony they called ``kacking.'' Prosecutors said Ms. Kazuck believed she was Jack the Ripper's mother and that the trio hoped to resurrect the 19th century British serial killer. At least five prostitutes fell prey to the Ripper's knife in London's seamy East End in 1888. Most were mutilated. The crimes were never solved. Ms. Barry and Ms. Lipsham originally pleaded innocent by reason of insanity. Psychiatrists found both competent to stand trial.

DOC.HEAD: French Evacuate Europeans from Troubled African Country
DOC.TEXT: French military aircraft evacuated 500 European women and children Friday from an oil center in Gabon after two days of riots and the abduction of 11 foreigners. The evacuees, mostly French but including some Belgian, Dutch and British, were escorted to the Port Gentil airport by French soldiers. Some planned to stay in Libreville, the capital of this African nation, and others flew to France on a special Air France charter. The director of Shell Gabon, Andre-Dieudonne Berre, the principal operator at Port Gentil, said, ``The rioters systematically destroyed the infrastructure that we have invested many years to create.'' Asked about a threat by rioters to burn installations at the oil-refining center, he said workers had reduced production to its lowest possible level. It couldn't be shut completely without risking damage to pipelines and other equipment. The violence broke out after the death of opposition leader Joseph Rendjambe, secretary-general of the Gabon Progress Party. Opponents accuse President Omar Bongo's government of murdering Rendjambe, whose body was found in a hotel room Wednesday. The government Friday created a special commission to investigate the death. Rendjambe's death triggered riots that resulted in the burning of the French consulate in Port Gentil, and a hotel and theater in Libreville on Wednesday. Many private businesses also were burned or pillaged in rioting that continued into Thursday. The government newspaper reported two deaths. Hospital sources said at least 17 people were injured. In addition, a French diplomat was taken hostage for several hours. Later, opposition party members took 10 oil executives hostage in Port Gentil _ eight Frenchmen, one Briton and a Gabon. They were released after French troops arrived and held talks with the dissidents. Friday morning, French troops patrolled the streets of Port Gentil, 100 miles south of Libreville. The country gained independence from France in 1960. In addition to the Europeans, there are a smaller number of Americans who work for oil companies based in Port Gentil, on the Atlantic coast. The government has been carrying out democratic reforms to replace one-party rule. On Monday, the constitution was amended to allow opposition parties to contest elections in September.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Vic Tayback, TV's Crusty Mel on `Alice,' Dead of Heart Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS one graf with funeral plans; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY27
DOC.TEXT: Vic Tayback, known to millions of television viewers as Mel the crusty diner owner on ``Alice,'' died Friday of a heart attack, his agent said. The actor was 60. Tayback, who had a history of heart trouble, including triple bypass surgery in 1983, died at home in his sleep at 1 a.m., said his agent and friend of 20 years, Fred Amsel. Paramedics rushed Tayback to Glendale Adventist Hospital but there was no chance of reviving him, he said. ``He just died in his sleep of a heart attack,'' Amsel said. ``He was just fine yesterday. He hadn't had any trouble since the heart surgeries. But he was a smoker. In fact, he just told me he quit smoking, again.'' Tayback, who played loudmouth Mel Sharples for nine years, appeared on several other TV series, including ``Star Trek,'' ``Bonanza,'' ``The Rookies,'' ``Emergency'' and ``Barney Miller.'' He was also a regular on the 1973 series ``Griff'' and the 1975 series ``Khan.'' On ``Alice,'' Tayback took a lot of kidding about his cooking and it became a running gag on the CBS comedy series. ``If I walked into a restaurant the other diners would look around and say, `I hope you're not cooking,''' Tayback joked in a 1985 interview. The actor had supporting roles in several motion pictures, including ``Papillon,'' ``Bullitt'' and ``The Choirboys.'' His TV movie credits included ``They Call it Murder,'' ``The Night the City Screamed,'' ``The Jesse Owens Story'' and ``The Three Kings.'' When the ``Alice'' series ended in 1985, Tayback returned to the stage, starring in such plays as ``12 Angry Men'' and ``Death of a Salesman.'' His parents were born in Aleppo, Syria, but Tayback was born and raised in the New York City borough of Brooklyn. ``I learned to speak the Syrian language but I left home when I was 16. I'll never deny my heritage. I'm proud of it,'' Tayback said in an interview. Tayback is survived by his wife Sheila; son Christopher; mother Helen; sister Emily; and brother Joe. Funeral arrangements were incomplete. ``I'm just devastated. I loved Vic very dearly and my heart goes out to Sheila and Chris,'' actress Polly Holliday, who played the waitress Flo on ``Alice,'' said from New York. Mass is to be said Tuesday evening at Incarnation Catholic Church. Burial was set for Wednesday at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Glendale.

DOC.HEAD: Greenpeace Protesters Arrested After Anti-Nuclear Protest
DOC.TEXT: Greenpeace protesters in inflatable boats Friday tried to place an anti-nuclear warning on two British warships visiting this Canadian city. As a result of their efforts, five members of the international environmental group were arrested, authorities said. Each was charged with operating a boat without a license, the authorities said. The protesters tried to place their warning on the hulls of the HMS Cumberland and HMS Glasgow before police boats surrounded them. The British warships are in Toronto on a 10-day visit that ends Wednesday. Greenpeace spokesman Trudie Richards said the ships ``are capable of carrying nuclear weapons, but we can't prove that they are carrying them now.'' British naval officials refused comment.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Journalists Awarded For Courageous Coverage of Drug Trade
DOC.TEXT: Colombian journalists under siege for covering drug trade in their nation have won the 1990 Louis M. Lyons Award for Conscience and Integrity in Journalism, Harvard University's Nieman Foundation said Friday. The award cites Colombian reporters, living and dead, for their work on the drug industry and its effect on that country. Luis Gabriel Cano, 67-year-old president of the newspaper El Espectador of Bogota, will accepted the award. The paper has lost staffers to death or exile and had its newsroom bombed in September. The Committee to Protect Journalists, a New York-based human rights group, has documented the killing of 20 reporters and editors in Colombia by agents of drug lords in the last five years. But Cano and other Colombian journalists estimate that 50 news organization employees, including business employees, have been killed. Among those murdered was Cano's brother, Guillermo Cano, El Espectador editor in chief and a columnist. ``Mr. Cano has lost his brother and several of his associates to the narco-mafia assassins, and recently suffered a major bombing to the paper's installations which caused $2.5 million in damages, seriously jeopardizing the paper,'' T. Roberto Eisenmann Jr., editor of La Prensa in Panama and a former Nieman fellow, wrote in nominating Cano for the award. ``Yet Cano struggled on, realizing that if his newspaper fails in its efforts, his country's institutions might crumble ... His courage is especially inspiring for our profession.'' A committee of the 21 members of the Nieman Fellow Class of 1990 chose the Colombians for the award, named in honor of former Nieman curator Louis M. Lyons. The award carried an honorarium of $1,000. Cano will travel to Cambridge come fall to accept the award on his Colombian colleagues' behalf.

DOC.HEAD: Hamburger Giant Says No To Irradiated Foods
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's Corp. on Friday declared that it has not and will not buy or serve irradiated food products, to applause from a food purity group and an order of Roman Catholic nuns. McDonald's announced its ban on radiation-exposed foods at its annual shareholders' meeting in this Chicago suburb. The fast-food giant also reaffirmed its policy of using only locally produced and processed beef. ``We do not, have not and will not purchase beef from rain forest or recently deforested rain forest land,'' McDonald's said in a statement. ``This policy is strictly enforced and closely monitored.'' The statement on irradiated foods came in reponse to a resolution filed last fall by a coalition of the company's shareholders requesting a clarification of corporate policy on the issue, said Christina Roessler of Food & Water Inc., a New York-based food purity group. The resolution was written by the Dominican Sisters of Adrian, Mich., and the Dominican Sisters of the Sick Poor in Ossining, N.Y. Both orders have holdings in McDonald's. ``This move reflects an important commitment to food safety and to our consumers. McDonald's is the first restaurant to establish this far-sighted policy,'' Sister Pat Day of the Dominican Sisters said at the meeting. A number of food companies, including H.J. Heinz, Quaker Oats, Ralston Purina and Borden Foods, announced this year they would not use irradiation in making their products or buy irradiated foods or ingredients, Roessler said. Irradiation, exposing foodstuffs _ especially meats _ to radioisotopes such as cobalt 60 and cesium 137, has been proposed as a food preservation method since at least the early 1960s. Proponents say the technique reduces the need for potentially dangerous chemical preservatives, lowers refrigeration costs and leaves no harmful radiation in the food. Opponents say it can leave trace radioactivity or harmful residues in food. The Food and Drug Administration approved irradiation May 1 for the treatment of commercially sold poultry. Last July, New York State passed legislation banning irradiated foods there for two years. New Jersey passed similar legislation in December, and Maine has enacted an indefinite ban on such products.

DOC.HEAD: Artsfest Gets Under Way As Celebration of Storm Recovery
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: With a rallying cry of ``Let the music begin,'' the city celebrated its recovery from Hurricane Hugo with the opening Friday of Spoleto Festival U.S.A. ``Let the music begin, the dancers dance, the choirs sing and the children play,'' Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. proclaimed as brightly colored balloons fell from the roof of City Hall and were chased along a nearby street by young children. The opening also featured a brass fanfare and the singing of a choir. ``I'm happy to see you here today. I never thought I would be,'' composer and festival founder Gian Carlo Menotti told about 1,500 people gathered under a warm sun outside City Hall for the midday ceremonies. Menotti said when he saw the devastation from the Sept. 21 hurricane, he thought it would be two or three years before the festival could be staged again. ``I was shocked,'' he said, adding the city looked like ``a shipwreck'' in the aftermath of the storm. The roof of City Hall was ripped off during the hurricane but has been repaired. The roof of St. Michaels Episcopal Church across the street, though, still shows scars of the storm's fury. Hugo's 135 mph winds killed 29 people and left $5.9 billion damage in South Caris wife and daughter receive bachelor's degrees. Actress Joanne Woodward, who squeezed more than a decade of study into her busy professional life to receive her degree, drew applause from 285 graduates and more than 3,000 spectators when she kissed her blue-eyed husband before them. Newman peppered his 20-minute speech with anecdotes about his life and the creation of his salad dressing. He urged the crowd to pay attention to the spirit of community. ``Community happens the instant two like-minded individuals build something for someone else, address a grievance, take a risk,'' he said. The actor said last year's pro-democracy demonstrations in China and the tumbling of the Berlin Wall were examples of what can come of belief in community. ``The best thing you can give yourself is the gift of possibility and believing in the possibility of others,'' Newman said. He urged the graduates to be ``the response, not the silence'' for the future. After daughter Clea Olivia Newman received her degree, Newman stood from his chair on the stage and gave her a hug and a kiss. DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Invaded Sharon Gless Home Pleads Innocent to Burglary
DOC.TEXT: A woman accused of invading the home of ``Cagney and Lacey'' star Sharon Gless and barricading herself inside a bathroom for seven hours pleaded innocent to a felony burglary charge. Joni Leigh Penn, 30, of Garden Grove entered her plea Thursday before a Municipal Court judge who set trial for July 12. If convicted, she could be sentenced to five years in prison. Penn, armed with a .22-caliber semiautomatic rifle and 500 rounds of ammunition, allegedly broke into the actress' Studio City home on March 30. The actress wasn't home at the time. Authorities said Penn had been obsessed with the actress for years. She had mailed hundreds of letters to Miss Gless, who obtained a restraining order barring the woman from coming near her. Penn allegedly planned to commit suicide after sexually assaulting Miss Gless, investigators said. During Penn's preliminary hearing, police Officer John P. Anderson testified that she said, ``If I can't have her, nobody can.''

DOC.HEAD: Paul Newman Commencement Speaker, Proud Relative of Two Graduates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0772 to fix cycle designator.

Actress Joanne Woodward, who squeezed more than a decade of study into her busy professional life to receive her degree, drew applause from 285 graduates and more than 3,000 spectators when she kissed her blue-eyed husband before them.
