DOC.HEAD: Perpich Invites Gorbachev To Attend Ecumenical Service During Sunday Stop
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been invited to attend an ecumenical service when he visits Minnesota, Gov. Rudy Perpich said Thursday. The service will be on Sunday, June 3, at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. Paul near the Capitol, Perpich said. ``We would like to see like an ecumenical service for peace and friendship,'' Perpich told radio station WCCO-AM. ``We'll see if he accepts ... It'll be very, very interesting.'' The invitation was extended jointly by the governor and Archbishop John Roach of the Minneapolis-St. Paul Archdiocese, said Perpich spokesman Ray Bohn. State officials said they did not know when they would receive an itinerary from Soviet officials. Gorbachev plans to make a six-hour stop in Minnesota after concluding his Washington summit conference with President Bush. He is scheduled to arrive at 1 p.m. and leave for California at 7 p.m. The tentative schedule includes a welcome luncheon at the governor's mansion and a 5 p.m. meeting at a Minneapolis hotel with a group of Midwest business and agricultural leaders. But Gorbachev and his wife apparently plan considerable sightseeing while in the Twin Cities. Perpich said Gorbachev's wife, Raisa, has asked to meet with a typical American family, and that the Steven Watson family of Minneapolis has been chosen. ``She really wanted to visit with a middle-class family in Minnesota. ... The family that's selected has four children, and for some reason, they (the Soviets) wanted a family that also has a dog. I guess they ... wanted what they consider a typical American family.'' The Watsons' daughter, Lisa, 13, was part of a cultural exchange program and visited the Soviet Union last year.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Denied Parolee in Mobile County Racial Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A white parolee with a history of racial hatred was charged Thursday with murder and attempted murder in a shooting that left a young black man dead and his companion paralyzed, authorities said. Daniel Amos Pilot, 21, of Theodore was arrested Wednesday while driving to a construction job, said Mobile County Sheriff Tom Purvis. District Judge Mike McMaken ordered Pilot held without bond on murder and attempted murder charges in the killing of Darren Jessie, 21, and the wounding of Joseph O'Cain, 17. McMaken said Pilot was in violation of his parole and that a hearing on revoking his parole would be held later. The heavily tatooed suspect, his hands cuffed and his head lowered, walked by reporters without making any comment. Jessie was shot to death March 31 while sitting in a car outside a grocery in Theodore, a predominantly white suburb of Mobile. O'Cain was shot in the back as he fled the car. Jessie's mother, Catherine McCants, had concluded the shooting was racially motivated because her son was dating a white clerk at the store. ``I'm glad they got him,'' she said Thursday. ``I feel more comfortable now that they got somebody, but I'm still worried and upset.'' Purvis told a news conference that the investigation of the shooting determined Pilot didn't know Jessie or his girlfriend and that the interracial romance was not the motive. The sheriff said Pilot's ``hatred for blacks'' appeared to be the motive, but declined to elaborate. Pilot was paroled from a state prison March 12 after serving four years of a 12-year sentence for receiving stolen property, said state prisons spokeswoman Debbie Herbert. The sheriff would not say what words were spoken between the gunman and the two victims, but said Jessie and O'Cain were ``innocent of any provocation or wrongdoing.'' Another racially motivated killing rocked Mobile in 1981, when a black 19-year-old, Michael Donald, was picked at random from a city street and beaten to death. His body was hanged from a tree. Three Ku Klan Klan members are serving prison sentences for the killing, which was recently made into a television movie by NBC.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Bus Driven By Replacement Crashes
DOC.TEXT: A Greyhound bus driven by a replacement driver crashed Thursday, injuring eight passengers, authorities said. The driver told investigators a tractor-trailer forced him off the road, but at least three witnesses indicated he may have fallen asleep at the wheel, said patrolman Steve Kelso of the highway patrol. Investigators from the National Transportation and Safety Board went to the scene. Greyhound has reported at least 30 incidents of violence against the company, including shootings of buses, since its drivers began a nationwide strike March 2. Kelso said the Greyhound bus carrying 46 passengers went off Interstate 80 just east of Wamsutter early Thursday when it failed to make a curve. The bus crossed the median and went into a drainage ditch. All 46 passengers were taken to Carbon County Memorial Hospital in Rawlins, and eight were being held for overnight observation and treatment, Hospital Administrator Dick Mills said. All eight were in stable condition, said Mills, who did not know the extent of their injuries. The driver, 50-year-old Bobby Williamson of Chicago, was not hurt. Kelso said Williamson told him a large truck had played ``highway tag,'' repeatedly passing the bus, then slowing to make the bus pass until the bus was finally forced off the road. However, the patrolman said, there were reports from at least three witnesses who were awake either during or immediately before the accident that Williamson had been drowsy and was crossing lanes. Greyhound spokesman Bill Kula said the driver had fulfilled the rest quota prescribed by the Department of Transportation before getting behind the wheel in Cheyenne. ``The driver had had a 13-hour rest and break period which more than met DOT requirements,'' Kula said. ``He had all the rest he needed. It would not have impaired his driving ability in the least.'' George Gravely, another Greyhound spokesman, said the company was investigating whether the bus was forced off the road. ``I don't want this to sound like we've lost confidence in the driver or support everything he said. But typically, we will review everything he says.'' Williamson is a replacement driver who began driving for Greyhound when members of the Amalgamated Transit Union went on strike, Gravely said.

DOC.HEAD: France Bans Nazi Literature
DOC.TEXT: The French government on Thursday banned three neo-Nazi magazines from West Germany, calling the publications racist and anti-Semitic. The order follows the desecration of a Jewish cemetery two weeks ago in southern France that prompted further desecrations, protests from Jews and others and nationwide soul-searching about anti-Semitism. In Thursday's order, Interior Secretary Pierre Joxe banned distribution and sales of the three magazines, which are translated into French for distribution to extreme-right groups. None of the magazines have large circulations. However, Joxe said the works ``threaten the public order because of their apologies for Nazism, racism and anti-Semitism.'' His authority to ban them comes under a 1939 law controlling foreign publications. France has been ungoing a wave of protests and recriminations since a Jewish cemetery in Carpentras was desecrated two weeks ago. A corpse was mutilated and 34 tombs desecrated, and the case remains unsolved. Since then, similar incidents have been carried out in France, Israel, Canada and elsewhere. In the latest French legal action, a court in Poissy, west of Paris, charged a 26-year-old man with painting anti-Semitic graffiti on the doors of a vocational school. The messages, discovered Tuesday, were aimed at the school's Jewish director. On Wednesday, a judge in Saint Herblain freed under court supervision three skinheads charged with profaning 90 graves at a Catholic cemetery in the eastern French village. Mayor Charles Gautier denounced the decision by Judge Gilles Dubigeon. In a letter Thursday to Prime Minister Michel Rocard, the mayor said the three suspects should have been held in jail while awaiting trial. In another development, extreme-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen on Thursday criticized a court decision to fine him for referring to the Nazi gas chambers as ``a detail of World War II history.'' In a statement by his National Front party, Le Pen criticized Wednesday's ruling as political persecution and an infringement on his free speech rights. The court in Nanterre, outside Paris, ordered Le Pen to pay 18 cents to each of 11 organizations that filed suit against him after the remark in 1987. Judge Lefoyer de Costil said ``freedom of expression ... has a limit.'' He also ordered Le Pen to pay $720 to each of the groups to cover legal fees. ``This decision only takes into account the interpretations of my political enemies and not at all the explanations I provided,'' Le Pen said. ``This irreversible judgment is proof of political persecution against me.'' The 61-year-old politician has been increasingly ostracized since the desecration of the cemetery at Carpentras. Le Pen, a deputy in the European Parliament, wants to expel immigrants from France and enact laws to keep them out. He denies repeated accusations of being racist or anti-Semitic.

After months of delay, $720 million in emergency U.S. aid to the new democratic governments in Panama and Nicaragua is finally ready to flow southward following final approval by Congress. But the engine behind the bill was not the altruism of members of Congress. Rather, it was nearly $4 in hometown spending for every dollar in foreign aid contained in the money bill. When finally sent to President Bush early today, the measure had swelled to more than $4 billion. It included programs that ranged from filling in a collapsed utility tunnel on a street in Salisbury, N.C., to giving the Samoan islands a $750,000 ferry boat. The measure did include $300 million to boost the struggling government of Nicaraguan President Violeta Chamorro, and $420 million to help the new Panamanian democracy recover from U.S. trade sanctions and last December's invasion.

Members of Congress are trying to stop President Bush from giving another year of trade benefits to China, whose leaders they called butchers and pirates. Bush announced on Thursday he would extend most favored nation trade status to China for an additional year, despite the administration's unhappiness with Beijing's human rights policies following the June 1989 massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators at Tiananmen Square. This is the second time in a year the president has fought with Congress over China. The last time, when the issue was how to protect Chinese students studying in this country, Bush won a narrow victory. The announcement touched off a firestorm on Capitol Hill, in part because many lawmakers thought Bush might impose some conditions on Beijing at the same time he approved trade benefits.

President Bush's summit next week with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev may mark the end of one era in U.S.-Soviet relations and the beginning of another. The main business the two will conduct symbolizes the old era. They will sign a declaration to reduce U.S. and Soviet strategic nuclear weapons _ by much less than the 50 percent initially advertised _ and probably commit themselves to pursue further cutbacks. The declaration will make the May 31-June 3 summit, like the majority of its predecessors, an arms control summit. At the same time, Bush and Gorbachev will begin the transition to a new superpower relationship forced on them by a rapidly changing world.

A waning Soviet threat has prompted NATO to slash war games nearly in half, replacing them with computer simulations, and to slacken the response time of some forces, the alliance's chief military commander says. ``People don't want big exercises because the looming threat of an immediate war has lessened,'' U.S. Gen. John R. Galvin, the supreme allied commander in Europe, said Thursday. ``We have cut down significantly on the amount of noise, maneuver damage (and) general bother, and yet we have accomplished our exercises to train to the standards that are required,'' he said in an interview at his official residence in Mons, about 40 miles southwest of Brussels. That should come as good news to West Germans, who have increasingly called for a cutback in NATO maneuvers on the ground and in the air that have been prone to sometimes deadly mishaps. Most of the exercises are held in West Germany.

Manuel Noriega's defense lawyers, saying they were betrayed by the U.S. attorney's office in a botched deal to pay their fees, have threatened to reveal the details of the CIA's secret payments to their client. A prosecution-sponsored proposal to have the government pay the lawyers as much as $350 an hour fell apart Thursday when a federal judge said he could find no legal basis for the arrangment. Opponents had called it a ``legal slush fund'' for Noriega. As their part of the deal, Noriega's defense had agreed to postpone a showdown over $11 million they say their client received from the CIA and other intelligence agencies. That agreement is now void, lead defense attorney Frank Rubino said after a hearing on the issue. ``They couldn't take the heat that came out over this agreement,'' Rubino said of the U.S. attorney's office. ``Now we shall litigate every dime Gen. Noriega's been paid by this government, and we shall litigate it as publicly as possible.''

The two Democrats locked in a runoff for the U.S. Senate nomination are going easy on each other and aiming their fire instead at potential Republican opponent Sen. Jesse Helms. Democrats Mike Easley and Harvey Gantt have carefully avoided attacking each other during the first two weeks of the runoff campaign. But they frequently jabbed at Helms. ``They have a lot of common supporters and it's hard to insult people who are fairly close to you,'' said Thad Beyle, a political science professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Beyle characterized it as a ``gentlemanly'' runoff designed in part to avoid alienating voters who could choose to sit out the November general election.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: A first add containing the following items, AM-Navy-Iowa, AM-Military Crash, and AM-Car Bomb, will move when these stories become available. The add will move as a9911.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday warned that the Soviet Union would review its policies on European arms control and security negotiations if a reunited Germany joined NATO. Gorbachev's remarks contained the Kremlin's most dire warning yet about what steps it would take if a reunited Germany joins the Western military alliance. The Soviet Union wants Germany to belong to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. The Bush administration favors NATO membership for a united Germany. Gorbachev said at a news conference that Western leaders seem to assume a unified Germany would join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and said Moscow was very wary of that prospect.

A beleaguered Soviet premier appealed to consumers Friday to stop their panic buying of food, triggered by his announcement of plans for sharp price increases, and urged lawmakers to quickly approve economic reforms. Opposition deputies in parliament demanded a no-confidence vote aimed at bringing down Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov's government, but he got one important voice of support for his program: from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``I'm hoping in the end, after all the debates _ and they won't be simple _ we'll agree that we have to move toward a market. I'm sure of this,'' Gorbachev said at a news conference. Ryzhkov's plan, broadcast on national television Thursday, proposes tripling the price of bread and other flour-based products on July 1 and increasing the prices of most other consumer goods in January.

President Bush began a pre-summit vacation Friday pledging to sign as soon as possible a Panama and Nicaragua aid package swollen by tens of millions of dollars worth of pet projects for members of Congress. The measure provides $420 million for Panama, which is rebuilding after U.S. economic sanctions and an invasion of American forces last December to topple Manuel Antonio Noriega from power. Nicaragua's new government, led by U.S.-backed President Violeta Chamorro, will receive $300 million. Overall, the spending measure provides $4.4 billion in domestic spending and foreign assistance. The administration's high priority on winning aid for Panama and Nicaragua led Bush to swallow pork-barrel spending added by Congress.

Gonzalo Pereira plans to get to his polling station early for Sunday's presidential election _ the less time spent standing in line, the less chance of being killed by a bomb, he says. A lot of Colombians are saying the same thing as car bombs explode in major cities. Most are believed set by drug lords trying to sabotage the vote. At least eight bombs have exploded across the country in the past two weeks alone, killing 34 people. More than 200 people have died in attacks since the government declared war on drug traffickers in August. The latest fatal bombing was Thursday in Medellin, where five people died when a car bomb exploded. Another blast in the city Friday injured three people.

The U.S. trade deficit shrank to $26.4 billion from January through March, the smallest quarterly imbalance in more than six years, the government reported Friday. The Commerce Department said the 8.2 percent improvement in the trade balance was a result of record-high export sales that offset the highest volume of foreign oil shipments in more than 12 years. The improving trade performance, if it continues, would be good news for the U.S. economy. Over the past three years, rising exports have accounted for more than one-third of total domestic growth as American manufacturers enjoyed a boom in foreign sales. In other economic news Friday, the Commerce Department reported that consumer spending shot up by 0.6 percent in April. However, the National Association of Realtors reported that sales of existing homes fell 2.1 percent in April.

Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat urged the U.N. Security Council on Friday to send an emergency force to protect Arabs in the Israeli-occupied territories from a ``war of extermination.'' Opening an emergency council session, Arafat called for an end to Israel's 23-year-old occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, a ban on Jewish settlements in the territories, and international sanctions against Israel. The violence ``has reached an extremely dangerous and explosive point,'' the Palestine Liberation Organization chief said. He urged appointment of a permanent U.N. envoy to monitor the situation; a Security Council investigation into ``all crimes'' allegedly committed by Israel against Palestinians; and immediate preparations for an international Middle East peace conference. Initial responses from other delegates were largely non-committal. France and the Soviet Union said the council should consider a U.N. observer force. In Israel, a top aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Arafat's speech was ``full of lies and distortions.''

Congressional findings ``cast grave doubt'' on the Navy's official conclusion that a troubled sailor probably caused the blast that killed 47 servicemen aboard the battleship USS Iowa, lawmakers said Friday. The new investigation, by the General Accounting Office, suggests the explosion may well have been an accident. Congress' report came one day after the Navy reopened its own investigation, citing unexplained ignition of gunpowder in a test. The Navy, in a report last September, concluded that gunner's mate Clayton Hartwig probably set off the April 19, 1989, explosion by inserting a chemical detonator between bags of powder in one of the warship's 16-inch guns. The service resumed testing after Congress sought advice from scientists at the Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M., who then conducted an independent analysis of the Navy's initial findings. Sandia analysts said at a Senate hearing Friday they believed a possible cause of the Iowa explosion was the unintentional high-speed overramming of gunpowder bags in the barrel. The GAO said forms of some of the chemical constituents of what the Navy had theorized was an ignitor were ``either commonly used in the turrets or are part of the maritime environment.''

An Air Force fighter jet crashed into a residential area in rural south Georgia on Friday, killing the pilot and a housekeeper as it ignited two homes and hurled fiery debris across a highway. It was the second time since November that a military jet crashed in Georgia and killed civilians on the ground. Kathleen Guthrie, executive secretary at the Atkinson County sheriff's department, confirmed the deaths, but identities were unavailable. Ms. Guthrie said no one else was killed, although she earlier had reported three deaths. The F-16A ``Fighting Falcon'' was on a training flight from Moody Air Force Base near Valdosta _ about 40 miles away _ to Lake George Weapons Range in Florida when it crashed. The pilot was the only occupant, said base spokeswoman Dee Tait. One house and a mobile home were destroyed when the jet slammed into a row of homes on U.S. 441 north of Pearson shortly after 9:30 a.m., authorities said. At least four other homes, including the home of Curtis and Mary Alice Corbitt's house across the highway, were damaged by debris that flew in all directions.

Two activists for a radical environmental group were arrested Friday in connection with a bomb blast that ripped their car apart, but their supporters painted the duo as victims, not criminals. ``The evidence is strong they were transporting this device and that's why they were arrested,'' said Oakland Police Lt. Mike Sims at a Friday news conference. ``Based on our determination of the placement of the device in the car, we believe they should have known it was there. We believe it went off accidently.'' Judi Bari, 40, required surgery at Highland Hospital for a fractured pelvis and suffered other injuries. She was in listed stable condition Friday. Darryl Cherney, 33, suffered minor injuries including a head cut. He was treated and released Thursday night. The two Earth First! supporters were being held for investigation of possession and transportation of explosives. Cherney was booked into city jail, and Bari was under guard at the hospital. Bari's lawyer, Susan Jordan, said later that it's ``inconceiveable that they would destroy their movement by doing that. It's always easy to charge somebody who's unpopular.''

DOC.HEAD: `Stalin': The Revolutionary, the Despot and the Generalissmo
DOC.TEXT: A magnificent chronicle of Josef Stalin, the great and evil Soviet leader who built the 20th century's most powerful communist state on the bodies of 20 million people, opens tonight on PBS. His life and the totalitarian nation he devised from a backward, 19th century peasant kingdom are chillingly evoked in ``Stalin,'' a three-part series co-produced by Boston's WGBH-TV and Britain's Thames Television. Its executive producer is Phillip Whitehead, who won an Emmy in 1974 for ``The World at War,'' the BBC's landmark World War II chronicle. He brings the same thoughtful research and production values to Stalin's life.. Rare, archival footage, some released by the Soviets for the first time, is combined with interviews of gulag survivors, bodyguards and living relatives of Stalin _ including his rarely interviewed daughter, Svetlana Alliluyeva _ and his rivals Lenin, Trotsky, Bukharin and Kirov. Even the series' graphics are powerful and effective, from the compelling main title sequence to maps and ``mug shot'' layouts that trace the rise of Stalin and the fall of his Politburo rivals. The first episode, ``Revolutionary,'' chronicles the obscure origins of Iosif Vissarionovich Dzhugashvili, a poor boy from the provinces who fled the seminary to become a revolutionary and took the name Stalin, or steel. Young Stalin impressed Vladimir Lenin with his revolutionary zeal and is inducted into the Central Committee of Lenin's Bolshevik Party. There he eliminated his rivals until he becomes the sole Soviet ruler in 1929. The second episode, ``Despot,'' relates how Stalin used state terror to force central control of industry and collectivization of agriculture, inducing a famine that killed 7 million people in 1932 and 1933. No footage of that famine survives, only still photos of emaciated children and corpses, and newsreel film of the increased grain exports Stalin ordered to obtain industrial machinery while his own people starved. ``Despot'' for the first time implicates Stalin and his secret police in the assassination of popular Leningrad party leader Sergei Kirov, a rival whose death triggered the so-called Great Purge of 1934-38, in which 20 million people were killed and 8 million imprisoned in labor camps. The episode also shows how Stalin used the propaganda machinery to create his own cult of personality, which enshrined him as a beloved uncle and teacher at the same time he was ordering mass arrests and executions. The final episode, ``Generalissmo,'' covers Stalin's career as a military leader who took the Baltic states in the ill-famed 1939 non-aggression pact with Nazi Germany and was utterly surprised when Germany invaded in 1941. By the war's end, he had imposed communist regimes throughout Eastern Europe, and relations with the West were rapidly deteriorating. In 1953, he had just begun another purge when he was stricken by a fatal cerebral hemorrhage. ``When he took Russia on, it only had wooden plows,'' says one Soviet, ``and, when he left it, it was equipped with nuclear weapons. At his death, Stalin left Russia one of the two most powerful states of the modern world.'' They say even in the gulag he was mourned. ``Stalin'' is the second excellent PBS documentary to emerge from glasnost, Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's policy of openness in Soviet society. The first was former New York Times correspondent Hedrick Smith's superb look at contemporary Soviet society, ``Inside Gorbachev's USSR.'' Both documentaries complement each other and both, in their way, are tributes to the indomitable character of the Soviet people, who survived a monster like Stalin and are beginning to dismantle the nightmare he created.

Elsewhere in television ... WHAT ``IT'' IS: Lorimar Television has begun production in Vancouver, B.C., on Stephen King's ``It,'' a four-hour horror miniseries scheduled to air this fall on ABC. ``It'' stars Harry Anderson, Dennis Christopher, Annette O'Toole, Tim Reid, John Ritter, Richard Thomas and Tim Curry as ... gasp! ... Pennywise the Clown! ``It'' is directed by Tommy Lee Wallace from a Laurence Cohen screenplay, based on the horror master's best seller about a wave of unexplained child killings in a sleepy town in Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Ruben Blades Says Critics Won't Silence Him
DOC.TEXT: Ruben Blades, a gadfly of Latin American entertainment and politics, is speaking out again in a new cable movie, and says his critics won't keep him quiet. ``If you criticize Fidel Castro, then the left won't buy your records,'' he said. ``If you criticize Ronald Reagan, then the right won't buy your records.'' Blades wrote politically charged songs before beginning his acting career. ``Tiburon,'' Spanish for ``shark,'' likens U.S. policy in Latin America to a shark stalking the weak in the Caribbean. In ``Muevete,'' or ``Change Yourself,'' he criticizes social ills in Latin America, especially racism. Blades was interviewed on the Mexico City set of the HBO production ``One Man's War,'' the story of dissident Dr. Joel Filartiga's struggle for justice against the regime of former Paraguayan President Alfredo Stroessner. The film, in which Blades plays the Filartiga family's lawyer, is to be shown on Home Box Office next fall, but no air dates have been set. Filartiga, who is portrayed by British actor Anthony Hopkins, said the film ``shows that the criminal dictatorships in Latin America must be confronted.'' Filartiga's outspoken criticism of the Stroessner regime cost him the life of his 17-year-old son Joelito, who was abducted, beaten and tortured to death, allegedly at the hands of a police death squad, on March 29, 1976. ``One Man's War'' depicts the physician's struggle to bring his son's killer to justice. Filartiga, who continued to criticize the Stroessner dictatorship even after he had been threatened, was asked on the set why he didn't tone down his rhetoric. ``It would have been suicide,'' he replied. ``If I had quieted myself, Stroessner would have killed me and nothing would have happened. My only security was in denouncing him.'' The presumed leader of the death squad, Asuncion police Inspector-General Americo N. Pena-Irala, fled to the United States, where he lived as an illegal alien. Filartiga filed a lawsuit in 1979 in U.S. federal court and won a $375,000 award four years later, when Pena-Irala was deported to Paraguay. Eventually, an appeals court boosted damages to $10.4 million. It was, as Filartiga's lawyer said at the time, ``the first time judgment has been made in one country for torture in another.'' Despite the award, Pena-Irala is free in Paraguay, and Filartiga doesn't expect to collect a cent. Stroessner, driven from power last year, lives in exile in neighboring Brazil. It is one of the sadder ironies of Latin America that Blades, a Panamanian, Argentine actress Norma Aleandro and Brazilian director Sergio Toledo each have felt the brunt of dictatorships in their own homelands. Aleandro, best known for her role in ``The Official Story,'' about an adoptive mother's discovery of abuses by Argentina's military dictatorship, had to flee that country with her family after receiving death threats. Blades has close friends who were in danger from dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega until his ouster by U.S. forces, and Toledo's father was jailed for political differences with Brazil's military rulers. Aleandro and Blades said they don't seek roles in politically oriented films, but would not act in a film that justified repression. ``I would never consciously align myself with what I consider wrong,'' Aleandro said. ``I am not interested in working as an actor in propaganda films. That I won't do,'' said Blades. Toledo said that viewers of the HBO movie will be able to identify with the tragedy of the Filartiga family whether they have lived under a repressive regime or not. ``Every time you go deep into the heart of the characters, I think you can achieve a kind of universalization. What I hope is that we can create an empathy between audience and characters,'' Toledo said.

Elsewhere in television ... TED TURNER LOOKS SOUTHWARD: Ted Turner's Turner Network Television service, or TNT, will start a special Latin American and Caribbean satellite ``feed,'' starting in January. The project, Turner's first international expansion of one of his two entertainment networks, basically will be a movie service, network officials say. It initally will show English-language films with Spanish-language subtitles, but eventually hopes to offer the films with soundtracks in Spanish and Portuguese.

DOC.HEAD: Is The ``Credit Crunch'' Real or Imagined?
DOC.TEXT: Well, is there or is there not a credit crunch? The Federal Reserve, which should know, says more than half the banks it surveyed recently said they have tightened lending standards for small- and medium-size businesses. But the National Federation of Independent Business, which insists it should know becs members more than 500,000 independent businesses, finds no evidence of credit tightening nationally. In contrast, Sindlinger & Co., which claims to have firsthand information on the ause it claims abasis of about 1,000 telephone interviews each week throughout the year, says a ``credit crunch recession'' is under way. Gail Fosler, chief economist of the Conference Board, which keeps tabs on business and economic matters, disagrees. ``There is no evidence of a credit crisis, managed or otherwise, brewing in the financial system,'' she says. In that case, what should you make of an informal survey of 60 business people at a meeting of SBANE, the Small Business Association of New England? Asked if a crunch existed, eight replied no, four were unsure, 48 said yes. Or this statement by Martin Perlman, president of the National Association of Home Builders: ``The results of the survey (1,142 buildert experiencing more difficulties than others...'' Neither, they say, does it means that ``credit conditions are not somewhat more troublesome today than two or three months ago.'' But for now, they conclude, what is called a credit crunch ``is more smoke than fire, though the smoke is thick enough to warrant a watchful eye.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Plunge Into America's Heartland Unlikely to Yield Hayseeds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT Monday to Sunday; PICKS UP 3rd graf, ``If you ... of Minnesota.''
DOC.TEXT: Skyscrapers will provide the backdrop instead of cornstalks when Mikhail S. Gorbachev follows the footsteps of an earlier Soviet leader into America's heartland. Gorbachev's six-hour stop in Minneapolis on Sunday to meet with captains of industry and agriculture promises to bear little resemblance to Nikita Khrushchev's 1959 visit to an Iowa farm. ``If you want to go to a place in the Midwest that is different than New York, and you want to go to a place that is not a Rust Belt center but a place on the cutting edge, it could be that Minnesota is the place,'' said Thomas Noonan, a Russian studies professor at the University of Minnesota. Fourteen Fortune 500 companies are headquartered in the Twin Cities area, more than in all but three other U.S. cities. One of those companies, Control Data Corp., has been such a loyal trading partner with the Soviets that it once accepted shotguns and rare books as payment for mainframe computers, said Control Data spokesman Rick Berglund. Minnesota also is the base of one of the Soviet Union's biggest trading partners in grain, giant Cargill Inc. As the home of many world-famous artists, composers, playwrights, authors and musicians, plus two orchestras, two museums and two theaters with international reputations, Minnesota also has long cultivated its cultural image. The Twin Cities area alone has more than 200 theater companies. ``Minnesota does represent an ideal American condition in so many ways _ a hard-working and civic conscious population, high standards of excellence in all endeavors, an openness to new ideas, a sense of leadership,'' said Martin Friedman, director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis. ``Minnesota is a national leader in the arts, a public accustomed to quality _ open-minded, tolerant _ a public that encourages invention,'' he said. Envelope magnate and best-selling author Harvey Mackay said Gorbachev should find in Minnesota ``a sense of our good ol' work ethic, strong individualism, that this is not just a visit to do business with the Soviet Union to feather our nests.'' ``You can't X-ray a person's bankbook here by looking at the cut of their suit or the grille on their car,'' Mackay said. Much of what Minnesota is may not come as a surprise to Soviet visitors because the state has been a leader in U.S.-Soviet exchanges, said Liza Malott, program officer for the President's U.S.-Soviet Exchange Initiative with the U.S. Information Agency. Exchange visits have involved Minnesota and Soviet artists, actors, students, bicyclists, scuba divers and mushers. Minnesota and Soviet chemical dependency counselors discussed cooperation on alcoholism rehabilitation research; the International Diabetes Center in suburban Minneapolis is involved in a cooperative venture to build a diabetes center in Moscow; children's theater companies from Moscow and Minneapolis traded performances; and a Minnesota-Soviet bicycle team is in the midst of a Twin Cities-Soviet Union trek. Minneapolis-St. Paul has a sister-city relationship with Novosibirsk, and Duluth is a sister city to Petrozavodsk. To stimulate more trade, Minnesota will open trade offices in Moscow and Budapest this summer, said Richard Bohr, executive director of the Minnesota Trade Office. William C. Norris, founder and chairman emeritus of Control Data, said several Minnesota companies enjoy favored status in the Soviet Union because they have demonstrated loyalty during rocky political times. When the Soviet Union intervened in Afghanistan in 1979, for example, Norris lobbied against the trade embargo imposed by former President Carter. ``It was a mistake,'' Norris said of the embargo. ``We have so much to gain by tapping into their economy.'' Karin Berkholtz, a Latvian member of the Governor's Commission on Eastern Europe, said there are up to 12,350 Ukrainians, Latvians, Estonians and Lithuanians living in Minnesota, some of whom plan to demonstrate while Gorbachev is in town. Others in the state, however, may be oblivious to the Soviet leader's visit. In southwestern Minnesota, for example, farmers may be preoccupied with the grasshopper plague. The insects devoured whole fields last year and are expected to be worse this year. But dairy farmer Tom Hirsch of rural Sleepy Eye is enthusiastic about the upcoming visit. ``It's a great idea,'' Hirsch said. ``We've got the wholesome rural life, and I think he's interested in that. I think he's really a headsy person to come to Minnesota.'' Hirsch said Gorbachev's visit should help Minnesota farmers sell their crops to the Soviets. ``I think it will have some positive (effects) on the trade negotiations,'' he said. One of the few similarities in the Soviet visits to Iowa and Minnesota will be the hype. In Iowa, armed guards and an unruly press corps of 300 shadowed Khrushchev. In Minnesota, Gov. Rudy Perpich has proclaimed the Gorbachev visit ``bigger than the Super Bowl,'' which the Twin Cities will host in 1992. ``No one really knows yet how this will develop,'' said Peter Zidek, a supercomputer consultant from Apple Valley. ``But it's big and it will open a lot of eyes to the Twin Cities.''

DOC.HEAD: German Interest High in Bush-Gorbachev Summit
DOC.TEXT: Perhaps nowhere in Europe will there be as much interest in this week's summit meeting between George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev as in the two Germanys _ East and West. With 380,000 Soviet troops stationed in East Germany and 250,000 U.S. troops in West Germany, the two nations that are about to become one have the keenest interest in superpower negotiations to drastically reduce foreign forces stationed on their soil. Along with the troops, some of the world's deadliest weapons are kept on German soil: high-tech jet fighters; nuclear-tipped, short-range rockets; and thousands of atomic artillery shells. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said earlier this month that it was up to Germans to decide ``the internal aspects'' of unification. On troop levels, Baker said outsiders could become involved in the discussions, but here, too, the Germans were in charge of their future. The troop negotiations, being conducted in Vienna, Austria, by NATO and the Warsaw Pact, have been flagging and will be one of the prime topics when Bush and Gorbachev meet for four days in Washington, beginning Thursday. Bush himself said last week that ``the talks haven't gone as far or as fast as I would like to see. ... Maybe we can find some way at the summit, or before the summit, to move CFE (the talks) forward.'' U.S. officials have said they feel Moscow is reluctant to conclude a Conventional Forces in Europe treaty unless there are assurances that the large West Germany army will not pose a threat after unification. One U.S. official, who requested anonymity, said recently that it would be difficult to complete a treaty this year because of the German issue and also because of Soviet concerns about the steadfastness of the East European allies. The day before Bush spoke, however, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said after meeting with his West German counterpart, Hans Dietrich Genscher, that Moscow ``advocates an acceleration in the Vienna negotiations.'' West German officials were quoted in Geneva, where the two men met, as saying the U.S. perception of Soviet hesitancy on the treaty might be a misunderstanding. Shevardnadze himself, asked if could confirm the purported Soviet position on the German military, replied, ``No.'' In December, the two superpowers agreed to slash their central European forces to 195,000 each, with the United States allowed to keep an additional 30,000 troops in Britain and southern Europe. There are now 305,000 U.S. troops and an estimated 565,000 Soviet troops in Europe. Looking toward the summit, Capt. Stefan Lang, a spokesman for the West German Defense Ministry, commented recently, ``We hope important signals in the direction of arms controls come out of the summit, but what exactly they will be we don't know.'' No one is more eager for major superpower cutbacks than the Germans. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government says it wants the eventual complete removal of Soviet and U.S. short-range nuclear weapons from German soil. ``We believe that the Lance (missile) and nuclear artillery have lost most of their significance, and therefore there should be thoughts about how these rockets can be negotiated away,'' Lang told The Associated Press. He stressed, however, that the Lance missiles should be removed only in negotiations, because ``the Soviets still have a huge superiority in this area. This should occur in a balanced way.'' An agreement to reduce conventional forces would open the way to negotiations on the superpowers' nuclear arsenals in Europe. Washington and the other NATO allies have said they are ready for talks with the Soviets on the short-range nuclear weapons, most of which are based in Germany. But NATO has not taken a clear stand on negotiating the numbers of these weapons down to zero. A feud could break out within NATO if attempts are made to replace short-range nuclear weapons in West Germany with air-launched rockets. ``I am warning against a new atomic arms race. New weapons are not needed,'' Genscher said recently. The future of NATO, and of American troops in Europe, could become a bone of contention as well. Some West German politicians, including Genscher, have warmed up to the Soviets' idea of creating new ``European security structures'' to take the place of NATO and the Warsaw Pact. But Washington and other NATO partners say they are vehemently against replacing NATO. The Social Democrats, Kohl's main political rivals, have also said NATO and the Warsaw Pact should be transformed into a new, Europe-wide security arrangement. The Social Democrats are pressing NATO to make major changes that would better reflect the rapid waning of the once-mighty, Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. ``It would be very good if the Americans prepared the way for this with constructive proposals (during the summit),'' Horst Ehmke, disarmament expert for the Social Democrats, said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, May 29

For Release Monday, May 28
DOC.HEAD: `Yield Curve' Takes Positive Turn
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: The recent downswing in interest rates isn't the only development that has encouraged analysts as they follow changes in the cost of borrowed money. A good many observers also have been heartened to see the ``yield curve,'' which tracks the differences between short- and long-term interest rates, bending into a positive shape. Now that long-term interest-bearing investments carry yields higher than their short-term competition, these analysts see potential benefits for investors of many kinds. ``The historical record suggests that this is a reason to be optimistic about the prospects for common stocks,'' says Mark Stumpp, research director at PDI Strategies, a part of the investment management affiliate of Prudential Insurance Company of America. A ``normal'' yield curve is supposed to have a positive slope _ that is, show a gradual increase in yields as maturities increase on debt securities of the same or comparable issuers. In theory at least, a long-term Treasury bond should yield more than a short-term Treasury bill, because its owners expose themselves to greater risks _ in particular, regarding inflation. Changes in the inflation rate don't have much time to affect the purchasing power of the money an investor ties up in a Treasury bill that has a life of only three or six months. In the case of a bond that won't come due for as long as 30 years, by contrast, inflation can have a devastating impact. A 30-year commitment involves a lot of other unknowns as well, including such seemingly remote possibilities as the chance that the credit standing of even a blue-chip borrower like the federal government might diminish over time. When the yield curve flattens or inverts, as it did for much of the past couple of years, it often is regarded as a symptom of economic imbalance or uncertainty. As recently as six months ago, the yield curve for Treasury securities was practically a level line, with yields hovering just under 8 percent whether you were looking at a 90-day bill or a 30-year bond. Then, through the first four months of 1990, long-term interest rates rose while short-term rates barely budged. That helped tilt the yield curve to a positive slope that has persisted as rates turned downward this month. Toward the end of last week, yields in the Treasury market ranged upward from 7.92 percent for three-month bills to 8.11 percent for six-month bills and 8.15 percent for one-year bills. The longest-term bonds, meanwhile, were yielding 8.60 percent, though between about seven-year and 30-year maturities the curve was still flat. According to Stumpp, this offers considerable food for thought for anyone with a stake in the future direction of the stock market. Over the last 30 years, he says, stocks have fared far better in six-month periods after the yield curve in December or June had a positive slope than they did in the relatively few comparable periods when it was flat or inverted. Prices rose in more than three-quarters of the periods ushered in by a curve with a positive slope, and fell almost two-thirds of the time when they started out with a flat or inverted curve. As those calculations show, Stumpp acknowledges, the ``yield curve indicator'' for stocks cannot be taken as infallible. ``Nevertheless,'' he concludes, ``judging by the historical record of this indicator, stocks look better than they did late last year.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, May 28

For Release Tuesday AMs, May 29, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Bill Bradley: From Dollar Bill to Capitol Hill
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: For a long time, he feared he'd be known as ``Sen. Bill Bradley, former New York Knick'' for the rest of his life. The image of a man ``wearing short pants in drafty arenas'' didn't seem to enhance the credibility sought by New Jersey's young senator when he arrived here in 1978. So the Rhodes scholar with a great baseline jumpshot deliberately shunned the key. ``Dollar Bill'' _ a nickname he earned from his pro teammates because of his frugal handling of his affairs _ set out to apply his sense of discipline to mastery of parliamentary procedure. He built support for tax reform, forging alliances until Congress overhauled the tax system in 1986. He fought for the Superfund cleanup bill, child nutrition programs, more Medicaid money for poor mothers and children, all the while plunging himself into details of foreign policy, Third World debt and international trade. ``The important thing is to get things done,'' he says. Twelve years after what he calls his divorce from basketball, Bradley returns alone in the summers to a court near his mountain home in Denville, N.J., to relax with his famous five-spot warmups _ ``but not the jumpers, you understand,'' he says good-humoredly. ``The heart is willing, but the knees aren't,'' the former Knicks forward laments. About all he puts them through in Washington these days are sessions shooting hoops with his 13-year-old daughter, Theresa Anne. Aides say the daughter he devotedly drops at school each morning and cares for four days a week shows signs of catching up with her father's legendary technique. Playing with her has helped him put basketball back into perspective after several years in which he believed he could only be taken seriously on Capitol Hill by pushing his NBA career firmly into the past. ``Now I look back and I can think more easily about it; the fact of the matter is that I like the game,'' says Bradley. The senator picks his 6-foot-5 frame up from his office chair during an interview over coffee to point out reminders of what he's mastered in his 46 years: a golden gavel for presiding 100 hours in his first Senate session and photographs from his 1970 and 1973 NBA championship victories with the New York Knicks. He takes equal pride in the gavel and the shot of him wrapped in a bearhug around Willis Reed, triumphant after the Knicks' 1973 championship. Sports metaphors occasionally punctuate his conversation. ``In basketball and in politics, the only score that counts is the one at the final buzzer,'' he says when asked about Republican predictions that his opponent will do well to capture 38 percent of the November vote. Bradley also says he'll serve out another six-year Senate term to the buzzer, despite recurring speculation that he will seek the presidency. His supporters take his word at face value. ``I believe that in his heart and his head, he believes he is going to serve out his full term,'' says Harold Hodes, once chief of staff to former New Jersey Gov. Brendan T. Byrne. But, he adds, ``between 1991 and 1992 a lot of things can happen.'' Would waiting until 1996 hurt him? Are supporters pressuring him to run? ``It's a very funny thing,'' Bradley responds. ``I assume that's what people talk about sometimes, but that's not what they talk about with me. I think people respect my sense of service. They know that if they mention anything to me about that, that I will say, `Look, my interest is New Jersey.''' Still, Bradley-watching has become a pastime within both parties. Roger Stone, a Republican consultant who helped elect Ronald Reagan, says Bradley is conservative enough and independent enough to appeal to GOP voters. ``Our party could nominate a Bill Bradley,'' Stone says. ``If you look at his votes on Contra aid, defense issues, the MX missile, the B-1 bomber, he looks at issues one-by-one.'' And, looking at Bradley's command of 64 percent of the vote in his last re-election bid, Stone adds: ``A lot of Republicans obviously voted for him in 1984.'' Bradley's fair-tax policies have appealed to even some of the most conservative voices. ``He's not one of those Democrats who has never met a tax hike he doesn't like,'' says Howard Phillips, chairman of the Conservative Caucus. The most common negative that people on both sides say about Bradley is he lacks charisma. The word comes up again and again, along with references to improvements in his once-sleep-inducing speeches. ``I think there isn't any Bradley charisma. But it's obvious that he cares about people. It's obvious he listens,'' Stone says. ``On a one-on-one basis, he's easy to like.'' Christine Todd Whitman, the GOP candidate who hopes to unseat him in November, has criticized Bradley for endorsing proposed campaign spending reform legislation when his own campaign kitty is way above the $5.5 million limit that would apply in New Jersey. For his part, Bradley bemoans being forced to spend so much to buy television time in the expensive New York and Philadelphia media markets because New Jersey has none of its own. ``You end up being collectors for television,'' he says. But he says he needs to raise the money to fend off any possible negative GOP campaign. The cautious nature is part of Bradley's style. For the past two years he also has been playing in national political circles, Hodes notes. He has spent countless hours jetting to podiums around the country on behalf of campaigning colleagues. ``Remember the early endorsement of Michael Dukakis, at a very critical time for Dukakis; the decision to back Ron Brown for Democratic National Committee chairman. New Jersey was a swing seat for Brown and Bradley endorsed him,'' Hodes says. And at the same time, Bradley has quietly been learning about issues outside New Jersey. For example, although New Jersey has a strong agriculture industry, the senator made several visits to a South Dakota wheat farm to study another region's farm problems. ``I went back over time,'' Bradley says. ``I have to physically experience things; it's not enough for me to read the book.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, May 29

DOC.HEAD: Civic Forum Led Revolution, But Has Many Election Challengers
DOC.TEXT: It won the ``velvet revolution,'' runs the government and smiles on every village from its happy-face symbol, but Civic Forum has tough competition in the nation's first free elections since 1946. Polls show it leading, but with less than a quarter of the total vote. Civic Forum appears likely to lose to the Christian Democrats in Slovakia, the more rural and Roman Catholic of the two constituent republics. Campaigning began officially April 29, with rallies, posters on practically every available surface and endless spots on radio and television. Each of 23 parties fighting for seats in the federal parliament and the Czech and Slovak legislatures gets four hours of time. Czechoslovaks will vote Friday and Saturday. Few differences are evident among the parties. All reject the communist past, including the Communists. All favor a market economy and parliamentary democracy. Civic Forum's membership cuts across the political spectrum. It claims to be neither left nor right and emphasizes its well-known personalities, including President Vaclav Havel, experience, aninciples. Civic Forum's competition comes from a flock of new or remodeled parties, chief among them the Christian Democrats, buoyed by recent center-right victories in East Germany and Hungary. ``We shall win ... but I don`t know how big it will be,'' said Jana Ryslinkova, a mathematician who speaks for Civic Forum. ``I think it won't be less than 30 percent.'' Havel, Civic Forum's biggest asset with voters, is officially setting himself apart from organization he helped found, on grounds his office requires impartiality. The immensely popular president does help indirectly by participating in events organized by Civic Forum. He opened its indoor-outdoor exhibit on recent Czechoslovak history, which draws large crowds. Under a new proportional system, a party whose candidate list gets 5 percent of the vote nationally is guaranteed representation in Parliament. Up to six parties could qualify, forcing Civic Forum to make a power-sharing arrangement. Parties variously describe themselves as right, center or center-left, but the main distinctions involve economic control and social benefits. Leftist parties such as the Communists, Socialists and Social Democrats favor slower conversion to capitalism and some retention of benefits. The Christian Democrats reject any degree of socialism, empasizing their identification with ``Christian values and tradition.'' Some Civic Forum leaders want to retain elements of socialism. A survey last month by the state polling organization said Civic Forum picked up strength in April, to 22 percent from 19 percent the previous month. The Christian Democrats had 15 percent overall, but led Civic Forum's partners in Slovakia 22 percent to 12 percent. In November, Civic Forum seemed to be the country's only authentic political force. Its rallies attracted hundreds of thousands of people and persuaded Communist leaders to step aside peacefully. Since then, the government it dominates has improved Czechoslovakia's image abroad, negotiated a deal for withdrawal of Soviet military forces by June 1991 and erased myriad symbols of the old order. Radical overhaul of the economy must wait until after the election, however, in part because of divisions in the government over how fast to go. Ms. Ryslinkova, the Civic Forum spokeswoman, said the edge goes to Civic Forum over parties offering similar programs because ``what we have more than the other parties is the ... people able to lead.'' Hoping to overcome it is the Christian Democratic Alliance of the People's Party, formerly allied with the Communists, the Christian Democratic Party in in the Czech republic, and the Christian Democratic Movement in Slovakia. The alliance has joined forces with associations of would-be entrepreneurs and farmers and appeals to those with Christian values, said Miroslav Bartos, a People's Party candidate and one of the parliamentarians appointed in December to replace resigning Communist deputies. Communist spokesman Josef Hora said his party, which ruled from 1948 until last year, might get 10 percent to 12 percent of the vote. The party claims a membership of 900,000 in the population of 15.5 million. Hora complained that critics don't take the party's ``renewal'' seriously and still blame it for the repressions of the past.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, June 3

DOC.HEAD: Chocolate Company Survived Communism, Regained Old Name
DOC.TEXT: The label on a chocolate box makes a metaphor for the troubled tale of postwar Poland. ``Formerly E. Wedel,'' it says in large letters. In tiny print, a footnote adds: ``22nd of July Confectionery Industry Works.'' Three generations of Wedel family labor were erased by Communist fiat in the postwar zeal to nationalize private industries. It took four decades to figure out it was all a big mistake. Now that Poland is embracing capitalism once again, the 22nd of July Confectionery Industry Works also will be ``formerly.'' The new label is not expected to commemorate it. The chocolate company is to be one of the first five state enterprises offered for sale to private investors as post-Communist Poland tries to revitalize a crumbling economy. From the state-owned industries, private companies are to be formed to flourish or fail without government subsidies. First for the auction block are those deemed to have the greatest chance of success, and Wedel occupies a special place in Poland as a prewar company that still means quality to consumers otherwise awash in shoddy goods. When the means of production were liberated from the capitalists, it is said the workers at Wedel ``spontaneously'' called for it to be renamed in honor of July 22, 1944, when a Soviet-backed committee proclaimed itself the government of Poland. The candy-loving class and Wedel's foreign customers were not impressed. As the Communist economy staggered through its last years, apparatchicks in the confection section finally admitted the blunder. The Wedel name went back on the packages, with the delicate addition of ``formerly,'' and the official name became a postscript. This year, the national holiday was changed from July 22 to May 3, the date of a Polish constitution in 1791. Andrzej Karbowniczek, who runs the factory, said: ``Regardless of political changes, we have never been ashamed of the example of a man who achieved very good results'' in the chocolate business. That man was Jan Wedel, third-generation capitalist. His grandfather, Karol Wedel, opened a Warsaw candy shop in 1851 and the family's fortunes were sweetened by the second generation, Emil, who sent his own son, Jan, to Paris and London for instruction in chemistry and management. When Jan returned, the business expanded further. The Wedels opened a Paris shop in 1937 and flew the candy to it in their own airplane. Jan Wedel is remembered with reverence in Warsaw. ``The company was Wedel's `family','' the weekly Tygodnik Solidarnosc said. ``He attended name days, birthdays, weddings; granted loans, helped solve life's problems.'' Wedel's factory was occupied by the Germans during World War II and partially destroyed. Then, says a promotional booklet from the mid-1980s, ``The liberation of Warsaw began ... the socialist expansion of the factory.'' One day in 1949, the company was nationalized by People's Poland and no longer belonged to the Wedel family. ``People close to Mr. Wedel said he was most happy that the old machinery was replaced by modern machines,'' said Karbowniczek, the factory director. Happy to lose his family's legacy? Well, Karbowniczek said, Wedel ``was a clever man. He did not intend to fight ... because he knew it was ... useless.'' Tygodnik Solidarnosc said that Wedel was allowed to return as a technical manager's assistant, but that the factory register shows him leaving after less than a year due to ``poor health.'' The newspaper suggested the real reason for his departure was harassment by Communist Party operatives at the factory. Witnesses often saw Wedel sit for hours on a bench in the park across the street, staring at the factory, the paper reported. In 1950, one Boleslaw W., identified as a candy wrapper, wrote to the Communist Party daily Trybuna Ludu: ``It has been five years since the factory has been reopened by the Polish Communist Party . .. years of comrades' efforts to ... improve production and improve working conditions. Production and the existence of the factory itself have now nothing to do with the capitalist Wedel and owe everything to the working class. ``Up to this moment, against logic, the factory has been working under the old name Wedel. How can it be? How is it possible to export under the capitalist's name? Our export production must be our tool of propaganda ... of production of working people, without capitalists.'' The name 22nd of July _ 22 Lipca in Polish _ was adopted, whether by ``spontaneous'' demand of workers or by the apparatus. Karbowniczek said the decision ``was not too fortunate. I had a lot of problems with foreign trading partners who were asking who that Mr. Lipca was.'' There are said to be Wedel heirs, two nephews and the children of Jan's last wife, but the management said none had inquired about reclaiming the factory. Parliament is still drafting laws on selling state companies and returning nationalized properties to former owners. With agreement in principle, first steps have been taken at such major enterprises as the Gdansk shipyard where Solidarity was born and the Universal foreign trade company, but complex mechanics have yet to be resolved. What, for example, should be the balance between ownership by Poles and foreigners and by investors and workers? How is the value of a company to be established when standard Western accounting principles have never been applied? ``Bid low,'' was the advice of a Western businessman helping organize the sales. The Wedel factory, which has about 3,000 employees, made sweets last year valued at 126 billion zlotys, or $13.2 million. Roughly 20 percent of its production was exported, including the trademark Wedel chocolate wafers in round blue-and-white boxes. ``Wedel is one of the first enterprises to be privatized because we are one of the best,'' said Jozef Rutkowski, the factory's financial manager. ``We belong to the group of enterprises that can guarantee to their shareholders that their capital will be quickly multiplied.'' The company suffered with the decline of Poland's economy. In 1983, under martial law, there was not enough foreign currency to buy raw materials and chocolate production ceased for the first time in Wedel's history. Managers say the company has enjoyed relative financial health, however, in part because of the loyalty of customers and employees. Karbowniczek, the manager, did not appear to grasp the irony of a company outliving four decades of communism, because of quality stemming from its capitalist founders, to become one of the best candidates for return to private hands. He did see a parallel with Poland: ``It is like the history of our nation, because ... regardless of whether it was private, a stock company or a state-owned enterprise, it survived.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, June 3

DOC.HEAD: Nothing Known of Man Who Stopped Tanks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to include LaserPhoto notation
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY326 of May 25
With BC-China One Year Later
DOC.TEXT: The man who captured the spirit of the 1989 pro-democracy movement by stopping a column of tanks has vanished. An Associated Press photograph and television pictures showed the man, in a white shirt, standing defiantly before the tanks near Tiananmen Square on June 5. The pictures appeared around the world and became a symbol of the pro-democracy protests. Some Chinese sources believe it is almost certain the young man was arrested and executed soon afterward. A London newspaper, the Sunday Express, identified him last June as Wang Weilin, a 19-year-old student, and quoted Wang's friends as expressing fears he was put to death. No other foreign news or human rights organization has been able to identify the man or obtain hard evidence of what happened to him. Some expressed doubts about the name Wang Weilin. After stopping the column, the man climbed onto the turret of the lead tank and pleaded with the soldiers to turn back and stop killing people. Ultimately, bystanders led him away and he disappeared into the crowd. Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin said in an interview with ABC television May 2 that the dramatic pictures illustrated the army's forbearance. He said the pictures showed tank drivers would not run down a citizen and proved the allegations of tanks crushing demonstrators were lies. Jiang said he could not confirm whether the man was arrested. When asked whether the young man had been executed, Jiang replied in English: ``I think never, never killed.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, May 27

For release Thursday, May 31, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Moynihan Crusades To Build a Better Social Security Card
DOC.TEXT: Daniel Patrick Moynihan was 15 when he got his Social Security card in 1943. He promptly lost it. ``It didn't look like anything worth keeping,'' the New York senator recalled. ``It did not suggest its importance.'' Moynihan, who chairs the Senate subcommittee on Social Security, for more than a decade has been crusading to replace the paper card with something more impressive and tamper-resistant. ``I think it a rather simple proposition that a plastic, counterfeit-proof Social Security card would reduce fraud and enhance public confidence in our Social Security system,'' he said at a recent subcommittee hearing. ``We should have a durable, plastic card that people can carry around in their wallets and feel that they have something, a card that gives them a sense of membership in the Social Security system.'' That ``simple proposition,'' however, keeps bumping up against longstanding fears that the Social Security card would become a national ID card the government could use to keep track of people. Those concerns were born with the Social Security system itself in the 1930s, when there were worries that the giant retirement system would become a bureaucracy that had everyone's number and knew all about them. As a result, the government designed Social Security cards ``to be pulpy and wear out in six weeks or whatever and not give any sense that the Third Reich was appearing in the United States,'' Moynihan said. A more enduring card would help instill confidence in Social Security and reduce crimes based on false identities perpetuated with counterfeit cards, according to Moynihan. But even now, when the use of Social Security numbers is widely accepted for a variety of purposes, the government is wary of making any changes that would suggest a national identification system. ``The administration has always had fundamental concerns about the possibility of the Social Security card and number becoming a universal identifier in this country,'' Louis D. Enoff, the agency's deputy commissioner of programs, said at a hearing of Moynihan's subcommittee last month. The General Accounting Office, in a March report to Congress, suggested that debate already may be largely moot. ``Many would argue that we already have an almost universal identifier in the country _ the Social Security number,'' the GAO said. It noted that a Social Security number is needed to report income earned from work, to claim children 2 and older as dependents for tax purposes, and to obtain driver's licenses in many states. Moynihan thought he had succeeded in improving Social Security cards in 1983, when Congress enacted legislation requiring the government to come up with a new counterfeit-resistant card. But the new cards, although more difficult to tamper with, look much like the old ones and still are made of paper. His crusade is receiving renewed attention this year because it has been linked with the issue of employment discrimination by employers afraid of being punished for hiring illegal aliens. Under the nation's 4-year-old immigration law, workers can establish their legal eligibility to work by presenting any one of 17 documents, including Social Security cards. The GAO's report said discrimination might be reduced by simplifying the process for checking work eligibility, perhaps by relying on a revised Social Security card or a driver's license with a verified Social Security number. ``Using a single card would reduce employer confusion and make it easier for employers to comply with the law's verification requirements without discriminating,'' the agency said. But Enoff told the subcommittee that Social Security does not need a better card and that there are less expensive ways to address employment discrimination. Gene McNary, commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said immigration law prohibits the establishment of a national identity card, but does allow the creation of an ``employment authorization document.'' ``We have to work to find a way to produce the latter without violating the restriction of the former,'' he told the subcommittee last month. ``We don't want a card that is going to have to be carried, that is going to cause people to feel they live under Big Brother.'' The Justice Department's Andrew Strojny warned the panel that designating any one card as a universal work authorization document could create ``a major change in the relationship between the government and its citizenry.'' ``Had I been required to produce my Social Security card for inspection when I was hired by the Department of Justice, I would be unemployed today,'' he said. ``I lost my Social Security card over 20 years ago.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thurs, May 31

DOC.HEAD: `Grandmother's Cookbook' _ A Recipe for Preserving the Past
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Rose von Hohen kneaded and cut thousands of Hungarian noodles over the decades following a recipe that existed in her mind's eye and in her practiced hands. Her family, like families everywhere, nagged her for years to write down the recipes before they were lost forever. She finally did, and the result is ``Grandmother's Cookbook'' _ a folksy compilation by Mrs. von Hohen and a granddaughter, Carrie J. Gamble. Mrs. von Hohen, 81, provides the recipes for Austrian-Hungarian dishes she learned from her mother, while Ms. Gamble illustrates the beginning of each chapter with watercolors of wildflowers her grandmother treasured while growing up in rural Pennsylvania. Each wildflower elicits a remembrance. The wisteria that covered an arbor over the driveway, for example: ``The big clusters of purple flowers looked like bunches of grapes and were so fragrant. They were always full of bees too. In fact we had a beehive in our attic because of the wisteria. I remember our neighbor helped us take it down one day and we got a washtub full of fragrant honey from it.'' Mrs. von Hohen, in a recent telephone interview from her home in Hatboro, Pa., said she's mystified in the renewed interest in such traditional favorites as cabbage noodles, liver dumplings, ``potatoe balls'' and jelly buns. ``Nowadays they put so many flavors together, and these are so plain,'' she said. Ms. Gamble, in a phone interview from her home in Doylestown, Pa., is not so modest in assessing her grandmother's cooking: ``Twenty years later people will remember a cake my grandmother made.'' Mrs. von Hohen grew up on a 42-acre farm in Bucks County that she refers to as the Homestead in her book. She remembers that all the cookies she made as a child were either round or half-moon shapes, cut out using a glass because they had no cookie-cutters. ``We raised everything _ homemade butter, chickens. We didn't have to skimp on what we cooked with. Things really tasted good then. I don't think butter today has any taste,'' she said. When she was 16 she went to Philadelphia to cook for a wealthy family and expanded her repertoire. ``When I first came to the city I couldn't eat the chicken because I didn't think it had any taste, because I was used to fresh-killed chicken. Or eggs either, I couldn't eat them because I was used to fresh. On the farm we had an apple orchard and peach orchard and you made your own jellies and preserves.'' She quit her job three years later to get married, and began cooking for her husband and his family. ``There were always a lot of people to cook for,'' she said with a laugh. Mrs. von Hohen has three children, 11 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Her husband died in 1985, and since then she has lived alone in an apartment. Her cooking these days is confined to meals for herself and Wednesday night suppers she prepares for her one of her daughters and Ms. Gamble. She also cooks special treats for holiday gatherings, like the poundcake and saffron bread she made for Easter. Asked if any of her children or grandchildren are good cooks, Mrs. von Hohen said all of her granddaughters were given copies of the book and are trying out the recipes. ``They've had good luck with them. Most of my granddaughters just got married,'' she said. Although she never used the term, Mrs. von Hohen's kind of cooking is called comfort food these days. She doesn't own a microwave or food processor _ ``those things are a pain'' _ and her only concession to modernity is a hand mixer she uses when her shoulder bothers her. Her recipes are written in a language that is usually clear if somewhat untraditional. Instructions for one dish tell the reader to cut bread into 1-inch squares and ``fluff the squares'' with melted margarine. Mrs. von Hohen said her favorite recipe in the book is the goulash. Here it is, verbatim: HUNGARIAN GOULASH= Put 1 tablespoon oil in a pan. Finely slice 1 large onion and fry in oil until golden brown. Add 1 teaspoon paprika. Stir it around and add the meat. You can use chicken, beef or veal. Add a piece of green pepper, a stalk of celery, a tomato (fresh or canned), 1 bay leaf, and 2 cloves. Salt and pepper to taste. Steam the meat until it draws juice. Then sprinkle 1 tablespoon of flour on the meat. Add 1 or 2 cups of water and simmer until tender. This usually takes about 2 hours. Add 1 or 2 diced potatoes for the last { hour. I like to serve this with rice, noodles, or bread dumplings.
``Grandmother's Cookbook'' was published by Ms. Gamble's printing company. It is available by sending $14.95 to Carrie J. Gamble Inc., 505 East State St., Doylestown, Pa. 18901.

DOC.HEAD: States Urged to Set Better Standards for Board and Care Homes
DOC.TEXT: States should set tougher standards for board and care homes to ensure that elderly and disabled residents receive proper care, a federal report recommends. Almost all states set board and care standards on personal care, fire safety, sanitation and licensure, according to the report from the inspector general's office at the Department of Health and Human Services. However, only ``limited attention'' is given to the level of care needed by residents, training and dealing with unlicensed facilities, the report said. Board and care facilities offer residents room, meals, help with activities of daily living and some degree of supervision. More than 1 million elderly and disabled individuals live in such facilities, the report said. Use of board and care homes has grown with the deinstitutionalization of the mentally ill, the availability of Supplemental Security Income benefits for the aged and disabled, and a shortage of nursing home beds and other long-term care services, the report said. It recommended that states improve their ability to identify unlicensed facilities and to encourage board and care homes to become licensed. It also recommended that states enforce their requirements with sanctions such as fines, restrictions on new admissions and closing homes. Procedures for handling complaints should be publicized so that complaints reach the proper authorities, it said. As an outgrowth of abuses in board and care homes, Congress in 1976 enacted legislation requiring states to set standards assuring that SSI recipients do not live in substandard facilities. The HHS study was based on interviews with federal and state officials, board and care operators and advocates for residents, visits to board and care homes, and an analysis of current standards. Nearly half the state officials interviewed felt their states assigned a low priority to board and care regulation, and a majority felt the 1976 legislation could not be enforced. Nearly three-fourths of state officials and 80 percent of care providers and advocates recommended a common set of national minimum standards. These would include basic safety and service requirements, ways to deal with unlicensed facilities, staff training and requirements for different levels of care.

DOC.HEAD: Voice Traits of Elderly May Cause Prejudice
DOC.TEXT: Older people who speak loudly may not be hard of hearing _ they may be responding to negative stereotypes about them, a speech communication researcher says. ``Stereotypes sometimes include cranky, weak and ill,'' said linguistics Professor Harry Hollien, founding director of the University of Florida's Institute for Advanced Study of Communication Processes. Older people who have trembling, breathy or jittery voices may be negatively stereotyped as grouchy or frail, he said. Hollien published a study called ``Old Voices: What Do We Really Know About Them?,'' and has categorized distinct voice characteristics of different age groups. Aging reduces the number of sensory nerve endings, often causing impairment of vision, hearing and reflexes, Hollien said. Hollien also found that voices of aging men and women become similar after menopause. ``In pre-adolescent ages, boys' and girls' voices can hardly be told apart,'' he said. ``After puberty, the characteristics go in opposite directions and after menopause, they start to become alike again.'' Other vocal characteristics of the elderly include change in vocal fry _ the lowest voice register in human frequency. As a person ages, the vocal fry becomes lower, adding a ``rough, jittering'' quality to the voice. Breathiness _ or air loss during talking _ also correlates with aging, Hollien said.
