DOC.HEAD: Passing Wealth to Minors Takes Planning
DOC.TEXT: In today's consumer-oriented society, most people have possessions and, in some form or another, many people have plans to pass their wealth to their children or other young relatives. Whether at the prompting of a financial adviser to get some tax savings by shifting income to another person or solely out of generosity, many people begin transferring their property during their lifetimes. However, when the recipient is legally a minor, a problem arises: State property laws restrict minors from possessing, owning, managing, selling or transferring property. In addition, third parties often assume a greater risk dealing with minors because children may disaffirm or renounce any contract they have entered. The solution to these complications can take many forms: trust arrangements, court-appointed guardianships or custodianships, and even state-authorized means of transfer. All states have special laws that make it easier and legally safer to make a gift to a minor. These laws primarily take two forms: the Uniform Gifts to Minors Act, which has been adopted in almost all states, or the Uniform Transfers to Minors Act, which at last count was in place in 34 states. UGMA, which has been in effect since 1956, provides that an adult donor may make a gift of securities, money or a life insurance product to a minor by having it registered in the name of, and delivering it to, an adult (either the donor or another adult) or institution to hold as custodian for the minor. UTMA, a creation of the Uniform Law commissioners in 1983, is much broader in its scope; it allows any kind of property _ real or personal, tangible or intangible _ to be given as a custodial gift and, unlike UGMA, also applies to such property transactions as repayments of loans borrowed from minors and tranfers of property from trusts, guardianships or estates. Under both forms, the minor acquires legal title to the property gifted; the adult relinquishes all title. Under either act, after a gift is made, custodians generally maintain the same powers over the transferred property that unmarried adult owners already have. The custodian may invest, manage or dispose of the gifted property on the minor's behalf, for any purpose whatsoever, short of using the income from one property to fulfill a legal obligation of support toward the child. When income produced by a custodial gift relieves an individual, such as a parent, of a legal obligation to feed and clothe a child, the law taxes that income to such an individual. Of course, grandparents or other family member donors, unless they also have been appointed the child's legal guardian, need not be concerned with this problem. Both acts provide for turning over the custodial property after the child reaches a specified age. The UGMA legislation originally established the time of the distribution as age 21; however, in many states, this has been reduced, typically to 18. In some states, the age at which the child is entitled to receive the property can be extended by the donor, but in no event beyond age 21. UTMA sets the age for distribution of gifted property at age 21, and at 18 or other state-specified age for property other than a gift. One should consult individual state law regarding what age applies. Overall, UGMA and UTMA transfers provide a simple, inexpensive means to a desirable end. Both allow an adult to make a substantial gift of property to a child without the child having to assume control of the property while still a minor. In addition, the parent or other relative may continue to monitor or manage the growth of the transferred property while achieving his or own personal financial planning goals.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE

DOC.HEAD: Adventure Trips Alluring for Older Travelers
DOC.TEXT: Are you an older American looking for an unparalleled travel experience to an unusual or exotic destination? You're not alone. Adventure travel is increasingly popular with everyone over 35. Those seeking a rigorous challenge are going trekking, white-water rafting and cross-country skiing. Others want the stimulation of an unusual setting but an itinerary that's not too physically taxing, so they are choosing soft adventure, which might include bicycling, hiking or nature walks. Several factors contribute to the surge in popularity of adventure trips. Americans age 35 and older are in better shape today than ever before. Increased emphasis on the desirability of a low-fat, high-fiber diet, along with greater awareness of the benefits of regular exercise, have produced more vigorous people living longer. More than that, being active and fit has become fashionable. This has some wonderful side benefits: more healthy people with a greater store of energy and vitality. It seems this rediscovered vitality has spawned a new sense of adventure among middle-age to older Americans. People today are looking for more unusual things to do in more and more out-of-the-way places. In a way, it seems we have,000, is the county seat of rural Atkinson County. Moody Air Force Base is located about 40 miles away. In November, a Navy jet crashed into an apartment complex north of Atlanta and burst into flames, killing two residents of the complex and seriously wounding the pilot. The fighter was trying to land at Dobbins Air Force Base when it crashed in suburban Smyrna. Last May, a jet from Moody accidentally dropped a live, 500-pound bomb onto a rural area of Marion County in west Georgia. Air Force officials said a worn-out, malfunctioning bomb rack caused the F-16 to drop the projectile during an exercise. The bomb exploded in some trees, but no one was injured and no major damage was reported.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Seek to Quadruple Alzheimer's Research Funding
DOC.TEXT: Legislation has been introduced in the House and Senate to quadruple federal spending for research on Alzheimer's disease and related disorders to more than $560 million by 1993. ``Four million victims of Alzheimer's disease and related disorders ... is a frightening figure for policymakers and the American public to contemplate,'' said Rep. Edward Roybal, D-Calif., chief House sponsor of the bill. ``Their numbers and their plight must prompt Congress to reassess and greatly expand its commitment to funding Alzheimer's assistance and research.'' Roybal, chairman of the House Select Committee on Aging, said the nation spends less than $1 on research for every $600 in Alzheimer's-related costs to society. The nation spends four to 11 times as much for research on other major diseases such as cancer, heart disease and AIDS, Roybal said. In addition to increasing research funding, the legislation would provide $125 million to help states establish Alzheimer's programs to help victims and their families.
DOC.HEAD: Center for Black Aged Cites Six `Living Legacy' Honorees
DOC.TEXT: Six black Americans are being honored as ``living legacies'' by the National Caucus and Center on Black Aged. Their portraits were being hung in the ``living legacy gallery'' at the center's housing development for senior citizens in Washington. The six are: _ Gorham L. BLack Jr., 67, of Harrisburg, Pa., cited for his work as first secretary of the Pennsylvania Department of Aging and regional director of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. He promoted legislation to reduce prescription and medical service prices, strengthen fire and safety provisions for the elderly and establish equal employment opportunities for minority senior citizens. _ Eugene S. Callender, 63, of New York City, who promoted significant changes in housing, education and employment for minorities through his leadership as a Presbyterian minister, New York City director of the ``New Cities in Schools'' program, New York Urban League executive director and former director of the New York State Office for the Aging. _ Clara McBride Hale, 90, of New York City, a foster parent ``surrogate mother,'' recognized by former President Reagan in his 1987 State of the Union address as a ``true American hero'' for her work with drug-addicted infants. She takes in and cares for children of unwed, working and drug-addicted mothers. Since 1969, more than 600 infants have been cared for by Mother Hale and her staff at Hale House Center for the Promotion of Human Potential. _ Dorothy Irene Height, 77, Washington, D.C., president of the National Council of Negro Women Inc., who mobilized black women as leaders in the struggle against chronic hunger, malnutrition, poor housing, illiteracy, inferior eduation, health and other problems, while providing 40,000 units of low-income housing and other career education programs. She initiated annual Black Family Reunion celebrations in major cities in 1987. _ Josephine Harreld Love, 75, of Detroit, cited as a gifted concert pianist from age 11, who performed for audiences in the United States and abroad while promoting cultural enrichment programs for urban and inner-city areas through museums, libraries, schools and colleges in Detroit and elsewhere. She founded a non-profit fine arts museum for young people and organized traveling exhibits of black artists, authors and designers. _ Mae Brown Phillips, 95, of New Carrollton, Md., credited with starting the campaign for the District of Columbia Commission on Aging, reduction of metro bus fares for senior citizens, and the development of the first ``model cities'' senior center. The center was founded in 1970 and is a 3,000-member non-profit organization that provides housing, employment training and advocacy services for black senior citizens. Since 1979, 60 senior citizens have received the ``living legacy'' awards. This year's honorees were chosen from among 100 candidates.
DOC.HEAD: Most Tour Groups Stay in North America
DOC.TEXT: More than 12 million Americans plan to take a trip with a tour group in the next two years, and more than 80 percent of them are likely to be within North America, a study found. The study found that group travel appeals to people who are older, widowed and retired. Those who preferred group travel cited value, convenience and safety as important factors. ``Gone are the stereotypes and the misconceptions of group tours characterized by the old phrase, `If this is Tuesday, it must be Belgium,''' said George C. Guenther, president of the National Tour Association. The findings are based on a study of 18,400 households in the United States administered by Longwoods International Inc., a travel research firm. The National Tour Association has 3,700 members, and the organization's non-profit arm, the National Tour Foundaton, commissioned the study. Among the results: _ Eighty-three percent of escorted travelers stay in the United States, Canada or Mexico. _ The top destinations are those of scenic beauty or cultural or historic interest.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thurs, May 31

DOC.TEXT: President Bush unconditionally renewed China's most-favored-nation trade status for one year, but said it's too early to talk about giving the same trade benefits to Moscow. The move on Thursday, which had been expected, caused an uproar in Congress from members of both parties who consider the administration's China policy too accommodating to the current leaders in Beijing. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., criticized Bush for failing to put any conditions on the one-year extension to prod China toward reforms.

The nation's economy grew at a sluggish annual rate of 1.3 percent in the first quarter, the government said. The growth was slower than the 2.1 percent rise estimated a month ago because of what analysts consider a healthy reduction in business inventories. The Commerce Department report on Thursday also said the inflation rate rose to 6.7 percent in the January-March period, up from its earlier estimate of 6.5 percent. It was the highest inflation rate since late 1981.

A Japan Airlines order for 20 Boeing 747-400 airplanes is one of the top Boeing orders of all time and makes JAL the largest customer for the jumbo jet, Boeing officials said. Boeing said Thursday that the order, worth $3.1 billion, brings to 40 the number of firm orders placed by JAL for the 747-400s. JAL also has options for 34 more of the aircraft that could boost the order yo more than $7 billion.

The Bush administration called on states to help stop children and teen-agers from smoking by banning cigarette vending machines and licensing tobacco retailers. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said Thursday state lawmakers should be use federal laws governing alcoholic beverages as a model in outlawing cigarette vending machines.

Ivan F. Boesky deducted $50 million in government penalties from his income taxes, the former stock speculator said at the securities fraud trial of his one-time associate John A. Mulheren Jr. In Boesky's third day on the witness stand, the defense sought again Thursday to undermine his credibility and to portray him as a greedy man who transferred chunks of his fortune to his wife when a federal dragnet closed on him in 1986. Mulheren is accused of breaking the law to help Boesky cheat on his taxes and evade federal securities laws.

Corporate after-tax profits rose 0.2 percent in the first quarter of 1990, a slim increase that marked the second consecutive rise after three quarters of decline, the government said. The Commerce Department said Thursday that profits after taxes increased $3 million to $157 billion on top of a 2.8 percent increase in the October-December period of 1989.

Japan agreed to send trade experts to Ohio to help promote imports from that state under a new strategy to reduce trade friction by dealing with individual U.S. states. Ohio Gov. Richard F. Celeste signed the agreement Thursday with chairman Minoru Masuda of the Japan External Trade Organization, which has decided the state-based approach is Japan's best bet for reducing its $49 billion trade surplus with the United States.

President Bush vetoed a bill authorizing $2 billion in spending by Amtrak, complaining that a provision in the bill to expand federal regulation of railroad acquisitions ``represents a step backward for the entire rail industry.'' Bush took issue Thursday with a provision to require the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve the acquisition of railroads by non-railroad companies. Bush called that ``an unwarranted regulatory roadblock to the financial restructuring of the railroad industry.''

Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov warned his countrymen of the ``painful processes'' needed to rescue their stagnant economy, but he said there was no choice but to abandon central planning and adopt a market system. Ryzhkov owned up Thursday to the catastrophic state of the economy and faced a barrage of criticism that climaxed with demands for his government to resign. His two-hour address to the Supreme Soviet parliament was televised.

Stock prices suffered a small setback Thursday and the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials broke a string of three consecutive record closing highs by slipping 0.71 to 2,855.55. The bond market lost ground after giving a chilly reception to the government's auction of $8.5 billion in five-year notes. The dollar finished mostly higher in foreign exchange trading. Cocoa futures prices rallied to new 14-month highs, gold prices rebounded after a big loss the previous session, and energy, livestock, meat, grains and soybean futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: The Questionable Thesis Behind A Tax Increase
Also moved in advance.
DOC.TEXT: You'll probably win the argument if you contend that an out-of-control budget deficit is the reason why higher taxes are being considered. Repeat it often enough and it sounds right, sort of like that old sales trick of asking the customer to answer a series of simple questions with an obvious ``yes'' answer, and then springing the big one on him: ``And of course you do want this new life insurance policy, don't you?'' Same with the deficit: Many people accept the notion that it is now more oppressive than it has been in years, and they'll even give you the reasons, such as tax cuts in the Reagan administration and slow revenue growth now. But the facts have little kinship with the belief. In relation to the gross national product, a measure of the economy's size, the deficit is now at a rate less than half what it was in 1983, when it reached 6.3 percent. In that decade of the 1980s, during which so much attention was paid to tax cutting, a series of undistinguished increases, followed by a so-called major tax reform, doubled tax receipts to more than $1 trillion a year. It is one of several prevalent beliefs that Rory Costello, for one, would like to see put to bed. Costello, economic analyst at Dean Witter, has a long list. It includes these: Inflation is continuing to rise; we're already in a recession; housing is collapsing; and the United States must raise interest rates in order to compete for capital. All exaggerations, he suggests. Of these, the one most discussed of late seems to be the budget deficit, in part because of President Bush softening his anti-tax stand and stating his willingness to discuss the possibility of raising revenues. Advocates of higher taxes often suggest the government is revenue-starved, says political economist Daniel Mitchell, who responds: ``In both nominal and inflation-adjusted dollars, taxes are at the highest level in U.S. history.'' Mitchell is a senior fellow at the Heritage Foundation, which tends to make his opinion significant, since the foundation, a conservative think tank, has enjoyed considerable influence in both the Reagan and Bush administrations. The foundation maintains that member opinions do not necessarily reflect its views, but that might be likened to the laundry saying it isn't responsible for returning your clothes. The foundation loudly promotes its members' views. Mitchell's view is this: The cause of the deficit is not a lack of revenue but runaway government spending. To raise taxes now would mean a recession, and consequently even lower revenues. To raise taxes would merely fuel more spending. Moreover, he suggests there is a matter of political integrity, stated thusly: ``President Bush repeatedly promised the American people that he would not raise taxes. Candidate Bush correctly promised to veto any tax increase. President Bush should follow through on that commitment.'' Mitchell states that even though annual tax revenues have climbed $540 billion since 1980, the deficit is higher because of the approximately $610 billion-plus increase in federal spending in that period. His conclusion: ``George Bush has distinguished himself first and foremost by his anti-tax hike policy. Now his credibility, integrity, commitment to principles, and political and economic wisdom are put to the test... ``If Bush expects to keep the support of the people who put him in office, he must read their lips. They are saying: `Mr. President, keep your promise. No new taxes.' ''

DOC.HEAD: Businesses, Farmers Relieved at Bush's Decision on China Trade
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's one-year extension of preferential trading status to China assures it will remain a leading buyer of key U.S. exports ranging from grain to lumber to heavy machinery, business people say. They said the Bush decision announced Thursday also assures no supply disruption or price jumps in important consumer imports from China, including a wide array of clothes and shoes, toys and small appliances. Bush rejected Congressional pressure to suspend China's most-favored-nation status, which it has held for a decade and entitles the country to low tariffs in selling goods to the United States. Critics wanted Bush to scrap the status to punish China's government for its crackdown on dissent, which began nearly a year ago when troops attacked student protesters in Beijing. U.S. businesses that rely on China trade said such punishment would hurt the wrong people and invite certain retaliation. ``We felt that in the interest of keeping trade lines open and allowing U.S. farm products to flow into China, it was critical that this be extended,'' said Jack King, spokesman for the American Farm Bureau Federation in Park Ridge, Ill. ``I think history has shown that when we turn our back on foreign customers, there's always another country willing to fill the need.'' Steve Halloran, director of the grain department of the National Farmers Organization in Corning, Iowa, said a Chinese withdrawal from the U.S. wheat market likely would have depressed prices much like the Soviet grain embargo did a decade ago, hurting farmers for a problem they didn't cause. ``Anytime you interfere in trade relationships with political mandates such as this, you're going to see a negative impact on the prices,'' he said. ``Unfortunately, it's always a long climb back up the price ladder.'' One of the most ardent lobby groups that pressed for the most-favored nation extension was the United States-China Business Council, a coalition of companies with longstanding investment commitments and operations in China. The council had argued MFN status was not a concession to China, but rather the standard treatment the United States extends to almost all its trading partners, including such countries as South Africa, Iraq and Syria. The Soviet Union does not have MFN status. China has emerged as one of the most important U.S trading partners since commercial relations first were established nearly two decades ago. In that time, two-way trade has gone from near zero to about $18 billion a year. The trade also has moved sharply in Beijing's favor, with exports to the United States about double the level of U.S. sales to China. Experts in U.S.-Chinese trade estimate that China now provides one-third of the toys sold in this country, 10 percent of the footwear and 15 percent of all imported clothing. It also is a leading buyer of U.S. wheat, purchasing more than $1 billion worth last year or about 20 percent of total U.S. exports to the country. American aircraft, machinery, lumber, and high-quality cotton are other important products purchased by the Chinese. ``We're very pleased that the president has decided to renew MFN,'' said Jodi Levin, spokeswoman for the Toy Manufacturers of America in New York, which had expressed strong concern about a possible suspension. ``For industry and American consumers, and for that matter, Chinese working in the factories overseas, this seems to be a resolution that will make the most people happy.'' Without MFN status, toys from China would be subject to a 70 percent tariff, vs. 6.8 percent now, U.S. Customs regulations show. Tariffs on sweaters would have gone from 6 percent to 60 percent; electric hair dryers from 3.9 percent to 35 percent; women's trousers from 17.7 percent to 90 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Say Blue Laser Process May Quadruple Optical Disk Storage
DOC.TEXT: Researchers at IBM say they have found a new way to produce blue laser light that could squeeze four times as much information on computer optical disks. Moving the process from the lab to an end product is years away, Michael Ross, a spokesman for International Business Machines Corp., said Thursday. Nevertheless, analysts and manufacturers said IBM could reap big profits if the process helps the optical storage industry, still in its infancy, take its place beside magnetic disks and tape. Current optical disks use infrared diode lasers to make marks as small in diameter as 0.8 microns. A micron is a millionth of a meter. Scientists from IBM's Almaden Research Center in San Jose used a quarter-inch-long potassium niobate crystal to convert infrared light to blue laser light, which has half the wavelength. The blue laser can focus on a spot 0.4 microns in diameter, half the diameter of a conventional laser. That potentially could permit an optical disk to hold four times more information _ the equivalent of perhaps 800 Bibles on a 5\-inch disk. William J. Kozlovsky, an IBM research staff member, and Wilfried Lenth, manager of advanced lasers, told the Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics in Anaheim Thursday that the process was at least five times more efficient than others at converting electricity into blue light. ``It's almost the Holy Grail of the optical data storage industry,'' said Bob Abraham of Freeman Associates Inc., Santa Barbara-based consultants to data storage companies. ``It's been long recognized that the wave length of the laser beam has been the big limiting factor.'' He said IBM had been researching optical disk technology for years, although the company today produces only magnetic disks. ``It may be a few years yet before we see products,'' Abraham said. ``But whether they choose to manufacture or license it they're likely to be making a great deal of money.'' Optical disks, which look much like CDs or the small storage disks used in many PCs, can store enough data to replace whole tape libraries of computer information. Optical storage is a more secure way to store data than magnetic disks because it is much harder to erase accidentally. One U.S. company that already makes optical disks, and would be interested in licensing the rights if IBM's process becomes practical, is Maxoptics, a division of San Jose-base Maxtor Corp. ``At this point it's a little early to tell how useful it's going to be but it certainly appears the potential is there to quadruple the information stored,'' said Joe Davis, Maxtor's vice president of advanced product planning. ``We eagerly await more information so we can begin studying it,'' Davis said. The storage capacity of both optical and magnetic disks has reached stunning levels. Maxtor recently began shipping a 5\-inch optical disk that can store the equivalent of 200 Bibles, Davis said. It also markets what he said was the highest-capacity storage disk in the world, a magnetic disk that can handle the equivalent of 400 Bibles. Davis said that even if the improved optical disk pans out, it's far too early to write off magnetic disks, particularly when information needs to be erased or written over. The storage capacity of magnetic disks, also known as Winchester disks, is now about 100 times greater than 10 years ago, he noted. ``Let's suppose it does work out as they say,'' Davis said. ``This breakthrough took several years. Contrast that with Winchester technology, where every two years you seem to double the capacity.''

DOC.HEAD: Credibility the Key Question as Boesky Leaves the Witness Stand
DOC.TEXT: Ivan Boesky survived two days of hostile questioning on the witness stand, but it remains to be seen if the same can be said for his credibility. In a third day of testimony Thursday, the former speculator said he was able to write off on his income taxes half of the $100 million penalty he paid to settle the biggest insider trading case in Wall Street history. He also said his wrongdoing didn't end with his guilty plea. He admitted violating prison rules by paying other inmates to do his laundry. Boesky gave his first public testimony about his crimes at the securities fraud trial of his former friend and associate, John A. Mulheren Jr. He is the prime witness for the government, which alleges Mulheren broke the law to help Boesky cheat on his taxes and evade federal securities laws. In two days of heated cross examination, defense attorney Thomas P. Puccio tried to destroy Boesky's credibility by portraying him as a greedy liar who had turned on a former friend to save his own skin. ``I think we accomplished what we wanted to accomplish with Mr. Boesky,'' Puccio said at the end of the day. Mulheren and Boesky were once close friends when Mulheren was an arbitrager at Jamie Securities. But the relationship soured when Boesky fingered Mulheren and other alleged co-conspirators as part of his plea bargain, under which Boesky pleaded guilty to one conspiracy charge, spent two years in prison and paid $100 million to the government. On Thursday, Boesky revealed that he had deducted $50 million of the penalty from his 1986 income taxes. That amount had been a repayment of the illegal profits he reaped from insider trading in 1985. The other half of the penalty was a fine. Boesky lawyer Charles Davidow said he did not know whether the deduction _ taken as a capital expense _ was legal, but he assumed Boesky's tax attorneys or accountants had reviewed it at the time. U.S. District Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum allowed defense attorneys to discuss the deduction to attempt to show that the penalty was not as painful or expensive as it appeared. Although confirming the deduction, Boesky said he could not remember exactly how much he made in illegal profits in 1985. Puccio claimed illegal profits based on insider information from investment bankers Dennis Levine and Martin Siegel actually totaled $187 million. Boesky again was temperamental under cross examination, refusing to answer numerous questions unless he saw documentation to refresh his memory. Puccio asked him a dozen times whether he has revealed to the government all of the crimes he ever committed. Boesky said he revealed all the crimes he was required to tell under the plea bargain. He said his net worth fell from at least $100 million in 1986 to nearly nothing when he was sentenced in late 1987, but he would not say whether he transferred his funds to his wife, as Puccio suggested. ``I do not recally any financial activities of 1986,'' he said repeatedly. He deflected Puccio's accusations that he was greedy, saying that in 1986, in the midst of his downfall, his holdings weighed on his mind ``less than you might think.'' He also denied committing any wrongdoing with his money to avoid having to pay $1 billion in damages to parties that have sued him. Boesky said none of those lawsuits has been settled. Boesky did admit one violation in response to Puccio's question about whether he broke the law while in prison. Boesky said he violated a rule by paying someone else to do his laundry. ``There were a couple of chaps who did laundry there and I gave them a few quarters to do my laundry,'' he said. Boesky's testimony under cross examination only grazed over the charges against Mulheren. The government alleges Mulheren manipulated the price of Gulf & Western Inc. stock for Boesky's benefit and held stock in Unocal Corp. for Boesky so the arbitrager could cheat on his taxes. Boesky implicated Mulheren on those charges earlier in the week under direct examination by Assistant U.S. Attorney E. Scott Gilbert. Mulheren faces 41 charges of conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud and record-keeping violations. The trial resumes Tuesday with Boesky's chief trader, Michael Davidoff, on the stand. He testified briefly Thursday afternoon, saying he had met Mulheren 10 or 15 years ago and had both a business and social relationship with him.

DOC.HEAD: Experts: Credit Crunch Easing, But N.E. Economy Will Remain Sluggish
DOC.TEXT: New England's economy is in for another 18 months of sluggish growth even though the region's credit crunch may be easing, a panel of experts said. Legislators, economists and bankers gathered at a symposium on the tightened credit market in the Northeast agreed the worst may be over. Federal regulators have largely completed their intensive review of real estate lending in the region and the slowdown in lending caused by that review appears to be diminishing, the participants said. But Wayne Ayers, chief economist of the Bank of Boston, said Thursday the end of the crunch does not mean that credit will automatically begin to flow freely again. ``The economy in New England has been, and I think will continue to be pretty soft for the next 18 months,'' Ayers said. High wages and housing prices are discouraging businesses from moving into New England, Ayers said. And commercial and residential construction, fed by the boom years of the 1980s, has far outpaced demand leading to a severe contraction of that industry. ``The New England economy has yet to bottom,'' Ayers said. ``There are no `sleeping beauty' industries out there that can realistically be expected to rejuvenate the region's economy.'' The symposium was called to address the extent to which stepped-up federal regulation in New England may be accelerating the region's economic slide. That question remained unsettled, but participants agreed that recent moves by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Federal Reserve and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. have eased the concerns of bankers. Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., a member of the House Banking Committee, said a meeting two weeks ago between the heads of those three federal regulatory agencies and the American Bankers Association was a key step in easing fears of a regulatory clamp on lending. In that meeting, the Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan along with the comptroller and the head of the FDIC urged bankers to continue making loans to credit-worthy customers. ``I can't remember the last time the three top regulators thought it important to tell bankers to lend money. That was at least implicit acknowledgement that things were too tight,'' Frank said. ``The Secretary of Commerce does not meet with Iacocca, Smith and whoever runs Ford and say `Gee, I think you guys should sell cars.''' Frank Maguire, Deputy Comptroller of the Currency, said the major purpose of that meeting was to thwart what the OCC viewed as an overreaction by bankers to regulators. Frank disagreed, saying there was strong evidence indicating that the OCC was being overly strict in ordering New England banks to reclassify loans as ``non-performing.'' That step forces banks to add more money to their loan loss reserves, money that might otherwise be loaned. Regardless of who was at fault for the credit crunch, there was little doubt among the panelists that it had some downward impact on the economy. In Connecticut, more than 80 percent of the 2,000 businesses that responded to a survey sensed a shortage of available credit, according to John Rathgeber, vice president of the Connecticut Business & Industry Association. More than 60 percent of those responding, Rathgeber said, reported that they were unable to get credit on the same terms they had always enjoyed. The problem was concentrated in the working capital area, money loaned to help businesses maintain day-to-day operations. ``The unavailability of working capital has tremendous spinoff effects on the economy,'' Rathgeber said. ``For Connecticut's economy and for New England's economy, we need access to credit markets.''

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Executives Can't Get to the Point on Paper, Consultant Says
DOC.TEXT: Top corporate executives spend nearly three months a year writing letters, memos and reports but waste much of the time because they can't get to the point, according to a recent survey. Motivational Systems of West Orange, which provides business writing and management training programs to corporations and government agencies, said a survey of 200 corporate vice presidents found few knew how to write effectively. ``It's incredible how much time people spend on the rewriting of communication,'' said Roger Flax, president of Motivational Systems. ``It's costing America billions of dollars.'' Flax said much of the writing he's seen in 20 years as an instructor is too wordy, poorly organized or confusing. ``We have found that people have what we call `blue book' disease,'' he said, referring to the blue-cover examination booklets that high schools and colleges use to administer tests. ``What managers and executives do is they write to fill up a report and they're not concise,'' he said. Business writers should try to limit sentences to 15 words and paragraphs to four lines, and avoid cliches, Flax said. ``The problem is in the schools. Schools are not teaching conciseness,'' he said. ``The kids are getting so hung up on grammar that they can't put their thoughts on paper.'' Howard Carroll, a spokesman for the National Education Association in Washington, said blaming teachers for bad executive writing was ``ludicrous.'' ``Writing is not easy for anyone. I think depending on what standards we're talking about, you'll find most professional people do not write well,'' he said. Christine Kelly, a professor of management communications at New York University's Graduate School of Business Administration, said writing difficulties usually reflect more basic problems. ``The problem the survey seems to be responding to is more fundamental than that. It's the ability to express yourself,'' said Ms. Kelly, who also is director of the management communications department. Most of the students who apply to the business school have had at least five years of professional experience, she said, but their admissions essays reveal a lack of confidence in their writing. ``They've been told at work that they're too verbose,'' she said. ``What I see in the writing is not well developed ideas, which tells me they have problems expressing what they're thinking.'' Ms. Kelly said writers should worry about getting their thoughts on paper _ the nipping and tucking can be saved for later. ``Writing is a craft and a skill and it can be developed,'' she said. ``The underlying problem is that you first have to get your ideas down. You have to be able to write freely and comfortably.'' Flax, who earned a bachelor's degree in psychology from the University of Maryland, said poor writing in the workplace leads to lost productivity and sales, low morale and job insecurity. He suggests one way to write better is to write as you would speak. ``Conversational writing leads to more credibility and more conciseness,'' he said. ``Another point is they should really proofread aloud. If they proofread aloud they'll hear their mistakes,'' he said. If the thought of reading aloud is unsettling, Flax suggests a ruse. ``Pick up the phone and proofread to yourself.''

DOC.HEAD: Essential Oils Exports Reach Record High
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Exports of essential oils _ the kind that smell and taste good _ rose to an all-time high last year, says the Agriculture Department. Last year's exports of essential oils reached nearly $144 million _ a 17 percent increase over a year earlier and well above 1987 exports of $114 million, according to an annual report. Essential oils are obtained from natural raw materials by distillation or through a mechanical pressing process. The oils are widely used in perfumes, cosmetics and pharmaceutical products, and to flavor food and soft drinks. ``As income levels in foreign countries increase, certainly the markets there will have an increase of these export items,'' says Rex Dull of the deparment's Horticultural and Tropical Products Division. ``Countries are utilizing more of them in their confectionary products, and markets for them are growing rapidly in these countries.'' In fact, exports of peppermint oils increased by 22 percent to 1,510 tons, with Japan replacing the United Kingdom as this countries largest export market for these oils. U.S. exports of orange oil were up 61 percent, nearly doubling in value to $10.2 million. Lemon exports also doubled year-earlier levels, largely reflecting increased sales to Japan and the United Kingdom. While exports of most essential oils increased, U.S. imports of the same products fell 12 percent from 1988 to $132 million. The decline largely reflecting smaller imports of sandalwood, vetiver, nutmeg, geranium and cassia oils, and good crop yields by U.S. farmers. Peppermint yields in Midwest producing areas were well above the drought-damaged levels in 1988 and prices have fallen accordingly. But demand for peppermint oil continues strong, which has kept prices from falling further, despite the large 1989 harvest and prospects of another good outturn this year. Reversing a trend dating back to the 1960's, consumers now favor natural flavorings over synthetic ingredients. Dull, in a telephone interview Thursday, attributed this trend to the changing health habits of consumers. ``In recent years, people have become more health conscious and want to move toward consuming more natural flavored products,'' he said. ``People are afraid of what artificial flavoring will do to their bodies.'' Industry studies estimate that natural flavors now comprise three-fourths of the U.S. market and artificial flavors the balance, whereas the reverse was true in the 1960's.

Gather up the chickens, cows and corns for the Agriculture Department's first livestock and crop census next month. The department's National Agricultural Statistics Service will conduct the survey June 1-15 to assess 1990 crop and livestock production and inventories. Information provided by a sample of about 130,000 farmers and ranchers nationwide will be used in making state, regional and national estimates. ``Gathering this type of information from producers is the only way to develop reliable crop and livestock estimates for an orderly marketing system,'' says Rich Allen, Agricultural Statistics Board chairman. ``The estimates are a working tool to help farmers and ranchers in their decisions about production, marketing and investments in their operations,'' he said.

Mushroom growers have new hope in fighting their worst enemy _ flies. A new natural organism might be the weapon to eliminate mushroom flies that threaten the $500 million-a-year mushroom industry, according to two Agriculture Department scientists. They say the organism would allow growers to avoid using insecticides to eliminate the pests. Mushroom flies breed so quickly in mushroom beds that their increasing population usually requires growers to use insecticides to save the crops. If not, the flies lay their eggs in the compost that growers feed to mushrooms. Then, the hatched fly larvae eat the mushrooms. But the scientists say the organism Steinernematid nematodes, added to the mushroom bedding, burrow down into the compost. There, these microscopic, whip-like organisms devour fly larvae. ``Right now, we can achieve 85 percent control of the flies by adding 600 Steinernematids per square centimeter of compost (about 4,000 per square inch),'' says William Nickle, of the department's Agricultural Research Service.

DOC.HEAD: House To Consider Soybean Subsidies And Sugar Prices In 1990 Farm Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A boost for soybeans and revisions in the government's sugar price protection program will be among the provisions in the 1990 farm bill going before the House. The House Agriculture Committee approved a section of its bill Thursday that put soybeans in a government subsidy program designed to cost taxpayers nothing. The panel also voted for some changes in the sugar program that drew praise from producers and criticism from the manufacturers of candy and other sweets. ``The House bill addresses the complex U.S. sugar program in a manner that will benefit consumers, producers and foreign quota holders,'' said Luther Markwart, chairman of the American Sugar Alliance. Thomas Hammer, president of the Sweetener Users Association, called the committee's plan ``more outrageous than the current domestic sugar subsidy program'' that he said hurts consumers. The government regulates prices by limiting the amount of imported sugar that can be sold in the United States. The manufacturers of sweets say that drives prices up. Sugar cane, sugar beet and corn sweetener producers say it stabilizes prices. The House bill would: _Maintain the current 18 cent loan rate, with discretionary authority to increase it based on cost of production or other factors; _Extend the term of the loan from six to nine months; _Guarantee a minimum import level of 1.25 million tons; _Provide for triggered mandatory domestic marketing allocations for cane and beet sugar to guarantee minimum imports if it looks like they're falling below 1.25 million tons; _Limit marketing of crystalline fructose to 200,000 tons when marketing allocations are in effect; _Create a re-export program that would allow poor sugar-producing countries like those in the Caribbean and Central America to sell U.S. refiners raw cane at 7 cents over the world market level, thus enabling refiners to sell the sugar on the world market; _Make disaster payments to Louisiana sugar producers whose 1990 crop is severely damaged by the 1989 freeze. The committee's plan for soybeans is an effort to boost production without costing the government any money. ``It gets the soybean producer into the program in a way that provides him with an insurance policy on his price,'' said Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., chairman of the subcommittee on wheat, soybeans and feed grains. ``It's not all the oilseed community may have wanted, but it's more than they could have expected,'' said Rep. Fred Grandy, R-Iowa. Congressional economists say the plan won't cost the government because the loan rate of $5.25 to $5.51 a bushel is below the predicted market price in every year of the five years covered by the bill. The government only bears a financial loss if it loans more money or guarantees higher prices than farmers get on the open market. ``It's a modest beginning,'' said Rep. Bill Emerson, R-Mo. ``It brings to the commodity the recognition it deserves.'' The House committee also voted to freeze target prices for wheat and feed grains at current levels but allow farmers a slight increase in that price if they cut back on the number of acres they plant. That plan also was designed to comply with the tight budget constraints placed on the committee by House budget writers. The target price would be $4 a bushel for wheat and $2.75 a bushel for feed grains. The committee has been wrestling with efforts to improve soybean production since it began writing its farm bill earlier in the year. The United States, which used to lead the world in soybean production, has fallen behind because government programs have made it more profitable for farmers who could grow soybeans to plant wheat or corn instead.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Rejects Board Recommendations to Control Cruise Ships
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard says it would rather not push for a greater U.S. role in the safety of luxury cruise ships that carry 7 million passengers a year out of U.S. ports. Coast Guard Commandant Paul Yost, in a letter released Thursday, rejected National Transportation Safety Board proposals that would give the U.S. government more authority over ships that are U.S.-owned and carry mostly American passengers but are registered abroad. ``While unilateral actions are tempting as an easy fix,'' Yost said, ``I continue to believe that efforts through international channels must be the principal route to achieve improvements.'' When a cruise ship is registered under a foreign flag it is not subject to U.S. labor laws or safety regulations. The letter to the NTSB agreed with some of the board's recommendations for improving cruise ship safety. But Yost said he favors pursuing most safety improvements through the International Maritime Organization, since the rules then would apply to vessels worldwide and protect more Americans. ``To pursue a two-tiered approach to passenger safety would not be in the interests of all our citizens,'' he said. The board had asked the Coast Guard to sponsor legislation to gain more authority over foreign-registered ships while also pursuing international agreements. The board recommendations came in a report in October that proposed a stronger U.S. role in ensuring the safety of cruise ships that operate out of U.S. coastal cities. It cited crews who speak no English, a lack of life vests, inadequate safety equipment, unsafe ship designs and other problems. The safety board said 264 people have died in cruise ship incidents or accidents over the past 25 years, and more deaths could occur in the future. Yost acknowledged that foreign-flagged vessels operating out of U.S. ports require close monitoring and said some ships lack sufficient maintenance and crew training. He said there are communication problems, but rejected a board proposal for legislation requiring that 75 percent of crew members speak English if a ship operates in U.S. waters. This ``would be detrimental to our efforts at the international level,'' Yost said, noting that the Coast Guard is pushing for international rules to improve crew-passenger communication. Yost also rejected an NTSB proposal that U.S. safety investigators be given greater access and authority over incidents in international waters when they involve a foreign ship operating out of a U.S. port. ``Accidents which occur aboard foreign vessels outside U.S. territorial waters are, as a matter of national sovereignty, properly beyond our normal jurisdiction,'' he said. Yost said, however, ``While I may disagree with some of the statements in your report, I fully support the general notion that close attention needs to be paid to the safety of passengers traveling on cruise vessels.'' Legislative hearings on some of the NTSB proposals are scheduled next month.

DOC.HEAD: Tobacco Divestment Project Battles Business As Usual
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Advocates battling for a cigarette-free society have begun a divestment campaign they compare to the one apartheid opponents used against South Africa. Officials at the Boston-based Tobacco Divestment Project said Thursday they have begun pressuring hospitals, universities and state retirement funds to sell their holdings in tobacco companies. ``We're hoping that much like the anti-apartheid movement brought about a shift in the way South Africa was viewed ... this will bring about a shift in the way tobacco companies are viewed,'' said Patrick Reynolds, whose grandfather founded R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. and died of smoking-related emphysema. The anti-smoking campaign recently appears to have gained momentum. Health Secretary Louis Sullivan's called Thursday for a ban on cigarette vending machines. Harvard University and City University of New York said recently they would sell all stock in companies that manufacture tobacco products. Sullivan, testifying before the Senate Finance Committee, also proposed creating a licensing system for tobacco retailers and establishing penalties for those who sell cigarettes to minors. The World Conference on Lung Health, at a meeting here, issued resolutions that included a call for the international community to ``sever all forms of support to the tobacco industry.'' ``We believe all this will really tighten the vice around tobacco firms,'' said Brad Krevor, the divestment project's executive director. Krevor said the project's 12-member board and grassroots activists around the country are asking institutions to reexamine their investment portfolios and, where necessary, sell ``inappropriate'' holdings. ``We will no longer allow the predatory marketing practices of these (tobacco) companies to continue,'' he said. George Knox, a spokesman for Philip Morris Cos., said the tobacco maker was aware of the divestment effort but far from panicked. ``We are not sitting here biting our fingernails,'' he said in a telephone interview from New York. ``But clearly we are not unconcerned with the issue.'' He said investors buy and sell stock based on a variety of criteria but that so far ``we've still had a healthy market in our stock and expect that to continue.'' Krevor health and life insurers would be a particular project target because they offer breaks for non-smokers while simultaneously investing funds from policies in tobacco stocks. ``We certainly are holding tobacco company stocks, but I haven't found anyone interested in talking about the divestment project at this time,'' said Charles McGillicuddy, a spokesman for John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co. in Boston. Krevor said he was optimistic that targeted stockholders would be receptive to the divestment campaign because ``in many cases people don't even know they have tobacco holdings.'' In his May 18 announcement, Harvard President Derek Bok wrote that the school's board ``was motivated by a desire not to be associated ... with companies engaged in significant sales of products that create a substantial and unjustified risk of harm to other human beings.'' Divestment project officials, who launched their campaign here May 10, said beyond applying financial pressure they hoped to sway legislators toward higher tobacco taxes and a ban on cigarette advertising. Cigarettes, health officials say, cause about 390,000 premature deaths annually from lung cancer, heart disease and other cardiovascular disorders.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Vetoes Amtrak Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Amtrak trains are unaffected by President Bush's veto of a bill authorizing $2 billion in spending for the passenger rail service. The president's objection deals with a provision on who can buy railroads. It was Bush's first veto of 1990. He returned 10 bills to Congress in his first year in office last year. Congress has yet to override a Bush veto. Amtrak spokesman Clifford Black said the veto would not affect daily train operations because the railroad is working with money that Congress already had appropriated for 1989-1992. Bush took issue with a provision that would require the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve the acquisition of railroads by non-railroad companies. ``This requirement is an unwarranted regulatory roadblock to the financial restructuring of the railroad industry,'' Bush told Congress in a veto message Thursday. The veto will indefinitely postpone plans for a commuter line between Washington, D.C., and its northern Virginia suburbs, Black said. The bill contained technical provisions necessary for the project to open. The legislation, sent to Bush May 10, would authorize a new, three-year government subsidy of $2 billion to Amtrak, the national rail passenger service. Actual spending levels are set by separate appropriations bills. Black said Amtrak supports the provision that prompted Bush's veto, although it applies only to private freight railroads. The spokesman said Amtrak relies on private freight lines for its tracks outside the Northeast corridor and ``does support ICC oversight of takeovers of railroads by non-railroad companies.'' Bush attributed the ``rejuvenation of the rail industry since 1980'' largely to an easing of burdensome federal regulations. He said the Amtrak bill would reverse that trend. The bill ``contains an unprecedented new regulatory review requirement and represents a step backward for the entire rail industry,'' Bush said. He said the additional regulation ``would interfere with the ability of the nation's largest freight railroads to obtain needed capital or to change existing capital structure.'' The provision also would impose a new barrier to any attempted takeover of a rail line by the carrier's own management or employees, Bush said. The president said existing law provides adequate protection of the public interest in rail acquisitions. Bush administration officials had complained earlier that the bill amounted to a government subsidy of about $29 a passenger. However, Bush did not refer to the measure's cost in his veto message. A presidential veto can be overridden only by two-thirds majorities of both the House and Senate. Rather than try to override the Amtrak veto, Congress more likely will remove the provision that Bush finds objectionable and return the modified bill to the White House for his signature.

DOC.HEAD: Tobacco Company Engineer Convicted of Helping Cuba Fake Winstons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: If these Winstons didn't taste good like a cigarette should, it could be because they were counterfeited in Cuba. Three men, including a former R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. engineer, were convicted Wednesday of violating export laws and the U.S. trade embargo against Cuba by shipping equipment to the island to make imitation Winstons. They exported a carton-stuffing machine, cigarette-wrapping equipment, red and gold ink and other items through Panama to Cuba, where the fake Winstons were manufactured for export, according to prosecutors. ``It should be a big embarassment for Cuba,'' said Keith Prager, who supervises the investigating U.S. Customs unit. ``This case ... shows how desperate the Cuban government is, that they are down to counterfeiting cigarettes.'' Customs officials heard about the scheme after a tip on some equipment shipments in March 1989 and the discovery of 1,800 cases of Cuban-made Winstons in the Netherlands in August. Prosecutors claimed that sales of the American cigarettes could have made $2 million for Cuba's foreign exchange-starved economy. It wasn't clear whether any of the cigarettes were eventually sold. Convicted after a nine day trial were former R.J. Reynolds engineering foreman Michael Macko; Emilio Ortiz De Zevallos, the Peruvian director of a Panamanian export company, and Frank Van Ameringen, who ran several small tobacco companies from his home in Miami. They face prison terms of 15 to 21 months. U.S. District Judge Lenore Nesbitt set sentencing for July 23. De Zevallos' attorney Michael Tarkoff said the federal government was in effect making a civil matter into a criminal prosecution. ``These are regulatory-type crimes, civil actions,'' he said. The lawyer said the government never proved the men intended to violate the laws they were charged under.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Industry Squawks About Proposed State-Run Airline
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The airline industry is ``screaming like pigs to slaughter'' over a bill that would create the nation's first state-owned airline to ferry passengers on cheap California flights, the sponsor says. The measure proposing Golden State Air will be considered by the state Senate next month, but Democratic Sen. Art Torres isn't optimistic. ``The chances are tough,'' he said Thursday. ``Going up against the airline industry has not been an easy task.'' The Air Transport Association of America, an industry group, opposes the 1-cent per gallon jet fuel tax Torres has proposed to pay for the $13 million to $28 million start-up cost of the government-run airline. The group had taken a neutral stance on the bill until it was amended last Monday to include the fuel tax, which could cost the industry $24 million to $30 million a year. Commercial air carriers currently are exempt from jet fuel taxes in California. ``Now they're screaming like pigs to slaughter,'' Torres said of the airlines. ``They're afraid we're going to be competitive.'' Torres said he has received overwhelming support from businesses upset over seemingly irrational fares for commercial flights within California. He said people who regularly fly on business have been mailing him advertisements for $160 fares to Florida and complaining about $400 to $500 costs for a round-trip between Los Angeles and Sacramento. ``They just can't believe that it costs more for a one-hour business trip that it does to fly to Washington, D.C.,'' Torres said. He blamed federal deregulation of the industry for allowing large airlines to swallow smaller companies that operated in-state commuter flights. The state Public Utilities Commission said in December that rates for flights within California increased an average of more than 40 percent between 1979 and 1989, after adjustments for inflation. The Air Transport Association disputes those figures. The industry group claims that most Californians are satisfied with airline service and that average California air fares dropped between 1980 and 1988, when adjusted for inflation.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Picks Motorola, Stock Surges
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. stock surged to a 52-week high on news that Japan's major phone company chose its digital voice-transmission technology for that nation's cellular service. Motorola spokesman Tim Kellogg said Thursday that Japan Mobile Communications, known as IDO, has selected the Chicago-area company's cellular system for the geographic corridor between Tokyo and Nagoya, potentially one of the nation's busiest cellular-use areas. ``We don't have all the details, but the value to Motorola for Tokyo alone is $35 million for the next year,'' Kellogg said. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Motorola surged $3.75 to close at $83.75 a share. Motorola's cellular speech coder was selected as the technical standard by both Nippon Telephone and Telegraph and the Ministry of Post and Telecommunications, said Kellogg. ``The speech coder is part of the cellular system that digitizes the voice and sends it to a receiving unit and then it's decoded,'' he said. ``The license for the technology is royalty free,'' Kellogg said, adding that the selection of the Motolora speech coder enhances the company's ability to sell the Japanese the equipment for the coder. Motorola reported first-quarter profits of $127 million on sales of $2.5 billion due mainly to its quickly growing telephone operation. Total sales were up 16 percent.

The stock market showed a broad loss today in selling that hit technology issues hardest. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 14.47 to 2,841.08 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 7 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 295 up, 697 down and 474 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 20.45 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said the tone for the session was set overnight by word from Adobe Systems, a computer software company, that its earnings for the second quarter and full year were likely to fall short of analysts' estimates. Adobe shares, the most active stock in the over-the-counter market, tumbled 16 to 34{. Other computer and technology issues registered smaller declines on the news. Apple Computer, a primary Adobe customer, slumped 1} to 40\ in OTC trading. Among NYSE-listed technology stocks, International Business Machines dropped ~ to 117~ and Motorola 1 to 82}. After struggling through an extended rocky spell in the past few years, technology stocks have enjoyed a revival in the recent rally that has carried the market to new highs. Brokers said the latest word from Adobe came as a fresh setback to fans of a market group that often is particularly vulnerable to earnings disappointments. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .79 to 194.68. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .97 at 359.79. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average slipped .71 to 2,855.55. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 8 to 7 on the NYSE, with 712 up, 801 down and 507 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 155.14 million shares, against 172.33 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Borders Reopen to Trucking as Independents Lift Blockade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Truck traffic resumed across the Canadian-U.S. border after Canada's transport minister persuaded drivers to end their blockade, and automakers began reopening plants shut by parts shortages. Chrysler Corp. recalled 3,200 workers to its Windsor minivan plant today after independent Canadian truckers lifted a blockade of the Ambassador Bridge, a major supply route for U.S.-made auto parts. ``The situation is looking better by the hour,'' said Chrysler Canada spokesman Walter McCall. ``The flow of materials has been restored and the likelihood is good that workers will be on their full shifts (today).'' But truckers at some other southern Ontario border points, including Fort Erie across the Niagara River from Buffalo, N.Y., and Niagara Falls, remained snarled late Thursday. Trucks still were blocking a lane of the Lewiston-Queenston Bridge at Niagara Falls, allowing only cars to pass, state police said. Trucks were not being allowed across the Peace Bridge linking Buffalo and Fort Erie, and about 100 to 200 trucks were parked on each side of the span, bridge officials said. In Windsor, the blockade of 300 trucks strangled traffic Wednesday and part of Thursday on the span between Windsor and Detroit but gave way to a steady stream of trucks moving in a single lane by Thursday evening. The work stoppage was lifted after Canadian Transport Minister Doug Lewis said he would take up with the Cabinet the truckers' complaints about taxes and the free-trade agreement with the United States. ``I am pleased to have had the opportunity to learn directly from them their concerns about what they consider to be an unlevel playing field,'' he said. Lewis met Thursday morning in Windsor with a delegation led by Wayne Whitney, a protest organizer, and Bill Wrye, Ontario minister of transportation. About 5 p.m. Thursday, the crowd of protesters dispersed, apparently pleased with the agreement, said Windsor police Staff Sgt. R. Nichols. ``There were about 200 people and another 100 to 150 trucks there. But the truckers were happy, got into their trucks and drove away,'' Nichols said. A sign thanking U.S. truckers for their support during the blockade hung at an intersection where truckers had congregated during the strike. The protest was sparked by proposed increases in Canada's Goods and Services Tax that will affect the goods that truckers haul as well as the tires, insurance and diesel fuel they buy. The U.S.-Canadian trade agreement, which will remove almost all tariffs by 1999, will further handicap Canadian truckers, protesters said. The truckers said taxes and the free-trade agreement are crippling their ability to compete with U.S. drivers. The blockade also forced the shutdown of three General Motors of Canada Ltd. plants in Ontario and production cutbacks at one in Quebec. Some 13,000 auto workers were affected. Production also was disrupted at Ford of Canada. Ford plants closed early Thursday in Dearborn and Wayne, Mich.; Lorain and Avon, Ohio; Louisville; and Minneapolis, said company spokesman Peter Olsen. At Mazda Motor Corp.'s plant in Flat Rock, Mich., 20 miles south of Detroit, workers went home early Wednesday and Thursday, said spokesman Tom McDonald. Protesters also had blocked the truck lanes at the Canadian end of the Blue Water Bridge between Sarnia and Port Huron, Mich., while in Sault Ste. Marie, supervisor Jim Blain at the International Bridge said he received conflicting reports about the work stoppage. At Fort Erie, about 200 trucks jammed the approaches to the international Peace Bridge to Buffalo, N.Y. At Blackpool, Quebec, just across the border from Champlain, N.Y., a heavily armed squad of police persuaded Quebec truckers to dismantle their blockade Thursday morning. No violence was reported at any of the blockaded border points.

DOC.NOTE: $adv31
For release PMs Thursday May 31 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Street Vendors and Merchants: Economies at War
LaserPhoto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: First they shed their shoes and socks. Next came the shirts. Then the street vendors, more than 200 of them, removed their trousers. They stood in their underwear outside the municipal assembly building to protest police harassment, their flabby bellies and calluses testifying to lifetimes of hard work and bad food. One woman was in the group. ``We wanted the authorities to reflect on what those naked bodies represented in terms of unemployment, health problems _ of vulnerability,'' one of the leaders, Luciano Jimeno Huanosta, said after the strip-in. It was a startling tactic in this conservative society, but the vendors were desperate. Before the protest in April, police responding to shopkeeper complaints had blocked their turf for days and the vendors couldn't work. More than five hours after the disrobing, city officials agreed to withdraw the police. The unconventional tactic worked, but was only one maneuver in an increasingly bitter conflict between Mexico's formal and informal economies. The war between shopkeepers and vendors is a symptom of a sick economy. An estimated 40 percent of Mexican workers are unemployed or underemployed. A million new jobs a year are needed just to keep up with population growth. For many, especially the very young and very old, there is no choice but making a living on the streets. ``If they want to get vendors off the streets, they have to create jobs,'' said Federico Garcia Hernandez, 29, a second-generation street salesman. Street vendors always have been part of Mexico, but their numbers have risen steadily since serious economic problems began in 1982. The National Chamber of Commerce in Mexico City, which has done studies on the informal economy for three years, estimates the capital has 200,000 street vendors. If they keep increasing, it says, vendors will outnumber regular merchants in a few years. The main field of battle is the heart of Mexico City, a 440-square-block labyrinth of commerce, colonial churches, Aztec ruins, cantinas and cafes known simply as El Centro. You can buy anything in El Centro from a stuffed, two-headed calf to the dried, powdered, encapsulated skin of rattlesnakes to the latest VCR. It has streets of shops that sell lingerie and lace, other streets that sell lights, spare parts, sporting goods, housewares. You can buy from shops behind walls encrusted with layers of handbills or on curbsides so old they are worn down to street level. It's cheaper on the street. ``On foreign goods, they can undercut us by almost 50 percent,'' said shopkeeper Alberto Gaona. ``They don't pay the 20 percent import tax and they don't pay the 15 percent value added tax. And I'd estimate that 70 to 85 percent of their goods are foreign.'' The shopkeepers, who must pay utility bills, rent, salaries and taxes, say the vendors are driving them out of business. ``We have dead zones now, areas where all the merchants have shut down,'' said Guillermo Gazal Jafif, founder of Procentrico, a group of downtown merchants. ``It's a direct attack on the formal economy.'' Procentrico estimates 30,000 street salesmen are competing in El Centro with 12,000 established merchants. Merchants have pestered city hall for more than a year to evict the vendors who clog the area's narrow streets. The vendors have resisted with demonstrations, sit-ins, petitions and the now-famous disrobing. There have been vague promises that the dispute would be resolved, but no action other than sporadic police sweeps against vendors. Both vendors and merchants agree on the reasons for inaction: Street vendors are a lucrative source of bribes and payoffs, and part of the political machinery of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as the PRI. An elaborate system of payoffs is run by leaders of vendor unions. More than 50 such unions are said to operate in El Centro alone. All but a few are formally affiliated with the PRI, the Chamber of Commerce says, and the occasional crackdowns are almost always on independents. Vendors and merchants say the minimum payment by a vendor is 10,000 pesos a day, about $3, which buys a piece of turf free of harassment by policemen or competitors. The union leader keeps part of the money and uses the rest for bribes. The acknowledged queenpin of the PRI-affiliated vendors is a hefty woman named Guillermina Rico, who can muster as many as 18,000 vendors for party rallies and is said to have a Swiss bank account. Mrs. Rico, 54, operates from a warehouse crammed with video recorders and other electronics behind an anonymous iron door at the teeming La Merced market. The walls are hung with photos of her with presidents and mayors and other party luminaries. The Chamber of Commerce says union leaders collected an estimated 2.2 billion pesos in payoffs in 1988, about $1 million at the prevailing exchange rate. It has proposed dismantling the system and using the money to build markets where the vendors could set up shop. Procentrico also favors building markets. ``The vendors exist because of a deteriorating economy, official corruption and politics,'' said Sergio Rios Lara, one of Procentrico's directors. ``Things can't continue like this. Mexico is in a era of change. Things can't keep working like they used to.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thursday May 31

DOC.HEAD: Campbell To Sell Some European Food Units
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after the 6th graf with background.
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co. said today it plans to sell several of its European food units in an effort to focus on its more profitable businesses. On the auction block are D. Lazzaroni & C. SpA of Italy; Campbell Seafoods Division, which operates in the United Kingdom and Belgium; the vegetable division of Campbell Foods PLC in England; and Campbell Irish Foods Ltd. and Mallow Foods Ltd., both of Ireland. The latter three companies were acquired when Campbell took over Freshbake Foods Group PLC of Britain in 1988. Total sales of all the businesses to be sold exceed $200 million, the company said. Campbell, whose board of directors approved the divestiture on Thursday, said it expected the sale to result in a $55 million charge against fourth quarter earnings. ``The result will be a more focused European enterprise delivering stronger operating profits along with superior returns and cash generation,'' Campbell Chief Executive David W. Johnson said in a statement. He noted that Campbell is committed to ``rebuild the frozen convenience food operation, which promises international synergy and long-term potential.'' Campbell has faced increasing problems over the past year and has been frequently rumored as a takeover target because of its sluggish performance and depressed stock price. Some members of the founding family have urged a sale of the entire company. The firm has sought to remain independent by divesting underperforming businesses and closing plants, cutting costs and laying off hundreds of workers. The companies to be divested have excellent positions in their respective markets that should make them attractive to a number of prospective buyers, officials said. Lazzaroni, based on Saronno, makes premium biscuits and seasonal cakes under the Lazzaroni and Borsari trademarks, but the unit has suffered from operating losses. The U.K. vegetable division has a 20 percent share of the frozen green vegetable market in Britain, while Irish Foods holds a 42 percent market share in Ireland. Its sister company, Mallow Foods, is a leading supplier of dehydrated vegetables, with a 25 percent share of the European market in dried peas.

DOC.HEAD: Existing Home Sales Off in April
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, According to, to update with today's mortgage rates; alson on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes fell 2.1 percent in April, their third drop in four months as they continued to lose momentum due to high mortgage rates, a real estate trade group reported today. The National Association of Realtors said resales of single-family homes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.33 million units, down from the March rate of 3.40 million. Existing home sales hit their 1989 peak of 3.56 million units in November and December and then fell in January, February and April. Sales were unchanged in March. According to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Crop., rates ranged from 10.25 percent to 10.56 percent during April. They had dipped to 10.33 percent by today. John A. Tuccillo, Realtors chief economist, said the high rates are keeping many prospective buyers out of the market in hopes of future rate declines. But despite the cost of mortgages, the sluggish Northeast market posted the only gain in April. Sales rose 4.0 percent to 520,000 units in what the Realtors president Norman D. Flynn called a ``buyer's market'' caused by supply exceeding demand. Sales slipped 1.1 percent to 900,000 units in the Midwest and dropped 3.7 percent to 1.31 million units in the South. But they plummeted 7.9 percent to 580,000 homes in the West. The Realtors said the national median price for an existing home in April was $95,300, down 1.0 percent from March but up 2.6 percent from April 1989. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less. The median price fell in all regions. It was down 5.4 percent to $140,700 in the Northeast, down 4.9 percent to $134,900 in the West, down 2.4 percent to $75,300 in the Midwest and off 0.3 percent to $85,700 in the South.

DOC.HEAD: With Homes Sales
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate home mortgages are currently averaging 10.33 percent, down from 10.37 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.53 percent this week, down from 8.56 percent the week before. The rates, compiled from a national survey, do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.NOTE: $adv28
For release Monday May 28
DOC.HEAD: Caldor Deal Shows Private Junk Market Is Still Open to Borrowers
DOC.TEXT: A discount retailer laden with takeover-related debt taps the junk bond market to raise $300 million. That may sound like just another tale from the easy-money days of the 1980s. But the deal took place last week, notwithstanding the current talk of a credit crunch and the death of the junk market. The fact that the Caldor discount chain was able to raise a hefty sum to refinance existing debt showed that some investors still have appetites for non-investment grade credits, bankers say. Caldor and most other recent junk issuers have had to raise their funds via private placements rather than in the public bond market, however. They've also had to structure their financing deals more conservatively, with tighter covenants to lure buyers. ``The buyers are really in the driver's seat,'' said John Crotty, a high-yield bond specialist at First Boston Corp. For insurance companies and other big institutions willing to buy junk, ``they can really tailor the bonds that they are buying.'' So far this year only four borrowers have made public offerings of junk bonds to raise a total of just $382 million, said David Unger, who tracks the high-yield market for First Boston. In the same period last year, before the bankruptcy filing of Campeau Corp.'s retailing arms and the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. virtually shut down the market, the total exceeded $11 billion. ``For all intents and purposes, the public market is dead,'' said Anthony Napolitano, who tracks private placements at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei. So Caldor looked for financing in the private junk market, which at an estimated $170 billion is nearly as large as the public market. Caldor was taken private last October when a group of investors that included management and the investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. bought the discount chain from May Department Stores Co. in a $552 million debt-financed deal known as a leveraged buyout. Garrett Moran, a managing director of DLJ, said the bank sat down with insurance companies, pension funds, mutual funds and Japanese institutions to hammer out long-term financing to replace the buyout group's temporary bridge loan. The result was a three-part deal: $160 million of senior floating rate 7-year notes paying interest of 2} percentage points over the London interbank rate; $40 million of 7-year 12~ percent senior notes, and $100 million of 10-year subordinated notes paying interest of 15 percent and carrying 7-year warrants to buy 12 percent of Caldor's equity.
