It took a month to hammer out the deal and sell it to about 50 institutions, Moran said, compared to the two to three weeks it used to take to launch a public bond issue. Caldor also had to include stricter covenants and include equity warrants, unlike the heydays of the junk market, he said. Still, it got the money. ``It shows that reasonable deals can get done in good size,'' Moran said. In recent weeks, bankers say more than $1 billion in deals have been done for borrowers such as the furniture company Ethan Allen Inc., drug chain operator Jack Eckerd Corp. and Multimedia Corp., the publishing and broadcasting company. Hal Guenther, senior vice president who handles private placements at Kemper Financial Services, said the private market could be capable of absorbing a couple hundred million worth of bonds a week. What's more, borrowers can save money because they don't have to pay the hefty underwriting fees of a public issue, he says. Guenther says his company hasn't found any of the recent deals attractive enough to buy. But he welcomed the trend toward giving bondholders better protection against default and away from notorious features like pay-in-kind bonds and coupon resets. Homer Rees, president of Prudential Capital Corp., agrees. Terms are becoming more realistic than a few years ago, especially when equity options are included as in Caldor's deal, he said. ``People are being paid more commensurately with the risks that are being taken,'' he says.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for May 28

DOC.HEAD: GM to Make Cars in East Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with vote on executive pensions; SUBS 10th-last grafs pvs bgng: Also at ...
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. will begin making cars in East Germany later this year, company Chairman Roger Smith said today as he addressed shareholders at his last GM annual meeting. If GM starts production as planned in October, the world's largest corporation will become the first U.S. automaker to make vehicles in the region undergoing rapid political and economic reform. Smith, who retires July 31 after 9{ years as head of GM, said the company will make Opel Vectra cars for sale in Europe under a joint venture with East Germany's Automobilewerke Eisenach. The company will assemble about 10,000 of the cars this year. Production of the four-door sedans, about the same size as the Chevrolet Cavalier, is expected to increase to about 150,000 annually by the mid-1990s, GM spokesman Jack Harned said. Chysler Corp. has planned a joint venture to make minivans in Austria. Ford Motor Co. is studying vehicle assembly plans in East Germany but has yet to announce any specific plans. Automobilewerke's factory in Eisenach currently makes the Wartburg automobile. Harned said production of the Vectra will be a separate operation. ``It's not GM taking over Wartburg,'' he noted. GM currently makes the Vector in Russelsheim, West Germany. Smith said the joint venture with Automobilewerke is the first step of GM's ``New Europe'' strategy. In addition to making cars, GM will begin building engines and assembling a small number of cars in Hungary by early 1992. During Smith's tenure, GM's share of the U.S. car and truck market fell to about 36 percent from about 44 percent. Also at the meeting, GM shareholders voted to double the pensions of 3,350 top executives by changing the formula for calculating them from one that considers salary alone to one that bases pension on both salary and bonuses. Of 503 million shareholder votes, 83.3 percent favored the proposal. Smith weathered some personal attacks during debate, including opposition from corporate gadfly Evelyn Davis of Washington. ``Roger, in due respect to you, you don't need this type of a pension,'' she said. The proposal also had been opposed by Michigan state Treasurer Robert Bowman, who administers 8.8 million shares, about 1 percent of outstanding stock, through five pension funds. The proposal would cost about $42 million annually. Bowman has said there are better uses for the money, including product development, further plant modernization and beefing up an underfunded pension plan for other employees. Bowman said before the meeting he would ask incoming Chairman Robert Stempel to reject any such approved increase.

DOC.HEAD: Meredith Agrees to Sell SAIL Magazine to Cahners Publishing
DOC.TEXT: Meredith Corp. said Friday it has agreed to sell SAIL magazine to Cahners Publishing, which already produces Power & Motoryacht, MotorBoat and Motoryacht International magazines. The price was not disclosed. The magazine has a monthly circulation of 170,000, making it the largest circulation sailing magazine in the world, Meredith said. Meredith, based in Des Moines, is a diversified media and real estate business best known for its Better Homes and Gardens and Ladies' Home Journal magazines. Cahners, of Newton, Mass., is part of Reed Publishing (USA) Inc. ``SAIL is the `bible' _ it has a tremendous franchise in the boating industry _ and it's always been a Cahners `acquisition tradition' to seek out publications like SAIL that are leaders in their fields,'' said Terry McDermott, the president of Cahners. Jack Rehm, president of Meredith, said SAIL has performed well for the company over the years but is being sold as part of a strategic plan. ``Meredith publications are targeted to a home and family readership. In the 10 years since we acquired SAIL, our magazines have become even more focused on that audience,'' Rehm said.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Say Program Trading Helped Cause Share-Value Loss
DOC.TEXT: Computer-triggered selling on the Chicago futures markets helped cause the sharp loss in the value of shares on the New York Stock Exchange last Oct. 13, federal regulators say. ``Index arbitrage and other program selling significantly accelerated and exacerbated the market decline,'' the Securities and Exchange Commission's division of market regulation said in a report. The report was presented to the House Commerce finance subcommittee on Thursday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 190.58 points, or 6.91 percent of its value, on Oct. 13. Overall, the nation's securities markets lost $190 billion in value, including $160 billion in the last 90 minutes of trading. On the next business day, Monday, Oct. 16, another sell-off was followed by a sharp upswing in heavy trading before the markets stabilized. The investigators found a large number of futures sales by speculators on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange during critical times on Oct. 13. ``CME floor traders did not provide net liquidity to the market,'' the report said. ``Given current market and regulatory structures, there can be no assurance that the extraordinary volatility of Oct. 13 and 16 will not be repeated or surpassed in the future,'' the investigators concluded. The report said a ``circuit breaker'' mechanism that was developed after the 1987 stock market crash may have slowed the market decline last year. The mechanism, which temporarily limits price swings, was imposed after a 12-point drop in the price of a Standard & Poor's basket of futures. Imposition of the circuit breaker coincided with a steep decline in the level of program selling on the New York Stock Exchange and a reduction in the rate of the price decline in NYSE stocks, the report said. ``While a direct causal relationship is difficult to establish, at a minimum, the division's findings do not indicate any harm to the markets attributable to the imposition of the circuit-breaker mechanisms,'' the report said. The SEC and the Bush administration have been pressing Congress to give the SEC authority to regulate stock-index futures. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission now regulates such trading.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Gain On Strong Exports, Rain Forecasts
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were moderately higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, boosted by surprisingly strong export sales and the arrival of a new round of showers in the Midwest. In a report released late Thursday, the Agriculture Department said export sales of corn, wheat and soybeans rose last week, contrary to normal seasonal patterns. The corn and soybean markets also were supported by reports of rain falling across Illinois and forecasts for scattered showers in the Midwest through the weekend. The rain threatens to further delay planting progress in areas already well soaked by recent rains, analysts said. ``It looks like a real soggy run for the eastern Corn Belt,'' said Richard Feltes, director of commodity research with the futures brokerage Refco Inc. In early trading, wheat futures prices were 1 cent to 3 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.31{ a bushel; corn futures were 2 cents to 3{ cents higher with July at $2.82{ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2{ cents higher with July at $1.54 a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents to 5{ cents higher with July at $6.19{ a bushel. Cattle futures were narrowly mixed while pork futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .05 cent lower to .05 cent higher with June at 73.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .13 cent lower to .03 cent higher with August at 83.60 cents a pound; live hogs were .08 cent lower to .25 cent higher with June at 65.90 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .03 cent to .13 cent higher with July at 65.60 cents a pound. Cattle futures fell on Thursday while hogs advanced and pork bellies dropped sharply.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Mostly Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with closing stock prices.
DOC.TEXT: Shares finished mostly lower Friday on London's Stock Exchange after mostly sluggish trading before a long holiday weekend. Monday is a bank holiday in Britain. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index finished down 11.5 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,265.6, slightly below its high for the day of 2,276.3 and above its low of 2,258.4. The Financial Times 30-share index was down 5.2 points at 1,800.0 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 5.63 points to close at 1,228.69. Volume was a light 385.6 million shares, compared with 420.3 million shares Thursday. Profit-talking and an absence of buyers for the majority of the session dragged prices lower, traders said. A lack of corporate or economic news further burdened the market, they said.
Here are the major business events and economic events scheduled for the coming week (some dates are tentative; times are EDT):

DOC.HEAD: The AP

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices lost ground today in selling that hit technology issues hardest. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 13.52 to 2,842.03 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 8 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 559 up, 881 down and 497 unchanged. Analysts said the tone for the session was set overnight by word from Adobe Systems, a computer software company, that its earnings for the second quarter and full year were likely to fall short of analysts' estimates. Adobe shares, the most active stock in the over-the-counter market, tumbled 16\ to 34\. Other computer and technology issues registered smaller declines on the news. Apple Computer, a primary Adobe customer, slumped 2 to 40 in OTC trading. Among NYSE-listed technology stocks, International Business Machines dropped 1[ to 117| and Motorola 2] to 81]. After struggling through an extended rocky spell in the past few years, technology stocks have enjoyed a revival in the recent rally that has carried the market to new highs. Brokers said the latest word from Adobe came as a fresh setback to fans of a market group that often is particularly vulnerable to earnings disappointments. Dennison Manufacturing jumped 8\ to 27\ and Avery International fell 2{ to 26. Avery agreed to acquire Dennison through an exchange of stock. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell .78 to 194.69. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .76 at 360.00. Volume on the Big Board came to 86.53 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: High Mortgage Rates Affect Sales of Existing Homes
DOC.TEXT: High mortgage rates continued to dampen sales of existing homes through much of the nation in April, although the Northeast posted its first gain since last fall, a real estate trade group said Friday. The National Association of Realtors said overall resales of single-family homes slipped 2.1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.33 million units. It was the third drop in four months as mortgage rates remained in double digits. Sales were unchanged in March. The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Crop. said rates ranged from 10.25 percent to 10.56 percent in April. They had dipped back to 10.33 percent by Friday. Rates also have affected sales of new homes, which fell for four consecutive months through March. The Commerce Department will release the April sales figures Wednesday. Although mortgage costs remained high, sales of existing homes in the Northeast increased for the first time since October. Purchasers bought at an annual rate of 520,000 units in April, up 4 percent from the 500,000 units sold the previous month. Norman D. Flynn, Realtors president, said inventories have risen while prices have fallen, and the buyers' market caused by supply exceeding demand attracted buyers despite the high rates. The median price of an existing home in the Northeast was down 5.4 percent to $140,700, compared to the national median of $95,300. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less. Elsewhere, sales fell. In the high-cost Western market, sales plummeted 7.9 percent to 580,000 units, despite a 4.9 percent drop in its median price to $134,900. The median price had been $147,100 as recently as November. The resale rate in the South fell 3.7 percent to 1.31 million units. The median price was $85,700, down 0.3 percent from March. Sales also slipped 1.1 percent to 900,000 units in the Midwest, where the median price fell 2.4 percent to $75,300.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Says Airline Employees Entitled to Damages
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines employees who lost wages and benefits in 1983 when the company was allowed to reject its labor contracts are entitled to damages, a federal appeals court said Friday. But the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals rejected the employee unions' contention that the bankruptcy court judge who originally ruled in the matter should have removed himself from the case. Shortly after his ruling, Judge T. Glover Roberts accepted a partnership in the law firm that represented Continental. Roberts risked an appearance of impropriety when he accepted the position, the appeals court said. But the judges said the job was offered after Roberts had ruled in the case. Glover had ruled in favor of Continental in rejecting employees' claims for future wages and benefits. The unions had claimed they were entitled to wages and benefits they would have received if their labor contracts hadn't been dumped when Continental filed Chapter 11 bankruptcy papers in 1983. The employees kept working under emergency work rules approved by the bankruptcy Court. ``Recognizing that the agreements here at issue do not guarantee employment, we hold that the difference between the wages and benefits set out in the agreements and the wages and benefits actually paid under the emergency work rules are recoverable as unsecured claims to the extent that work would have been available had the agreements not been rejected,'' the appeals court said. The court sent the case to the bankruptcy court to determine when Continental would have had to cease operations had it not cancelled the contracts and to calculate appropriate damages.

DOC.HEAD: Tag Team: Label Maker, Ticket Outfit To Merge
DOC.TEXT: Stick-on label maker Avery International Corp. has agreed to merge with Dennison Manufacturing Co. of Framingham, Mass., which produces office supplies and systems to tag and ticket clothes for retailers, the companies said Friday. The new company, Avery Dennison Corp., will be based at Avery's Pasadena headquarters. The friendly deal, recommended by management of both companies, still must be approved by stockholders and regulators. Dennison shareholders will receive 1.12 shares of Avery common stock for every share of Dennison common stock, a deal that values Dennison at about $500 million, the companies said. Avery has annual revenue of about $1.7 billion and 11,700 workers. Dennison's annual revenue is about $770 million and the company has about 7,000 employees. Representatives of both companies will have to study details of how operations will be merged before any decision is made on whether to lay off workers, Avery spokeswoman Diane Dixon said. Avery and Dennison have a range of complementary products sold under such brands as Avery, Fasson, Dennison, National and Carter's, Avery chief executive, Charles D. Miller, and his counterpart at Dennison, Nelson S. Gifford, said in a joint statement. They said that offered excellent opportunities for expansion. ``The new company will have a strong, worldwide presence in office supplies and industrial systems, enhancing our ability to compete against other global companies. ``In addition, our complementary strengths in the tag and ticket business provide us with the opportunity to develop new business more cost-effectively,'' they said.

DOC.HEAD: Corn Futures Climb On Rain Forecasts
DOC.TEXT: Corn futures prices rose strongly Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending the gains of the two previous sessions amid rain forecasts that threaten to further delay planting progress in the Midwest. Other grain and soybean futures also advanced. Forecasts for scattered showers Corn Belt through the Memorial Day weekend and well into next week ``overwhelmed everything else'' in the market Friday, said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. About 20 percent of the nation's corn crop remains to be planted, Lespinasse said, and if farmers don't get the seed in the ground within the next 10 days, yield losses are likely. That propect was reflected in steeper losses in the contracts for delivery of corn from the upcoming crop than in the July contract, which represents the last of the old-crop corn. The pattern was reversed in the soybean market, reflecting the possibility that farmers will plant soybeans on acres they had planned to sow with corn. Indications of strong export sales of U.S. grains supported all the markets, analysts said. At the close, wheat futures were unchanged to 3 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.30{ a bushel; corn was unchanged to 5{ cents higher with July at $2.84 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2{ cents higher with July at $1.54{ a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cents to 4{ cents higher with July at $6.20 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Rebirth of Ad-Free Ms. Magazine Now Set for Late July
DOC.TEXT: The owners of Ms. magazine say reader response to their plans to resurrect the publication without advertising was strong enough to proceed, but they have delayed its reappearance until late July. The 17-year-old feminist magazine suspended publication last December because of heavy losses and a sharp decline in advertising. In March, plans were announced to resume publication without ads starting in June. But Andrea Kaplan, a spokeswoman for the magazine, said Thursday that the relaunch date now has been set for July 31. She blamed the delay on ``a lot of launch details'' that must be addressed. Lang Communications Inc., a New York-based company that acquired Ms. last fall, previously said that barring ads from the magazine would free writers to pursue topics without worrying about how advertisers might react. But magazine executives indicated earlier this year that resumption of publishing would depend on getting enough people sign up for subscriptions, which were set at $40 a year _ more than double the previous $16 rate. The magazine will appear six times a year, down from 10 previously. Ms. Kaplan declined to say how many people have signed up for subscriptions. She said Chairman Dale Lang and other magazine executives met two weeks ago and decided to proceed. She said the subscription response was ``close to their projections'' and that it was particularly strong from young women just out of college. Industry analysts warned that it would be difficult to generate enough revenue from circulation alone to be profitable, particularly because many other magazines have taken up some of the topics on which Ms. built its franchise with feminists. But Lang hired noted feminist author Robin Morgan as its new editor in chief and she has said the magazine will address topics that have not been explored fully enough in women's magazines. She has cited as examples stories on the role of women in the upheavals in Eastern Europe, homeless women and violence against women. The magazine also will feature fiction and poetry from women and investigative reporting. Ms. founder Gloria Steinem helped drum up support for the relaunch, writing a pitch for the magazine that was included in a March mailing to about 600,000 potential subscribers people, including those who had been subscribing to Ms. when publication was suspended. Ms. Kaplan said the magazine is continuing to solicit subscriptions, and expects a total circulation of ``less than 100,000.'' She said Lang expects to break even on the publication for the first year without advertising.
Stock prices took a tumble today, pulling back from the record highs they reached earlier in the week. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 34.87 at 2,820.68.

DOC.HEAD: Macy's Cash Flow Rises 4 Percent in Latest Quarter
DOC.TEXT: R.H. Macy & Co. Inc.'s cash flow, crucial to the company's ability to reduce its heavy debt, rose 4 percent during the retailer's third quarter, a spokesman said Friday. Based on preliminary results, Macy's cash flow _ its earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation _ rose to $160.2 million from $154 million a year earlier, spokesman Jim Fingeroth said. The company suffered a net loss in the quarter, which ended April 28, of $63.1 million, down from $64.1 million a year earlier. Final figures for the quarter were expected to be released in mid-June. The news followed months of concern about the company's financial health and was welcomed by investors, who bid up the price of Macy's junk bonds Friday. The company, which remains saddled with debt after a $3.6 billion leveraged buyout in 1986, is dependent on its cash flow to pay its bills. Investors have been concerned about Macy's results since the company suffered a $39 million loss in its second quarter. The second quarter included the critical Christmas shopping season, a time when retailers expect to earn as much as half their annual profit. But this past Christmas, Macy was forced to take heavy markdowns on its merchandise to compete with Campeau Corp.'s department stores, and its profits vanished. The Campeau units, also struggling after billion-dollar buyouts, had slashed their prices to bring in sales in an unsuccessful attempt to avoid a bankruptcy court filing. Macy's creditors also have been concerned about the retailer's financial state. On Thursday, Heller Financial Corp., a company that lends money to Macy suppliers, said it was reconsidering its standards for financing shipments to the retailer. Macy's junk bonds fell sharply Thursday in response to Heller's announcement, but the issues recovered some ground Friday.

Stock prices fell sharply today, retreating from the record highs they reached earlier in the week. Technology issues suffered some of the day's biggest losses. Analysts said the tone for the session was set overnight by word from Adobe Systems, a computer software company, that its earnings for the second quarter and full fiscal year were likely to fall short of analysts' estimates. After struggling through an extended rocky spell in the past few years, technology stocks have enjoyed a revival in the recent rally that has carried the market to new highs. Brokers said the latest word from Adobe came as a fresh setback to fans of a market group that often is particularly vulnerable to earnings disappointments.
