DOC.HEAD: Anheuser-Busch Bids Farewell to Its LA Beer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, Hunter said... to DELETE incorrect time element. Picks up 7th graf, Other non-alcoholic...
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Anheuser-Busch Inc. said Friday it was ending production of LA, the brewer's poor-selling, reduced-alcohol beer that apparently lost its niche and could not find a new one. The beer, with about half the alcohol of regular beer, was introduced six years ago as the first response from a major brewer to the trend toward more responsible drinking. LA's slogan was ``for the way you live your life today...LA.'' But the trend LA tried to ride ended up spelling its demise, analysts said. On Friday, Anheuser-Busch executives said they were getting rid of the LA brand because they didn't want the beer to take sales away from its new no-alcohol beer, O'Doul's. ``It was clear to us that the two brands came to compete for essentially the same consumer segment,'' said Jim Hunter, vice president of sales for the St. Louis-based brewer. ``And it became clear that O'Doul's was emerging as the consumer's choice.'' Hunter said O'Doul's, which was introduced nationally earlier this year, has exceeded sales projections by more than 30 percent. He said the company plans to increase production of the beer once LA production ends June 30. Other non-alcoholic beers, including Miller Brewing Co.'s Sharp's and Pabst's NA brand, also are starting to get more room on store shelves around the country. Some analysts said Friday that the demise of LA would not necessarily mean the new no-alcohol brews were doomed. O'Doul's and other no-alcohol brews are considered a clear alternative to regular beer, not a half-step like LA. ``The beer drinker either wants the regular beer, or the lower calorie beer or no alcohol at all,'' said Julie Niemann of Stifel Nicolaus & Co. Inc. in St. Louis. ``This was a neither-fish-nor-fowl kind of thing.'' Robert Weinberg, professor of marketing management at Washington University and a beer industry consultant, said, ``It was not enough of an alternative. It seemed like a hybrid product, sort of a compromise.'' Weinberg said he drank LA occasionally at a restaurant near his office _ until the restaurant stopped stocking the beer because he was the only customer requesting it. ``The demand was indeed small, even though it was marketed aggressively,'' Weinberg said. ``So, I think it was a matter of time.'' LA beer never was a highly popular product for Anheuser-Busch. In 1984, LA sales totaled about 300,000 barrels, a fraction of the 80 million barrels of beer Anheuser-Busch company makes annually, according to industry estimates. Sales steadily fell and were about 20,000 barrels for all of 1989, analysts said. Anheuser-Busch did not expect either LA or O'Doul's to be big sellers, one analyst said. ``Both LA and O'Doul's are meant not only to be profit makers, but in my opinion, they have been introduced to fill a social need,'' said George Thompson, of Prudential-Bache in New York. ``I think that in that context, the company really isn't terribly concerned that they make a lot of money _ the point is to provide an alternative.'' Thompson said LA's failure indicated consumers were not that interested in having an alternative to regular beer. ``The fault lies here not with Anheuser-Busch, but with the consumers,'' Thompson said. ``Anheuser-Busch knows how to sell beer, if there's a willing consumer base. If there isn't a willing consumer base, then even the good Lord couldn't sell it.''

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Slip Due To Economic, Treasury Announcements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to correct cycle designator to AM.
DOC.TEXT: Treasury security prices closed lower Friday after a series of reports that spelled bad news for the bond market, including consumer spending figures that were rosier than analysts had expected. The government's bellwether 30-year bond, which lost 7-16 point Thursday, fell another | point, or about $6.25 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, rose to 8.66 percent from 8.61 percent late Thursday. Trading was extremely light due to the long Memorial Day weekend. Analysts said the market was affected by the government's report that consumer spending increased by 0.6 percent in April, the largest increase since it rose 1.2 percent in January. The increase was seen as a good indication of future economic growth. Traders had been expecting an increase of about 0.4 percent, said Mike Casey, international economist at Maria Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc. Bond prices usually decline on signs of economic improvement because it decreases the likelihood that the Federal Reserve Board will ease interest rates. Casey said the market also soured as the Treasury announced plans to sell $12 billion in cash management bills Wednesday to raise new cash, $2 billion more than expected. An increase in the supply of a security often causes prices to fall. In addition, analysts said the market was affected by weak bidding in Thursday's auction of $8.5 billion in five-year Treasury notes, as well as the dollar's sharp drop against the Japanese yen in European trading early Friday. ``There wasn't any tremendous blow, but just a series of small, unfortunate things that happened over the course of the day,'' Casey said. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments fell from 3-32 point to [ point, intermediate maturities fell from [ point to 17-32 point, and long-term issues dropped | point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 3.14 to 1,147.99. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell [ point to 91 9-32. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.54 percent from 7.53 percent late Thursday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 7.99 percent as the discount rose 7 basis points to 7.74 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 8.16 percent as the discount rose 4 basis points to 7.74 percent. Yields on one-year bills increased to 8.22 percent as the discount rose 8 basis points to 7.66 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 5-16 percent, unchanged from late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Mostly Lower
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil and heating oil futures prices fell while gasoline futures were mixed Friday as traders squared their accounts in advance of the three-day Memorial Day weekend. The July contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, slipped 3 cents to $17.80 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange following a 31-cent decline Thursday. Later contract months also showed small losses. Among refined products traded on the Merc, the June contract for home heating oil dropped 0.15 cent a gallon to 49.66 cents, after falling 0.40 cent on Thursday. Later months showed bigger declines. Warm weather is usually a slack period for heating oil, analysts say. Gasoline futures were mixed. The June contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline rose 0.18 cent to 63.41 cents a gallon on top of Thursday's 0.72 cent advance. But later contract months for gasoline futures fell. The July contract, for instance, dropped 0.37 cent to 61.00 cents a gallon after rising 1.05 cents Thursday. Peter Beutel, assistant director of the energy group at Elders Futures Inc., said the rise in the near-month gasoline contract may have reflected the surge in demand that usually accompanies the summer driving season, which unofficially begins with Memorial Day. Natural gas prices declined. The July contract fell to $1.592 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.600 Thursday. Beutel said trading in each of the energy futures categories was volatile and active at times during the session, but he said prices were driven mostly by technical factors, including the reluctance of traders to hold vulnerable positions in the market over a three-day weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Beech-Nut Recalls Two Products Because of Tiny Stones
DOC.TEXT: Beech-Nut Nutrition Corp. said Friday it was voluntarily recalling two baby food products because small stones were found in some of the jars during routine checks. The stones apparently were in a shipment of peas used in the company's Table Time Vegetable Stew with Chicken and Stage 3 Chicken Noodle Dinner. The company said it was investigating why the shipment was not thoroughly cleaned by the supplier. The products were produced at Beech-Nut's Canajoharie, N.Y., plant, said Patrick Farrell, a spokesman for Beech-Nut's parent company, Ralston Purina Co. He said the pebbles were found during routine quality control checks of more than 183,000 jars. He said the company found 52 small stones ranging in size from one-eighth inch to one-half inch. The company said it has received only one consumer complaint and no reports of injury. The vegetable stew is marked with an expiration date Feb. 28, 1992, and the chicken noodle dinner has a March 9, 1992, expiration date. The products are also included in a Stage 3 Dinner Variety Pack marked for use by March 1992. The products were distributed to Alabama, Connecticut, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Missouri, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Texas, Vermont, Virginia and West Virginia. Farrell said consumers can return the products to stores where they were purchased for a refund or exchange. The company's consumer affairs hotline between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. EDT is 1-800-523-6633.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Maker Recalls 285,000 Front-wheel Drive Vehicles
DOC.TEXT: Subaru of America announced Friday it was recalling 285,000 front-wheel drive cars because of possible rear suspension corrosion. The models affected include the 1980 to 1984 Subaru front-wheel drive sedan, hatchback and hardtop models. The automaker said it was also recalling the 1985 and 1986 front-wheel drive hatchback models. Subaru said the rear suspension of the vehicles could be corroded in areas of the country where large quantities of road salt are used. The corrosion could make operation and control of the vehicle difficult, the company said. Subaru said owners of the recalled vehicles are being notified to return the car to a Subaru dealer, where the suspension will be inspected and rust-proofed or replaced.

DOC.HEAD: National Semiconductor and NEC Form Chip Pact
DOC.TEXT: National Semiconductor Corp. said Friday it signed a pact with NEC Corp. to sell one of the Japanese company's leading edge computer memory chips and explore deals in marketing, manufacturing and technology. The initial agreement between the two electronic giants covers Tokyo-based NEC's high-volume SRAM chips _ a static random access memory device with 256,000 bytes of memory. ``This agreement broadens our memory products portfolio to include SRAM products required by manufacturers of a variety of communications products,'' said John Hekking, vice president of National Semiconductor's memory division. Hajime Sasaki, vice president of NEC's semiconductor group, said the agreement will contribute to the company's memory products business, ``but more importantly, it will promote NEC's policy of international cooperation.'' National Semiconductor said it would begin offering the NEC memory devices in July. ``It's just one more step in the partnering in the semiconductor industry,'' said analyst Daniel L. Kleskin of Prudential Bache Research in San Francisco. ``Texas Instruments and Intel also are selling Japanese chips. It's a recognition by them, and others, that a semiconductor company can't be all things to all people. But they need to provide a full line to their customers, so it makes sense to work with other companies to provide products they don't have.'' Kleskin said the National Semiconductor-NEC pact ``can be a win-win deal.'' ``There's not a high margin of profits for National because NEC has to make a profit, but the risk is minimal because they don't have to build a plant to make the chips,'' he said. ``For NEC, which is about a $5 billion company, it's a very small deal ... But it shows a willingness to work with American companies.''

DOC.HEAD: Iberia Orders 16 Boeing 757s
DOC.TEXT: Iberia Airlines of Spain has ordered 16 Boeing 757s for about $1 billion and taken options on another 12 of the twinjets, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said Friday. The planes are for use on European, African and Middle Eastern routes, with delivery to run from early 1993 to 1997 if all options are exercised. Engine selection is to be made later, a Boeing statement said. The planes were ordered with 188 seats each, 86 in business class and 102 in tourist. The deal boosts total 757 orders to 648 planes by 33 customers. The order was announced one day after Japan Airlines ordered 20 Boeing 747-400s in a deal valued at $3.1 billion. Boeing orders for the year are now 154 aircraft valued at about $12.4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Canon To Distribute FPS Computers
DOC.TEXT: Canon Sales Co. Inc. will distribute FPS Computing systems in Japan under an agreement announced Friday. FPS said Canon, a subsidiary of Canon Inc. of Japan, will acquire certain assets of the Oregon computer company and expects to trade using the name FPS Computing. ``The current technical computing market in Japan is expanding rapidly, and Canon views this partnership with FPS Computing as a natural and logical extension of their already successful computer workstation and systems business,'' FPS said in a statement. Several FPS supercomputers have been installed by Japanese corporations, including Sony Corp., Nippon Telegraph & Telephone Corp. and Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd. Canon Sales is responsible for all Canon sales activities in Japan, including office equipment, workstations and computer systems. FPS makes high-performance computer systems for scientific, engineering and technical applications. The company was founded in 1970 as Floating Point Systems Inc.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices took a spill Friday, giving up some of the gains that carried the market to record highs earlier in the week. Technology issues bore the brunt of the selling in a session marked by sharply reduced activity on the eve of the long Memorial Day weekend. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 34.63 to 2,820.92, cutting its gain for the week to 1.01 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 7 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 543 up, 947 down and 507 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 120.25 million shares, down from 155.14 million in the previous session, as a good many traders got an early start on the three-day holiday weekend. The markets will be closed on Monday for Memorial Day. Analysts said the tone for the session was set overnight by word from Adobe Systems, a computer software company, that its earnings for the second quarter and full fiscal year were likely to fall short of analysts' estimates. Adobe shares, the most active stock in the over-the-counter market, tumbled 15\ to 35\. Other computer and technology issues registered smaller declines on the news. Apple Computer, a primary Adobe customer, slumped 2 to 40 in OTC trading. Among NYSE-listed technology stocks, International Business Machines dropped 2{ to 116\; Motorola 3 to 80}, and Hewlett-Packard | to 47\. After struggling through an extended rocky spell in the past few years, technology stocks have enjoyed a revival in the recent rally that has carried the market to new highs. Brokers said the latest word from Adobe came as a fresh setback to fans of a market group that often is particularly vulnerable to earnings disappointments. Elsewhere, Dennison Manufacturing jumped 8] to 27] and Avery International fell 2\ to 26\. Avery agreed to acquire Dennison through an exchange of stock valued at about $500 million. Philip Morris dropped 1| to 42{, weighed down for the second straight session by news of a federal regulator's call for new state constraints on cigarette sales. Other losers among the blue-chip industrials included American Telephone & Telegraph, down 1\ at 41|; General Electric, down 1 at 68]; DuPont, down 1[ at 39[, and Texaco, down 1] at 57\. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 147.19 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $28.25 billion, or 0.82 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 1.76 to 193.71. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 4.82 to 413.63, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 3.83 at 354.58. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 4.60 to 453.69. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 359.84, down .92.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls Against Yen, Little Changed Against Others
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply against the yen but otherwise was little changed in foreign exchange Friday as investors regained confidence in the Japanese currency. Gold prices generally were higher. The recovery of stock prices in Tokyo helped boost confidence in the yen. The Nikkei Stock Average, the Japanese market's best-known indicator, rose more than 1,300 points this week. The dollar skidded to 149.40 yen in New York from 151.15 late Thursday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 150.05 yen from 151.55 yen, and was quoted at 149.70 yen in London. Traders said currency trading generally focused on the West German mark amid growing uncertainty about German unification. Market sentiment ``turned very bearish against the mark,'' said Earl I. Johnson, an assistant vice president with Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago. The mark had soared in the days after the Berlin Wall began to come down last winter, symbolically signaling the move to unification between East and West Germany. But uncertainty about the union of the two Germanys and their currencies has been increasing recently and has taken a toll on the mark, traders said. Concern over political problems in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union also influenced trading in the mark. The dollar rose to 1.68235 marks in New York from 1.6815 late Thursday. In earlier European trading, the dollar rose to 1.6810 marks from Thursday's 1.6780. Dealers said U.S. trading was light in advance of the long Memorial Day holiday weekend. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.4235 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.6615 French francs, up from 5.6555; 1,235.50 Italian lire, up from 1,233.50; and 1.1830 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18435. The dollar was narrowly mixed against the British pound. Sterling fell to $1.6905 in New York from late Thursday's $1.6910. In London earlier, the pound rose to $1.6895, from $1.6890 late Thursday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Thursday's late rates included: 1.4245 Swiss francs, up from 1.4190; 5.6585 French francs, up from 5.6445; 1.8820 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8740 on Wednesday; 1,234.15 Italian lire, up from 1,230.75, and 1.1837 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1853. Gold prices rose in New York. On the Commodity Exchange, a troy ounce of gold for current delivery picked up $1.70 to close at $368.20, and Republic National Bank later quoted a spot bid of $367.50, up 90 cents. Earlier, gold rose in London to a late bid of $367.34 a troy ounce from $366.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $367 from $364 late Wednesday. The market was closed Thursday. Gold fell overnight in Hong Kong, slipping 51 cents to close at a bid of $367.83. Silver for current delivery fell 1.3 cents to $5.215 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Silver slipped in London to a late bid of $5.23 a troy ounce from $5.26 late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Shearson Lehman Omits 2nd-Qtr Dividend, Cites American Express Merger Pact
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc., which is in a merger pact with its majority owner American Express Co., said Friday it would omit its common stock dividend for the second quarter. Its regular dividend has been 18.75 cents per share of common stock. The move will save the nation's second largest brokerage company about $16.5 million in dividend payments on its 88 million shares of common stock. Only about 29 million of those shares are owned by holders other than American Express, which owns the remaining two-thirds of Shearson common. American Express agreed in March to acquire the Shearson shares it does not already own. Under terms of the merger agreement, each publicly-held Shearson share will be converted into 0.48 of a share of American Express common stock. No date has been announced for completion of the merger. Shearson said the merger agreement gave it the option of paying or omitting its second-quarter dividend. Last month, Shearson reported it lost $915 million in the first three months of the year, the securities industry's largest quarterly loss. The loss reflected moves Shearson made to right itself after expanding too rapidly in the 1980s. Shearson took a $630 million charge against its earnings to pay for a restructuring that included 2,000 layoffs and the elimination or reduction of several businesses. In addition to omitting the common share dividend, American Express will not receive a quarterly dividend on the $750 million in convertible exchangeable preferred stock of Shearson that it owns. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Shearson fell 37.5 cents a share to $13.75.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Plant Contract Awarded
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Missiles and Space Co. on Friday won a $550 million contract to design and build a solid-rocket booster plant in northeast Mississippi. Jerry Berg, a NASA spokesman at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., said the contract to Lockheed's Sunnyvale, Calif., division includes $314 million to design and construct new buildings or modify existing ones, and about $236 million to buy equipment. The facilities will be constructed mainly at Yellow Creek near Iuka, a government-owned site of an abandoned nuclear power plant. Construction is expected to take 3{ years. NASA will also build a static motor test-firing stand at its Stennis Space Center near Bay St. Louis, add nozzle production at its Michoud Assembly Facility near New Orleans, and modify test installations at the Marshall space center to accomodate the advanced solid rocket motor, or ASRM. Lockheed Missile and Space Co. was awarded a $44 million contract to build the test-firing stand at Stennis, NASA also announced Friday. The ASRM is designed to replace the space shuttle's current booster rockets in the mid-1990s. The contracts awarded Friday were companions to one awarded to Lockheed May 11 covering design, development, test and evaluation of the new rocket motor. Lon Miller, a spokesman at Stennis, said construction would begin later this year or next, after necessary permits are obtained. Rocket motor testing is scheduled to begin in 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Five Principals of Failed Insurance Co. Plead Guilty to Mail Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Five of the six family members controlling the Champion Insurance Co. empire pleaded guilty to mail fraud charges Friday in a deal with the federal government. U.S. District Judge Frank Polozola accepted the pleas but delayed a decision on Justice Department recommendations for light sentences until after an investigation. The indictment had charged that officials of the company concealed over $2 million that was provided to Louisiana Insurance Commissioner Doug Green for use in his 1987 election campaign. Green was not indicted and has denied any involvement with Champion. Under the plea agreement, Champion owner John Eicher and his son, Naaman, would receive no less than 37 months or no more than 46 months each. Indicted on 19 counts of mail fraud, they pleaded guilty to four. Each count carries a normal maximum sentence of five years. Patricia Eicher, wife of the owner; Tina Eicher, wife of the son, and Meredith Eicher, the owner's daughter, pleaded guilty to two counts each. As part of the arrangement with U.S. Attorney Ray Lamonica, the women would be sentenced to no more than six months each with the possibility of no jail time. The women, along with Ashley Eicher, another daughter of the owner, were indicted on 11 counts each of mail fraud. Ashley Eicher is scheduled to go on trial in July unless an agreement is reached in her case as well. ``There may be some action next week that would eliminate the need for a trial,'' said Lamonica. The Eichers also must agree to cooperate with the government in the ongoing investigation of Champion and to testify at any trials. Defense attroney John Di Giulio was asked later if that part of the agreement was aimed at an investigation of Commissioner Green. ``Possibly,'' he said. ``The government didn't tell me.'' Prosecutors alleged Green's 1987 campaign was bankrolled by a Champion subsidiary. Green, a personal friend of Naaman Eicher, also had business dealings with Eicher prior to his election. In addition to the federal charges, a state grand jury in Baton Rouge, a federal grand jury in New Orleans, and a grand jury in Montgomery, Ala., have also named the Eichers on dozens of counts ranging from forgery to mail fraud in connection with Champion. The company was Louisiana's third-largest insurer of autos, with 100,000 policyholders, when it collapsed in June 1989. Champion got a clean bill of health in February 1989 from an audit ordered by Green. The audit said the company had $19.5 million in surplus assets. The failure left $150 million in unpaid claims in Louisiana and an undetermined amount in the states of Alabama and Tennessee where it also operated. Nine subsidiaries fell shortly after Champion's collapse.

DOC.HEAD: Government Concludes 21-Month Probe of Utility With No Charges
DOC.TEXT: A 21-month investigation into alleged tax fraud by Southern Co. and its utility subsidiary in Georgia has ended with no criminal charges filed, the federal government said Friday. U.S. Attorney Ray Rukstele said he notified Southern and Georgia Power Co. that he would not seek indictments against the companies or any individuals in the tax probe. However, Rukstele said he has suggested that the Internal Revenue Service consider pursuing civil action against Southern. He declined to comment on whether a related investigation into possibly illegal campaign contributions by another subsidiary was continuing. An IRS spokeswoman in Atlanta refused to comment on the case. The Atlanta Journal, quoting unidentified sources, reported that federal investigators also were continuing to look into alleged improprieties in the steering of Southern pension funds to a brokerage firm that employs the son of company President Edward L. Addison. Rukstele said his decision against pursuing criminal charges pertained only to tax accounting practices involving Southern and Georgia Power Co. Georgia Power President A.W. Dahlberg said at a news conference Friday that Rukstele's announcement ``validates'' the company's position that its methods of accounting for spare parts, the focus of the federal probe, were proper. Dahlberg said he could not comment on whether other aspects of the investigation were continuing. The investigation began in August 1988 when a Georgia Power accountant told the IRS that the company may have failed to account properly for spare parts. At issue was at what point the company was required to deduct the cost of emergency spare parts: when they are purchased or when they are used. The probe shortly afterward was widened to include political campaign contributions and took a bizarre turn with a still-unexplained plane crash in April 1989 that killed an executive and two Southern pilots. Southern's Florida subsidiary, Gulf Power Co., pleaded guilty last November to conspiracy to make illegal campaign contributions and was fined $500,000. The plea agreement placed most of the blame for the scheme on Jake Horton, the Gulf Power vice president who was killed in the crash. Authorities said at the time that the plea did not preclude further action in other areas of the case. During the tax investigation, federal agents raided the offices of Southern and Georgia Power to confiscate tax records. An internal investigation by Georgia Power found that no wrongdoing had been committed. In addition to Gulf and Georgia Power, Southern is the corporate parent of Mississippi Power, Alabama Power and Savannah Electric and Power.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Treasurer Expected to Leave
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. Treasurer Frederick Zuckerman is likely to retire this summer to become involved in other business matters, a company spokesman said Friday. ``Our management reluctantly agreed to let Fred pursue the many other opportunities open to someone with his knowledge and expertise,'' said company spokesman Tom Houston. He said officials of the nation's No. 3 auto maker acted after Zuckermen told them several months ago of his desire ``to involve himself in corporate restructuring.'' An exact date for Zuckerman's departure has not been set, Houston said, but likely would be this summer. Zuckerman, 55, became Chrysler's vice president and treasurer in December 1981, when the company was in the throes of beating back bankruptcy on the strength of federal loan guarantees. Recently Chrysler has fallen on hard times again and is in the midst of a cost-cutting program designed to carve $1.5 billion out of its $26 million annual budget by the end of the year. Zuckerman joined Chrysler in October 1979 as an assistant controller. Before becoming vice president and treasurer, he was a general assistant controller.

DOC.HEAD: Too Much Rain Keeps Corn Futures Prices Growing
DOC.TEXT: Too much rain kept corn futures prices growing Friday and new forecasts called for no change in the soggy conditions that have stalled spring planting in the Midwest. Other grain and soybean futures also advanced on the Chicago Board of Trade. On other commodity markets, cocoa futures retreated; livestock and meat futures rose; precious metals were mixed; and oil futures were mixed. Corn futures settled 1 cent to 5 cents higher in Chicago with the contract for delivery in July at $2.84 a bushel. The July contract's gains totaled 9\ cents in the three days ending Friday. Wheat futures settled { cent lower to 3 cents higher with July at $3.30 a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2 cents higher with July at $1.54{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 3} cents higher with July at $6.19 a bushel. Forecasts for scattered showers in the Corn Belt well into next week ``overwhelmed everything else'' in the corn market Friday, said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``It's wet, it's been wet and it looks like it's going to continue to be wet,'' he said. After the close, the National Weather Service released a six-to-10-day forecast predicting wetter-than-normal conditions in the Midwest from May 31 through June 4. ``It looks like a real soggy run for the eastern Corn Belt,'' said Richard Feltes, director of commodity research with the futures brokerage Refco Inc. About 20 percent of the nation's corn crop remains to be planted, Lespinasse said. If farmers don't get the seed into the ground within the next 10 days, yield losses are likely, he said. That propect was reflected in steeper losses in the new-crop corn contracts than in the July contract, which represents the last of the old-crop corn. The pattern was reversed in the soybean market, reflecting the possibility that farmers will plant soybeans on acres they had planned to sow with corn. Cocoa futures fell sharply on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, erasing Thursday's gains as traders took profits ahead of the long holiday weekend. Prices climbed to new 14-month highs on Thursday and surged again in early trading Friday on news of a customs workers strike in the Ivory Coast, the world's biggest cocoa producer. Traders quickly discounted the importance of the strike, though, since most of the available Ivory Coast cocoa already has been shipped. Cocoa settled $25 to $30 lower with July at $1,464 per ton. Most livestock and meat futures rose moderately on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in pre-weekend position-evening after several days of weakness, especially in pork futures. After the close, the Agriculture Department released a monthly report that showed 102.2 million pounds of pork bellies in the nation's commercial freezers. The number was near market expectations. Live cattle futures settled .02 cent to .25 cent higher with June at 73.52 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .07 cent lower to .13 cent higher with August at 83.77 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .37 cent higher with June at 65.95 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .12 cent to .38 cent higher with July at 65.85 cents a pound. Gold futures rose modestly on New York's Commodity Exchange on light volume, supported in part by slight weakness in the dollar. The advance extended the market's recovery from Wednesday's plunge of more than $11 an ounce. Gold futures settled $1.50 to $1.90 higher with June at $368.40 a troy ounce; silver was 1.3 cents to 1.5 cents higher with May at $5.215 a troy ounce. Energy futures ended mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Near-term crude oil deliveries finished slightly lower after a burst of buying early in the session that analysts linked to bullish chart signals. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 5 cents lower to 12 cents higher with July at $17.80 a barrel; heating oil was .15 cent to .38 cent lower with June at 49.66 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .40 cent lower to .18 cent higher with June at 63.41 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Secures $5 Billion Credit Backing for Oil Industry
DOC.TEXT: Iran will direct an unprecedented $5 billion in hard currency credits to its oil industry this year, Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh said Friday. Tehran radio, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Aqazadeh as saying the economic backing was made possible ``with cooperation between the Ministry of Economy and Finance, and Iran's Central Bank.'' The massive investments underline Iran's commitment to rebuild and update its oil industry, which was badly battered in its eight-year war with Iraq. Oil and gas related industries, which earn more than 90 percent of Iran's foreign exchange, were deprived of funds for maintainance and development as funds were channeled to the war effort. But Tehran began rebuilding immediately after the United Nations-sponsored cease-fire halted the conflict in August 1988. The credits announced Friday comprise about 6 percent of the country's $80 billion budget for the current year, which began March 21. While inaugurating a methanol plant in southern Iran on Friday, Aqazadeh said Iran's current sustainable production capacity will be boosted from 3.3 million barrels a day to 3.7 million barrels a day in four months and 4 million barrels a day next year. He said products from the new plant would help produce glue, paint pharmaceuticals, petrochemical products, as well as car and jet fuel, according to Tehran Radio. Because domestic demand for methanol would be low until other industries develop, he said the excess methanol would be exported, earning Iran $12 million a year. Iran's deputy oil minister, Ahmad Rahgozar, said last month that an additional $5 billion will also be invested in the petrochemical industry over the next five years. After more than a decade of isolation and xenophobia, Iran is encouraging foreign investment in its projects. Aqazadeh said last March that the country was talking to numerous companies about gas and oil development. At present Iran is cooperating with Soviet, Japanese and South Korean firms to develop its oil fields.

DOC.HEAD: Two Trump Operations Announce Job Cutbacks
DOC.TEXT: Two of developer Donald Trump's operations, the Taj Mahal Casino Resort and the Trump Shuttle airline, announced Friday they are eliminating a total of about 370 jobs as part of streamlining efforts. The cutbacks come amid speculation that Trump has overextended himself with rapid expansion into the airline and Atlantic City, N.J., casino industries. The Taj Mahal Casino Resort said it is cutting 300 jobs, mostly in its culinary section, less than two months after it opened. In a separate announcement, a spokesman said the Trump Shuttle, which serves air passengers on the busy Boston-New York-Washington, D.C. route, had furloughed about 70 of its roughly 1,000 employees. Ed Tracy, who oversees Donald Trump's Atlantic City properties including the Taj Mahal, said the cuts reduce the total casino-hotel staff to about 6,700. He said the lost jobs are part of an overall streamlining effort at Trump's three casinos, which include Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino and Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay. ``Some of these positions will be taken up by other properties,'' Tracy said. ``It's tough to understand why the massive readjustment other than if they decided to go outside for supplies,'' said Roy Silbert, president of Local 54 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Restaurant Union. Tracy said the casino found it had overstaffed for the property's April 2 opening. The gaming hall set a city record in its first month with $34.2 million of gross gambling revenues, but underwent a management shakeup in its first week amid problems with its slot machines. Trump spokesman Howard Rubenstein said in announcing the shuttle layoffs that they were part of a continuing streamlining effort. The layoffs involve clerical and other support workers but no pilots, he said. Rubenstein said the shuttle is now operating in the black. It reportedly had been losing money since Trump acquired it from Eastern Airlines last year for $365 million. In April, Trump disclosed that he had hired Merrill Lynch & Co. to negotiate the possible sale of the shuttle. A week ago, Pan Am Corp. said it hoped to sell the Pan Am Shuttle, which is the main competitor to the Trump Shuttle on the East coast corridor.

DOC.HEAD: GM Shareholders Approve Doubling Chairman Smith's Pension
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT spelling of car model Vectra.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DT3
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. shareholders approved a plan Friday to boost executive pensions, nearly doubling the annual retirement pay of outgoing Chairman Roger Smith to about $1.1 million. Pensions for executives vs. those for hourly workers doubtlessly will be a hot topic when negotiations between GM and the United Auto Workers union open in July, just a few weeks before Smith retires July 31. Also at the four-hour annual meeting, Smith said the automaker would begin building cars in an East German joint venture in October, becoming the first U.S. automaker to make vehicles in Eastern Europe. The company said 83.3 percent of the 503 million voting shares supported the proposal to boost the pensions of 3,350 top executives, including Smith, who received $2.5 million in compensation from GM in 1989. Technically, the GM board didn't need shareholder approval to increase the pensions, and Smith expressed dissatisfaction over the process. ``We don't expect to do it again,'' Smith said. ``It, apparently, was an experiment gone astray.'' Under the revised plan, the base used in figuring pensions was changed from salary alone to salary plus bonuses. Putting the proposal to a vote may have been sparked by a desire to limit bad feelings if word of such a boost arose for the first time during contract negotiations. ``I would certainly much rather go to bargaining with the UAW knowing where we are as opposed, (instead of) going through bargaining and all of a sudden having a surprise,'' incoming GM chairman Robert Stempel said at a news conference after the annual meeting. UAW Vice President Stephen Yokich, head of the union's GM Department, called the pension increases unjustifiable. He praised the stance of Michigan Treasurer Robert Bowman, who voted the 8.8 million shares of GM stock he controls through five pension funds against the retirement benefit proposal. Bowman said the $42 million annual cost of the pensions should go toward product development, plant modernization and an underfunded pension plan for hourly employees. ``I think Mr. Smith can eke out a retirement'' without the increase, Bowman said. Said Yokich, ``It's encouraging to see Michigan's top officials ... provide leadership for an emerging consensus that today's world requires that big corporations make consumers, communities and workers a bigger priority than satisfying the voracious economic appetites of their executives.'' The GM pension proposal snared attention earlier this week at the union's bargaining convention in Kansas City. One of the items high on the union's agenda this summer will be pension improvements for its 446,000 retired members, who make up almost half its membership. Opposition to the executive pension plan at GM's annual meeting got personal at times Friday. ``You, sir, with all due respect, will do extremely well,'' said shareholder Louis Gilbert of New York. Stockholder Evelyn Y. Davis of Washington, a fixture at corporate annual meetings, said, ``Roger, in due respect to you ... you don't need this type of pension.'' GM said it studied dozens of large companies and found that GM's executive pension plan ranked in the bottom fifth. Smith said GM recently lost 60 of its executives, partly because of the pension plan. Smith declined to say who they were or to list their specific objections to the previous plan. During Smith's 9{-year tenure as GM chairman, the corporation lost market share, closed plants, laid off tens of thousands of hourly workers and slashed its executive payroll. The company also underwent an aggressive plant-modernization program and cut more than $12 billion in costs since 1987. GM plans to increase its presence in Europe, especially in Eastern Europe, where rapid political and economic reforms are opening new markets. GM said it will make four-door Opel Vectra cars in a joint venture with Automobilwerke in Eisenach, East Germany. The company plans to assemble about 10,000 of the cars this year, a volume expected to grow to about 150,000 annually by the mid-1990s. Chrysler Corp. has planned a joint venture to make minivans in Austria beginning in mid-1991. Ford Motor Co. is studying vehicle assembly plans in Eastern Europe, but has announced no specific plans. Automobilwerke's factory in Eisenach makes the Wartburg automobile. GM spokesman Jack Harned said Vectra production will be separate from Wartburg manufacturing. ``It's not GM taking over Wartburg,'' Harned said. GM currently makes the Vectra in Russelsheim, West Germany. Smith said the joint venture with Automobilwerke is the initial stage of GM's ``New Europe'' strategy. Besides making cars, GM will begin building engines and assembling a small number of cars in Hungary by early 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Former Head of Chicago Merc Barred From Futures Trading
DOC.TEXT: An administrative law judge found Brian P. Monieson, former head of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, guilty Friday of failing to adequately supervise two employees accused of defrauding customers. Monieson, chairman of GNP Commodities Inc., was barred from futures trading and ordered to pay a $500,000 fine. GNP Commodities was found guilty of similar charges and ordered to close all customer accounts within 30 days and pay a $500,000 fine. Monieson's attorney, Jerrold E. Salzman, said the penalties against his client and the trading firm are on hold while the ruling is appealed to the full Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The two traders, Ira P. Greenspon and Norman K. Furlett, also were found guilty by Judge George Painter of the CFTC. A lawyer said they were considering an appeal. ``The fraud in this case was committed against the retail customers, a euphemism for relatively small public customers who are virtually defenseless,'' Painter said. ``The shame of this case is that GNP and Monieson were so callously indifferent to the wrongs done to their most vulnerable customers,'' he added. CFTC attorneys said Greenspon and Furlett engaged in ``allocated'' trades that bilked customers of thousands of dollars. The term refers to initiating futures contracts without the required customer account numbers, then keeping profitable trades for themselves while socking customers with the losses. ``The facts set forth in this matter constitute a pernicious, widespread and institutionalized scheme of cheating and defrauding customers,'' Painter said. He banned Greenspon and Furlett, both of Malibu, Calif., from the futures industry and fined them $75,000 each. Monieson's attorneys argued that as chairman of Chicago-based GNP Commodities, he was not involved in daily oversight of his employees and should not be liable for failing to stop any wrongdoing. Painter dismissed those claims, referring to testimony from others who said Monieson was clearly a hands-on manager. ``It appears that Monieson's misplaced allegiance to Furlett and Greenspon overshadowed his greater duty to the customers they were defrauding,'' the judge said. Monieson, of Northbrook, Ill., and GNP Commodities were found guilty of failing to adequately supervise the two traders from September 1984 through May 1986. Monieson was Merc chairman from 1983 to 1985. Futures are contracts to buy or sell commodities, ranging from agricultural products to stocks and bonds, at a specified price on a future date. People trade futures contracts either to lock in commodity prices in advance, thereby reducing their financial risk, or to speculate on price changes. In Chicago, GNP Commodities issued a statement calling Painter's decision ``unprecedented and unwarranted.'' If executives are responsible for their traders' misdeeds, even when the executives did not personally benefit, ``no firm could continue to do business,'' the statement said. Mark S. Boyle, one of two attorneys representing Greenspon and Furlett, said he had not seen the entire 135-page ruling but was considering an appeal. ``We still maintain they did nothing wrong,'' Boyle said. Neither of the men currently works for GNP Commodities, he said. Meanwhile, in Chicago, the Merc on Friday fined GNP Commodities $100,000 and told the firm to continue its voluntary effort to pay $300,000 to customers who may have been harmed. Under a proposed settlement with the Merc, GNP Commodities neither admits nor denies violating exchange rules.

DOC.HEAD: Procter & Gamble Negotiating for MTV Contract
DOC.TEXT: The Procter & Gamble Co., one of the nation's largest television advertisers, is negotiating a multimillion-dollar, multiyear contract to advertise on the MTV cable network. P&G spokesman Terry Loftus acknowledged Friday that negotiations are in progress, but declined to elaborate on terms being discussed with the music and entertainment network. Advertising Age, a trade publication, said the potential deal includes a six-year contract that could exceed $50 million. Loftus said he did not know how long the negotiations would take. Advertising on MTV would fall in line with P&G's shift since the mid-1980s to reduce the amount it spends to advertise on the NBC, ABC and CBS television networks while spending more on ads designed to reach specific markets. MTV targets viewers in their teens to mid-30s. P&G, a Cincinnati-based maker and seller of consumer goods, health, beauty care and food products, was for years the nation's largest advertiser. But in 1988, its U.S. advertising budget of $1.507 billion was topped by Philip Morris Co.'s $2.058 billion, Advertising Age said. When spending outside the U.S. is included, P&G is the world's largest advertiser with a combined budget of $2.4 billion. In October 1987, Procter & Gamble signed a multimillion-dollar contract for commercials on WTBS in Atlanta, an independent television station whose programs are shown nationwide, and six independent TV stations owned by Tribune Broadcasting Co., including WGN-TV in Chicago. P&G also advertises on News Corp.'s Fox network. Analysts said P&G began spending less on network TV advertising because viewer loyalty to the networks was declining and the company wanted to tap regional niche markets. P&G has sponsored racing cars and a racing boat, auto and gem giveaways, 21 Barry Manilow concerts and a two-year national tour of the Ringling Bros., Barnum & Bailey Circus. It has also advertised in informational brochures in doctors' and dentists' offices through Whittle Communications of Knoxville, Tenn., and on Whittle's Channel One news program shown in secondary schools. ``Our advertising strategy hasn't really changed over the years,'' Loftus said. ``Our goal is still to communicate with the consumer. The difference today is that we are finding our consumers in different places than they were some years ago.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Pension Insurance Fund Claim Against LTV Takes No Precedence
DOC.TEXT: The federal pension insurance fund's $2.2 billion claim against LTV Corp. should be reduced, according to a ruling by a judge who also rejected an effort by the fund, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp., to push its claim ahead of others in the company's bankruptcy case. The size and status of PBGC's claim against Dallas-based LTV has been a key issue in the 2-year-old bankruptcy case, one of the largest in corporate history. The decision, released by the company Friday, could cost the PBGC more than $1 billion if the agency also loses a related case pending before the U.S. Supreme Court. ``If allowed to stand, the bankruptcy court's ill-founded ruling will severely undercut our ability to reduce or prevent losses to the pension insurance program,'' said PBGC Executive Director James B. Lockhart. ``PBGC intends to challenge the ruling in federal district court,'' Lockhart said. The 67-page ruling by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland in New York turned aside PBGC's effort to set the size of its own claim. It also set aside the agency's assertion that the claim took precedence over other creditors, including banks, bondholders and tradesmen. ``The PBGC is basically advocating that it is entitled to promulgate and enforce, even in a bankruptcy case, regulations which violate fundamental bankruptcy provisions and principles,'' Lifland wrote. The PBGC claimed that its expertise in pension funding gave it the authority to determine the size of future pension payments, but Lifland said, ``Bankruptcy courts are often and routinely called upon to determine the present value of projected future payments, the value of a claim over time, and the value of a recovery which is in the form of payments over time.'' As for the claim's standing, ``the PBGC has no legal basis for arguing that its claims should have a priority status,'' he said. Lifland's ruling answers the question of ``where does this claim stand and how much is it,'' said analyst Gary Heinz at Delaware Bay Co. in New York. ``This is almost as, if not more significant, than the basic issue before the Supreme Court,'' Heinz said. The government has asked the Supreme Court to decide whether the PBGC, which insures pension funds, has the right to force LTV to reassume responsibility for three pensions funds terminated when subsidiary LTV Steel Co. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in 1986. The high court heard arguments in the case in February, and a ruling is expected before the court adjourns for the summer in late June or early July. ``If the Supreme Court decided to leave LTV pension plans with PBGC, the bankruptcy court could reduce PBGC recoveries, and increase losses to the insurance fund by as much as an additional $1 billion,'' said a spokeswoman for the fund. ``Lifland has chosen his timing to make this statement to emphasize his opinion of the case law,'' said bankruptcy expert Chriss Street at Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. in Chicago. ``Given his highly respected position on the national bankruptcy bench as the jurist who has handled the most complex and difficult cases,'' Street said the decision could have far-reaching impact on bankruptcy cases. In addition to the complicated LTV case, Lifland is the judge in Eastern Airlines' bankruptcy case and handled the petition by Manville Corp. ``Judge Lifland has sent a pretty strong message to federal agencies that they don't possess the confiscatory powers that some of the bureaucrats in the agencies would have us believe,'' Heinz said. In 1986, LTV Corp. filed for protection for the parent company and its 65 subsidiaries, including LTV Steel, LTV Aerospace and Defense and LTV Energy Products. It listed assets totaling $2.06 billion and liabilities of $1.5 billion. Primarily because of disputes over the PBGC claim, the company has yet to file a reorganization plan.

DOC.HEAD: Meridian Oil to Buy Gas Reserves of Unicon
DOC.TEXT: Meridian Oil Inc. will buy all producing properties of Unicon Producing Co. for $399 million, a move that increases its natural gas reserves by about 500 billion cubic feet, the company announced Friday. A statement issued by Meridian, a subsidiary of Burlington Resources Inc., said the deal should be concluded within a month. The agreement is subject to approval by the Federal Trade Commission. Burlington spokesman Don L. Pope said the acquisition would strengthen Meridian's position as the largest independent natural gas reserve owner in the U.S. As of Dec. 31, its reserves amounted to the equivalent of 4.6 trillion cubic feet and ranked ninth among reserve holders, Pope said, behind No. 8 Unocal Corp. and No. 7 Texaco Inc. Unicon is a Texas partnership of subsidiaries of Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc. and Kiewit Continental Inc. Its proven reserves, 94 percent in the San Juan Basin of northwestern New Mexico, contain about 500 billion cubic feet of natural gas with ``excellent potential for significant future reserve additions,'' said a statement from Meridian. California utilities provide the biggest market for Meridian gas, buying around 35 percent to 40 percent of the company's production, while about half of Unicon's production goes to Gas Co. of New Mexico, Pope said.

DOC.HEAD: Power Systems Division Sold To Finnish Company
DOC.TEXT: Morrison Knudsen Corp. announced Friday that it has sold its North Carolina-based Power Systems Division to Wartsila Diesel Inc., an affiliate of Finland's Oy Wartsila AB. The transaction will produce more than $20 million in cash for Morrison Knudsen, the company said in a news release. The money includes proceeds from the sale of the division and its outstanding billings. The Power Systems Division manufactures and sells diesel-powered electrical generating units in Rocky Mount, N.C. The generators are used primarily by industrial customers as standby power sources. The Boise-based construction and engineering company said the sale is part of a long-range strategy to focus its Rail Systems Group's activities on the transit car and locomotive markets.

DOC.HEAD: Union Carbide Corp. Names New President
DOC.TEXT: Union Carbide Corp. has named H. William Lichtenberger as its new president and chief operating officer. Lichtenberger, 54, will succeed Robert D. Kennedy, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer of the chemical company, Carbide said. Lichtenberger was named to the position Wednesday. He is president of Union Carbide's chemicals and plastics unit, a post he will continue to hold. Lichtenberger joined Union Carbide in 1959 as a research engineer for the Linde gas division, becoming general manager for gas products in 1982. He became president of the solvents and coatings division in 1985 and in 1986 succeeded Kennedy as head of the chemicals and plastics group. A graduate of the University of Iowa with degrees in liberal arts and chemical engineering, Lichtenberger also earned an M.B.A. from the State University of New York while working for Carbide.

High mortgage rates continued to dampen sales of existing homes through much of the nation in April, although the Northeast posted its first gain since last fall, a real estate trade group said. The National Association of Realtors said Friday overall resales of single-family homes slipped 2.1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.33 million units. It was the third drop in four months as mortgage rates remained in double digits. Sales were unchanged in March.

Consumer spending posted a moderate 0.6 percent gain in April, while personal income rose 0.3 percent, the government said. The Commerce Department said Friday that consumers spent at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.68 trillion. That was the largest gain since a 1.2 percent jump in January. But the department said personal income increased only half as fast as spending, for a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.69 trillion. That was the lowest increase since 0.2 percent last September.

The U.S. trade deficit shrank to $26.4 billion in the first quarter, the smallest quarterly imbalance in more than six years, the government reported. The Commerce Department said Friday the 8.2 percent improvement in the trade balance in the January-March period was a result of record-high export sales that offset the highest volume of oil imports in more than 12 years.

General Motors Corp. shareholders approved a plan to boost executive pensions, nearly doubling the annual retirement pay of outgoing Chairman Roger Smith to about $1.1 million. Pensions for executives vs. those for hourly workers doubtlessly will be a hot topic when negotiations between GM and the United Auto Workers union open in July, just a few weeks before Smith retires July 31. Smith also told the annual shareholders meeting Friday that GM would begin building cars in an East German joint venture in October, becoming the first U.S. automaker to make vehicles in Eastern Europe.

An administrative law judge found Brian P. Monieson, former head of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, guilty of failing to adequately supervise two employees accused of defrauding customers. Monieson, chairman of GNP Commodities Inc., was barred from futures trading and ordered to pay a $500,000 fine in Friday's ruling. But Monieson's attorney, Jerrold E. Salzman, said the penalties against his client are on hold while the ruling is appealed to the full Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

The federal pension insurance fund's $2.2 billion claim against LTV Corp. should be reduced, according to a ruling by a judge who also rejected an effort by the fund, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp., to push its claim ahead of others in the company's bankruptcy case. The decision, released by the company Friday, could cost the PBGC more than $1 billion if the agency also loses a related case pending before the U.S. Supreme Court.

National Semiconductor Corp. said it signed a pact with NEC Corp. to sell one of the Japanese company's leading edge computer memory chips and explore deals in marketing, manufacturing and technology. The initial agreement between the two electronic giants covers Tokyo-based NEC's high-volume SRAM chips _ a static random access memory device with 256,000 bytes of memory. The deal was announced Friday.

Anheuser-Busch Inc. said it was ending production of LA, the brewer's poor-selling, reduced-alcohol beer that apparently lost its niche and could not find a new one. The beer, with about half the alcohol of regular beer, was introduced six years ago as the first response from a major brewer to the trend toward more responsible drinking. On Friday, Anheuser-Busch executives said they were getting rid of the LA brand because they didn't want the beer to take sales away from its new no-alcohol beer, O'Doul's.

Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc., which is in a merger pact with its majority owner American Express Co., said it would omit its common stock dividend for the second quarter. Its regular dividend has been 18.75 cents per share of common stock. The move, announced Friday, will save the nation's second-largest brokerage company about $16.5 million in dividend payments on its 88 million shares of common stock.

Stock prices took a spill Friday as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 34.63 to 2,820.92, cutting its gain for the week to 1.01 points. The dollar fell sharply against the yen but otherwise was little changed in foreign exchange trading. Bond prices closed lower. Grain and soybean futures advanced; cocoa futures retreated; livestock and meat futures rose; precious metals were mixed; and oil futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Bondholder Committees Endorse Resorts Restructuring Plan
DOC.TEXT: Resorts International Inc. said Thursday that committees representing the company's bondholders have agreed to swap their $927 million in bonds for reduced debt and a majority of Resorts' equity. The restructuring plan still must win approval of two-thirds of the bondholders in a formal vote, the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Camden, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission and the government of the Bahamas. In addition to Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel in Atlantic City, Resorts owns casino property in the Bahamas. Thursday's endorsement of the recapitalization plan comes one week before a May 31 hearing in bankruptcy court on the plan. ``I am pleased that the bondholder committees have endorsed our plan,'' said Resorts chairman Merv Griffin. ``Now we will focus our attention on making Resorts the world-class resort it can be.'' The plan filed under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code would give bondholders 78 percent of the company, dropping Griffin's stake from 100 percent to 22 percent. Resorts, in turn, would exchange the $927 million in debt held by those bondholders for a reduced debt service. The plan filed with the court gives senior secured bondholders $292.8 million in new notes and 2.5 percent of Griffin's shares. Holders of Resorts' highest paying bonds, 16| percent, would receive 32.4 percent of the shares and $58.9 million in new bonds. The remaining bondholders would get 43.1 percent of the company's stock and $78.6 million in new notes. The plan also sets aside a legal kitty of $5 million to pursue a possible legal action against Donald Trump, who swapped Resorts to Griffin for the newly opened Taj Mahal Casino Resort next door on the Boardwalk.

DOC.HEAD: Moody's Downgrades Bank of Boston
DOC.TEXT: Bank of Boston Corp.'s credit rating was lowered by Moody's Investors Service because of continued weakness in the Massachusetts economy. ``The rating actions reflect the continuing uncertainty associated with the corporation's exposures to the New England economy and the national real estate market,'' Moody's said in a statement Thursday. Moody's praised the bank, saying it had moved to manage its troubled real estate portfolio. But, Moody's added, ``the exposure remains large in relation to capital.'' Bank officials said they were disappointed with the move. ``With more than $3 billion in capital and reserves, $37 billion in assets and with our geographically balanced and diverse businesses, we have the financial strength and are well positioned to deal with uncertainties in the current environment,'' said Peter J. Manning, chief financial officer. The bank's senior debt was downgraded one notch to Ba1 from Baa3. Its subordinated debt and commercial paper ratings also were downgraded.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Truckers End Three-Day Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf to UPDATE with blockade still on at some points, details; picks up 4th graf, `Transport Minister ...' A version also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Independent Canadian truckers ended their three-day strike Thursday afternoon after transportation officials in Canada promised to address their complaints about taxes, authorities said. ``The blockade ended about a half hour ago,'' said Staff Sgt. R. Nichols of the police department in Windsor, adjacent to Detroit. It was one of a number of border cities where blockades had choked off U.S.-Canadian commerce. ``There were about 200 people and another 100 to 150 trucks there. But the truckers were happy, got into their trucks and drove away,'' Nichols said. But truckers at some other southern Ontario border points, including Fort Erie across the Niagara River from Buffalo, N.Y., and Niagara Falls, remained snarled. Trucks were still blocking a lane of the Lewiston-Queenston Bridge at Niagara Falls late Thursday night, allowing only cars to pass, state police said. Trucks were not being allowed across the Peace Bridge linking Buffalo and Fort Erie, and about 100 to 200 trucks were parked on each side of the span, bridge officials said. Transport Minister Doug Lewis said after meeting with truckers that he would take up with the Cabinet their complaints about taxes and the free-trade agreement with the United States. ``I am pleased to have had the opportunity to learn directly from them their concerns about what they consider to be an unlevel playing field,'' he said in a statement. The protest was sparked by proposed increases in Canada's goods and services tax that will affect everything from the goods that truckers haul to the tires, insurance and diesel fuel they buy. The U.S.-Canadian trade agreement, which will remove almost all tariffs by 1999, will further handicap Canadian truckers, protesters said. The truckers contended that taxes and the free-trade agreement are crippling their ability to compete with U.S. drivers. The blockade dried up the flow of U.S.-made auto parts to Canada, forcing the shutdown of three General Motors of Canada Ltd. plants in Ontario and production cutbacks at one in Quebec. Some 13,000 auto workers were affected. Production also was disrupted at Chrysler Canada and Ford of Canada. Ford plants also closed in Dearborn, Mich.; Wayne, Mich.; Lorain, Ohio; Avon, Ohio; Louisville, Ky. and Minneapolis, said company spokesman Peter Olsen. ``How and when things will be back to normal really depends on the flow of auto parts,'' he said. Spokesman for the other automakers didn't return calls to their homes Thursday evening. At Mazda Motor Corp.'s plant in Flat Rock, Mich., 20 miles south of Detroit, afternoon-shift workers were sent home four hours early Wednesday afternoon. Day-shift employees were sent home two hours early Thursday, and the entire plant was expected to close Friday, spokesman Tom McDonald said. The plant gets windshields, brakes and other components from Canadian suppliers. Lewis met Thursday morning in Windsor with a delegation led by protest organizer Wayne Whitney and Bill Wrye, Ontario minister of transportation. Whitney, Wrye and Tom Baldwin, president of Teamsters Local 880 in Windsor, spoke later in the morning to about 200 truckers milling near the foot of the bridge. The negotiators drew shouts, catcalls and curses after saying Lewis could promise only to relay their concerns to Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and his Cabinet. ``We want answers right now!'' bellowed a voice from the crowd. ``We haven't been here two days for nothing. We'll be here another week if we have to.'' ``You can't get laws changed in two hours,'' Baldwin pleaded. ``You can't consider them false promises.'' Protesters earlier blocked the truck lanes at the Canadian end of the Blue Water Bridge between Sarnia and Port Huron, Mich., said Morris Hall of the Michigan Department of Transportation. Automobile traffic in Port Huron and on the Ambassador Bridge was moving freely all day Thursday. Authorities at both bridges refused to let trucks enter Canada because of the likelihood they would be blockaded and hinder other traffic, Hall said. No violence was reported at any of the blockaded border points.
